38923957.review: A Hat in Time manages to balance nostalgia to older 3D platformers and new original stuff and it turned out great. On one hand, you have the Time Rifts, which most of them could be nearly indistinguishable from retextured Super Mario Sunshine secret levels, (but this time they don't make me insanely frustrated) and you have the actual levels. There are 4 levels with multiple parts, and they're all pretty fun and unique. Mafia Town is the first area, and progression is structured like Mario 64 / Sunshine. You get one time piece, the next one opens up. Battle of The Birds is similar to the previous, but instead, it has a forking path, and it's apparently a competition. You do the first level, then two more show up, and for completing them, you get points toward whoever's side the level is on based on performance in the levels. The other levels have unique elements as well. (Subcon Forest's thing being that you sign contracts to unlock each level, and Alpine Skyline's thing being that it is a freeroaming level.) The character is fun and easy to control, the art style is reasonably good except for the unmodeled 2D texture faces that don't move along with the voice lines, the level design is pretty good. There's even modding support, so if you know / learn how to use Unreal Engine 3, you can make your own levels, or you can just play with other people's mods. All really cool stuff. All in all, I'd say that this is worth your time if you like 3D platformers. Have a good day.

38885028.review:
Simplesmente um dos melhores jogos plataformas que já joguei.

A Hat in Time é um jogo plataforma com uma pegada muito divertida, boas piadas e trocadilhos, além de excelentes personagens, a maioria deles bem memoráveis por suas personalidades e formas como são abordadas no jogo.
Eu procuro palavras para descrever esse jogo, porém não acho, em vários momentos percebemos a quebra da 4a parede, no qual os npcs conversam conosco, jogador. Também pego como um ponto extremamente positivo a atmosfera e o visual do jogo, simplesmente deslumbrante.

[h1]Prós:[/h1]
Personagens memoráveis, com suas próprias características e com uma história simples de acompanhar 
Jogabilidade simples, porém com bastantes movimentos.
Visual lindo, com cada fase possuindo sua particularidade
Divertido na sua medida, sem forçação de barra, o jogo, por mais que seja um pouco curto, não fica enrolando uma história desnecessária. 
Trilha sonora fantástica pra cada fase, combinando bem com cada visual 
Ferramenta pra printscreen presente no próprio jogo

[h1]Contras:[/h1]
Por mais que esse jogo seja fantástico alguns problemas foram percebidos durante minha jogatina, sendo eles:
-Controles não respondem bem as vezes, principalmente nas movimentações em paredes e quando vai se utilizar o gancho, é comum o jogo não responder bem a não ser que você esteja no ponto exatamente certo
-Bugs de movimentação que podem estragar uma jogatina (durante o primeiro boss eu acabei no "ataque da bola" dele e fiquei preso durante alguns minutos até conseguir me soltar.

Esse jogo é altamente recomendado, cada frame dele daria pra ser utilizado como um wallpaper, as telas de loading também possuem artes fantásticas. Na minha opinião este sim é o melhor jogo de 2017. Espero que ele seja tão valorizado quanto os outros indies

38882003.review:
Excellent game with excellent writing. The levels are a mix of open worlds that give you a goal and let you figure out how to platform there, and more linear levels where there's really only one path you can take. The real magic however comes from the major differences between the various worlds you'll visit: their storylines and characters, and how the levels are incorporated into these. In one world you'll be doing choirs for an evil forest spirit after you sold your soul to him, in another one you have to help two director birds who both want to win a movie trophy. The music is absolutely top-notch, Your Contract Has Expired can compete with Megalovania in terms of catchiness.

Unfortunately the game suffers from Super Mario 64 syndrome: your greatest enemy is the camera, which is constantly trying to reposition itself and gets in the way with the more trickier jumps. More than once I've had to make a leap of faith because the camera decided to move while I was in the middle of a hard platforming section and didn't have time to readjust it. Fortunately the game has much more to offer than just pure platforming, so this problem is not as bad as it could have been.

38881809.review:
If this is suppose to be some sort of new spin on action platformers then it doesn't do a very good job. It is pretty much the same as any other collect-a-thon. It has a little bit of dynamic movement like a mario game would have. double jumps, sprinting, wall jumping, and diving. I can't help but feel that a lot of these movement mechanics were just ripped strait from Mario 64. Instead of collecting stars or shines like you would in mario you collect hour glasses. the most enoying thing about this is every time you collect one you get sent back to the hub world. 

This is a game that is trying very hard to be mario, To the point that it is trying too hard. If you want to play this game then don't bother. super mario galaxy is way more fun. you could download an emulator and play Mario 64 for free and get the same experiance. I give this game a 5-10.

P.s.
Just because a game looks good doesn't mean it will be fun to play. There has to be more than just good graphics. Also, the graphics in this game are not really that beautiful. I got bored with them almost right away.

38854584.review:
Basically a game that captures the fun essence of 3D platformers with all the charm that should come with them.

A Hat in Time is a game that revels in giving you a variety of challenges to tackle in an effort to reclaim all your lost time pieces. Whether you're hunting for vault codes to open a safe, sneaking around to find evidence of a murder, using a scooter to deliver mail to underlings or using various tools at your disposal to ascend to the top of a giant windmill. Each challenge in the core worlds is a joy to tackle and the variety ensures things never get old. For the platforming challenges naturally many of these stages will test your leaping skills, but special note to the time rift stages - bonus levels akin to the ones in Super Mario Sunshine where the focus is entirely on platforming your way from A to B.

Hats and badges form the core of your powers to assist you. Hats grant powers like sprinting, throwing explosive potions or using dimensional powers to alter certain platform's solidity. These hat powers really help to shape the adventure by requiring players to switch around as necessary. As new hats are obtained new areas in old locations open up. Badges are more optional (with the exception of the grappling hook, which is needed to access many areas) and offer perks like preventing fall damage or letting you charge up a beam attack.

Aside from the 40 time pieces in the core game you have many other collectables to acquire. Yarn balls are needed to craft the hats to progress, although there are more of them than needed to craft all hats, leaving the rest just for fun. Artefacts open up new time rifts for some of the time pieces, while rift tokens can be exchanged to play a slot machine which rewards cosmetic items like clothing dye, music remixes and hat styles. Even if this sounds a bit short to you then fear not, because this game also has Steam Workshop support. Currently the feature is in beta so requires players to actively sign up via the game's properties to the beta, but once done you have a wide variety of additional content. Some of this is even more cosmetics, yet you can also find entire new levels within the workshop.

Did I mention the charm this game has? Hat Girl, for being a mostly silent protagonist (outside of a few general shouts) exudes personality. Even just leaving her idle shows her dancing on the spot or playing with dolls. During play you can play patty-cake with certain mafia goons, see her hiding scared from a monster that puts even the resident demon to shame or play the lead of a marching band. Other characters don't slack here either. The mafia goons are hilarious with their dialogue, the contract demon of the third world is a riot from start to finish and we certainly can't forget Moustache Girl's rebel antics.

Admittedly, like with any 3D platformer, the camera can get a bit wonky in places (most notably if it has to go up against level geometry). However, this has been a magical adventure, and with Workshop support there's plenty more to do even after finishing all the official content. This is definitely standing out as one of my most memorable experiences of 2017.

38854553.review:
A Hat in Time is [i]fun[/i].

Let's start with options. I always say that the quality of the main menu and available options speaks volumes about the quality of the game itself. There is a surprisingly detailed assortment of options available here. Hell, motion blur is even separated into per-object motion blur and screen blur (because who likes screen blur?). Every option is accompanied with a description of what it does. In terms of essential options, you have all the ones you'd expect from a decent PC game: FoV sliders, individual audio sliders, wide array of FPS locks, and plenty of graphical options.

Performance wise, I get a consistent 120 FPS on a i5-6600K and GTX 1070 with every option maxed (except screen blur, of course). Seems fairly optimized for my particular build, but your mileage may vary.

Controls are tight. You never feel like you're fighting against the game.

Level design is, well, good. Not great, but good enough that you certainly don't notice its shortcomings while playing. When you step back and think about it though, the level design really isn't anything to write home about. In general I found the levels to be too busy and lacking cohesion. They're not very memorable in the sense that if you were to drop me in a random part of a level, I'd have difficulty identifying exactly where I was.

There's a ton of little details in the world that are just delightful. There's an adorable little roomba that roams your spaceship! But the one thing that really stood out to me is the 4-piece band you have in your spaceship. You can tell this band to play you some tunes, and get this: the members of the band only start playing at their corresponding parts of the song! If there aren't any drumbeats, the drummer doesn't drum. The trumpet player doesn't start playing until the song has trumpets. That's an incredible attention to detail.

Which I guess brings me to the soundtrack. It's phenomenal. At the time of writing (with a -20% discount), the deluxe edition is only $4 extra, and is well worth the cost. Gear with Breakfast has also put up the full soundtrack on YouTube, so go check it out!

The platforming is solid. It's not hard as nails; there's some measure of difficulty but not frustratingly so.

There's a lot of collectibles. Typically you get cosmetic rewards for your efforts. The platforming is satisfying enough that I had no qualms in going out of my way to collect 'em all.

Overall A Hat in Time is an exceedingly good game. I think it's one of those games that are greater than the sum of its parts. While each aspect of the game is good in and of itself; put together it's just a work of art.

38853054.review:
A Hat in Time is absolutely beautiful concoction of new and old that has since rocketed to one of the most memorable games of 2017 for me. It is able to effectively emulate the wholesome charm of old-school games like Banjo Kazooie, whilst still feeling differentiated. It also captures the fluid and polished movement of more recent titles like Super Mario Galaxy and the like. Being separated into four worlds with only 40 time pieces to collect may seem on the shorter side, but the way the game takes an utterly unique premiss with each world means it keeps the punches rolling and the gameplay changing.  This all culminates in enjoyably cheerful experience that honest to god warmed my heart while also leaving me challenged.

Overall, I would recommend this to anyone look for a bit of personality in their game (old or new). Fantastic writing, heart-of-gold charm and amazing originality - 9/10

Pros:

Unfortunately, I was incredibly disappointed and frustrated once I started playing. The camera often does inexplicable things, where you'll be zoomed-in to a bizarre angle. I spent more time adjusting my camera than actually playing the game. 38841848.review:
*Spoilups
[i]What's that quote about ‘original games are great, but those that take inspirations from the greats are masterpieces’?[/i]

A Hat in Time is one of those games that, right after completion, you wish you could re-experience for the first time again. From its title screen to the first cutscene, the game feels… alive.

I like-a-me some 3D platformers. [i.e. Uber biased] Several games that A Hat in Time’s are some of my all-time favorite and it’s great to see that legacy continued. 3D Platformers (especially, triple A ones) are becoming less and less predominate with only a few significant releases for the genre in 2017. It’s heartwarming to see people vote with their wallets to fund passion projects and to then see those games become successful.

Enough rambling. Hat Kid controls smoothly. Most jumps are composed of combination of a single jump, double jump and dash [with a small cancel]. There’s also one long jump that the sprint hat uses (same distance, not as much height), wall momentum (double jump gets you way higher) and wall jumps. There’s not much complexity [that I know of] here for, say, the wizards of Mario 64 speedrunning to utilize, but for us mortals, it’s plenty. The double jump is forgiving and you can easily recover from most slightly over/underestimated jumps. You’re not allowed to switch directions with the dash, but that’s pretty fair considering how that might be abusable. Wall jumps felt a little off a times, despite their rarity. There’s no way to cancel sliding down a wall into a straight fall so I found myself instinctually pressing A out of impatient to get off a wall resulting in a tumble into the abyss. More than anything, the fact that I felt obligated to mention these moveset hiccups both displays my involvement in Hat Kid’s movement and the potential for even more subtle mechanics that might allow for a higher skill cap.

A Hat in Time orchestrates a beautiful aleatoric soundtrack where leitmotifs and unique instruments breathe life into and give a signature feel to both characters and chapters.. Tunes, like the Main Theme, appear in numerous situations, branding the aspects of the game as connected adding to their memorability. There are plenty of great examples of this. The way the music in purple time rifts fades between instruments or how an overworld melody changes between biomes or how boss themes ramp up during battles, to name a few. It’s something you were and think, "Once I'm done with this game [avoid spoiler tracks] I'm going to listen to this stuff over and over". [Although it should be noted that the music always sounds better when you’re enjoying it as a part of the game]. Parts of the OST also fulfilled my chiptune element quota :3 [i]Serious[/i] props to Pascal Michael Stiefel for capturing a brilliant sense of adventure.

A few technical problems did show up here and there but it wasn’t anything unforgivable. Sometimes collision errors appeared when the game had tricky geometry or struggled with apply wall jumps. One instance forced me to return to hub after getting caught falling above ground endlessly. The way this game handles circular objects can be a bit off sometimes as well. Grabbing nonexistent ledges and generally being afraid to hop onto round surfaces also hurts the game’s otherwise polished surroundings.

Chapters feel like toy boxes and have a good density of little secrets/intractables. Chapters not only change up visually but have an assortment of unexpected variety (hallway sprints, races, stealth segments, parades etc.) that have you wondering what they’ll come up with next. Nothing ever feels like that game has failed at trying to contain too many types of gameplay, a common trap for other platformers. Outside of Chapter 2, areas have a central act that let you explore and choose what objectives you want to complete first. Personal choices like where to explore, what Acts/Chapters to do and even what Hats/colors you wear make for an adventure of your very own.
Secrets, in the form of token/relics [for time rifts]/yarn, foster spatial awareness that turn landscapes into memorable play-places. Finding and playing the bonus time rifts, with their somber music, were some of my favorite moments.

A Hat in Time is filled with frienemies who, plot-wise, are on your side but seem to be okay with a few murders here and there (perhaps in acknowledgement of Hat Kid’s god-like superiority). The personalities of NPCs are across the board silly and enduring. For example, Mafia Town hosts some Mafioso that are both aggressive and a few that just want to chit-chat or play patty-cake. I also love Hat Kid’s lovable and confident nature. Detail in the animations for walking have her stomp around like a superhero and extras like that are topnotch. Collectively, A Hat in Time has too many little moments to count. It feels like love and care went into bringing these areas to life.

Thankfully, completion is forgiving, there no achievements about getting every token/yarn. 100% means you’ve seen every mission and done a few goofy extras. Going all out and getting all the yarn or tokens to grab hats/colors is your choice. Some of the harder achievements, the four I don’t have, are all something I spent a decent amount of time on before becoming too frustrated to continue. I’m a little disappointed in myself for diving into them knowing my typical response to ‘beat with one health’ challenges. Through my drive to pointlessly acquire achievements, I ended up hurting my last few experiences in a game I enjoyed. For Steam’s in-game overlay, this has been its final nail in the coffin and I’ve chosen to disable it from now on and learn to savor games in the moment more.

A Hat in Time has been, and will continue to be, a fantastic escapade. It’s a great reminder of why I love video games and there’s plenty more I could discuss. There’s always an element caution when shouting praises at a game in this manor so it’s good to try to stay real. After all, the worst way to recommend something to someone is to completely overhype it. In the end, A Hat in Time blew me out of the water and it’s something that I hope others can enjoy as much as I did <3
I can’t wait to see that crazy stunt Gears For Breakfast tries to pull off in the future. In the meanwhile, I’ll be anxiously waiting to play custom levels and watch the community flourish with the inclusion of modding.

[Note to Self: First shot at trying to give games I enjoyed as many words in a review as the games I’ve disliked. Structure and content wise, it’s way easier to write with a critic stance but it’s still important to talk about what worked and why. If this assortment of scratches did make any sense, oops. It’s an ongoing process :) ]

38841180.review:
In a generation where many developers try to coast by on nostalgia value, it's nice to see a game that captures that giddy platforming delight I had back when I first gave Super Mario 64 a spin. Though not without its faults, A Hat in Time is an exciting 3D-platformer romp with quite a bit of love and charm backing it all up. 
Marooned in space on the way home from.... Something, the protagonist Hat Kid must retrieve the Magical Hourglasses used to power her ship. The stakes are high--however, as once people find out these trinkets have the power to reverse time, all bets are off. In typical 3D-platformer fashion, Hat Kid has a wide range of moves, powers, and gadgets to maneuver the jump-heavy worlds and plenty of goals to achieve. Missions range from challenge stages to races, and while many of said challenges aren't particularly challenging, they still offer an enjoyable time. The levels are backed up by a distinct artistic vision reminiscent of Wind Waker and Paper Mario--a cutesy, almost storybook world with goofy characters. The soundtrack evokes the orchestral pieces from Super Mario Galaxy along with newer, groovier tunes, and the voice acting ranges from excellent to somewhat annoying. Thankfully the developers included a special item to turn most dialogue into the jibber-jabber made popular by Banjo-Kazooie, so nothing grates too much. As for the script itself, it's simplistic, but fun. You won't find yourself laughing at every joke, but there are definitely ones you will laugh at. The game doesn't take itself too seriously, nor does the plot. In conclusion, if you find yourself weighed down by a few extra dollars and you catch this on sale, give it a shot. Even if you don't love it you'll get a good amount of mileage!

38837166.review:
Very charming, possibly-incomplete (see Cons section), light-hearted platformer, bringing back memories of N64 platformers.  Think along the lines of Mario 64, Banjo-Kazooie, and Donkey Kong 64.  Thoroughly enjoyed my playthrough of this little gem; A Hat in Time is a fine example of what someone can make utilizing Unreal engine.  You collect yarn to unlock a variety of hats which contain special powers.  Each power allows you to reach new areas or unlock new stages.  You also collect gems as currency to purchase ability badges that either upgrade your hat powers or give you some abilities.  3 badges and one hat may be worn at a time, so learning to switch when needed is essential (but not that difficult).  A few takeaways:

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
[b]+  Art Style:[/b] Well-funded.  Wonderfully textured environments that fit the cartoony feel.  Whoever the main artist is, there are tons of in-game "artwork" and illustrations to be found.  Kudos to whoever the artist(s) was/were, as well as the director for investing to have so many illustrations done.

[b]+  Platforming:[/b]  This is the main difficulty and focus of the game.  While not impossible or requiring mastery levels of practice, there are some solid challenges to overcome.  Hopefully you, the reader, understand when I describe a "pooper retracting up your spine" feeling, yes?  

[b]+  Level Design:[/b]  Like the Art Style, the various worlds shine brightly.  Each are beautiful in their own way and are full of life.  Besides your main spaceship (think Peach's Castle), you have 4 themed worlds to visit.  Each world has distinct zones to visit that differ, but fit in with the theme of the world.  Most are open worlds while one is instanced.  Puzzles mix between fighting bosses, scavenger hunts, difficult platforming, and even stealth!

[b]+  Voice Acting:[/b]  Suitable, non-cringy dialog.  A few adult-nudges for any parents that are playing with kids.  No obnoxious, Eddie Murphy sidekick.  

[b]+  Controls:[/b]  Surprisingly smooth.  

[b]+  Original Soundtrack:[/b]  Subjective, but very well done.  Original songs that fit the game, with the exception of two.  One is a mixture of two Zelda OoT songs and the other... I swear it is a remake of Merry Christmas Mr. Lawrence.  Not complaining though, MCML is one of my favorite songs.

[b]+  Steam Workshop:[/b]  Custom fun!  Players are creating their own levels and designing their own hat skins.  

[b]+  Ends:[/b]  The game ends.  You don't have to grind, buy loot boxes, or whatever online nonsense.  Strange to think one would get excited about something ending, but its >current year+1.

[b]+ (Almost) No Political/Social Agenda:[/b]  Story is free of any of that nonsense.  There is onneeee small political joke against capitalism tucked away in a level.  I'm guessing whoever owns Gears for Breakfast likely believes differently now that this game is a hit.  Funny how that works, huh!


[h1]Cons:[/h1]
[b]-  Length:[/b]  You will likely not reach the [$1 / 1 hour] quota on you first playthrough.  Mario 64 had 120 stars and cost $70 at launch in 1998.  This game has 40 "time pieces" (same as stars) and costs around $30.  I managed to collect them all in the course of 18hours while not exactly speeding through levels (taking screenshots, eating meals, looking around the levels for fun).  In addition, did not use any guides.  More time will be invested to collect the achievements.  the Achievements call for beating a certain number of stages without losing a life or beating a boss without taking damage.  If you dabble in user-created levels through Steam Workshop, you will likely cross the $1/1hr threshold.

[b]- Collecting / Power Ups:[/b]  Once you know the main use of each ability, there's very little "creative applications" for them.  The game is very straight forward.  When originally starting the game, I was speculating if one could further upgrade their hat powers with extra yarn (items needed to unlock the ability hats).  Turns out they don't.  There's a badge that powers up one hat, and another that reduces cooldown for two others.  That's it.  Additionally:
[list]
    [*] No investing currency/yarn to power or level up items.
    [*] Very small amount of "relics" to collect.  I think 14 or so?
    [*] No side-quests or trading items to NPCs. 
    [*] You cannot obtain every cosmetic unlock. 
    [*] In the Purple Time Rift (World themed stages), collecting all the photographs doesn't seem to do anything.  No achievement or in-game scrapbook to review them.  They don't appear to count towards save-file completion %.
    [*] No final, ultimate, power hat for 100%'ing.
[/list]

[i]Note:[/i]  Don't sweat like a thick, elephant cup, elf milf in a sinkhole when you suddenly realize you have no more coins to use the cosmetic-item-giving slot machine.  Also, don't scratch your head when you end the game with 100% and still have hat-creating yarn leftover.  This is working as intended.  You can obtain additional slot machine coins by playing user-created levels.  As for the leftover yarn, no idea what (if anything) is planned for them.  

[b]- Enemies / Challenges:[/b]  Boss fights are challenging and very entertaining.  However, the normal rank and file enemies are extremely limited.  Once you observe the one way they attack and the easiest counter, that's all you need to know.  The challenging aspect of this game is platforming, not fighting.   Puzzles do repeat, however.  None are overwhelming difficult or elaborate.  No Zelda 64 Water Temple, but also no Skyrim spinning totems.  While more focus is placed on platforming, doing the "throw the bomb" puzzles became dull after the 10th time.

[h1]Conclusion:[/h1]
You will know from the art style and hearing "N64 platforming" whether or not you will want this game.  I found it to be an extremely enjoyable, light game and enjoyed every minute of running around.  Wondering now if there will be any updates / DLC that add anything.  Its a bit interesting that the game ends with excess yarn in your inventory.  I certainly do recommend A Hat in Time to friends.  If by some remote chance a member of the development team is reading this, please consider these for the next DLC or game in the series:

~ Ability to power up hats with a currency/yarn.
~ More relics to hunt.
~ Sidequests with NPCs.
~ Some sort of a final hat to spend excess yarn with.
~ Collection notebook/menu that shows progress of everything collected and numbers that are missing.  This includes Purple Time Rift photos, R.K. notes, relics and yarn.

38834570.review:
A Hat in Time is a game that borrows from Super Mario 64, Super Mario Sunshine, Super Mario Galaxy, and Banjo-Kazooie, featuring 3D platforming mechanics, collecting things for the sake of collecting things, and multi-objective large open areas with wacky yet not out-of-place designs (perhaps a bit of Psychonauts?)

That said, AHiT is worth much more than just nostalgia: it's cute, humorous, challenging, and a lot of fun, while also meeting modern standards with high-quality graphics and fluid, precise controls. There's also modding support with a bunch of well-made mods already available on the Workshop (currently in an opt-in beta).

Also, you can ride a Roomba.

(Note for OSX users: Modding support beta is currently only available on Windows. DirectInput controllers - most notably DualShock (PlayStation) controllers - are not recognized properly by the game at the moment, so you may have to use keyboard controls.)

38833819.review:
I grew up playing 3D platformers, so after my disappointment from Yooka Laylee’s supposed mediocrity (still haven’t played it), my interest was sparked by A Hat In Time. I finally got to give it a chance, and after I started I couldn’t stop, the whole time with a smile on my face. The devs know exactly what their game is in terms of game design and it shows, in other games I would consider it too ambitious to switch up level design so much but A Hat in Time does it with a lot of tact, and I actually welcomed it. Whether it was the short vignettes of the movie studio or the vast, beautiful expanse of the mountains, this game made me smile at every turn, it was infectious, and I couldn’t help but see the love and care put in by people who actually care about video games.


Pros
------
-Change in level design from act to act was done well and was actually welcomed

-Adorable story and characters

-The controls felt great, and the tutorialization was fun

-Kept gameplay fresh with badges and other missions

-Some of the visuals are absolutely amazing in this game, and some of the visual experiences left me audibly saying “WOW!”

-Exploration was fun

-Surprisingly deep amount of customization for the main character

-Great music!

-Made me laugh constantly
 


Cons (minor complaints, just little things I think the game could have to make it better)
------
-Lack of free roam after completion of worlds/ levels (you can practically free roam in most 	levels, but it would be nice to have a dedicated feature for free roam on all levels that 		have collectibles.)

-Sometimes it felt like a map was needed to navigate, and I think would be useful to younger and/or more inexperienced players who have a trouble with landmarking in games (I’m thinking mainly in the forest level)

-Graphically there was a lack of polish, but no game breaking bugs, and totally understandable for an indie dev for a game of this scale (this seems contradictory to my pros statement, but this game was on a spectrum graphics-wise).
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


Overall this was one of the most pleasant experiences with a game I’ve had in a long time, and it was good from top to bottom. There was a lot of good games to come out of 2017, but A Hat in Time is definitely in my top 5 this year.

38822822.review:
TL:DR If you like the old school platformers like super mario sunshine and Banjo and Kazooie with a mix of some modern ones you will most likely enjoy this game. The humor's fantasic and the platforming is fun. It controls well and has a good sense of difficulty.

Pros:
+Awesome soundtrack
+Colorful atmosphere
+Cute artstyle
+Great level design
+Memorable characters

Cons: (Mostly Personal Nitpicks)
-The Camera can be annoying to work with in tight spaces
-Feels a little short but its great to replay the levels
-I've had some collision issues when Dashing into certain things but that's the only giltch I ran into

A hat in Time feels like a throwback to old school golden age of platformers. It takes insperation from the collectables from Banjo Kazooie without making collecting everything feel like an outright requirement. Super Mario Sunshine with the various amounts of ways you can travel, jump, run and pounce your way through the game along with some level ideas. And even physchonauts of all things from its original and very funny humor. To memorable characters you meet while progressing through the game.

The Story of the game is pretty simple, there isn't much that happens spoiler wise. The main character Hat Kid is trying to get home but while doing so she lost all of her Time Pieces which is fuel for her ship. If she wants to return home she needs to collect them. You don't need all of them to beat the game but its nice to play extra levels and it feels great when you complete and gather everything. The controls for the game are great! you can use a keyboard or controller to play the game. You can unlock different abilites by collecting yarn and turning that yarn into hats. Each hat acts differently and can bring something new to the table in regards of movment, combat, or ultility.

My few complaints about the game is the camera doesn't feel like it likes to cooperate in tight spaces, which can make certain jumps pretty tricky or annoying to deal with. Another complaint I have is that I've had Hat Girl's collision when dashing into certain objects getting her stuck in certain objects or places and having me to restart the level. Its nothing game breaking and its mostly nit picks, But for a game that was on Kickstarter its a great game to play. It can feel a little short towards the end of the game but all the levels were memorable and there wasn't one that I hated.

All in all its a solid kickstarter game that made me enjoy playing and collecting everything I could. I'd give it an 8/10

38821258.review:
A Hat in Time - a bright and upbeating action-adventure platformer that will surely bring you back to the times when things were much simpler.

The game follows a simple story: a kid with a hat heads home with her spaceship that uses hourglass-shaped entities called timepieces as fuel. But all things goes so wrong when she passes through Mafia Town. Now, in order to return home, she must retrieve all the timepieces while meeting all new friends and foes.

The game features multiple levels, called "Chapters". For each chapter there would be multiple "Acts" for specific scenarios and activities. So level diversity is something that's definitely not lacking. Activities can be racing, fetch quest or going into special levels called timerifts. Players are dropped into a Chapters and they can either follow that scenario or just go around and explore freely without time limits.

As Hat Kid, you are aided by your trusty umbrella as a weapon and a collection of Hats with special abilities to overcome obstacles. This can be a simple default Hat that locates the main object of interest, or a time-stop Hat, or even a Hat to see the alternative world. Keep in mind that a Chapter may feature obstacles that is impossible to do until you get the right upgrades in later Chapters, but these are usually not game-stopping, so no worries. You can still progress through the stories normally from collecting enough timepieces.

The overall tone of the game is amazingly diversed. It's upbeat, funny, a little bit spooky and maybe sad. But there's no noteworthy cringe moments so people can watch you play without feeling awkward.

It's no suprise that the game is inspired by other 3D platformers such as Super Mario 64 or Banjo-Kazooie, and for these games, music has always been a great part of them and it's no exception for A Hat in Time. The music definitely gives me a lasting and positive impression.

The game is my personal GOTY for 2017. I would wholeheartedly recommend this game to you if you find joy in exploration, platforming and CUTE things!

日本語非対応でも是非プレイして欲しくなる作品です。アイテム配置や細かい配慮のあるシステムで導線が分かる素晴らしいレベルデザインで英語が苦手でも進められています。
バンジョーとカズーイの大冒険やYooka Laylee、マリオサンシャインなどが近い印象です。難易度も普通に進めていく分には程よくリトライする程度でサクサク進められています。日本語対応前のYooka Layleeはクイズが多く問題文がそもそも理解出来ず進めないなどありましたがこちらの作品はそこまで問題ないです。
他にも、カラフルで見ていて楽しくなるビジュアル、様々なモチーフでついついのめり込んでしまう各種ワールド、可愛いキャラクター達、けしてハイエンドグラフィックや今時な技術満載では無くとも少し懐かしさを感じる作り込みは刺さる方にはしっかりと刺さると思います。今年の3Dシングルアクションゲームでは一番のお気に入りになりました、是非プレイを。

- Enter a movie studio
- Two birds are arguing about whose movie is better
- See a machine that gives sunglasses
- Ignore conversation
- Run to machine and get a pair of glasses.

- Don't have to tell me twice

If you're wondering if you want to buy this game or not, well...
Do you like mario sunshine?
Do you like banjo and kazooie?
Do you like actually decent jokes that don't make you groan?
Do you like collecting things?
Do you like jumping on different platforms to collect those things?
Do you like hats?
Do you like cute little girls? *wee woo wee woo* NO, not like that..
Do you enjoy bringing down an establishment of organized crime using an umbrella?

Saying yes to any one of these things means you will definitely enjoy this game. It may be short to some but every second of this gem is well done. The quality far outweighs the quantity. Buy this game, jump around, beat people with an umbrella, sell your soul, join a parade, become a movie star, and save the universe from time anomalies. Good luck, and go get that completionist hat!

p.s. Time stop hat is best hat. Fight me.

So yeah, nice game 10/10 would buy again.

Overall, this game is a solid 3D platformer that is worth your time. I wouldn't say it's downright amazing, but it was hard to find problems with it when I mostly enjoyed the game.

Pros:
- The controls feel fluid and responsive.
- Gameplay varies heavily. Sometimes the game is a fast-paced platformer, other times it's about exploring an open world, and at one point it's even a genuinely scary horror game.
- The soundtrack is enjoyable.
- The story is fun (especially in Subcon Forest), and the game is full of cuteness and funny dialogue.
- There is a bunch of content that I still have not played, in spite of having "beaten" the game, and supposedly the developers are going to add even more content in the future.

Cons:
- The graphics are a bit lacking, though it is in a cartoonish way.
- There was no reason for the hook to be a badge (just a minor nitpick)

38788310.review:
This game is a harkening back to all the beloved mascot 3D platformers that came before it. The influence of Banjo-Kazooie, the Super Mario series, a bit of Conker's Bad Fur Day, and a healthy dose of Psychonauts to name a few is sincerely noticeable. Also noticeable is a soundtrack that soars with the whimsy of Mario Galaxy, the cutsie charm of Banjo, and something entirely own with the likes of several guest musicians including Grant Kirkhope, of Banjo and Conker fame. And what also sticks with you is the constant barrage of clever and adorable details that didn't need to exist to make this game stand on its own, but was lovingly crafted regardless. Though it stumbles once in my opinion, I couldn't recommend this game possibly more. If you're on the fence and reading this for some reason: Buy. This. Game.
The cuteness is unlike any other, entirely its own brand of adorable lovability and unending charmfullness. 

However, there are a few moments that were especially damning for this beloved game, and that is one of its levels: Alpine Skyline. This level is a bit of a callback to Banjo-Kazooie's Click-Clock Woods, a 4-part level with seasons differentiating it. Alpine Skyline by contrast is divided much more subtley by various themes such as visual puns like Lava Cake being a several story tall row of increasingly smaller piles of lava, like a super-heated wedding cake. The level is devoid of linear pathways in a more find-it-yourself fourway. It allows for freedom but is devoid of the game's typical charm and cutesy  style. It's a gorgeous level that feels very empty due to the lack of direction present in all other chapters. No major supporting character was present to offer the level of memorability that Mafia or The Snatcher had. Throw on top of this the gameplay extending Finale that was just a bit absurd in the way that it tests patience more than any other. Frankly, Alpine Skyline was an unnecessary level that could have been replaced by something far more memorable. But with such a shining star of a game, a knick in the paint isn't that bad overall.

Despite that rant, though, A Hat in Time is a modern classic of 3D platforming and a wonderful addition to a childlike longing for the happier times. A world of unending intrigue, love, and charm is something we all need from time to time. I'd recommend this to anyone who loves to have fun and would like to tap into their inner child.

38778325.review: Absolutely incredible. A Hat in Time is a love letter to N64-era collectathons, with a fluid, satisfying movement system, four wonderfully designed worlds full of fully-voiced, super charming characters, and awesome music by Pascal Michael Stiefel and Grant Kirkhope. 38770253.review:
This is a really, really _fun_ game to play.

Pros:
* Level design is whimsical and inventive.
* Music is really well done, and transitions between states is very smooth and intuitive.
* Combat is good, though the "double-jump then seek-attack" combo can be hard to get 100% of the time.
* Dying outside a boss fight is usually fairly forgiving.
* Boss fights are tough, w/o being impossible.

Cons:
* Levels are mostly platform-based, so lots of practice is required before you can do the trickier moves reliably.
* Game doesn't explain that many optional areas of the 1st zone's levels are inaccessible w/o hats obtained from further zones.

TL;DR: If you like whimsical level design and your reflexes aren't worse than mine (and mine suck), you should get it.

8/10

38760861.review:
Going into A Hat in Time I honestly wasn't too sure what to expect, I had heard comparisons to everything from Super Mario Sunshine, to Yooka-Laylee and Banjo Kazooie and everything in between. The only thing I knew I'd be getting was a platformer from a kickstarted indie developer.

With that being said A Hat in Time has surpassed all of my expectations and has been one of the few new games I've not only purchased in recent years, but enjoyed enough to want more, and more.

This review will discuss aspects of the story, characters, levels, etc. and thus will contain mild spoilers. If you've watched trailers and/or played the Beta none of this should come as a surprise, but nontheless here is your obligatory:

 - MILD SPOILER WARNING - 

The Story: (everything discussed is seen in the trailer)

A Hat in Time is about a young girl (Hat Girl) trying to find her way home. Suddenly while in orbit above "Mafia Town" a member of the Mafia breaks his way into Hat Girl's starship in an attempt to force her to pay a tax. While rather simplistic and certainly a callback to other popular platformers' style of handling story such as the Super Mario series this direction also feels fresh and charming.

With such a simple goal as 'get your Time Pieces back so you can go home' A Hat in Time really frees the player to have as open-ended of an adventure on the planet as they want in the meantime.

As is customary with games in this genre though, there isn't much to talk about here. Story is never the selling point of games in this genre and A Hat in Time focusing on letting you make your own story out of what they've provided should only encourage gamers to pick it up.

Characters:

It's no surprise to anyone that's watched the trailers or played the Beta that Gears for Breakfast has gone out of their way to make likeable, and very memorable characters for their game.

 - If you're one of the people that hasn't watched trailers or seen anything, let me assure you, they're fantastic -

The protagonist, Hat Girl, is "heckin'-cute", or adorable as I'd simply put it and helps give the game a very unique charm. Other minor characters such as the Mafia are given just as much attention and they really help make the areas you explore feel alive. This is a great improvement off of other titles in the genre which just feel like you're jumping across random platforms suspended in space (like many newer Mario titles would have you do).

I won't give a breakdown of each character, as I'd like to keep spoilers to a minimum, but I can assure you there is plenty of charm hidden in this gem of a game.

Levels:

Here I'll mostly discuss what the levels bring to the table as I'm not quite qualified to speak on behalf of level design (although I did enjoy how they were all layed out). So here goes:

A Hat in Time is broken up into five 'Chapters', each Chapter being a different portion of the planet your starship is in orbit above. Chapter 1, Mafia Town is a large town built on a tropical island paradise.  Chapter 2, Battle of the Birds takes place within a film studio (and movie sets). Chapter 3, The Subcon Forest is (as you'd guess) set within a forest. Chapter 4, Alpine Skyline is a very beautiful level set atop lofty mountain peaks (and totally open to free roaming might I add). Chapter 5 I will leave as a surprise, mostly because I didn't expect it to be anything like it was and I'd like to allow you a similar opportunity to be surprised.


Overall, I have no idea if any of this would help someone to pick up the game, but these are my thoughts on these three aspects of the game after beating it. I haven't 100%'d the game as of yet, at the time of writing I've beaten the game with the minimum of 26 time pieces (with 40 total to collect in the game - although I hear there's also rumors of free DLC going around, I'll have to look into that), so I may come back to edit this if my opinion on anything changes between now and when I 100% finish. Throughout my playthrough I was graced with wonderful platforming that was not too challenging (even with a keyboard and mouse - no controller needed here folks!), a good difficulty that straddled the line between easy and hard, never too easy but challenging at times, and a wonderful overall experience. A Hat in Time is the kind of game I used to expect from 'AAA' companies before they became consumed by greed and I wish the best to Gears for Breakfast. I genuinely enjoyed A Hat in Time and I will more than likely continue to for a long time. From what I've heard the game is also open to modders so I likely won't get bored of this title for quite a long time.

After all is said and done my final rating is:

(Minimum % rating): 10/10

Now that I have finished I can say that I stand behind my initial rating: 10/10.
I hope this review helped you!

38759407.review:
A Hat in Time is fantastic! The game consists of different worlds, similar to Mario 64 or Mario Sunshine. Each world is entirely unique. The main goal of the game is to collect time pieces (stars). Along the way you will meet a colorful cast of characters, discover new game mechanics, and collect different hats which give you different abilities.

The platforming is the main focus of this game and when it works, it shines. Sometimes I do feel like I have to fight with it a bit though.

The game is a little short as well, however, what it lacks in quantity, it makes up for in quality. Every single goal and world is wonderfully crafted. The plot and subplots are easy to follow but are interesting enough to stay invested.

A Hat in Time hammers hard on the nostalgia, but it still seems new. While other 3D platformers seem to lack ingenuity, A Hat in Time is exploding at the seems with great fresh content.

I give A Hat in Time 8/10.

38752526.review:
What a game. 
Incredibly cute characters, and equally cute writing. But along with the sweetness of the sheer cuteness there's also a fair bit of humor - I was laughing during most of my playtime. If you have played Super Mario Sunshine, and liked that, chances are you'd enjoy this game as well.

The only gripe I have with this game would be the length; it does feel somewhat short after you complete it. But in my opinion that doesn't make the price too high. Especially on a sale, for someone looking for a cutesy story with some very decent 3d platforming to go along with it, this is a must-have. 

I encountered a few glitches, mostly clipping issues with moving platforms. But none of them were all that game-breaking. Where one of the times was when I was intentionally trying to find alternate routes you could move, resulting in clipping through a wall and ending up in a spot I couldn't get out of. 

All in all, this is a purchase that I in no way regret. It felt like playing through Sunshine for the first time again.

38736075.review:
i lack the capacity to explain how exceptional this game is, i like to think i am pretty critical of games and i spent the entire game (90% total completion) looking for issues to have with it, i expected the movement mechanics to have at least slight issues, they were flawless. I expected the comedy aspects of the game to be cringe due to the cutesy nature of the game, it was hilarious. if you havent played corgi quest yet please do, you wont regret it. I expected the story to be bland and for the wonder of the well designed maps to wear off before late game, but each new area was more spectacular than the other and each time piece i aquired gave me a snowball feeling of wanting more. The difficulty was easy enough for me to feel unencumbered as i explored the maps, but challenged enough for it to keep me engaged with the levels mentally, the boss fights are hard enough that you may spend a few lives learning the attack patterns but not enough to frustrate you in any way, it amazes me how devs balance difficulty so well and its always something i look for in a single player game.

Now for the negatives, please be aware that i was intentionally looking for negatives and all of these are very much nitpicking, some you may not even notice. For one i noticed that i began finding some minor glitches in the later stages of the game specifically in the time rift levels. Secondly and personally my biggest downfall is the price to time played ratio, i have a rule i like to follow which is that i need to get 1hr of gameplay per 50c spent on the game, at full price that would mean 60hrs which is simply unreachable without replaying a considerable amount of missions, i took my time playing through, checking for secrets and only reached 19 hours. i will likely continue playinf for the last few time rifts and yarn that i missed, but i doubt i will get above 30hrs. lastly i would simply like more acheivment to go for, just some goofy ones that i can do to get more playtime down.

suggestions:
there is basically nothing i can suggest to "fix" the game as it is not in any way broken. The dev team is FAR above my level of knowlage on what makes a game great. One probably stupid question if the devs would like to continue working on the game would be to add a multiplayer race mode with simple linear maps the test who is the best platformer player of you and your mates. But honestly i see no need on adding multiplayer to this game when it is already such an excellent  single player experiance.

Rating: 9.8/10
Never thought id give such a high rating

38725498.review:
So recently I just 100% the game (minus the achievements), and I can safely say that this was one of the best games I played this year.

The movement of the game is very fluid and is a blast to experiment with; you can take huge shortcuts and take shortcuts if you learn to master how to utilize your tools to the fullest potential. The game also has a very cute artstyle and sense of humor. The game never truely takes itself seriously and that benefits the whole  lighthearted feeling of the game. The artstyle, while a bit rough, is charming and works well.


The only problems  I really had with the game involved HOW the story progressed and a couple of issues I ran into during my playthrough. The main antagonist of the story and the way the story moves felt a bit disorganized as I never really saw the villain as all that important or relevant until the very end of the game. The bugs that I ran into have (to my knowledge) been patched out by the developers, so this shouldnt effect as many others and their playthroughs any more.

TL; DR: Every single moment of this game felt like a blast to play and was overall a very nice experience. It wasn't perfect, but I can't recommend this game enough. I look forward to seeing more from Gears for Breakfast.

I played this game a ton on my brother's steam account and I loved it. Saw it on sale and decided to buy it. Unfortunately, it is unplayable on my computer. Let's run down why.



1. Sensitivity issues.
The sensitivity default for me was at a level of "Holy jesus I'm rotating at 100,000 RPM". Cranked it down to the minimum, and it was still stupidly sensitive. Made it really hard to control my character.

2. Frame rate inconsistancies. 
At medium high graphics I can run at about 90 FPS. This is not the issue, which is the sudden and common freezing and frame stutter also causes the mouse to freak out, making it even MORE unplayable.


3. Error to save graphics and sound settings.

Self explanitory.



All in all, I love the gameplay and plot (From playing on my brother's account) but there are a TOn of issues that make it unplayable. I might try it again when I get some upgrades for my PC.

38700526.review:
A Hat in Time is perfection. Granted, it's ten hours long, but they are ten hours of perfection. The visuals are beautifully adorable. The hats are unique and entertaining. Every level is a hand-crafted masterpiece complete with A-grade cinematic score and never the same gimmick twice. It has collectibles I actually want to collect, and mini-campaigns I actually want to follow.

They must've realised how insanely good the game was halfway through development, because they just started doing whatever they wanted and it worked. There's a freeroam section, and it's rewarding and varied. There's a survival horror segment, and it's creepy as hell. I had a boss fight with a haunted outhouse and it was bloody awesome. I led a marching band across rooftops in a marching band equivalent of Snake, and instead of being frustrating it was the cutest thing I've seen all year. The marching band music was better than actual marching bands. I got an umbrealla that shot laser beams, fell in a mud puddle and pretended to be an alien monster, and rode a scooter through an exploding train, and it was all masterfully executed. This game just cannot fail. [i]It. Cannot. Fail.[/i]

If someone asked my why sequels exist, I'd show them this game. Because sometimes it isn't a matter of fixing things - sometimes it's just making more of utter gaming perfection. Buy this game. That isn't a recommendation, that's me demanding you to throw your money at these people so they can make more incomprehensibly brillaint games. We need more from these people. I don't care what it is, they're incapable of making something bad. Just buy the game. Just do it. Do it for the hats.

If I had to make any complaints, it would be that boss fights are a fairly long endevour with very little to no checkpoints for the fights. There were also a couple parts of the game that felt like you needed to think excactly like the developer did in order to continue because the puzzle is not very intuitive, But those parts are very far and few between. 38683461.review:
Objectively: 8.5/10
Personally: 9.5/10
If you don't own this already, you're stupid

It's a medium budget indie game so expect some bugginess, but all in all it's a great game.
I know the comparison is done to death, but this game is seriously way better than Yooka Laylee, and had a fraction of the budget. You could tell that the developers really cared about what they were creating, and they put a lot of love into the game. The soundtrack is phenomenal, the gameplay is awesome, the characters are zany and memorable. A Hat in Time has a great sense of humor, and is one of the best platformers to come out for a very long time. This game is nothing but fun, and it's loaded with memorable segments. Each level is charming and unique.

There are some minor camera issues which can affect gameplay, but I didn't really have a problem with it.
There are also some graphical/animation glitches, but they don't affect the gameplay.
There's also some bits that you can tell are unfinished, like the developers had bigger plans for some areas but unfortunately ran out of budget.

It's fun, just play it. Support good indie devs.

Didn't really think of myself as a platformer kinda person until this game.  I can't begin to describe the love put into this game but I will try and summarize it.

Story 7/10:
Cute but some parts lacking development.  Still has a good story nonetheless.

Gameplay 9/10:
The controls are nearly perfect, and the design of both worlds and enemies feels like a lot of thought was behind it, and they all came out great. I only have one minor gripe with the jumping but it's very negligible and most likely a preference of mine.

Soundtrack 10/10:
NieR: Automata, Undertale, Final Fantasy, Persona.  A Hat in Time's soundtrack is on-par with these games imo.

Sound FX 8/10:
Matches the game, although some (mostly minor) animations seem to be missing sound effects? (Laser badge)

Art Direction, Style, and UI Design 10/10:
The game is as cute as advertised.  I've never been lost in the menus.  Everything is crisp, vibrant, pleasant, even fun to look at.

Conclusion (a very high) 9/10:
Pick up this game right now if you like cute things and/or platformers.  It's a must-have for both categories.

38679476.review:
Wow! A Hat in Time hat mich von der ersten Minute an überrascht. Das Spiel versprüht sofort einen großartigen Charme, der mich als alten Nintendo-Hasen voll abholt. Dabei bedient es sich derart schonungslos bei Genre-Größen, dass ich beim Spielen mehrere "Flashbacks" hatte. Das große Vorbild ist definitiv und unübersehbar Super Mario Sunshine vom Gamecube – ohne die Wasserschleuder. Die erste Spielwelt riecht in jeder Ecke nach Piazza Delfino & Co. – was gut ist. Auch der Grafikstil, das Glühen der einzusammelnden Ster... äh, Sanduhren und nicht zuletzt die Special Stages sind sehr stark inspiriert. Ich musste eine Weile überlegen, wo ich das alles schon mal gesehen habe. ;-) Hinzu kommen natürlich eigene Ideen sowie ein klasse Humor. Dazu meine ich starke Einflüsse aus Super Mario Galaxy, Banjo-Kazooie und eine Prise Zelda: The Wind Waker zu sehen, was natürlich ebenfalls rockt.

Was bei mir immer ganz wichtig ist: die Musik. Und hier streichelt das Spiel direkt so die Ohren, dass ich einfach feiern muss. Melodische Ohrwürmer noch und nöcher, stets mit passender Tonlage und Dramatik - top! Das verleiht A Hat in Time meiner Meinung nach das gewisse Etwas, welches bei mir den Unterschied zwischen "gutes Spiel" und "Perle" ausmacht.

Natürlich stimmt auch das Gameplay. Ich hab's direkt mit einem Xbox-360-Pad gestartet und war entzückt über die direkte, stets präzise Steuerung. Hüpfen, Gleiten, Prügeln, alles ist so, wie man sich das wünscht. Sogar die Kamera ist gelungen! Mit Maus und Tastatur würde ich aber nicht anrücken. Grafisch reißt das Spiel trotz Unreal Engine 4 keine Bäume aus, aber der Comicstil ist nett und weitgehend sauber, wenn man vom (kurioserweise) fehlenden Temporal-AA und kleineren Schatten-Artefakten absieht.

A Hat in Time hat mich noch stärker in seinen Bann gezogen als Yooka-Laylee und daher bin ich sehr froh darüber, das Spiel so spontan und unvoreingenommen eingesackt zu haben. Uneingeschränkter Kauftipp an alle, die mit 3D-Hüpferei und dem knuffigen Stil etwas anfangen können. Achtung: Das Spiel ist nur auf Englisch verfügbar. Sicher, das ist kein RPG, aber es gibt sowas wie eine Inszenierung, Story und viel Humor – den sollte man verstehen.

Bad things:
The level felt cluttered and the yarn felt useless. I had gathered 8 yarn before the first time you catch the moustached girl. Parts of the level reminded me of super Mario 64 where you could go into  one level and see different 
stars to collect, but you couldn't interact with the collectables.The characters faces textures look stuck on like a robot chicken episode, but when the game is in 3d. It just looked shitty when I realized this and it doesn't seem to match the rest of the game. Going through the game and all of a sudden there is a character from deep space I GUESS that sells you upgrades.
Why is the dash the only thing to hurt enemies when they get red? There are lots of parts in this game that just happen without explanation, like the game is unfinished.

The graphics are very great and decent, but at somepoint the character 3D design is still kinda "miss".....especially the texture when it comes to other environment and lightning....but it still cute since it meant to be like that i suppose. and they added the feature to customize the main character which is a great idea, [b] thank you so much for that [/b] , as it has Steam Workshop feature available for modders aswell. And also the artworks, especially the loading screen artworks....i absolutely loves it, it is really amazing and very well done. i could just sit and watch the loading screen anytime cuz how satisfying and cute it is.

and the last one not least, the soundtrack. you cant make a good game without a great and memorable soundtrack. as this game has it and has it unique own soundtrack in each worlds. and they also add the remix soundtrack for each worlds...which is a nice addition.

[b] OVERALL [/b] i guess the platform games will just gonna keep better and better in each year as the current gaming state is actually getting pretty awful with giving us a lots of paid DLC and greedy developer......(Yes im talking to you [b] EA [/b] )

38661775.review:
Absolutely fantastic!
10/10

Pros:
-Cartoony style really gives zelda windwaker vibes
-The game takes its mechanics and presentation from super mario sunshine and galaxy, which is one of my favourite games of all time
-Every chapter and act has new mechanics that keep it fresh
-Hat kid is way too cute
-One chapter has freeroam, so you can go around and plantform as much as you like
-ZA WARUDO!
-So many random moments that will make you smile like an idiot
-Boss fights are really, and i mean REALLY exciting
-Soundtrack is gorgeous
No really, if you have the chance to get the deluxe edition with the soundtrack, get it

Cons:
-Game requires good pc specs to run properly, which is weird for a cartoony game, but the areas are so big that rendering everything on the highest quality requires a really good pc
Keeping it on performance mode gives the best performance-quality ratio
-Kinda too short, and the ending feels kinda abrupt
This will probably be fixed by the two extra chapters that are coming on the way, and by mod support
These will probably give us some more content, and mod supports gives the game virtually infinite content

Overall, if you even slightly like plantformers, this is a must buy.

38634495.review:
You're spurred out of your bed by a screeching alarm clock, begin to head to the kitchen to eat your two day old chinese food from the fridge, and instead are greeted by a beefy mustachioed man beating on the glass window to your spaceship. What's that, why does a spaceship have an openable window? Why is this man seemingly able to just be in space without a suit? WHO CARES!

This game is charming. Like, really charming. Each level is beautifully detailed in a style that reminds people of Elf in Tights 2: Sea Shanty of the Red Boat and they pull it off swimingly. There's a good amount of collectibles strewn about each level map, including balls of yarn to make new hats with different powers, special coins that your space child can gamble with to get new aesthetic changes and the usual platformer currency barfed all over the place for people to collect called pons. Pons can also be used for upgrades, particularly for pins, which you wear on your hat to gain extra effects.

Each world has chapters, which has a different objective based on the same map. After enough chapters are completed, there's a finale, which involves beating the snot out of people with protective raingear like an umbrella. There are also things called Time-Rifts, which are basically obstacle courses that you have to go through in a similar manner to Italian Tropical Janitor 3: Maximum Hydration on the gamecube.  Simple enough concept, sure, but this games music score, tight controls and whimsical feel are extremely happy, anti-depressive and really wrap up an extremely solid package of a game.

It is a short-ish game though, even if you want the 100%. The longest time sink in the game is probably getting every single color palette and hat skin from the slot machine on your ship. But the game is so buttery smooth in the gameplay department that it makes it all enjoyable and worth every last shekel. A Hat in Time is not a breakthrough of exciting new platforming standards, but it has mastered a lot of the tried and true elements of the classics.

A Hat in Time gets 4 Chinese Leftovers out of 5.

38609903.review:
This game is a masterpiece on par with a lot of the 3d Mario games.  While I've only played Mario 64 and Galaxy, I'd still easily say I enjoy this game far more than them;  The hat system is great, and I love using each individual power, as well as using them one after another on certain occasions.  All the chapters have a unique theme: [SPOILERS START HERE] Mafia Town is an island with enemies that you can choose to fight, and a flying sub-island which contains the boss.  Battle of the Birds has the crowd-pleasing acts of DJ Grooves, and the wild west train acts of the Conductor.  Subcon Forest has the overall spooky atmosphere, the eerie (Not really eerie, more like run like hell or get frozen by a shadow of a person) mansion of Queen Vanessa, and the Snatcher's contracts.  Alpine Skylines has the four portions which are made up of platforming, be it over lava, over death pits, the inside of a windmill, or trying to not get slapped into hell by the pompadour birds.  [SPOILERS END HERE] While there are only a few main characters (Around 2 or 3), the plot is good, the player character is extremely loveable, and I found myself enjoying a large amount of the other characters, whether they're main characters or side characters.  (My personal favorite is Snatcher.)  The bugs are extremely hard to notice and rather insignifcant when they are found.  
The boss fights are difficult, but not too hard;  They're going to pummel you sometimes, but that's until you figure out how to dodge the attacks, and a lot of the time it's a simple matter of leaping or diving at the right time.  Some of the bosses can be wacked all the time, but that's incredibly rare, or it's going to get you killed if you do try to.
The collectibles are fun to get and rewarding when you do get them, but besides the yarn, it's not going to give you anything more than cosmetics, so it's not too bad if you don't get them;  It's nice to get a lot of the cosmetics so you can give Hat Kid a look you're happy with. (My current favorite is lady bug hat flair for Sprint hat with the Blood Moon color scheme.)  The soundtrack is nice in the way that it sounds good and varies;  They're not going to give you a bloody orchestra for a train ride in the wild west, they're going to give you something fitting.  

TL;DR This game is great in many ways and has very little flaws, so buy it if you like quality platformers with good soundtracks.

A fantastic 3D platformer. The game is mostly upbeat, although a lot of interesting humor spices things up a bit. Excellent music, voice acting (although delivery feels a bit slow at times), and graphic style make for an enjoyable experience throughout the game. If you are a fan of 3D mario games, 3D rare games (N64 era), or the 3D platformers from the PS2 era (Sly Cooper, Ratchet and Clank, Jak and Daxter), you should pick this game up.

Small nitpicks. Landing on platforms that are rounded feel a bit inconsistent at times. One ability is nearly required once you obtain it, but it takes up an "upgrade" slot. While not nearly as bad as Assassin's Creed, the "run up the wall" move triggers a little too easily, making movement along narrow ledges troublesome at times.

38604046.review:
Game is highly overrated.  While it is an achievement by the development team and it is not a bad game by any definition, there are those who would say this game is on par with Mario.  They would be crazy.  

The game lacks A LOT of polish.  

The platforming is pretty medicore and quite often more annoying than rewarding. There is a lot of tight rope platforming where you cannot gauge where your character is in relation to the rope itself.  A lot of the level design is confusing and does not offer much in the way of visual cues to naturally guide you.  Instead you need to rely on a hat power up to point you in the right direction. 

Boss fights carry on FAR to long, and while they are not terrible exactly, a lot of bosses rely on TONS of visual clutter to provide an artifical challenge rather than a tightly crafted one. In fact, looking back the most difficult stages were ones with tons of visual clutter (Penguine Parade, Owl boss fight.) The most challenging boss however is the camera, good luck beating him. 

The controls feel way to loose. you will often find yourself running up a wall only to pull yourself up and over the platform and then falling to your death shortly after. Careful not to push that analog a bit to hard, hat girl will launch herself in that direction at tims and often to your death.  Something feels very off with your homing attack as well (Think sonics homing dash only slow and clumsy) then again the combat in general is pretty unfullfilling. 

There are quite a lot of bugs as well. Power ups that don't work at times (umbrella safe fall), clipping issues in some instances and a few other minor issues as well.  While not game breaking, after a while it starts to get harder to ignore.

It may be unfair to be so harsh on a small development team and kick starter game.  Anyone who can put out a game of this calibur through kickstarter should be proud of their achievement.  However, I personally did not enjoy this game at all.  After 10 hours I put it down and uninstalled because I found myself more furstrated fighting with the controls and camera (and I've been platform gaming since the 80s) on top of zoning out mentallly while just aimlessly running around some of the levels. 

I write this negative review because I bought it on the fact that everyone was overhyping this game and some even made the bold statement to say they enjoyed it more than Mario Odyessy.  Obviously that is their opinion and they are 100% entitled to feel that way but let me just say I almost completed 100% of Mario Odyessy but could not make it past 10 hours of this game. 38601337.review:
Ten hours to 100% this fantastic game.

[h1]Short Review:[/h1]

Soundtrack 9/10
Gameplay 9/10
Art Direction and Level Design: 8/10
Story: 6/10
Voice Acting: 9/10

Overall: 8.5 out of 10

This is a fantastic experience. A amazing throw back to collectathon game play like Banjo-Kazooie and Super Mario 64. The game play is flawless and smooth, albeit a tad frustrating at times. Some levels are harder then others, especially late game. This game also has amazing potential for speedrunners.

[h1]Long Review, describing each rating form the current above catagories.[/h1]

[b]Soundtrack, 9/10;[/b]

The soundtrack for this game is just amazingly perfect. Each song is fitting for each level and location in the game, and sets the atmospheres of the levels well. There are even a bunch of remixes for said levels that you can unlock via slot machine rolls you can get from completing the "Time rifts" (AKA, challenge levels). All the remixes are very well made as well. From the hard rock guitar rifts, to the western themed songs, to the spooky tunes, everything sounds great.

[b]Gameplay, 9/10;[/b]

I knew going into this game that it was a collectathon 3d platformer, but the depth of its flow and mechanics for platforming and running are just great! The sprint hat and grappling badge make for some awesome feeling parkour moments, and it all feels so natural. All of the levels accommodate games movement system with everything you can do, with long diving, wall running, etc. The collectibles are fun to grab and are all placed thoughtfully to make a constant run feel rewarding collecting 40+ Pons with one continuous sprint. Finding the Relics and mission objectives is rewarding as well, some of the challenges are pretty satisfying to complete.

[b]Art Direction and Level Design, 8/10;[/b]

The art direction and Level design is absolutely stunning. The 2d, and 3d art are all very well made. You can tell a lot of time and care went into all the pictures, models, levels, etc. All the main worlds are very pretty to look at, and the challenge levels are well.. a challenge. When you play a main world pink rift, you can collect pictures to look at. Some of them tell a story about something that happened in the world, like chapter 3's rift pictures detail a story about one of the villains you face against.

[b]Story, 6/10;[/b]

The story in this game is simple... if somewhat non-sensical. [spoiler]You are a small girl who is awoken by her ship, there is a member of a mafia somehow in space to collect a toll from you for passing by. And then there are birds in a movie studio... and then a spooky forest... and then floating islands with goat people and magical artifacts, and a angry austrailian girl who steals all your magic fule for her own selfish desires...[/spoiler] It dosn't make to much sence, but it's quirky and it's entertaining.

[b]Voice Acting, 9/10[/b]

The voice Acting in this game is sublime, all the voices fit their respective characters and nothing feels out of place. Not much else to say about it really.

[b]Conclusion:[/b]

This game is a great game. If you are new to collectathon games, or have been playing them since 1996, it is great for both partys to expirence! this game and POI have given me newfound hope for the collectathon genre to make a ressurectio in the modern day game scene. It's worth it's weight in gold at full price, or on sale. I recived it as a gift for my birthday, which made it even better.

38562826.review:
The platforming of Mario with the charm of the Wind Waker and the scenario design from Paper Mario. What's not to love?

In all seriousness, this game has rapidly become my favorite platformer of all time. Mouse + keyboard controls are incredibly tight and almost never frustrating. The writing is hilarious, the characters are endearing, the scenarios are incredibly inventive and unlike anything I've ever seen before, and the sheer variety of creativity here is stunning. All of it is good. None of it is dull. I can say, without a word of hyperbole, that I enjoyed this game more than Mario Galaxy. It's that good.

With that said, there is a bit of controversy still surrounding the game. JonTron is in the game and has not been removed. His role is very small, as an optional NPC, and I understand the developer's trying to not create the massive spectacle that Playtonic Games went through when they removed JonTron, but I still don't see why they couldn't have just silently patched him out. There's plenty of silent, unvoiced NPCs in the game (and occasionally, even voiced characters have unvoiced, text only lines) - what difference would one more make? His inclusion is a blemish on an otherwise spotless game, but, in my opinion, is not enough to invalidate the work done by the rest of the development team. If no one told you about JonTron, you probably would never have known about him being in this game in the first place.

At the end of the day, A Hat In Time combines fluid, satisfying platforming with an inventive world that you'd want to stay in for hours. Sure, minor nitpicks exist - Mustache Girl should have showed up more, Mafia Town is too Mario Sunshine-y, etc. - but ultimately, all of that melts away as you just enjoy the game itself. This is a platformer that certainly deserves a spot up there with the greats, if it doesn't exceed them altogether. Absolutely worth your time, especially since two additional chapters are coming for free. And if this game is on sale, then it gets an unconditional recommendation from me.

38556086.review:
To be fair, you have to have a very high IQ to understand A Hat in Time. The humour is extremely subtle, and without a solid grasp of theoretical hourglasses most of the jokes will go over a typical player’s head. There’s also Mustache Girl's rebellious outlook, which is deftly woven into her characterisation- her personal philosophy draws heavily from William Styron literature, for instance. The fans understand this stuff; they have the intellectual capacity to truly appreciate the depths of these jokes, to realise that they’re not just funny- they say something deep about TIME. As a consequence people who dislike A Hat in Time truly ARE idiots- of course they wouldn’t appreciate, for instance, the humour in Hat Girls existential Taunt *sticks tongue out at others*, which itself is a cryptic reference to Leo's Russian epic War and Peace. I’m smirking right now just imagining one of those addlepated simpletons scratching their heads in confusion as Gears for Breakfest genius minds unfolds itself on their Monitor screens. What fools.. how I pity them. 😂

And yes, by the way, i DO have a Hat in Time tattoo. And no, you cannot see it. It’s for the ladies’ eyes only- and even then they have to demonstrate that they’re within 5 IQ points of my own (preferably lower) beforehand. Nothin personnel kid 😎
