38553825.review:
It instills a sense of contentment that even its inspiration really never managed. And it is the kind of game where, there are no great screenshots you can really choose to represent the game  because every great screenshot you could take is something players should experience themselves.


The game is based heavily off Super Mario 64, but more specifically Super Mario Sunshine. The way the game it presents itself has a lots of roots in the gameplay themes Super Mario 64 started, but it feels significantly more inspired by Super Mario Sunshine in particular. The protagonist has the classic lean-in whenever they turn, along with the same leaping slide and laying sprawled out while sliding; all very reminisicent of the animations Mario had. The game has multiple gameplay and or theme concepts which are quite similar to Super Mario 64, Super Mario Sunshine and other games from the Mushroom Kingdom.

However the difficulty is not nearly as mind flaying as it could be in older Mario games, and the platforming is forgiving yet still stimulating to control. The game presenting a variety of different features which while not being overly complex or unique still give the gameplay a satisfying level of diversity. The maps are filled with meaningful collectibles used to either unlock cosmetics or new hats, presenting various platforming or soft puzzles to get to them. It is very satisfying to explore and just wander around in for the sake of it. 

The world itself is the strongest point, a silly cartoon dream of a place which is just dripping with sly humor that players can just stumble into while exploring the world map. It all feels just so simply enjoyable to be a part of. The music is wonderful and builds so much onto the atmosphere, and the boss fights are creative and fun.

The game goes beyond the open world with multiple objectives and scenarios theme however. There are all kinds of different unique levels and gameplay concepts implemented into them, almost none of the main levels in the game are just platforming; there is almost always a catch to it. The creativity never really goes dry, much like the games humor.



The game does show some signs of being a small developer title, some of the animations and such having a very unpolished look to them. Rough edges like this being visible in random places throughout the game but it is never really impairing in any way, it just serves as a reminder that this was not a full production game. Which is better anyways since if it was it would not be remotely as good.

The default camera can be overly sensitive at times, zooming in when the player gets too close to certain things in the environment which can make looking around for secrets tedious rarely. The presentation of various platforming obstacles players need to unlock the ability to use is also quite odd. Players can find them at the very start of the game and it just feels very crowding to be shown so many things you cannot do, so early in the game and with no explanation. Sometimes when the protagonist climbs up something and reaches the top they will vault up and ontop of it, but if the object is too narrow the protagonist will randomly vault too far and fall off. There is one level where players are expected to platform around for long periods, but at certain points the game freezes the player and shows them something changing in the map. Then it unfreezes the player and changes their camera to face that thing, so if the player is in the middle of something this will potentially screw them over and make them mess up the platforming. Which is extremely frustrating when there is an achievement for never failing the platforming in this level. The game has no autosave or manual save features for when players are just running around the open worlds, so if you spend any amount of time collecting everything in the open world maps; then your power goes out or the game crashes or anything, you lose all your progress. The only way to save to ensure this does not happen is to return to the hub, which makes the game autosave, but also wastes time and takes you away from wherever you were in the map. Certain dialogue in the game is not voice acted, even though almost all of it is. The Snatcher has the same dialogue for two different instances where you trigger his traps. The point based competition in one of the worlds is extremely biased against one of the sides. I put casual effort into one side, and repeated the levels until I got them almost flawlessly on the other side, yet the first side still won by a significant amount. The graphic for the grappling hook is not actually visible, the hook and umbrella do not appear it's just a chain that connects to things, and the trigger for status based hats is really over sensitive with the controller. You have to quickly flick in the trigger button to activate the hat, if you leave the trigger pushed in even for a fraction of a second it will turn off the hat effect when you release it again. Yet if you hold the trigger for an actual duration of time, then release it it will not cancel the hat effect. It exclusively only cancels it for no reason if you release the trigger soon after having pushed it initially; but not if you quickly flicked the trigger. 

It would also be nice if there were more uses for the basic and yarn currencies, as there are way more ways to get them then there are to spend. Which feels very unsatisfying in the late game if you accumulated a lot of them.

The single significant problem with the game is the Alpine Skyline. It is an open world platforming collectathon. There is no humor, no story, no creative design, no missions, it is just an open map with various platform intensive sections where players acquire the most important items needed from the world. None of the things that make this an amazing game are in the map, it is just padding basically. It is really boring and empty compared to the rest of the game, and only serves to highlight how far beyond other platformers this one is; because Alpine Skylines is basically a regular platformer that somehow snuck into this game.



A really wonderful platformer, certainly the best one I have played. Would wish there will be a sequel but it is hard to imagine this being topped by anything.

38523479.review:
One minute into this game and it had already captured my heart. A Hat in Time has filled the void that I had hoped Odyssey could and made me feel like a kid again. I went into this one with much skepticism seeing how it blatantly borrowed for existing platformers. The thing is it borrows all of the right features while still managing to be it's own thing. Right off the back the game's humor hit me with surprise body shot followed by an adorable right hook. Next I found myself wading through nostalgic juice with a restored sense of wonder. 

No review can express how worthy this game is of your time. Give it a try!

38517924.review:
I loved this game where more than I really thought I would, and I really believe it's because the game is so filled with it's own character and playful atmosphere you can't hate it. It's a game that I can relate to Super Mario Sunshine through experience, but I feels more like this is what playing Banjo and Kazooie back in the day would have felt like from how people talk about it.

Pros:
- The levels are fairly vast and fun to explore! This is where it feels like Sunshine because you have the ability to run and bounce around the levels fluidly, and there are rewards to being adventurous evrywhere you go. Each is also nothing like the last, and brings its own charm to the table every time.
-  The main character is absolutely adorable. 
- The game never feels tense or stressful. Some may argue this can be a negative/lack of challenge, but I found it allowed me to focus more on the art, jokes, characters, and game itself. It was so casual that I don't remember the last time I had this much fun just wandering around and finding all the little things the designers added in for those who looked to find.
- I've read some comments about the game being too short, and I think that's a load of crap. This game maintains the right amount of content to be short but sweet, and should give you a sense of your money's worth at the very least. 10 hours game time is more than reasonable for a $30 game if it takes you only 3 hours to make $30. 
- The game has a slot machine element that allows you to earn different looking hats for each power, different colour layouts for your outfit, and music remixes of the game's soundtrack. I thought this was a brilliant way to utilise it because getting a dinosaur hat has never been more rewarding and the customization feels just right. It's not overwhelming but it's incredibly noticable and fulfilling to experiment with.

Negatives:
- The combat isn't very well designed as in they just didn't focus on it as an integral part of the game, which I can agree it isn't. The boss fights play fine but the rest of the enemies are all the same really. You either do a basic swing attack, or jump and attack which auto glides you to them and that's pretty much it. 
- There's some false sense of rewards in this particularly designed for the completionist, or at least that's how it feels. You can collect yarn in hard to reach places, but it only takes one yarn of a type to create a new hat, and after that it serves no purpose at this point in time. It seems like it would have been used to craft new customizations for the hats or something but that was left out. They just serve as a number, no real point to them.

The game has a wide variety of levels, tons of stuff to collect, and secrets hidden left and right in the form of yarn, rifts, rift tokens, and my personal favorite part, a certain surprise in Dead Bird Studio after you finish the chapter. The entire time I was playing this game I was enjoying it, but the ending left me with this stupid goofy grin on my face. I totally recommend this game, and with 2 bonus chapters coming up, and multiplayer support, I'm excited to come back to it.

38408046.review:
Possibly the most refreshing 3D jump and run I've played for quite some time.. 

I jumped into this game with high expectations and I am somewhat satisfied. 
Tight controls, adorable grapics and good level design are the 3 things that speak for this game the most. 
It does a good job in introducing you into the game with Mafia World being a great tutorial, yet no technices really were introduced to you, yet it is easy to learn and you instantly get a grasp on the controlls, if you ever have played a Jump and Run before, no even if you ever played a third-person game you should be able to do just fine in A Hat in Time. 

Hat Kid and the rest of the environment are all "cute as heck" and it does a good job of making you fall in love with this adorableness. It also includes a well rounded humor, nothing far outstanding but it made me giggle on certain moments. 

I also mentioned level design. 
Every world feels unique and has its own little touch, I mostly liked world 2, since it had the most brilliant features. 
Although every level is well rounded and is always entertaining but some fall flat compared to others. 
You sometimes feel a bit bored and kinda get a feeling of being uninspired. 
Also you get confused what you have to do in some situations, since no mechanics get introduced that well. 
I found myself often standing infront of a hurdle I had to get over. Since I had no clue what to do directly I had to take a couple of seconds to understand what I was meant to do, either because I wasnt familiar with a new feature or because my camera wasnt focussing on it, nor was it obvious that I had to interact with the object placed in the room. 
That might sound not too troubling but in a Jump and Run it is important to keep up your flow all the time. 
This sort of game is the best if you can blaze through it, even if you dont know what you are doing. 


Another important point is polishing. 
This game defenitetly needs polishing! 
Cutscenes look really akward because characters only have one animation (I know this is due to budget, but such a well made game deserves to be beautiful). 
There is only one type of enemy/npc in each level and they have the same voice... It would be nice to have variety to make the worlds of this game really come to life. 

The story of this game could also have been better.. I really liked the premise going on of Hat Kid adventuring through the world making friends. But if you play the game you notice a certain formula happening. I dont want to spoil it but if you play the game you will notice what I mean. It is also sad that after you complete a world you dont get to interact with the previous characters youve met (not till after), which is sad because it could have been a wonderful story about friendship, but it rather feels like someone forgot about the characters during development after each world was finished. 


I think I might have said to much, and probably could have shortened it down, also I hope I did not scare you off with my criticism. It is a very special game and I had a blast playing through it and I plan to keep on playing it. 

8/10 - not enough hats

100% in less than 20 hours with a fairly casual play style but it hit all the points that Yooka-Laylee managed to miss.

This game is a collectathon metroidvania platformer like Banjo-Kazooie and Super Mario 64 that leaves a mark in the current generation of games. It's adorable and easy to pick up while offering something for completionists. It's no Odyssey but I enjoyed it nonetheless.

Pros:
- "Cute as heck"
- Easy enough to get into the controls
- Lots of optional challenges for people who enjoy platforming
- Great soundtrack
- A reason to collect all things. Timepieces get Hat Kid home and powerups make it easier. No macguffins here.
- Proper controller support. May not be configurable but at least it works out of the box

Cons:
- Cute to a fault. The characters don't have much development but to be fair, neither does Mario
- Some of the enemy patterns are downright annoying. Visually camoflauged cats that are invincible while hidden but attack you as soon as they become visible are not fun challenges.
- Midair homing attack is worse than Sonic's. Many times it doesn't even trigger.

Other thoughts:
- I was spoiled by Super Mario Odyssey. Cappy just makes things too easy and while the Hat Kid's dive technique is helpful, it's not "stop all momentum and change directions in midair" like Cappy. I found myself trying to Cap jump my way up many walls.
- The hookshot should have just been an umbrella upgrade instead of a badge. Once it's unlocked you pretty much keep it equipped.

38356441.review:
Charme e nostalgia são as palavras-chave para definir esse jogo. Quase que um sucessor espiritual de "Super Mario 64", porém com mecânicas atualizadas.

[h1]A História, Narrativa e Personagens:[/h1]

Não é uma história para se levar a sério, mas tudo começa quando você está indo pro seu planeta natal, um membro da máfia vem te cobrar dinheiro, você nega, ele quebra o vidro da sua nave com um soco e todo o seu combustível [time pieces] voam pelos ares para todos os lugares da galáxia.
O jogo é focado no humor e tem uma narrativa charmosa que te prende do começo ao fim, sempre apresentando novos personagens que apesar de alguns serem vilanescos, são cativantes, seja pelo humor, pelo visual, pelos bons diálogos ou por no final serem "fofos".

[h1]As mecânicas e a jogabilidade:[/h1]

Toda missão no jogo é diferente, sempre há algo novo a se fazer. O estilo de gênero plataforma clássico juntamente ao gênero de colectable [coletar itens] está mantido; você pode pular, dar pulo duplo e "mergulhar", alternando e fazendo uma série de combos, p. ex, ao mergulhar você pode cancelar o mergulho para dar outro pulo. Você usa um guarda-chuva para bater nos inimigos ou seu próprio mergulho ou um dos chapéus que possui habilidade de atirar gosmas mágicas explosivas.

Falando nos chapéus, há um número pequeno, porém rico em mecânicas, há um chapéu que você ganha a habilidade de correr, outro que lhe permite manipular o tempo, outro que permite atacar inimigos e por aí vai. Cada chapéu possui suas mecânicas próprias e você os desbloqueia ao coletar novelos de lã.  Também há as badges que você vai comprando com a moeda local do jogo [ao juntar um número suficiente para tal]. Badges como um imã para coletar mais dinheiro ao redor, impedir de você tomar dano ao cair de uma altura grande fazendo seu guarda-chuva virar um 'pára-quedas', badge para reduzir o cooldown do tempo de uso dos chapéus [fazendo um cooldown quase que instantâneo], badge de gancho, pendurando-se e balançando-se por aí, e por aí vai.


É um jogo riquíssimo em mecânicas que conserva o antigo e inova, não dando somente nostalgia, mas criando sua própria personalidade.

O level design também é excelente, como dito anteriormente, cada fase é uma aventura nova, há uma fase que você investiga um assassinato, em outra você está correndo contra o tempo para impedir de um trem se destruir, em outra você tem a liberdade de ir para onde quiser e fazer o que quiser, em outra você é um monstro de lama que tem que assustar a máfia, enfim, é notável o trabalho de equipe em proporcionar diversão constante de forma engenhosa para você coletar os time pieces.

Além disto, há as fases bônus, os "time rifts" que são desafiadores e estão lá para deixar claro a seguinte mensagem: Este jogo também é um colectable, faça o seu trabalho e complete tudo!

[h1]Os aspectos técnicos: O Gráfico, a câmera, a movimentação e a física:[/h1]

Visualmente o jogo é lindo, com seu charme único num visual 3D, e com uma câmera fluida e dinâmica que esconde o que está mais próximo da hat kid, fazendo com que a câmera não seja sua inimiga, senão sua aliada. E funciona na maior parte das vezes. A direção de arte do jogo é sensacional, há uma riqueza em detalhes, em especial em "Mafia Town", onde você vê personagens fazendo tarefas mundanas como observando a paisagem, dormindo em um local escondido para afugentar-se do trabalho, trabalhando, extorquindo alguém, entre outros; a hat kid também possui detalhes, como na missão que ela faz pose de investigadora, a forma que ela se expressa ao passar perto da máfia,  a pose de medo que ela faz numa missão de um mundo dark, entre outras, apesar de que em certas fases há uma certa confusão visual e cores exageradamente saturadas que cansam a vista em certos momentos. 

A movimentação é ótima, em especial da hat kid, que conforme já mencionado, possui vários detalhes ao redor de cada fase. A física do jogo é surreal, mas também não está lá para ser levada a sério, mas sim como um recurso de mecânica de jogo, deixando o jogo mais dinâmico e às vezes como recurso narrativo, dando um tom mais cômico.

[h1]A trilha sonora:[/h1]

A trilha sonora merece destaque, por dar uma alma ao jogo, sendo cativante e viciante em algumas faixas, dando o tom de cada fase, seja para empolgar, criar suspense, animar ou até mesmo amedrontar o jogador. Os efeitos sonoros também são muito bem feitos e bem encaixados, tendo uma ótima mixagem e edição de som.


[h1]Conclusão e nota:[/h1]

A Hat in Time é um dos MELHORES jogos de 2017 e digo mais: Um dos melhores jogos de plataforma já feito em todos os tempos, com seu visual cativante e personagens charmosos, uma trilha sonora digna de aplausos e um majestoso level design. A Hat in time é o que um jogo de aventura-plataforma 3D deveria ser: Extremamente divertido.

Nota: 9,5/10

[h1]Para mais análises, apoie-nos seguindo nosso [url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/30823884/]Curador[/url]

38320911.review:
Hat in Time is as close to a 3D Mario Platformer clone I've seen yet.

While the game has collect-a-thon elements, it shines in how Hat-Kid controls. 

The tricks and strategies you can learn to improve your overall movement strikes a strong resemblance in a lot of the 'king of platformers' such as Mario and Banjo. This is important because even after the credits roll there are things to learn how to control Hat-Kid more efficiently/quickly through levels. The game offers a decent challenge in terms of platforming. It welcomes newcomers, while offers an extra layer of challenge for those who want it. Supposedly NewGame+ will be a part of the free DLC coming to this game. There is also Steam-Workshop for community made levels/

The games story is charming, and the voice-acting is on point.

The replayability is there, but is up the the player. There is a 100% incentive, but is more a self-accomplishment type of reward. I found myself going back because of how enjoyable a lot of the platforming levels tend to be.

9/10, if you're looking for a satisfying platformer itch look no further.

38319120.review:
GET THIS GAME! It feels redundant to have to type out a review when all I'm going to say is a bunch of ways to say "GET THIS GAME!", but if you want details... well:

This is a classic 3D platformer with clear influences from Mario and Banjo Kazooie. You've got bright, colourful worlds with unique and varied designs, even within the same hub; there is an interesting and fun cast of quirky chararacters that all serve well to keep things interesting; and most importantly, Solid gameplay that is fun. That last one is important, at no point did I feel like the game was lazily padding out the runtime for the sake of being called a long game. What's here is focused and beautifully crafted.

The controls are smooth and tight with the possible exception of the camera. While it is customizable in the options menu(surprizingly more so than most other games), it does have a few hiccups, mostly when trying to figure out what terrain is going to zoom my camera in or take control away from me. 

The way A Hat in Time presents its world is worth mentioning as it really does add to the experience. No area is similar in terms of structure. The level design of the first world is drasically different from any following local and the same goes for the rest. They each have their own self contain narrative that ties each mission in. 

So.. yeah.... GET THIS GAME!

38296313.review:
Really enjoyed this game—I knew nothing about it until a friend told me about it a couple months ago, and shrugged it off at the time. He was insistent and got me the game for my birthday, and man...am I glad he did. As Super Mario Sunshine is, was, and remains my favorite 3D platformer of all time, this game hearkens back to it, and various other late 90s-mid 2000s 3d platformers, perfectly.

The game is beautiful, the soundtrack is wonderful and charming, there's lots of cool little rewards to get (as an incentive for careful exploring), the voice acting is enjoyable to listen to (rare in this genre), and the movement (about 95% of the time) feels natural and responsive. There's enough content in here for a super slowpoke completionist like me to get 20 hours out of the game, so if you're not willing to spend $30 for that amount of playtime, steer clear. That's the only reason I'd advise caution in this release; however, the Steam Workshop is in full effect, and allowed me to experience some surprisingly amazing user-created content on top of the "official" game.

I highly recommend this game if you're into 3D platformers at all, or need a good nostalgia trip from the days of your youth (if you were born in the early-mid 90s at least). With more official content inevitably on the way, even if you're done with the game quickly you probably will still feel like you got your money's worth, due to the amount of heart and character in the game. I can't say for SURE considering I got the game for free, but still, I would have spend the money without a second thought if I knew the game was this enjoyable. And you should too! Support these awesome indie devs!

38293374.review: Cuando era un niño siempre fui un gran fan de los plataformers: Banjo & Kazooie, Super Mario, Conker's Bad Fur Day, Gex, Jack & Daxter, etc. A Hat in Time es un juego que de verdad me hizo sentir muy bien y feliz, el solo volver a jugar un juego igual a los que jugaba en mi infancia me emociono. Es un juego muy bien diseñado, no te encontrarás en mapas enormes y vacíos ya que está bien distribuido el contenido en ellos y habrán muchos coleccionables; la composición musical de este juego es maravillosa y de verdad que encaja con el ambiente; el arte caricaturezco del juego hace que este a la par de los clásicos, son diseños simples pero muy llamativos; las mecánicas del juego son un matrimonio de las de Banjo & Kazooie y Super Mario Sunshine, hubo muchos momentos de nostalgia, el juego en si se siente bien; la historia tiene mucho humor y elementos absurdos, pero tiene mucho sentimiento y buena narrativa. Que más puedo decir? este juego se ganó un gran espacio en mi corazón y lo consideró mi juego favorito del 2017. Lo único que me pone triste es que sea tan corto.

38268618.review:
Overall grade: A+^∞

I probably can't convey my love for this little game well enough in this review, but I'll do my best. This review may come off as just another positive review on the already staggering pile of them, but it's important to realize that behind every positive review is a player just like yourself, and a unique experience gotten from playing hours upon hours. 

This game has been in development since 2013, and it shows, believe me, it shows. This is obviously a project of pure passion by the entire team over at Gears for Breakfast; you couldn't get a game of this calibre otherwise. The internet personality JellyElite said it best when he said 'I've never seen a game with so much life and love tucked into every corner.'

Controls like an aboslute dream, couldn't have asked for much more when it comes to the controls and the functions of the character. And the camera was about to be my ONLY complaint about the game, but then I realized that they added an option to change the camera to however you like it! So, there goes my only complaint about the game. 

The team over at Gears for Breakfast are ALL about community. They LOVE mods, they encourage it, and they love showing off the best and the funniest of them. Probably one of the most active Twitter profiles for a game that I've ever seen, and a very lively and friendly development team. A Hat in Time is exactly what it advertises and more, being a 'cute as heck 3D platformer' inspired by original classics of the genre doesn't even begin to describe how awesome this game is. Shattered any expectations I had of it.

Should you get it?: Absolutely. This is my personal Game of the Year, no doubt. I'm already way excited about the updates to come to this game, and if you get the game, I hope you will be too.

38259254.review:
Recommended for anyone wanting a 3D platformer.  The adorable look though can be decieving of the slighty aggressive nature of the game for little ones (and Vanessa's house could be nightmare fuel).

As a fan of platformers and without many to choose from on PC, this was a blast!  There is a lot of variety in collecting stuff, after 10 hours I felt like I mastered the little nuances of when to jump, double jump, double jump dash, and double jump dash jump.  

Levels are neatly packed together feeling full of life, and each time piece has its own little story, so it does not feel like collectibles were dumped in as a filler or time waster: each time piece feels rewarding.

Its fairly short, somewhat easy for a 101% Psychonauts and 120star Mario64 player, but just as fun to replay to see how much faster you can finish things.

I would play with two Steam controllers, one for me, and one for my 4 year old when she wants to do an easy jump or run across something.  Its all charming, but maybe I could do with 1 or 2 less mentions of murder and dying, haha.

38249068.review:
A Little Game That Could (Quote taken from a friend)

A Hat in Time is a very beautiful platformer that places you in the control of Hat Kid (or Hat Girl if you prefer), and the story starts merely because one of the enemy types called The Mafia want payment from Hat Kid while floating in their air space.  After some silly shenanagins you are thrusted onto the world to recover your lost Time Pieces that was sucked out ship.  

I won't go too far into the story as it is very simple, but for what story is there it is told very well.  You gain a different hat power up through out each world you visit, changing up the ways you can play the game.  The game also requires you to switch hats during certain situations in order to progress.

Hat Power:
KId's Hat:  Your starting Top Hat.  
Power of Hat: Points you in the direction of your objective, other than that not much else.

Sprint Hat: Increases movement speed and even when combined with the Scooter Badge your movement speed is increased even more.

Brewing Hat: Allows you to throw explosives to blow up crates.

Ice Hat: Gives you the ability to ground pound and with certain platforms, be bounced to to new areas or cuts travel time depending on the Ice Platform.

Dweller's Mask: Helps you jump on platforms that are intagnible. 

Time Stop Hat: While it doesn't necessarily stop time completely, this is probably the most powerful hat in the game as it slows down time so you can catch your breath or catch an enemy off guard easier.  This hat also works on boss fights.

There are also badges you equip to increase your abilities.  Some are useful, some are not so useful, and one allows you to fire a laser from your umbrella, which is a pretty dang cool thing in my book.

There are time rifts you have to dive into later on when you find relics hidden throughout the levels.  The style of the time rifts are very reminicent of Super Mario Sunshine, and this is in no way a bad thing since I actually liked the side areas in Mario Sunshine.  There are also one unique time rift connected to each world where you go through a small bit of the past of those areas and collect pictures, which you are then rewarded of why the world you are at is the way it is.

The only two negative I can say about this game is that the Ice Hat doesn't get much use and other than the ground pound, there is no other practical use for it outside of the ice panels.  It would have been interesting if it wiped away fires nearby but it's not total let down.  The only hat that I think is impractical when you find out how to move fast anyway IS the Sprint Hat.  Even with the badge extension I found myself hardly ever using the Sprint Hat, but it's a good first hat to introduce you to the hat mechanics later on.  

The only glitch I come acrossed was at the very beginning when you play Patty Cake with one of the Mafia and he hits you after you were done.  I couldn't jump and was hovering in the air for some reason going down a hill.  A restart fixed it and the bug did not happen since the start.

The pros definitely outweigh any minor con I could give it.  This game was made with so much love and understanding from people who love platformers.  Gears for Breakfast are going places.  A very simple but great story and amazing gameplay with amazing visuals that made me wanting more.  I don't know if there would be A Hat in Time 2 or not, but it's something I would love to see happen.  This game is worth every single dime and I highly recommend it!

38192655.review:
Probably the best 3D platformer on PC so far.

What makes a platformer good? The answer is: controls. And Hat Kid controls are responsive and allow the player to do a lot of things, while keeping it simple. Casual players won't have any problems with getting used to them, while more advanced players have tools to pull off some insane shortcuts and stunts.

The sound design is great. Music fits the locations, voices fit the characters and the voice-acting itself is well done.

2D art, special effects and world design is on point, everything is distinct, colorful and pretty. The only thing artstyle-wise I disagree with is how character faces have been implemented (2D texture for eyes and mouth), but eh, I can get used to it.

A Hat in Time is not a very long game, though there's 2 more worlds coming as a free DLC in the future. Also, it supports modding, so the community can provide some new content for the time being.

I absolutely love this game. It's a love-letter to the classics, which captures their charm, while improving upon them in every way.

38191914.review: I waited at least 3 years to get this game. I preordered it to play the demo and I thought the game was good then, but this is the best way to play the game. I put in almost a full day of play time over one week because of how well the game held onto my attention. Just as I was starting to get tired with one world I got pulled into a new one. The characters are great and the game is full of personality. The controlls are great and the platforming was never disappointing. There are still some problems with the game. To start it feels short but that is mostly because I binged the game as soon as it came out. FPS was  definetly an issue from time to time. I feel like I have a strong computer but even then in high poly areas slow down was common, but nothing game breaking. The graphics are a two way road. To me, they were charming and they matched the feel of the game, to others, they won't be up to snuff to what they're used to. I understand both sides but its a matter of opinion. The ending feels abrupt and kinda out of place. You can play the final boss before you have even played all of the worlds. On the topic of bosses though, this game has amazing bosses. I won't describe any of them other than that they are a delightful challenge. To anyone that likes platformers, this game is worth it. [h1]БОЖЕ 12 ИЗ 10 ИГРА ГОДА !!![/h1]

Да, я не преувеличиваю, это действительно просто потрясающая и очень милая игра, про маленькую девочку, которая летит домой на энергии песочных часов на космическом корабле из досок ))).
Я лично вообще не люблю подобные игры, но эта затянула меня просто буквально с первых 15 минут геймплея. Это просто бесконечная милота ! Оригинальные персонажи, незамысловатые уровни, всё красочно, красиво и хорошо оптимизировано.

По сюжету вы (вроде как) столкнулись с какой-то планетой и всё ваше "топливо" вывалилось в космос и упало на близ лежащие планеты. Ваша задача собрать их все и вернуться домой.

Весь геймплей игры основан на том, что вы находите клубки и получаете различные шапки. Каждая из которых даёт вам способности. При помощи этих шапок, вы проходите различные локации и дерётесь с боссами.

- Первая шапка, в который вы стартуете с начала умеет просто искать путь, куда вам идти.
- Вторая шапка - шапка ведьмочки, вы можете так скажем кастовать колбочку и кидатся ею во врагов.
- Третья шапка - позволяет вам бегать намного быстрее чем обычно, а так-же если найти значок, то можно будет кататься на скутере.
- Четвёртая шапка - шапка заморозки. Вы можете превратиться в ледяную статую и вас никто не может продамажить, а так-же по непонятным причинам вы можете совершать прыжки со специальных панелей на другие.
- Пятая шапка - шапка (жителя ?), короче говоря на уровнях бывают какие-то магические объекты, которые могут стать материальными только если активировать эту шапку.
- Шестая и последняя шапка - замедление времени. Сверх полезная шапка, для войны с боссами.

Из плюсов... вся эта игра огромный плюс, не пожалейте денег и купите эту игру, рекомендую всем без исключения.

Из минусов: пожалуй деревянная мимика персонажей, на лицах есть просто полигон, на котором меняются несколько текстур с разными эмоциями и ртами. Так-же отсутствует русская локализация, но уже есть не плохой русификатор на просторах ZoG форума. (возможно не работают некоторые достижения, но это не точно)

Отдельный мега жирный плюсик за OST, это 77 (?) потрясающих трэков и ремиксов на них, так-же в игре присутствует ещё несколько трэков, которые я не нашёл в OST. В общей сложности OST игры можно слушать примерно 5 часов.

38159909.review:
A marvelous achievement for Indie Gaming.

I don't know if I have the words to describe how much I'm in love with this game.
The level design is great, the characters are lovable, the graphics look great, the music is absolutely perfect, and the gameplay is superb. The controls never felt out of place or off, and overall the controls are really smooth, combining many different control elements from different games into a perfect control scheme. Every area of the game feels important, and there's very little empty space in each level which helps players not feel overwhelmed by each new level.
The story is simple, yet enjoyable. The acting is perfect, and the JonTron cameo brought a huge smile to my face.
In fact, this entire game brought a huge smile to my face. The adorable and creative character designs, the fun platforming elements... This is truly a fantastic experience whether you grew up playing classic platforming games or not. 
The finale of this game is perfect, and combines everything I loved about the game into one level.

This game is amazing. It blew away all my expectations and brought me happiness all 15+ hours it took me to complete the main story. I would highly recommend this game to any gamer I know. Gears for Breakfast, thank you for creating the best indie game I have ever played.

EDIT:
30+ hours and I've completed the game with 40 Time Pieces and all achievements unlocked, and I have to say it was definitely worth the time and effort to complete this one. This is the most fun I've had in a game in years. It was a joy to complete.

38147097.review:
I found myself with an itch for 3d platforming after playing the new Mario game for awhile (a family member's copy).  So I picked this game up to scratch the itch, and whlie it's not as polished as Odyssey, it's still a heckuva fun game with cute character designs, good level design, and fairly tight control.  I also have to give special props to the voice actors the game company hired for this game   Well done, ladies & gents! The boss fights I'd actually rate above the fights in Odyssey both in presentation and in gameplay.

I have some minor gripes about camera control in certain areas, and certain collectibles that feel like they're in a glitchy area you weren't supposed to be able to get to intstead of something that feels like a secret area more natural to the landscape.  But there's only a handful of such instances.

I have heard some other reviews criticizing the game for its length, but I got about 10-15 hours out of it myself in a single playthrough (and that's with getting the achievements but not exhaustively all the extras).  That seems about right for a game like this to me.  I would love to play more levels, but I think it's generally a plus to leave a game wanting more where it came from.

On the topic of difficulty, I think I should point out getting some of the achievements are more tedious than difficult.  The majority of the game is pretty easy though, even the bossfights.  It's about on par with a lot of nintendo games aimed at being challenging enough to be fun, but not so difficult as to be aggravating or frustating.  It's usually more about figuring out which abilities to use when and where, rather than pulling off tightly timed jumps in sequence.  Which is all to say I think the game is generally well balanced, but could probably use some more challenging achievements (like a different achievement for each boss beaten while wearing the one-hit death badge, and/or achievements for not using hat powers  on bosses.

38143339.review: From the beginning I thought it looked interesting. When I finally bought it I kept thinking, "What if this game is overhyped and is mediocre at best?" Those doubts were blown away the moment I got to mafia town. This game is a gem amongst so many of the generic/overhyped games out there. I was hooked on the platforming. It was fair, and forgiving even if you messed up a bit. Another thing that made the platforming so satisfying was the amount of control you had over your character. I can't even count how many times I was able to save myself from plummeting off. I loved every stage in the game. Granted I liked some better than others. I feel they all were well designed. My favorites being Subcon Forest, and Battle of the Birds for interesting level design and characters. Mafia town was a starter area done right. It was fun adventuring around and I loved the mafia characters. The fourth/final zone looked great, and I enjoyed the platforming, but it lacked the story and the interesting characters that the other 3 zones had. The story isn't deep or heavy, and you know what? That's what made it stand out to me. I loved the comedy and overall light heartedness of the story. I truly would give this game a 10/10. Gears for Breakfast let me just say this, "Thank you for making this beautiful gem. You did an excellent job!"

A Hat In Time is a perfect example of why I enjoy playing video games. It's fun and enjoyable, has a great cast of characters, has jokes and references, has a wonderful soundtrack, supports speed running, workshop mods, and has collectables out the wazoo! This game was designed around what made games like Banjo, Mario, Gex, Spyro, and many others so enjoyable to play and what makes us feel nostalgic about such titles. While it isn't like Yooka Laylee, literally a spiritual successor to Banjo Kazooie, this game is one of, if not THE best platformer/collectathon games on Steam right now and I would recommend it to anyone looking to add to their collection. 

Side note: This game is still being worked on, and as such modding is not fully supported. It has to be enabled, and I have encountered bugs with mods, so download them at your own risk. This does NOT make the game any less worth every penny, but I believe it should be mentioned.

38095219.review:
What a charm. It's refreshing to play a great 3D platformer other than another Mario game, though it is quite reminiscent of them. The controls are solid and work well with the environment. The graphics are beautiful, with many technical options in the menu. There are also many camera settings for adjusting how far and how much the camera tracks you. Characters are amusing and jokes are great. Attention to detail is spot on; there is so much content packed into the nooks and crannies of the game's various worlds.

     The platforming is tight and fair, and there is a lot of it. Cliffs and edges seem to flow organically with the world, yet jumping points from location to location are distanced just right. The player character receives different upgrades that augment platforming or attacking, all of which work well with the environment.

     Something I spent a lot of time on is the ability to freeze time and control the camera to take high-resolution pictures, complete with an on-the-fly depth-of-field slider. This is a neat feature that allows for a plethora of beautiful stills of the game to be made.

     This game took what was great about 3D platformers before it and added some of its own charm with its unique characters, innovative platforming, and attention to detail. I highly recommend picking this up.

38093613.review:

38092843.review:
Sometimes a game comes along and defies all expectations. A Hat in Time did that for me. I initially thought nothing of this game as nothing more than another "me too!" kickstarter game designed to exploit fans of dead genres, in this case the 3D platformer. My cynicism was enhanced by the imminent arrival of Super Mario Odyssey, a game that looked to be shinier, bigger and overall better than this little indie game. However, a friend said the right words and I reluctantly found myself clicking the purchase button, ready to play a few hours and leave it by the wayside.

I got 100% in A Hat in Time long before Odyssey even arrived.

A Hat in Time took my cynicism and replaced it with punching mafia and solving murder mysteries on a western train. It only asks one thing of you: to dive into its world like Hat Girl does into her ballpit, without any reservations And what a world it is. The first world alone involves you fighting cookery themed mafa with hilarious accents on a delfino-styled island town of impressive heights. From there it just gets crazier in the best way possible, as each world offers a unique scenario and overall tone. You'll find yourself leading a marching band on city rooftops in one level while collecting evidence for a thrilling and noir-drenched whodunit murder mystery in the next. Did I mention those two levels are in the same world? "Mafia doesn't care about consistency, mafia cares about fun!"- actual quote from the game. All of this is held together by genuinely good writing (unlike my unfortunte example). Every scenario is presented with a wink and smile and even the satire is generally treated with some wit and tact and not just blatant MANDATORY COLLECTIBLES AMIRITE LOL crap. The quirky nature of the game never feels forced, it manages to make all these disparate elements consistent. It even pulls off some genuinely touching moments, including an ending that was both surprising and touching. Think less Yooka Laylee, and more Psychonauts. 

Of course, a world can only be as interesting as the people that inhabit it and ohmygod ohmygod you guys I love these people, starting with Hat Girl. Simply put, she's equal parts adorable and badass. She expresses a child-like wonder in her interactions with the world and pluckiness thats also countered by hilarious sarcasm and cynicism (seriously, read her diary entries after completing each level). Yet at the same time she's an intergalactic time traveller who aint afraid to do what should be done to return home. She's the perfect representative of the game: whimsical, quirky and just plain bizarre. The supporting cast equally holds up well and receive the same level of effort and care in how they are characterised, my favorite character being the Devil himself. He steals every scene he is in and you can tell that the voice actor had way too much fun playing this maniacal devil may care figure. It says something that I genuinely came to care for a cast of characters that included: an opportunistic foul mouthed movie director, a terrible mafia cook and the Devil himself.

That's all good and great, but how are the mechanics? How does it play? To answer both, good. First of all, Hat Girl controls really well. Befitting her small stature, she is quick to the chase with a generous movement speed. She also has a sunshine-styled dive which when combined with a generous double jump can get you to a lot of places. She's a bit floaty compared to Mario, but she still gets the job done. In terms of general structure, its simple. Collect 40 timepieces across 4 worlds, in each world you can collect yarn pieces which are used to make the titular hats, pons (basically coins) to buy badges that change gameplay and relics which unlock bonus levels when assembled. The number of things to collect is remarkably restrained and it never feels like you're being buried under tons of useless busywork. Everything has a purpose and feeds into each other.

The mission structure matches the diversity and variety of the games tone and story beats. The first world is your typical sandbox, but everything after that deviates from typical 3D platformer structure. The second world is essentially a collection of linear but incredibly varied props set on movie stages while the Third world, Subcon Forest, starts off small but sections are opened up when you complete certain tasks. It's probably my favorite world in terms of sheer exploration. Whats great about these stages is that they're just as fun to play as they are to read. The murder mystery mission for example. It may sound like a mission that is fun to experience the first time around but a drag on later playthroughs because of its emphasis on answering questions and solving a murder but its actually a really fun stealth mission where you avoid agents and even collect key cards to unlock new parts of the train mgs style. The mechanics work perfectly in tandem with the story beats. There are no "talking section", both gameplay and story go hand in hand with each other. It's pure gaming flow.

There are also the titular hats to take into account. Compared to Odyssey's groundbreaking use of hats to fundamentally change Mario's moveset and interaction with the environment, A Hat in Time falls short. Saying that, they are still remarkably useful with special mentions going to the speedster hat which makes a quick character quick...er. One hat in particular, I wrote off as gimmicky and useless only to be surprised when the game utilised it in one of the best levels of the game (think of the lens of truth from ocarina of time but much more fluid). Switching between them is almost instantenuous and the level design encourages their use. They're also really cute.

There is a lot more I wanted to talk about, like the amazing hubship (corgi simulator needs to be a real game), the boss battles which every other 3D platformer needs to take notes from and the timewarp missions which are out there psychonaut style. But I'm kinda tired so I'll wrap this up. A Hat in Time is a fantastic 3D platformer. It's constantly creative in its writing and design. Sure its a bit too short and easy, the fifth "world" was nothing more than a bossfight. But what's there is good. Is it as good as Super Mario Odyssey? I dunno about that, but what I do know is that this game is cute as heck. And thats enough for me.

38091784.review:
Pros:

+Fun, PMTTYD-esque writing. Delightfully irreverent at times, charged with emotion at others.
+Incredible movement. Platforming is engaging and precise.
+Powerups, while niche in their uses, inject the platforming with even more variety.
+Super memorable characters. I won't go into detail here.
+Well crafted, open levels are fun to race through and explore.
+Each world tells its own self contained story, which is more than enough to keep you engaged.
+Music is fantastic, my head was bobbing along to every tune, and I even found myself listening to it while doing work.
+Queen Vanessa is like if you combined FNAF with the piano from SM64. Nuff said.

~Optimization. While running great under most circumstances, this would benefit from more effective and more drastic LODs, especially on larger worlds. Most levels run great, though I admit I'm pushing the hardware. Most folks shouldn't have an issue at 1080p or 1440p.
(I ran the game at 4K on a setup with a 4790K and a 980ti, ran at 60fps pretty consistantly) 

-Overarching plot is somewhat thin, though the individual worlds' stories make up for this.
-Sound design. Some effects are quite a bit louder than the rest of the soundscape, making volume management occasionally annoying. Mustache Girl occasionally sounds like she's right next to the mic compared with everyone else.
-Not gonna lie, some levels look a tad like Gmod. However, I'm speaking strictly about texture work. If some stuff was a little more high resolution or slightly higher levels of detail available, this would be fine.
-Call it a complaint, but I want more! Despite the game being short, it was worth every penny. I'd throw money at my monitor any day for DLC, a full expansion, or (dare I hope) a sequel.

Overall:
Despite my nags, this game is an A+ home run. I'd argue it's on par with any of the greats of 3D platforming; whether that be Spyro, the genesis Sonics, Crash Bandicoot or even Mario 64. Thank you Gears for Breakfast. This game is an absolute gem, and I'd shake every one of your hands for it.

38075897.review:
I've been waiting to finish the game so that I can write a review and say this one thing:

THIS GAME IS NOT CUTE SOMETIMES!! IT CAN BE PRETTY CREEPY AND UNNERVING!! TOT

Phew, got that off my chest! For real, I went into this game blind expecting a "cute-as-heck" 3D platformer inspired by the likes of Super Mario Sunshine, and that's *kinda* what I got, except after the first world there's just SO MUCH CREEPY AND UNFRIENDLINESS GOD.

CUTENESS: Okay, Hat Girl's design is very cute, and knowing that, the game rewards you with cosmetics to dress her up. The first world, Mafia town, is the cutest and brightest level of the game, and at first the game's format will remind you of SMS (each level zooms to the area of interest, you explore a large world and return to it to collect the main objects except with different tasks, bright blue water, etc. The Blue time rifts are also clearly inspired by SMS's "Secret of ..." levels.) The characters at first seem silly and friendly, like when you first meet Mustache Girl and the harmless mafia. 

DARKNESS: But as you progress to Dead Bird Studio and Subcon Forest, you realize the light colorful cuteness was all just an ACT!! O_O In just the second world, the game throws stealth mechanics at you, dims the lighting, and changes the music to either minor key, ambience, downbeat introspectiveness, or suspense. (As someone who believes in the power of game BGM soundtracks to affect the overall feel of the game, I recommend just listening to most of the tracks online to get a feel for the atmosphere of this game.) Seriously, many of the game's levels are dark and gloomy, including the purple time rift bonus levels, which also throw in an abstract uneasiness. Many of the game's characters turn out to be antagonistic, unfriendly, or straight up rude, and the humor darkens as well. Subcon Forest for example, is darkly foggy and features a talking noose, fire spirits celebrating death, and the selling of your own soul. (Chapter 4 in particular, with Queen Vanessa, is probably the scariest thing I've ever played in a "cute" game). The game's worlds just don't feel human; there's almost no consistency to the reality of each setting, and it's as though there's nothing to rely on but yourself.

So, that's my main actual criticism of the game. I bought A Hat in Time expecting a cute colorful platformer just filled with comfy moments, and the actual game turned out to have fairly little in the way of "comf".

GAMEPLAY-wise though, this game deserves a lot of credit. This very much feels like a game designed with classic 3D platforming in mind, as all the platform placements and mechanics seem to mesh very well together. The dive, wall-run, wall-climb, mid-air mobility, and double jump options all make it feel great to just jump around. The different-powered hats are also each very useful, and there are two very quick options to switch between them without going through a menu, so hats are more fun than annoying to use - the collectible placements also really take advantage of the hat powerups well, as does the entirety of the Alpine Skyline world. The Sprint Hat in particular, especially with the scooter badge, is a great way to add speed and mobility to the game. And knowing the history of A Hat in Time, you have to really hand it to the devs for creating a game with not just smooth mechanics, but HUGE worlds.

POLISH: There are times where the game's camera will follow very closely to you, and there are also certain slippery slopes you can get stuck on, and those moments can get annoying. There's often way too many collectibles than there are uses for, which sucks because this is a collectathon type of game (yarn and pons run out of uses after getting every hat powerup and badge). Otherwise, the game is overall well-polished.

OVERALL the game is a fun 3D collectathon platformer on its gameplay merits, and I enjoyed it, and I would recommend it! However, I can NOT recommend this game if you are looking for a cute, cuddly, comfy sort of experience- the game's aesthetic is just too unnerving, unhuman, unfriendly, and creepy at times for that. (To be fair though, there are elements of cute humor throughout the game, and the game's ending is shows the friendly side of each character.) If you can look past the surprisingly dark and unsettling aesthetic of most of A Hat in Time, I would recommend it just for its gameplay, but I really do wish the game was as light and cute as it seems to be at first.

38065243.review:
Just play it. Seriously.
Would recommend to every fan of 3D platformers.

A Hat In Time is an excellent collect-a-thon and is probably the best 3D platformer released on PC.
The controls even on keyboard are tight, responsive, Hat Kid has a few moves in her disposal (double jump, dive, walljump), different hats and a hook that you in the middle of the game.

This game looks really, really good - it's powered by a heavily modified version of Unreal 3 and it works well. AHiT has some technical issues, but most of them are fixed + they do not impact the experience in any major way - sometimes you'll get stuck in a weird place (temporarily, and if anything weird happens the game will respawn you a few meters away) for some reason, but that's everything I have encountered.

I love the music in this game. It's absolutely incredible. Composed by Pascal Michael Stiefel with many guests like Grant Kirkhope [strike](AND MOST IMPORTANTLY, GABE THE DOG)[/strike], it always suits the game really well, and some of the tracks will become part of my usual playlist (like "Your Contract Has Expired").

In conclusion, buy A Hat In Time
also, it's pretty short, 15h will be enough to 100% it (2 free worlds are coming though, + there is workshop support = lots of fan content)

38064127.review:
i got 12 hours out of it for my first playthrough, in which i got all of the rift tokens and time pieces in the game.

the two most important things to say about hat in time is that it controls incredibly well, and it has its own cute as heck identity. it doesn't just mindlessly try to clone games that it took inspiration from - it genuinely feels like a different game that is worth playing, rather than just a rehash of something you've already played before.

my biggest issue with the game is that there just wasn't as much as i would've liked. with 4.5 worlds and 40 time pieces - with only 25 necessary to complete the game - it definitely feels like it stops before it should. this issue will, of course, be remedied in the future, as a free update containing two additional worlds was confirmed on release. modding support is also definitely a plus, as there are already a ton of really great community-created levels artificially extending the game's lifespan. aside from this, my only real gripe is that it feels a bit rough around the edges at times.

38017684.review:
What can I tell you about a Hat in Time?
It holds an essence that almost no other game strives to achieve nowadays. 
From the very beginning, you're set in a huge, colorful and vivid world. As you begin to test your moves and buttons, you rapidly acknowledge the great responsiveness the controls have, and thus you understand from that very moment you set afoot above the first house, and gaze the impressive shore that's before you, you're into a good adventure.

A fresh plot.
Simple, with enough plot twists and turns to keep you wondering.
Clever humour, truck loaded with pop culture, intelligent refferences (I loved Jonbar's and the others on that same map)
A great tribute to the long gone days of thrilling platforming.
Really crisp and exciting boss battles, added with a phenomenal soundtrack.
With its cuteness overload, without being excessive, the challenging platform puzzles, and that endearing nostalgia you get from those games that inspired this jewel, this is, by far, my "Personal game of the year 2017" of everything I've played.

No one can deny the goosebumps and warmheart feeling you get when entering nearby a new Telescope(Area) and the subtle background music change, ala Banjo-Kazooie.

I have nothing left to say.
Its flaws are so minimal and trivial, they are easily overshadowed by all the immense good this game holds.

9.6/10 
Yours Truly.

38017351.review:
I absolutely loved this game. They attempted to make a old-fashioned collect-athon, and in every aspect they succeeded. It's cute, funny, and entertaining throughout almost the entire game. But I have to say, I wouldn't recommend this game to almost anyone. It's overpriced for the amount of content in the game. I 100% completed this game and got every single achievement in 11 hours. It has no replayability unless you're a speedrunner. If you do plan on speedrunning this game, I'd very highly recommend it. There's a ton of fun movement tech in the game and tons of interesting routes to take through each level. If you're not a speedrunner, don't buy this game at the current price of $30. I like to evaluate a games value using a pretty arbitrary equation: enjoyment * time played / price. Enjoyment can override a fairly large disparity in time / price, but there's no game I've ever played that would make up for a 1/3 disparity.

TL;DR Really great collect-athon that feels like a classic, but vastly overpriced for the amount of content in the game.

38000416.review:
The worlds are AWESOME, the mobility of hat girl is AWESOME, the stories of each world are AWESOME, the bosses are AWESOME, the music is AWESOME, the boss music is EARGASM at times and the artstyle is perfect for a collect-a-thon. Does it do better than Super Mario Odyssey? Certainly not. But it comes close. For the price, it's a must buy for any fan of plattformers like the 3D-Marios. 

It may be a bit short, but for me it was rather a pro than a con, as it kept things fresh, no world overstayed its welcome, the theming in the music didn't grow old and the 4th world just started to feel a liiiiittle uninspired after some time pieces, but it ended before it fell off the hype train. 

Personally, my favourite time pieces are the two bosses in the 3rd world (no spoilerino about them here) and the chapter called Train Rush, while trying to get the achievment in the first run for the latter.

The camera was a bit odd and off sometimes, but for a 3D plattformer, it was on the better end.

The only part I did not enjoy that much were the hats. Sadly, they feel more like a TLoZ approach, a "you need this power to progress / collect this collectable", than real powers that are helpful in more situations. 
The main hat wasn't really needed because I never had problems to find where to go next to advance, the witch hat wasn't really helpful outside of destroying stuff it's needed for as it is easier to hit enemies with the umbrella or a jump than throwing a potion, the ice hat was only needed for it's plattforms too, as was the fox mask, and the time slow hat just made things too easy, so I ended up never using it, because I wanted the original challenge. Only the speed hat was usefull outside of its own puzzles.

10/10 game for its price. I'd love to see another A Hat in Time game in some years. Don't rush it, I can wait another 5+ years if it's just as good as this one!

+Beautiful worlds with vastly different themes
+2nd best movement options for a 3D plattformer, closing in on Super Mario Odyssey
+Music gives the chills, and works outside the game too. Buying the soundtrack is recommended
+Great bossfights, challenging and sometimes funny
+Ends before it gets repetitive and boring
+Customization in colors and hat appearence for hat girl
+Personally, I liked the artstyle a lot

-May be a bit short for some
-Camera sometimes ruins the fun
-Most hats are useless outside of their specific puzzles or just make the game easier
-Artstyle may be a bit too cute for some
-Some enemies, like the exploding eggs, are a bit cheap as they home in really fast and strong and you have to cheese them to escape

The art is amazing, it reminds me of a cartoon almost, but better. Everything is so detailed, just look at the crystal-clear sparkly water in the Mafia town. It really is breathtaking, you tend to even stray from your mission just to explore the amazing world before you. 

In my opinion, the voice acting great. A lot of enthusasm and it just makes it fun to sit back and listen to the characters tell their stories, and they all have such amazing personalities that attach you to each and every one, even the villains. I am still obsessed with the Conductor, even though I had to battle him. They're just so well-developed.

Sure, the game has its ups and downs when it comes to bugs, but in all, it's amazing. I loved every second of it, even the challanging time rifts that had me ripping my hair out. (I'm talking about you, dumb owl parade time rift!) 

So yes, get this game. You won't regret it, you'll have an absolute blast.

37988893.review: I'm honestly upset that I didn't get this game until after the steam awards nominations, as this game would've been an easy choice for many of them!

37987021.review:
Bottom Line Up Front:
A Hat in Time is a solid 3D platformer which for the most part, doesn't make a whole lot of waves in the genre. The platforming is good, offering enough wiggle room to allow you to correct any mistakes you may make (if you act quickly enough) and giving you a real sense of wonder as you explore the worlds offered. By no means is this a pixel perfect, difficult platformer. The game feels much more focused on experiencing the world than on creating a difficult and rewarding experience like some other platformers choose to do. The game progresses less linearly than some other platformers with smaller stories contained within the world rather than one larger story that takes you through the game. The game has a great tone, being fun and lighthearted, with a few darker stories that appeal to the adults who grew up with games like these as kids.

The core gameplay loop:
You primarily play levels on a world where you'll earn a timepiece. Most levels you earn the timepiece by exploring and solving small puzzles or platforming challenges until you reach the end. There are a handful of bossbattles in the game that are all unique and fun. And some levels ask you to complete very specific missions to unlock the timepiece. Once you've gotten the timepiece on that level you can go back for collectibles, but I moved quickly from timepiece to timepiece. As you progress, rifts will open on levels you've already completed and you can go back and get another timepiece by finding the rift and completing the short platforming challenge there. As you progress gathering collectibles you can decorate your ship with a handful of relics, decorate your character with new outfits and hat styles, and outfit past levels with new soundtracks. As you progress you also gather yarns which you'll use to stitch new hats, allowing you to interact more and more with the levels you've already completed to unlock collectibles you weren't able to reach when you first went through. You can also purchase badges which affix to your hats giving your character different abilities or gameplay modifications (grappling hook, ability cooldown reducing, changing your sprint mechanic into your character jumping on a solid gold scooter, giving you only one heart, making all words spoken to your character come out as mumbling are just a few).

The Hats:
This games major gimmick is the inclusion of several different hats which each have different functions. You build these up over the course of the game, but I got most of them fairly quickly and easily. The hats are the root of puzzle solving and world exploration and quickly feel like a natural extension of your character. 

The Set Pieces:
The game offers 4 world setpieces (with two planned in future DLC) which are varied and unique. Each world has its own set of characters (the NPCs in this game are an absolute blast), enemies, and themes. Each world has a series of levels with different objectives which reward a time piece. Along the way to getting your time piece, you'll pick up various collectible yarns which you'll use to create new hats, rift tokens which you'll use to unlock outfits and music tracks, and relics which are trophies you'll take back to your ship and decorate it with. These worlds are varied experiences. 3 of the worlds are contained within one map; all of the levels/missions on these worlds are different objectives within that map. 1 world takes you through a variety of very small, linear maps which focus more on telling the specific stories of that level. In between these worlds you can wander around Hat Girl's space ship which is a colorful collection of rooms and (as the game progresses) NPCs. There are three rifts per world you can go back to find and complete. One of those rifts is always a pink rift which is longer and tells a story about that world. There also seem to be hidden diary pages in the game that you can unlock.

Replayability and value of time spent:
Let's face it. This game costs half the price of a AAA title (without a sale it's $30 at time of this review). I bought it at full price and at the time of review I've gotten 10 hours out of it. In these 10 hours I've beaten the entire story and collected all of the time pieces, but not quite all the collectibles or achievements. If I wanted to get the rest of the achievements and collectibles, It'd probably take me another few hours. That's what you're being offered with the core game. However, the developers have enabled in depth modding support allowing you to download from Steam Workshop community levels, new hats, new outfits and characters. I haven't spent too much time wandering around the workshop but I did see a few high quality mods that offer to extend the in game experience significantly. At the time of this review, no additional DLCs have come out and I don't know what their pricing scheme will be, but they also offer to extend the gameplay by about 50%. If you're a person who wants a lot of hours per dollar spent, this game might not be for you (yet! you can always wishlist it and wait for a good sale or wait until there's a lot of high quality workshop content to experience) but if you're a person who's okay with a game offering 10 or 20 fun hours with something like I am, then it's a good option if you like the premise of the game.

Final Note:
This game is fun for what it is. I'd recommend taking the time and money to experience it if you feel like it meets your personal criteria for how much content a game should offer. If you're looking through a lighthearted romp through a series of unique and colorful worlds with hilarious characters to meet along the way, this is the game for you. It's in my opinion, the best so far of the 3D platforming collectathon spiritual successors.

after getting a 100% completion (achievments not included), I really want to give my thoughts on the game

37957749.review: I really like this game, the movement is fantastic, the protagonist is cute, the characters are cool,  the atmosphere is great, the level design is very well thought out BUT this game just feels unfinished. For example, this game has some severe performance problems in some parts, it's also quite buggy and I got stuck in the world geometry pretty often. All of these things are not really important to me, and excusable with this being an indie title but they show that this game isn't quite a finished product. Another indicator is that you can get much more Yarn Balls than there are hats and there's nothing to trade them for, a very obvious choice would be to just make it so that you can trade Yarn Balls for coins that you can use on the slot machine that gives you cosmetics but the developers chose not to and so you're just stuck with a large amount of Yarn Balls that you can't do anything with because you've already unlocked all of the hats. This game also has a weird ending, it just ends, there's not a whole lot of levels and the story also has no real sense of progression, things just happen, then there's an unexpected bossfight and then it's over. Of course story is pretty much unimportant for a game like this but it still bugged me. It doesn't really have to do something with the games length, Super Mario 64 is also only about 15 hours or so long, but this game just doesn't feel complete or finished when you beat it. I don't regret buying this game and will still recommend it but it just feels like this could've been so much more. Maybe the Devs will add more content later and if so I will certainly change my review but as of now, this is my opinion. If steam had a point system  this would be a 7/10

37893140.review:
Three years after its initially promised release date, this Kickstarted game finally came to fruition. While that sounds like development hell on paper, what did the people at Gears for Breakfast manage to make?

A very nostalgia driven adventure in the most idealist of ways. It takes many ideas present in various Nintendo games of all generations and genres, mixes and matches them, and ends up with the best of it all in one cute as heck 3D platforming adventure. Every world, every level even, is boasting with personality and charm in ways that games like Yooka Laylee failed to deliver. Every character you meet is memorable, the stunts you can pull off with its speedrunning-friendly movement will keep you hooked and wanting more, and the Paper Mario-esque writing should guarantee a damn near constant smile on your face. If you want a game that's just a love letter directly to *fun*, this is it.

Also the game runs pretty great, has an uncapped framerate, and is completely open to modding anything: the very definition of a good fucking PC game. The worst thing about it is that there's no Linux port, so here's my +1 in support.

37866644.review:
This game is great.
I had initially heard about this 2 years ago and never really bothered checking it out so much; when it was about to come out, some of my friends started talking about it and I decided to check out some trailers... I eventually decided to buy the game, but I didn't really have much hope in a platformer this year (especially after Yooka-Laylee).

I must say that I was positively surprised. This game not only looks great and has a super cute artstyle, but it also controls amazingly well.

The platforming in here is one of the best you'll ever find in a game currently, trust me. Controls are super tight and thankfully the camera is very far from being an issue. Not only that but the game is very self-aware and the characters are extremely charismatic.

An interesting thing to note is that every single chapter of the game (4 as of this review) has a different "gimmick" to it. In the first one you basically have an open world to explore and get used to the controls, in the second you're given a choice that changes the outcome of that chapter, in the third you have a series of tasks to do, and in the forth you choose your own objectives.

And as implied above, there's still more content on the way. 2 more chapters and multiplayer are great addition to the game, and this isn't even considering that this game supports Steam Workshop mods. Those extra additions, in the long run, essentially make the game more than worth is price.

Do you like platformers and/or collectathons? Get this game. I'm sure you'll enjoy it.
You don't? Get it as well. You might be surprised at how good this kind of game can be.

37831603.review:
If you love 3D platformers, then you will find lots of joy with this game.
It got inspired by some of the old-school - most people know them as milestones - platformers, such as ‘Psychonauts’, ‘Super Mario 64’ et cetera.

This game didn’t match my expectations at all - instead it exceeded them so much, that I can frankly state that I haven’t got so much fun in a long time: It is the icing on the cake of a lot games I've been playing over the past couple years.

Everything in this game is seamless to its own ambitions as indie game: The controls are razor-sharp when considering that this game is mostly a platformer; the art style is gorgeous which mixes perfectly with the overall tracklist of themes, as they couldn’t be composed better, and what is more is that most musical themes are adapting on the world, they are so stunningly dynamic.
Both, the artstyle as well as the music are vivid and fitting the world’s theme.

Speaking of world themes: Do you wish to explore a town inhabited by the mafia or will you rather go on a spooky trip through the night, but hold on, you can also be a detective and investigate a murder case… just to name but a few.
About those worlds it can be said that they are gigantic spaces, some linear, some focused heavily on free platforming and exploration.
Whereat those linear levels concentrate more at the narrative of the world, thus providing very interesting dialogues and charming levels, the exploration driven worlds on the other hand makes you feel lost in their spacious areas submerged with content.
Instead of progressing further to the main quest, you can find yourself most of the time trying to climb objects for optional content, as the platforming is so much fun that it distracts you ultimately from your main goal. 
And even though those levels might appear bland due to their sheer size, there is yet little to zero lack of consistency, on the contrary every wrinkle of the world is plastered with exhilarating stuff.
Almost nothing of that came along to me as padding to artificially enhance the game’s length.
The games world even encourages you to explore freely at the very first missions, thus I skipped the tutorial to some degree.

Moreover it can be said that these maps are consisting of refreshing game-design, even though it is supposed to bring back that old nostalgic vibes, it yet feels like something completely new: Nothing feels like it has already been done before in the same way, and even if there are elements that are considerably taken as reference by the developers, they yet invented those principles further and absolutely nailed them.
If there is one term I could use to describe the aforementioned, I would simply call it a brisk experience.

However there is one more importance to this game, basically it’s charm: There is so much love put inside of those characters and dialogues that I can’t help but say that it feels alive and not like a conversation between two robotic entities.
Furthermore, those conversations between the characters are really hilarious, but also are some of the jokes inside of the game.

All that being said, I can recommend this game without any major complaints, since the only complaint that I have is that it was not as long as other games, but fortunately the content that it does have is absolutely worth your time: I rather play a short but good game than a long dragged out game.
