37813717.review:
This game is an absolute delight. If you are either a fan of the classic platformers or a generally new face within the genre such as I then prepare for an adorable romp through the wacky world of A Hat in Time! 

TLDR: Design is fun and can be really beautiful at times, Characters are a blast and I really wish I saw more of them, Music is great with more than a few stand out tracks, story leaves me wanting more in both good and not so good ways, challenge is well balanced in my opinion with a few areas that felt delightfully rough, and overall I had a good time. I wish I didn't rush through though.

Movement is a blast and the level design is made in a way that isn't too challenging for the gaming novice but rewards those who try to be creative in the way they get around. In many games such as these I always felt that collectibles were not something that I cared too much about as they merely grant maybe an additional life or just a few points to the score, but the different collectibles in this game (aside from the main story-required macguffins) provide you with additional abilities or traits that can make your traversal through the world easier, allow you to accomplish tasks at a faster pace, or just grant you another layer of defense against various threats.

I do enjoy the art style for the most part. Certain aspects like drawn on mouths and the lack of certain facial features were a bit jarring at first, but the design of the world rarely disappointed! This is coming from a poor individual whose computer cannot handle the full graphical settings of this game, but the lower settings still looked really nice and I was able to mind the occasional frame drops. (Wish I had the ability to enjoy the full experience though...) The final world was not my cup of tea since I am not the biggest fan of backtracking giant areas, but it was an isolated incident that really wasn't mandatory unless you are going for the complete experience. You can honestly finish the game rather quickly as you are able to face the final boss well before you have collected all time pieces, but where is the fun in that? 

I won't go into detail about certain events that I cared about the most to avoid too many spoilers, but there were many hits and few misses with a lot of the plot points in this game. I would have loved to see more appearances of a lot of my favorite characters while playing through the game! More story would have been neat in general, but there are future worlds being developed so I can wait a bit to see more! Oh also I like a lot of the tracks in this game. Musical delight indeed!

I apologize for the less than organized review, but I hope I was able to separate it enough to highlight and call into question different aspects of the game. I also really like the workshop feature. I saw a few people importing worlds that allow the excellent movement options to flourish in new environments while others provided even more was to get around in an already amazingly fluid game!

On one last note I miss that cool looking kid from the 2-player announcement from the kickstarter. I heard they were getting rid of that. Kinda makes me sad but it is their decision in the end. 

Thank you for your time if you decided to read this silly thing. Hope you enjoy/enjoyed the game!

37810854.review:
As always, this is only my honest opinion.

Grew up playing Mario 64 and/or Psychonauts? Stop reading here and buy the game.

A Hat in Time is one of those games with huge levels, that have small missions to obtain an item at the end of the mission before being brought back to the main hub... Personally, I love those as they play the strings of nostalgia in my heart.

Game play: Fun and fast with a good flow feel to it. If you're someone who's like me and likes to dive everywhere you know what I'm talking about. Game is quick to pick up on with controls that aren't too difficult. It can be a bit annoying rotating between hats if you're someone who isn't used to leaving an analog stick tilted until you leave the menu. You grow to get used to it though. The game is somewhat flexible in what you can do and when you can do. If throws in elements from other kind of games like Zelda where you cannot complete a task without finding the item to complete the task. You are not bound to one area and are absolutely encouraged to look through other areas and coming back to finish the one you started... There are some customization options also, with a workshop to come. 

Story: The story does make you feel for the antagonist a bit in a very humorous way(?) I mean their reasons are justified, but what they do ends up being a little extra towards the end. Which is fine for plot reasons.

Music: Great. The music is dream like and wonderful. I cannot applaud the music enough.

Faults: Every game has some faults. For me personally it would be some of the mechanics. I'm usually a player with little patience and tend to try to do stuff as quick as possible, and the game is very good at keeping up, until I miss that one swing because the game didn't register that it was a hook-able spot. Camera might also be your nightmare, but we all remember the camera for Mario 64, so if you managed to master that monstrosity growing up, this is cakewalk.

Overall I recommend this game. I really wish to see more for this game, like extra levels, but the way it is now? I enjoyed it. :)

37773072.review:
The past months have been particularly good for platformers it seems. Sonic Mania (DRM issue aside, I had a good time playing it), Cuphead, now this.

Now, this is from the perspective of someone who did not back this game on Kickstarter but backed Yooka-Laylee. Recent years have reintroduced my love of the sorts of platformers as seen on the fifth/sixth generation consoles, especially in the vein of Banjo-Kazooie or Psychonauts. Seeing a group of professionals who worked on Banjo-Kazooie form a new studio to pitch a game had me happily chip in around $12. Putting all drama aside, when I finally received my copy I've put in at least eight hours, and while I contend that reviews were a bit harsh to it, and that there are some positive things going for it (Grant Kirkhope's score being a pretty big one), there were some gameplay gripes I had and I didn't find it that memorable. Not a fan of its voice grunts either, especially when compared to Banjo-Kazooie.

So why did I bring this up? Well, when I received this game as a gift and played it, I found quite a few things about it that just blows it out of the water. There may be some things that needed polish, and it shows, but the characters are charming and well-acted, the worlds they inhabit grip me, with the sorts of themes that I would see in platformers of the sixth-generation era (especially Psychonauts or the Gamecube titles). I also find myself digging the music, as it does remind me of quite a few games that I have known. Also bearing in mind that this game was made lovingly by fans with a background in modding iirc, while Y-L was made by industry professionals, and the former is $10 cheaper at release. With all this, I just don't have the incentive of going back to playing Yooka-Laylee, while I can see myself playing this more.

This is just a really charming game that I certainly wouldn't mind 100%ing on more than one playthrough. If you haven't checked it out, please do.

Holy heck, this game is the PC 3D platformer I've been waiting for, and right now I'm going to say that I really *really* love this game to hecking death and beyonf. It deserves every amount of praise it gets and if you're a fan of 3D platformers or are looking for a first platformer to get into, this is the game to get. Why do I think this way? Glad you asked, I have many reasons!

1. The controls feel SO good, and there is so many options to do things with the amount of control you have over the cute Hat Kid, honestly she feels on par with Mario from Super Mario Sunshine, if not better. 
2. This game has a LOT of charm, every chapter oozes with delight and creativity, and it makes me so happy. Also, Hat Kid is so adorable, her voice actor did a pretty good job making the cute kid be cute.
3. Speaking of voice acting, 95% of this game is voice acted and it ranges from great to amazing. It makes every character have personality, and I don't think the game would be the same without voice acting.
4. The game looks beautiful, even with it's take on a cartoon-like artstyle, it just looks so pretty and I want some of the level intro cards as my wallpaper.
5. The soundtrack, oh my god, this game's soundtrack is equally as amazing as the game's looks itself, goregous tunes, catchy tunes, and it all just blends together with the current situation, I need to buy the OST to just listen to. (Which is more then 5 hours long, dear lord this game is so good)
6. The one thing that really got me excited for the game was the MOD SUPPORT, and from what I've been seeing from the Beta, almost anything is possible. Yes, as of this review the workshop/mod tools are in beta, but they are shaping up to be really good!
I might be missing some points here, but there are more if I missed any!

If there is one thing I don't like, but this is a minor problem, is the game length. I'm not going to spoil how many of the main collectables there are, but the length of this game will make you want more. But there is more on the way with 2 free DLC chapters in the future, AS WELL as a New Game+ mode along the way. But right now, if you want more content, the Workshop beta is the place to get that content, quite a lot of it is already on there!
This is my personal GOTY, I've been waiting so long for this game and it is way better then I hoped it would, and I'll surely be a part of this game's modding community, making content for this excellent game. I wholeheartly recommend it.

37742879.review:
A Hat in Time is a game I'd been anticipating ever since the kickstarter first appeared in ...2013? Wow, that was a long time ago... In any case, the game's a fantastic 3d platformer, brought up to a modern standard -- with a few quirks. 

The control is fantastic. Hat Kid has some of the most fluid control in a 3d platformer ever. The diving and dive-cancel mechanic is tons of fun to pull off, as well as the ground flip you can do to get more speed. They're also very broken, and can be used to skip over a majority of the fun grapple-based platforming segments.

The scenarios and characters you meet along the way are really fun and memorable. The gameplay never gets stale -- there's always something new to do. All this is accompanied by an great, upbeat soundtrack, with lots of variety and charm.

Some complaints:
The badge system is kind of obnoxious. By the end of the game, you only have 3 badge slots you can assign badges to. One of these will usually always be taken up by your grapple. If you want to use your camera, you have to equip it first. This is a minor complaint.

Inconsistency in quality. You can kind of tell what parts of the game were modeled and designed first. Some parts of this game, such as models, effects, and environments have an inconsistant look to them. Some animations look absolutely amazing, while some quite literally weren't changed from the beta build of the game. Some characters clip through other objects during their animations. Some dialoug doesn't have voice acting. These inconsistancies got to the point where it was incredibly jarring whenever I noticed them.
Of course, all of these problems are cosmetic, and don't ruin the game, persay... They just take you out of the experience for a moment.

But good game anyway. Buy this game. Just do it if you want a fun ol' romp. What have you got to lose? They're working on the free dlc, so there's even more cool stuff on the way!

37739367.review: I have yet to play to Yooka Laylee, another spiritual successor of Banjo Kazooie, but for an Indie Title, the love that went into this game shows. It scratches all of old itches (even has Grant Kirkhope, the composer for BK) and has a great deal of variety... within one chapter with one level you could be playing a level that plays like "Amnesia the dark descent" and another where you deliver mail/packages. If I had one gripe with this game it's that some of the levels are notably longer than others even within the same chapter...namely some of the Dead Bird Studio levels (as compared to the last chapter where everything is about an even length. Not a huge deal IMO, but one or two play sessions I ended up playing longer longer than I thought because the level length ended up being longer than I would have thought. There are supposed to be two more chapters based on the stretch goals of the Kickstarter, so I look forward to seeing what variety those bring and wish the game studio the best in any other future titles in this genre.

37728498.review:
A gaming masterpiece.

This is a love letter to video games.

In A Hat In Time, the player assumes control of Hat Kid, a (mostly) silent character, on a spaceship, eager to get home. An unexpected snag hits, and off to journey to 3D platforming worlds you go!

The story setup is brief but it works. A Hat In Time succeeds because although it advertises itself as cute-as-heck, it’s also fun-as-heck, peck-as-heck, and while there is a time and a place, this is the place. And this place draws you in, because while it’s not the biggest (it’s the first game released by Gears For Breakfast), nor the baddest (a Kickstarter project 4+ years in the making, with a modest budget and a modestly-sized development team), it does exude quality across the board regardless, in many aspects, taking many forms. A Hat In Time’s positives include:

+ FUN FACTOR/FUN. Lots and lots of fun! This game GETS IT. From the moment you wake on your spaceship and are placed to inspect your immediate surroundings, this game invites you. At first it is but a whisper. You go over to the dresser, chuckle, a tiny glimpse of the clever writing that awaits you, you then turn your head, and… there is a pool of pillows in your bedroom! Well then, dive in!

And that’s what it’s all about.

Diving in.

A Hat In Time wants you to interact. To explore. To dive in, to soak in its unique blend of personality and charm. Here’s your ticket, all aboard, passenger! You’re invited to this vibrant, crazy train! Nostalgic and trailblazing, A Hat In Time pays respect to the old and the new. The little things. The big things. This world is alive, full of details, both large and small, some random, some not, from Roomba rides, to scooter horns, to pattycake with the man in blue, to random posters plastered in various worlds, to talking owls, to curious crows, to picture taking, to jokes, to jokes WITHIN jokes, to clever responses, to humorous interactions, to easter eggs, to random jumps on floating cookies, to scary ledges, to tightrope mechanics, to engrossing music, to the vibrant surroundings and atmosphere, the list goes on. Which all amounts to --

Fun. A BIG bundle of fun! The game doesn’t have to tell you to HAVE fun, because the world IS fun. The worlds are a playground for Hat Kid, she herself a world of her own, able to convey, through facial expressions and body animations alike, a wide range of emotions such as joy, sadness, or her unmistakenly unwavering child-like innocence, sarcasm, and hope. Hat Kid’s adorable idle animations, her 'running-in-place’ animation, environmentally specific animations (keep a lookout during cold/mysterious/scary areas), cute voicelines (Her “Bye” to the Badge Seller awww <3), her “Fireballs,” her “Boo-yahs,” and so on and so forth, as well as her dedicated buttons to ‘blow kiss/smooch’ and ‘raspberry’, all come together to make her a ball of recklessly positive inspiration, ready to take on any adventure that comes her way.

+ CONTROLS. This is tight, responsive platforming paradise. Controls are crisp, enabling Hat Kid to move well to your desire. Her moveset includes running, a standard jump, a double jump, a long jump, a parkour-inspired wall jump, a dive, an air dive, a dive cancel, an air dive cancel, umbrella swipes, air homing attacks, etc. not to mention equippable hats and badges that add various skills and abilities to her arsenal. It seems like a basic layout, and it may appear so on the surface, but her runs, jumps, dives, and cancels provide a level of precision and a gateway for advanced play that allows for mid-air error adjustment, correction, and control, allowing her to maneuver platforms with relative ease. 

Her toolbox further rewards skillful players who are able to chain these abilities together to make use of speedruns, which are an embraced option in the game. A Hat In Time even goes as far as to include a speedrun timer in the options, for those willing to take on the challenge of going fast, fast, fast!

And because Hat Kid controls quite well, particularly resourceful players will be able to discover shortcuts and different ways to finish a stage. This is a mark of a good control scheme, as well as well-planned, well thought-out, and well-executed level design.

+ GENRE-BREAKING ELEMENTS. In a manor of speaking, this game surprises as it transcends its predominant 3D platformer roots and manages to mix genres such as stealth, mystery, and horror into one. I will be brief here because these sections are best experienced by the player itself, but will say that these sections make sense for each specific adventure, and are appropriate for each specific setting. It executes this wonderfully and it comes through beautifully. It does not feel tacked on, or existing just because it can, but is rather interesting and highlight some of the best and most memorable parts of the game.

+ SOUNDTRACK. Clocking in at over 5 hours, A Hat In Time’s soundtrack, almost all of which are composed by Pascal Michael Stiefel, along with a few other notable names (Grant Kirkhope + artists with remixed renditions of specific tracks), is genuinely one of the best parts of A Hat In Time AND (IMO) one of THE MAIN reasons to get the game. One of the most important elements for game immersion, A Hat In Time’s soundtrack is excellent, with memorable, catchy, and ambitious sections, spanning across different genres to create a defining mark and a long-lasting impression. Mindful players will recognize nostalgic sections/references amongst specific tunes (but it’s not a prerequisite, as the soundtrack, as a whole, is fantastic enough to listen to as a standalone, without the coat of nostalgia to cast judgment).

Simply put, this soundtrack is one to hold in high regard, in and outside of the game. I do (and will) play stages JUST to hear certain tracks, they’re that good, and such a joy to listen to! The variety here is astounding, likely offering something to suit the tastes of everyone.

+ OPEN-ENDED DESIGN. The game supports Steam Workshop, which means that it encourages mods/mod support (currently in beta). Options exist for new dyes/costumes, new hats, new abilities, unique levels, recreations of stages from beloved games, added difficulties, and so on and so forth. Intriguing possibilities abound, and we’re just at the tip of the iceberg.

+ HUMOR. A good chunk of the game’s personality and charm can be attributed to the humor and strong writing, clearly inspired by beloved games of old. Most of the humor here is appropriate for kids, although some border on the twisted and the macabre.

Whether it’s Hat Kid’s mannerisms, her interactions with objects/characters, the characters themselves, or a specific activity within a specific stage, A Hat In Time puts a nostalgic, yet distinct style to accompany and enhance these specific worlds, never artificial, and as wacky as the wacky worlds that they are set within. It just… fits. It’s ok to smile, and to laugh along :).

As far as negatives go, world 5’s main antagonist needs more screen time, more backstory, more motivation to emphasize why this character set out to become the very character this is in the final act. More fleshing out in this aspect is needed; as is, it ended up being too abrupt.

---FINAL THOUGHTS---

The game, per Kickstarter achieved stretch goals, will have worlds 6 and 7 arriving as free DLCs, and will have co-op modes available in the near future. There is much to look forward to!

Get this game and transport yourself to an amazing, memorable journey. Support a development team that put obvious love and care into their work! The charm, the precision, the detail – this is a fine example of gaming bliss. One that should endure – in time.

My wish is that Hat Kid becomes recognizable enough to the point that she becomes a classic, iconic, beloved video game character.

A Hat In Time cherishes the past, shapes the present, and has a promising future.

Play it. Be charmed by it. Enjoy it.

Love it!

So. I remember the first trailer that came out in 2014. I only saw it a year later, and I remember thinking about how this game looks fun. I looked up more but at the time that was it. Cons:

A Hat in Time is fun and that is really all someone has to say about it. 

I feel that too many games these days have forgotten what they really are. Too often there is such a disproportionate focus on high-octane competitive action, or cinematic high-budget storytelling, or even hair-pulling levels of difficulty that many games have left behind what makes this form of entertainment special in the first place. 

Nothing in this game exists for itself. A Hat in Time is built around the player and only the player. It doesn't stroke its ego to 'enhance' the experience or exploit its brand to sell copies. It just simply presents itself and says "have fun."

Everything about this game is designed to be fun. Every mechanic and feature has been given special attention so that nothing would ruin the experience. My favorite being the secret shortcut avalable to those who don't want to do the horror level, but still want to finish the game. 

The controls are tight and well thought out. Just moving the character around is enough entertainment for hours. Add the incredible soundtrack, the tastefull humor, the refined (albeit simple) artstyle, and a camera that rivals even some of the great 3D mario games and you have something truly special.

A Hat in Time is one of the best old-school 3d platformers in many many.

This game is nothing but a callback to the N64/PS2 era of 3d platformers, so if you're like me, and  happen to love games such as Mario/DK 64, Banjo Kazooie, Psychonauts, or the Crash series this game is undoubtedly for you.  This was one of the few select games that I've genuinely been excited for, and followed the development process despite not being a Kickstart backer. Let me tell you despite being a crowdfunded game, it 100% lived up to all my expectations.  Starting from the opening cutscene I just completely fell in love with the game, and for the first hour or so I just tried exploring, and admiring the first world's scenery.  From the lovable cast of characters, to the scenery, the OST (which in itself is amazing, and even includes some work from Grant Kirkhope), the game has managed to turn itself from a crowdfunded callback to a more or less dead genre, to it's own unique entity that stands amongst it's peers.

However, not everything was amazing.

* The price to playtime is about 1-2$ per hour, which is really not ideal. 
* There really arnt that many Time Rifts in the game, which are pure platforming areas that are essentially the same as the flood-less levels in Mario Sunshine.
* The "last" world, Alpine Skyline is so bad compared to the rest of the game its just sad. Alpine Skyline is  tiresome, uninteresting, and overall boring as all hell. However, I will give the game credit for  changing up the formula.

Overall A Hat in Time is just a cute, fun loving, feel-good kind of game, which I would reccomend to anyone.

On a personal note this game very easily could take my vote for GOTY  however, at the least it will be in my top 3 garunteed. Also >Shadman is a disgusting lowlife who should off himself for what hes done to this game

37668561.review:
Absolutely brilliant platformer! 8.5-9/10 very easily recommended if you like 3d platformers even slightly!

I grew up in the N64 'Golden Era' of 3d platformers and this game exudes with the charm and personality of those games while adding some good voice acting to improve. It follows the Nintendo ethos of having multiple, swift movement options but improves it by adding badges to change some techniques slightly and add visual flair. The game looks fantastic and runs pretty consistently with a cute cel-shaded art style and bright vibrant colours. There aren't a billion things to collect, I've 100%'d the game in 10hrs but that's a good thing, each of the levels are so unique and well designed with their own themes both visually and gameplay-wise. But above all, it has the polish, attention to minute details, memorable world designs and fluid controls that Yooka Laylee was somewhat lacking.

The X-Factor for this game comes in all of the worlds being like Super Mario 64, small and each Time Piece is objective based making it easy to keep track and maintain progress - EXCEPT for one world which uses the free roam style of Banjo Kazooie to great effect and is a nice change of pace. It didn't choose one style or the other exclusively, it gave a taste of both these brilliant formulae for platforming worlds and it works damn well.

Pros:
- Great art style and solid visual presentation
- Soundtrack is appropriate and very catchy in some places (favourite are Time Rift and Band Song #1)
- Not too many collectibles, so no DK64 burnout just some good fun exploring and snapping
- Controls are tight, smooth and very responsive (Hat Kid is the female Mario)
- Story is ridiculously light-hearted and very tongue-in-cheek (excl. a sad mini-story #Vanessa)
- Each of the 5 worlds are unique and not at all boring or similar to one another
- Camera is brilliant for a 3d platformer about 95% of the time

Cons:
- I'm really scraping the barrel, but there was some slowdown during intense changes in scenery such as Lava episode in Mafia Town
- Camera is a bit funny sometimes, but DON'T let that deter you please. It's simply something that all 3d platformers must bear, the camera will sometimes get stuck in tough spots but it never lead to me dying or losing progress in a platforming challenge
- No DLC yet (seriously Gears for Breakfast, we need dat dlc rite nouw ;) )

37627586.review:
劇情簡介                                                                                
帶著高禮帽的小女孩駕著太空船在宇宙中漫遊著，竟然有位不速之客來要保護費!         
                                                                                
「小女孩，所有的船來到古惑島都要向我們繳過路費，即便在太空中的也是一樣」        
                                                                                
小女孩一口回絕，想不到不速之客一拳打破了太空船的玻璃，太空艙內氣流猛地往外衝
鎖在大保險箱內的太空動力裝置全被氣流衝跑了!                                     
太空船沒動力可回不了家啊，小女孩得設法把散落在各個星球上的動力裝置找回來才行!

                                                                                
遊戲介紹                                                                        
A Hat in Time是一款3D平台遊戲，由獨立公司Gears for Breakfast製作發行，在Kickstarter上募資30萬美金，花費約4年完成                                        
A Hat in Time共有5大章節，其中2章節是線性關卡，另外3章節各是一張大地圖          
遊戲的完成度可說非常高，A Hat in Time是近幾年群眾募資很成功的案例               
                                                                                
我第一眼看到A Hat in Time立刻讓我回想起小時候的超級馬力歐64，和陽光馬利歐(Super Mario sunshine)，那些非常棒的3D平台遊戲。
A Hat in Time在遊戲機制和關卡設計上都有學到這些前輩的精髓，並更加強操作和變化，個人認為A Hat in Time是可以和super mario odyssey相提並論的遊戲


遊戲操控                                                                        
A Hat in Time包含3D平台遊戲一定要有的各種跳耀方式，二段跳、衝刺大跳、飛撲、蹬牆、俯衝攻擊、和鈎鎖。                                                        
                                                                                
二段跳、衝刺大跳：二段跳和衝刺大跳彼此互斥，想要二段跳就不能衝刺大跳，反之亦然  
                                                                                
飛撲：飛撲是可以快速增加水平距離的方式，在飛撲中途可以再次按下跳躍鍵中止飛撲並向上跳躍一小段距離，是個人認為非常好用的操作                                  
                                                                                
蹬牆：在跳躍碰上牆壁時小女孩都會往上攀爬一小段距離，只要碰到牆時再按下跳躍就會蹬牆離開，如果在蹬牆前沒有使用二段跳，在蹬牆後就可再跳躍一次                    

俯衝攻擊：在跳起時一定範圍內有敵人，可以立刻按下攻擊鍵，小女孩會在空中俯衝，撞擊敵人後往俯衝方向跳起一小段距離，此時可以再施展一次跳躍

鈎鎖：鈎鎖發動時必須按住攻擊鍵不放才可在鈎鎖上停留，小女孩可在鈎鎖上擺盪，甩出鈎鎖後可在空中進行二段跳

以上操作除了鈎鎖是後期才拿到的能力，其他則是一開始就可以使出的操作，這讓遊戲進行得非常流暢。
有些需要依靠帽子特殊能力才比較輕鬆到達的區域，也可以不靠特殊能力只用玩家巧妙的操作來達陣，這是我認為A Hat in Time關卡設計成功的地方。
玩家可以在初期就拿到後期的禮品和特殊能力，只要你的操作夠好，幾乎所有地方你都去的了!


A Hat in Time就如同超級馬力歐64一樣有不同功能的帽子來突破障礙，A Hat in Time共有六種不同能力的帽子，擁有帽子後可將帽子別上不同勳章來強化帽子的能力

A Hat in Time中小女孩共有4滴血，BOSS戰大部分都不會太難，但都有挑戰性
BOSS型態也有許多種變化，第一次碰到新BOSS可能都會死個4或5次，不過一抓到行動模式後就很好打了。
覺得挑戰不夠的玩家也可以裝備一血道具，來挑戰無損通關

遊戲畫面
進入遊戲前是繪圖風格，進入遊戲後是可愛的3D圖像，可愛的畫風讓我在冒險時總是無比開心，很高興這是一個大人小孩都可以享受的遊戲。
遊戲最高最低畫質差異不會太大，不過有些場景或莫名掉偵，尤其是空中大地圖章節，不過大部分時候我的電腦GTX950都是以
60fps來跑中等畫質，相信比較低的配備也可以用較低畫質來順順跑


遊戲音樂
我非常喜歡A Hat in Time的遊戲音樂，藉由音樂充分的表現出小孩子的快樂大冒險，他的畫風和音樂不停得勾起我小時候玩遊戲的快樂回憶

遊戲劇情
就是很簡單的小女孩要找回動力裝置回家，並打倒所有搶走動力裝置不還的大壞蛋
A Hat in Time每個角色都非常可愛，反派也是各有特色且討人喜歡，最棒的還是小女孩可愛天真加上調皮搗蛋，搶走小女孩的東西不還，就準備體驗她的怒火和超強的破壞力!

遊戲缺點
A Hat in Time在某些場景會進入固定視角來方便操作，不過這些固定視角的進入時機有時很奇怪，你有可能在空中跳到一半突然轉換成固定視角而操作失誤

遊戲檢查點機制不是很妥善，不小心摔落深谷有時候會從最靠近的檢查點重生，而不是你的上個檢查點，這導致我必須將我的血量耗光才能從上個檢查點重生，對我是不小的麻煩

總結而言A Hat in Time是很出色的佳作，集合可愛角色、很棒的音樂、不錯的操控性，成就一場小孩夢想中的大冒險。我通關收集全部動力裝置加上大部分的收集品，總時數是22小時，這22小時內充滿著歡樂，想不到A Hat in Time可以帶給我童年玩3D平台遊戲的快樂回憶，讓我在這22小時內像小孩一樣無憂無慮開心的玩著

劇情：8/10
遊戲性：9/10
美術：7/10
重玩價值：中

非常推薦喜愛3D平台遊戲、可愛角色和音樂的人來玩A Hat in Time!

我現在最大的遺憾是沒在Kickstarter支持他們，不過一定會多買幾份送人的!

37623771.review:
Viniendo de alguien a quien no le gusta mucho Mario 64 ni Banjo Kazooie, este juego es demasiado bueno.
No hay momento en el que esté jugando que no tenga una sonriza estupida en mi cara. Es gracioso, adorable, creativo y muy intenso en las peleas contra los jefes. ¡Maldito DJ Grooves! ¡Yo confiaba en ti! 

Los controles son muy buenos, variados y es divertido solo el saltar y lanzarse por ahí. En ningún momento sentí que había perdido por culpa de los controles o la cámara o nada parecido.

El soundtrack es perfecto. No tengo nada más que agregar, es simplemente perfecto.

Los niveles son obviamente la mejor parte del juego, son MUY divertidos y creativos. aparte de Mafia Town, el resto de los niveles y actos se sienten totalmente únicos. Entre un estudio de filmación, un tren con una bomba, una manción embrujada, etc. Todos tienen una forma totalmente diferente de jugabilidad. Algunos son mas abiertos, otros son mas lineales, en otros tienes que ser sigiloso, y ninguno de los niveles es aburrido en lo más mínimo. 

El dialogo y los personajes son hilarantes si sabes inglés, recomiendo no saltearlos, especialmente en los niveles del tren!

¡ENCIMA TIENE UN MODO DE CÁMARA COMO MARIO ODYSSEY! En serio, adoro sacarme fotos tontas con los personajes del juego

Lo único que tengo para quejarme son algunos glitches menores como algunas zonas con colision extraña y una parte que no tiene textura en uno de los jefes, por el cual puedes sacar la camara por fuera de los limites.


Hacete un favor y comprate esta obra maestra. No esperes a que baje el precio, porque vale la pena los 30 USD

37575821.review:
I haven't played a game that I was genuinely happy to be playing the entire time, in a loooong time. The levels are bright and fun, characters are well designed and cute, and the platforming is perfect. It made me very reminisant of Banjo-Kazooie and Super Mario Sunshine, what with the collectables, platforming, and abilities.

You know how is some games that you love, there's that one level or mission that you hate going back to on a new playthrough? Not here, each level was fun and challenging. Only drawback is that it was short. But hell, getting 100% took me ~17 hours, which in retrospect is not too bad. Considering the Devs are releasing two more chapters for free, I feel like I'll come back to this game a lot and crank up that playtime anyways.

For a game that I was moderately intrigued by upon hearing about it before its release, it has sky-rocketed to one of my favorite games of the last few years. I hope Gears For Breakfast keeps up the amazing work and goes on to make many more wonderful games.

37573357.review:
This game somehow wedged itself into my level of love for games like Super Mario Sunshine, and unlike Super Mario Sunshine, I didn't own this game for 15 years and have a ton of nostalgia for it.

Each level is completely different. It's not just platforming - it's exploring, getting famous, solving murders, stealth missions, mail deliveries, and fighting toilets. Even to the point where the tutorial's fun! From the get-go, you're given one of the most expansive and explorable maps in the entire game. Then when you're finished, you can beat it in 10 seconds and move on. And each boss actually has a lot of character and relevance to them, not just "a giant version of an earlier enemy" or something. There's some sort of build-up to them, which is something I adored about games like Undertale.

I just feel bad that this masterpiece was released right before Mario Odyssey. But I can't complain about getting two beautiful 3D platformers in one month.

I guess it goes without saying that this really is a throwback to the “Gamecube/N64” era of games, 5th to 6th gen consoles.

Stumbling upon this game by chance while it was in the late development stages was a gift from the gaming gods. Controls are tight and mostly responsive, movement speed is perfectly matched with the worlds, characters are rather charming, humor is generously sprinkled throughout most areas, combat is very simply, a lot of areas to explore and more. Not to mention the great soundtrack. Seems to be heavily inspired by the likes of Wind Waker and Sunshine. So if you like those games or merely have an interest in picking this one up. I would highly recommend it. 

I'm just reiterating what a bunch of other reviewers has said about this game at this point.

37472366.review:
An excellent example of a 3D platformer done right, with tight controls and camera work (for the most part). The story is a little shallow, but endearing and enjoyable with enough quirks to keep you engaged and laughing along with it. 
 
Pros 
- Beautiful artwork 
- Solid gameplay 
- Tight Controls 
- Intuitive game mechanics 
- Measured progression 
- Varied game areas 
- Collectables 
 
Cons 
- The camera can get stuck on/against objects and walls, although only rarely, making for some annoying jumping visuals. 
- A few moments of progression are confusing if you are a 'collectaholic', only telling you that you are missing something, not what it is or where to get it. 
 
Overall the best 3D platformer I've played in years, expect 10-20 hours of gameplay to complete, depending on how dedicated you are to collecting everything.

37472288.review:
Wow. You shouldn't need anyone else to say what's great about this game at this point because I'm sure between the youtube videos and the hailstorm of positive reviews this game already should look like a solid purchase but let me just say that within this game beats the heart of a true platformer. I never would have imagined such a small company could strive so boldly to earn a place among the Mario franchise titles and come so close to reaching it. The controls are fantastic, the levels all play wildly different from the others, and the characters are so memorable I already get the feeling of dusting off an old cartridge every time I launch this game. It's like couch gaming with an old friend.

It does need some work still. Mod support is not nearly as robust as I'd like (bugs will happen often), it is fairly easy to glitch the game out in certain places, and overall the game is possible to 100% in a fairly short amount of time. However, nothing has left me wanting. You can play the zones in (almost) any order and they have this nice flow that ends each world just before it starts to feel old. There's endearing characters at every turn, and while overall the game is very easy it has some nice challenges too. I can forgive the game for being short, because every minute is well made.

Overall, anyone who loves platformers will love this. In a world of serious, competitive, shooters and MOBA's, A Hat in Time is there to remind you that games should make you feel happy. They should entertain and captivate us.

An incredibely charming 3D platformer collectathon in the style of the Super Mario games. It is influenced by and has references for Super Mario Sunshine and Super Mario Galaxy specifically, but they do so tastefully. 37310906.review:
[Only about 5 hours into the game. Review will update with progress]

So, before we start. I've been looking forward to this game since 2015 and its kickstarter. I didn't back the kickstarter because I was a peniless student without a job at the time, but I was still looking forward to it. 
Flash forward to two years later. I brought the game only yesterday as I was in a busy period, but let me tell you... The long wait for this game was well worth it.

A hat in time is one of those "Good old 3D-platformers remade". But unlike Yooka-Laylee, it's actually good! The movement feels good, the camera acts how it should (i.e, you can always see you character), and let's be real, it's pretty much perfect.
I have a few complaints, but I'll save that for the end.

From the first time I loaded up the game, all I could think was "this looks awesome". Everything is consist. Everything looks like it's meant to be. The crazy spaceship that you're in... you don't quesiton it because it fits. The first island, "Mafia Island" feels natural somehow. There's no need for suspension of disbelief becuase it all feels natural to the game.
You can practically fly around the game with the amount of movement you're given, and yet the platforming is still a challenge as it should be... (Sometimes because of the controls and camera, but we'll get to it).

The characters all look awesome. You can tell that a lot of love went into how everything looks. Especially Hat Girl (Cause I don't know her name haha). It's kinda awesome. Even the small amounts of dialogue she speaks just sounds amazing. It's perfectly done. Then there's the NPCs. They were amazingly done to. I love the Marfia from as far as I've gone. I love talking to the random characters around and just hearing their random voice lines. Oh yeah, all the dialogue is voiced to!!!

The music of the game... I decided to buy the deluxe edition from the start, but holy cow. I did not realise just how amazing it was going to be. I love the music. I even spent a good 10 minutes in front of the TV in the ship listening to the dog bark remix of the song hahaha...

Anyway, this game is amazing. But let's mention the downsides. 
The camera doesn't have any elevation control and doesn't give you any options to pan it in order to make sure you stick the jumps (At least by default). This makes platforming a bit annoying at times.
Hat girl feels a bit slipery at times, making platforming a bit hard... She loves to run up walls a lot and screw up some of the more dangerous sections.
I want to like Mustache Girl because her voice is amazing.
Before you get the magnet badge, collectables really love going underwater and being unreachable.

Well, that's what I think about "A Hat in Time".
It's amazing. Totally get it.

37267500.review:
There are tons of reviews on why this game is absolutely amazing (and it deserves every single one of them), so I'm going to list off the few even slightly negative things I found on my first playthrough of the game:

[List]
[*]One (only one) time, I got stuck in a crane and had to restart the level.  I didn't even lose any progress or anything, I just had to go back to the start of the level.  No more issues.

[*]It took way me way too long to figure out where to assemble relics, but I may have just missed it when they first explained relics to you.  

[*]I wasn't a fan of how restricted Subcon Forest felt with the fire walls all over the place, but I still loved the area regardless.

[*]The camera felt a little weird on controller, with no way to really look up, until I realized I could change it to a traditional third camera in the settings.

[*]I would have liked it to be longer, but that's hardly a bad thing to be wishing for.  Even if it was 50 hours long, I would still want more.

[*]The badge system felt a little bit underwhelming.  The hookshot badge would usually take up one slot, because of how frequently you find spots to use it, and the scooter would usually take up another, just because of how great it is to get around a platformer quickly.  So, you were usually left with one slot, which feels like a missed opportunity.
[/List]

     And of all of those, only one of them is an actual game-wide criticism, and even then it didn't detract from the overall experience at all really.  Everything else in this game is absolutely amazing, from the controls to the characters and everything inbetween.  Seriously, these are the only bad things I can think of about this game, and I had to rack my brain for some of them.  Go buy this game, I can almost guarantee you will not regret it.

37265552.review:
For a simple concept of a 3D platflormer with the touch of different ability elements, this game was a instant hit for me from the moment I started up Chapter 1. From the vibrant level designs of each world to the detail and care put into each character came an amazing experiance I wasn't really expecting at first glance when I first purchased this game. This game would probably be one of the only platformers that I've loved playing in a long time, which shines with everything I hope for in any type of game.

Sure, there's a few downsides to the main game : Camera angles being trickey and annoying in some platforming stages in certain areas (especially in Chapter 3 and some Time Rifts), character models showing slight errors when displayed in certain cutscenes with clipping and even though I don't mind this at all, some people would say it'd be too short of a game.

But with this, the true potential of AHIT shines through and knocks those worries out. The game starts out fun and enjoyable and stays that way until the very moment you exit out. Each stage of every chapter has a ton of replay value with how much space there is to explore with the wide variety of obstacles to parkour through and with the touch of collectables that unlock ability hats, customizable material for Hat Girl to currency that help with buying pins which you can mix and match to your own style and advantage in different areas.

The main selling point of this game, in my opinion, would be the soundtrack, how it creates this amazing atmosphere throughout the story and the variety and personality put to each individual character you come to face throughout that make each area have more charm and give more reason to venture forth to see what they and the enviroment have in store for you to overcome.

I really do recommend this game to anyone no matter personal taste, you'll love it start to finish. It was worth all 4 years of waiting from the developers, and if you wanted to play even more of the game after collecting all 40 hourglasses, there's the big amount of fan made material avaliable on the Steam Workshop to go through.

37265057.review:
After being disappointed by Yooka-Laylee, I didn't really have high hopes that this would end up much better, but it quickly blew past my expectations and delivered what I would consider to be the best 3D Platforming experience on PC.

It's certainly not perfect; a few missions were a bit confusing to navigate, some collectibles a bit too hidden, but the great art style and plentiful rewards for going out of your way in each area counterbalanced any frustrations I had.  Honestly, the only real complaint I had by the end of the game was that I really wished there were more hourglasses to find and new areas to explore.  Luckily, with how open the modding tools are, I feel like that won't be a problem for much longer.

Plus, with multiplayer on its way, I'll have more than enough reason to play through the game again in its entirety in the future.

37219653.review:
So, A Hat in Time. This is a Kickstarter game that was in a development for 5 years and promised to bring back the memories of classic 3D platformer games... No, come back, please! This one is actually good, I promise!

*Ahem* So. It's surprisingly good. So far all content that the game offered me was great and it's one of the few games that I actually wanted to replay right after I completed it.

In this game you play as a girl whose name we don't know and is nicknamed Hat Kid. The game starts with you waking up on the spaceship on which you are flying back to your home. It uses hourglass thingies called time pieces as a fuel. On your way home you are flying past a planet from which a person who claimes to be a part of Mafia came to take a toll from you for passing over their town. Instead he manages to break the glass window on your ship and it results in losing all your time pieces as they fall on the planet and now you need to take them back so you could have enough fuel to fly back to your home.

The controls are good and tight. You have a variety of moves including a wall run, double jump and a dive which are pretty standart for a 3D platformer. You also have a variety of hats that have different abilities that help you to explore the levels. Also also, similar to Psychonauts you can buy and equip badges that add new abilities to your character or improve the abilites of the hats.

The game features 4 big worlds for you to explore (there are 5 worlds actually but the fifth one is just a bossfight) and they differ greatly in style and atmospere which helps to keep the game fresh and fun. For example, the first world named "Mafia Town" is a Mario Sunshine-esque world in which you are given the main objective you need to do but you can freely explore the map. The second world named Dead Bird Studio in which you are caught in battle between two movie directors that managed to get their hands on some time pieces is a more linear experience compared to the first world and so on. Each world also features bonus levels called "Time Rifts" which are pure platforming segments similar to Mario Sunshine. 

The art style of this game is very good and cute, can't really say anything else about it.

The characters in this game are very good and memorable. You have the Mafia with thick russian accent who punch barrels who are dressed as old ladies to keep the town in fear, you have a scottish owl who likes to film western movies on his own train with innocent owls that just want to get to their destination on his train and a sassy penguin who is a former owner of night club who decided to film movies too, and many more.

I also want to point out the voice acting in this game. It's one of the best I've heard in a game and it adds a lot of personality to the characters and makes them much better (you also have an option to turn off the voice acting if you do not like it). Voice actors did a really great job.

The music in this game is amazing. So far every piece of music the game offered me was a delight to my ears. The game musician really needs to get an extra credit for his work.
Here's an example:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2XUw1NxJS2k

While there are a lot of good things in the game, there are some problems too. The game also brought back some cons from old platformers like strangely placed and fixed cameras which can mess with your view and thus it makes navigating the level harder, controls sometimes can be a wee bit wonky, some rough edges when it comes to graphics and animations and a story is a bit shallow in some places.

Verdict.

A Hat in Time is a really good and solid game that managed to bring back the feeling of the classic platformers (and some problems) while mixing in some new stuff. I highly recommend to buy this game and try it out. For me this game was one the best gaming experiences (if not the best) I had in last couple of years and definitely my favorite game of 2017

37187459.review:
With the hype that was surrounding this game upon its release, I was... apprehensive, to put it lightly. To me, it looked just like a standard platformer with a mild charm to its art style. The characters were cute and it was a platformer. That's all you really get from it when just watching casual gameplay. But..

When you actually play the game yourself, it's very different. Because you aren't just looking at something cute now. /You/ are the cute. And that makes all the difference, because the way the main character, Hat Girl, controls is very fluid. She moves like you want her to and there are ways to improve your movement even further, just by playing the game. Some through the in-game equipment, such as a badge that makes you not bonk your head if you ram into a wall, but a lot of them are simply learning the gameplay.

That mixed with the actual platforming being challenging and, in most cases, interesting to figure out without touching anything dangerous makes the game flow even better. As a 3D platformer that has clear influences from top tier platformers such as Mario Sunshine, it does its job well. It may not seem like it at first glance, but it has the same heart in it that Mario Sunshine had and then some... But then you get into the negatives.

The gameplay is good. No doubt about it, but there are two major aspects that do hold this game back from getting a perfect score anywhere... The story and the level mechanics. 

Story wise, it isn't awful. I can't go into too much detail without tossing major spoilers in a review, but a major character doesn't make an appearance after the first ten minutes of the game... And that's bad. A lot of the characters also seem a bit too "singlular minded" and it gets really old, really quick when the Mafia guys refer to themselves as "Mafia" like three times in one text box. I can't recall how many times I muttered "Please stop saying Mafia" to myself. But on the flip side, there are other characters that act nothing alike that still end up being the exact same thing in the end. That's dull. Not a major issue, but dull. Lastly, it has to do with Hat Girl's own connection to everyone. But that's spoilers too.

As for the level mechanics, the big issue is that there are only a few things you can grab in a level before you have to leave. Even if the level is exactly the same as another chapter, which is an old way of doing it that we saw in Mario 64 or Mario Sunshine. Get the Star/Shine -> Exit Level -> Re-enter level on another chapter -> Repeat. It's an old style that kinda lost its charm awhile ago, but I understand the need of it. Didn't really enjoy dealing with it when the levels were the exact same, however. Only the Finale chapters for each stage felt like it deserved to be a separate level. However; I'll also say that each stage has its own loading screen and that's pretty great. The art style conveys the emotion of each one well enough that I was happy to see them, but playing through the same level three times for three different Time Pieces was pretty... meh. Not weird or bad, just... Meh.

As a side, it also bothers me there's no way to actively collect all the other vanity items in the game. This is to make it open ended for future levels and modded levels that come out in the future, but... There's a lot of stuff I can't get for a long time now because of that. Which is fine in the long run, but I can see a lot of people getting bothered they can't actually 100% this game for another year.

However, at the end of the day, I'd still recommend this game to anyone that enjoys platformers. It's a good game with minor faults that mostly lie in its story telling wanting to be episodic, but not including an overarching plot. The plot is there, don't get me wrong, but... It's not really a factor except at the beginning and end. That's bland, but we'll see how the DLC stuff handles that I suppose? Though that doesn't really help the base game, I think...

But y'know, 8/10. Great game, but it's not perfect. Hats off to you, you just needed more Time.

I backed this game years ago after seeing the kickstarter page shared on Reddit.  I absolutely fell in love with what they were trying to accomplish because of my love of Super Mario Sunshine and the like when I was younger.  It's still the only game I've ever backed on Kickstarter and that gives me a 100% success rate with Kickstarter games.
  
Watching the game develop and change over the years has been a treat.  The final product is an amazing game that is clearly developed by people who love this genre.  Hat girl is a cute and fun main character and brings a warm, friendly feel to the game. 

Pros:
- Controls are precise
- Beautiful environments
- Different environments for each "world"
- Great soundtrack
- Lots of hidden things to find and reasons to explore

Cons:
- Kind of short (to be fair more content is coming and there is a beta for mod support already)
- The story isn't super fleshed out

Overall I highly recommend this game if you're a fan of the Super Mario Sunshine/Banjo-Kazooie collectathon genre.

Avis subjectif: Un platformer 3D de qualité comme on en avait pas eu depuis longtemps ! Univers attachant, monde de grande taille, du charme, et gameplay irréprochable. A Hat In Time a tout pour nous rappeller l'indétronable Mario 64 dans son gameplay.
Le jeu est suffisament long pour son prix (environs 20h).
Et surtout, le jeu est complètement ouvert au modding. Déjà de nombreux skins sont disponible par les moddeur, et encore plus de monde!

Conclusion : Si vous cherchez un platformer 3D qui vous ramène à l'âge d'or du genre, n'allez pas voir ailleurs. C'est le meilleur niveau qualité prix du moment!

37045123.review:
A Hat in Time est très sincèrement un des meilleur jeu auquel il m'ait été donné de jouer récemment. Il réussi avec brio à remettre au goût du jour le platformer 3D grâce à un level design bien pensé, des niveaux diversifié et une bonne maîtrise des divers genres de jeu vidéo (même un petit passage type Survival Horror sans que ce soit bien méchant ou vraiment terrifiant, les codes de bases du genre sont respectés).

La mécanique principale est le chapeau qui donne des pouvoirs et qu'il est possible de changer pour dévérouiller de nouveau pouvoirs et qui permet, au fur et à mesure que l'on débloque les dits chapeaux, de revisiter et redécouvrir les anciens mondes, permettant une bonne rejouabilité du titre. Rejouabilité encore plus accentuer par la présence de mod divers, certains ajoutant des chapeaux (parfois de simple skins mais également des chapeaux uniques avec des pouvoirs inédits !), d'autres ajoutant de nouveaux niveaux parfois fort bien pensés !

L'ambiance cute du titre ajoute à son charme et on prend plaisir à suivre la Hat Kid dans ses aventures pour collecter les sabliers éparpillés dans les divers mondes.

Bref, si l'on veut retrouver le plaisir de Mario 64 de l'époque ou si l'on a pas assez de monnaie pour se payer une Switch et Mario Odyssey, jetez-vous sur ce titre vraiment agréable (en plus, le chapeau de Mario Odyssey est disponible via un mod avec des pouvoirs similaires).

37031961.review:
かわいい（かわいい）主人公が、特殊能力が得られる帽子をいろいろ被ったりするかわいいアクションゲーム。
発売後そのかわいさとゲーム性の面白さから、ネットで順調に[strike]えっちなイラスト[/strike] ファンを増やし続ける作品。

アクションや、面クリア制のステージの感じとしては某サンシャインに近い。
そして各ステージでいろいろな能力を持った帽子を手に入れて進む感じは某ムジュラに近い。
そんな名作ゲーの息吹が感じられる作品が、面白くないわけないじゃない。

しかし、ただ他作品の影響が感じられるだけのゲームに留まっているわけではない。
この作品に登場するキャラクターは皆個性豊かで、オリジナリティーがあり、
新しいキャラクターに会うのもこのゲームの楽しみのひとつの楽しみになっている。
なによりキャラクターが皆かわいい。

アクションは難しすぎず簡単すぎずちょうどいい感じ。
アクションに慣れてる人ならある程度の横着プレイが出来そう。いい意味で。

そしてワークショップに対応している為、新たな帽子や服の色が日々誕生している。
順調にワークショップアイテムが増え続けている様に、
順調にこのゲームのファンも増え続けるであろう（上手い事言ったぁぁぁぁぁ！）

36961529.review:
I love this game, if you like 3D platformers; check this out you owe it to yourself.

That's the short review, if you want more hype then I'll expand upon that. I'd hear about this game for a while and was fairly excited about it. To be honest I was actually a little more exited for Yooka-Laylee, which wasn't terrible; but wasn't the revival of 3D platformers. THIS, a hat in time, is what we've been waiting for by far. I can't say enough how polished and loved this game is. You can see with every small detail of jump accesability. That might be a strange term to use. What I mean is that if you play platformers and you take away the graphics in your mind, you can see the "Track" that the developer wants you to take. I replayed "Psychonauts" another one of my favorite games, and I realized that there was definitely a set path they wanted you to take. You can see the world without the graphics and realize in your mind. So after a while you start to feel like you don't have the same freedom. In the 3D Mario games you have set paths, but people who are skilled can overcome them. That might have more to do with it being so long since a lot of them came out. Sometimes using glitches, if you watch speed runners that is. A hat in time says if you see it, there is probably more than one way to reach it. I've watched reviews of people playing it and nobody does it the same way, that's a testiment to the games love and care. It almost looks like how Sonic games perform, where you see people just naturally navigating, as if the game were on rails. However unlike sonic, It's not on rails. 

I really can't say enough, I'd have to do a video review to do it justice. I'm making this now because this game needs more good reviews, it has overwelmingly good reviews; however it got overshadowed by cuphead because games journalists suck at playing games. Which is a shame because this game really deserves more attention. I think over time it will become known as a classic, it already has a cult following. Please try this game. It's more than worth your time.

36959922.review:
Wow, this game really blew my expectations out of the water. Coming into this, I expected it to be a somewhat enjoyable platformer, but the $30 dollar price tag for an Indie game kinda had me suspicious. After "100%-ing" the game (collecting all the time pieces and relics), I can fully say that this game was MORE than worth the price tag. The music is beautifully composed (my favorites being from the boss fights), the characters are extremely lovable and memorable, each act and each chapter are all unique (and god forbid, ACTUALLY fun), and it's blooming with creativity. I loved going along with the Conductor's batshit insane movies, I loved the legitamately creepy atmosphere of Queen Vanessa's Manor, I loved zipping around Alpine Skyline, each second of this game was magnificent and enjoyable at the same time. And though it isn't perfect at times (I was kinda disappointed about the ending), you can definetly tell all the hard work and love that the creators over at Gears for Breakfast put into this masterpiece. Yooka-Laylee tried to rejuvenate the feeling of old platformer collect-a-thons by retreading old ground, while A Hat in Time captured that essense by creating something entirely new and refreshing.

And though I know A Hat in Time won't be winning any big-time awards soons (being released incredibly near games like Mario Odyssey and Cuphead), it is one of the best Indie platformers, and one of the best Indie games I have ever played.

36927247.review:
The game is very good from start to finish though it felt a bit short. The game has nailed many things well and because of it, it's a pretty fun experience.

Positives:
-Good controls. Whether you use a Keyboard+Mouse or a controller is up to you but regardless, the game still feels smooth. Running around is fun and air dashing feels very satisfying to pull off. 
-Decent OST. The music in this game is top notch. It's well made and is pretty catchy. Same goes to the remixes. 
-Memorable characters. Everyone you meet from the mafias to the goats are interesting whether it's their characteristics or their appearance. Voices ain't bad for me at least. 
-Good level layout. For the most part, the levels are made well in a sense that going from point A to point B is not boring. Accompanied by the good controls, it's pretty fun to explore the areas of the game. Just don't get lost.
-The game looks beautiful. It's nice to look at the environment because of how vivid and interesting they look.
-Mods can be implemented. The good thing about this is that aside from appearance changes, it's possible to play different player made levels with their own unique functions which keeps the game from being stale. But as of now, it's still in beta so keep that in mind.

Negatives:
-The game feels short. I'm aware that the game isn't finished yet since I heard that there would be 2 more worlds and a co-op mode but as of now, it still managed to entertain but not that long.
-Bugs and glitches. Though I encountered some, it doesn't make the game unplayable but it doesn't stop it from being annoying. At least the devs are constantly patching things out to remove them.
-Some hats feel under-powered while some are too good. [spoiler]The final boss is easy because of the time stopping hat.[/spoiler]
-From what I remember, the lighting has some small issues in a way on how they are placed/implemented.

Overall the game is pretty good. Play it since it's worth your time.

36909640.review: I originally planned to buy Yooka-Laylee. I then saw tons of negative things about it, as well as a lot of people talking about this game. I decided to look into it and it looked fun and cute. A Hat In Time ended up being far more fun and enjoyable than I originally thought. The movement is fluid, snappy, and responsive. The levels are expansive and fun to explore. Not to mention the secret items to collect in said levels. The game is very well written, the game made me genuinley laugh more than a few times. The story isn't anything insanely complex or thought provoking, but it dosen't need to be in a game like this. It's simple, straightforward, and fun. All the various hats that you find throughout your journey are all fun to use, and the final stage makes use of all of them. The music is breathtaking, the soundtrack is incredibly well done and a complete pleasure to listen to. This game had me smiling from ear to ear the entire way though. This game fully scratched the itch for a great 3D platformer/collectothon that I had left from Banjo Kazooie/Mario 64 and Sunshine. A Hat In Time is an absolute joy to play through and I cannot stress enough how much I recommend it.

36902771.review:
At least 100,000 children are prostituted annually in the U.S., adding to the $9.8 billion U.S. sex trafficking industry. Children all over the country are subject to physical and sexual abuse, and most of the time it happens a lot closer to home than we would expect. Ninety percent of child sexual abuse victims know the perpetrator, and an astonishing 68% are abused by family members.

What’s worse, some of the laws surrounding child sexual abuse and child marriage (or lack thereof) actually enable their practice. As a result, more than 200,000 children in the U.S. were married in the past 15 years alone. We often view child marriage as only being an issue in third-world countries, but in reality, it occurs right here in North America, too. Children as young as 10 have been married to far older adults, despite the legal requirement to wed being 18, or legal adulthood, nationwide.

This is because many states have “legal loopholes” that allow adults to marry children. Not all states are willing to provide statistics on this problem, and many have provided only some details rather than the full scope, so that 200,000 is likely far below the real number of American child brides and grooms.

In May of this year, the Republican governor of New Jersey declined an offer to sign a law that would have made New Jersey the first state to ban child marriage without exception. Many people probably assume that child marriage is illegal in the U.S., but the sad reality is that these loopholes allow children to get married at a very young age. In New Jersey alone, approximately 3,500 children were married between 1995 and 2012.

The governor claimed that signing the law would have “conflicted with religious customs.” Some of these loopholes include if the child has gotten pregnant or if the child receives parental consent. Can you imagine your parents arranging a marriage for you, prior to the age of 18? Yes, this is the reality for many people all over the world, but few realize this happens in America too. Alternatively, could you imagine getting pregnant at the young age of 13 and then being forced to wed? This is a terrifying reality for many victims of child marriage.

207,468 minors are known to have been married in the U.S. between 2000 and 2015, but 10 states provided absolutely no data or inaccurate statistics on child marriage, so this number does not reflect the true scope of the issue. Of this number, most of the children were girls who were married to much older men, and many were as young as 13. Eighty-seven percent of these minors were girls, and although the majority were aged 16 or 17, many were much younger.

Amongst the youngest to get married were three 10-year-old girls in Tennessee, who married men between the ages of 24 and 31. Another young boy was married at the age of 11 to a 27-year-old woman in the same state.

It’s not just Tennessee; children as young as 12 were married in Alaska, Louisiana, and South Carolina, and 11 other states permit 13-year-old children to get married. Keep in mind that, in most of these cases, the minors were marrying older adults, not other minors. Only 14% of these minors were actually marrying other minors, but even still, is it really okay for a 17-year-old to marry a 13-year-old?

Although most of them married adults no older than 30, in some cases, children were permitted to marry adults decades older than them. There was one case in Alabama where a 14-year-old girl married a 74-year-old man, and another in Idaho in which a 17-year-old married a 65-year-old man.

Let’s remember that, although most states recognize that sexual consent can be granted by those aged 16 to 18, a person can still be charged with statutory rape for having sex with a minor. Despite this, many states are granting children with marriage licenses, including minors who are much younger than 16.

Senior Counsel for Policy and Strategy at Tahirih Justice Centre Jeanne Smoot explained that most of the children who get married as minors are those living in poverty. She stated: “Almost all the evidence indicates that girls in cities don’t get married young, that girls from middle class or wealthy families, don’t get married young. This is a rural phenomenon and it is a phenomenon of poverty.”

An astonishing 27 states don’t even have laws to set an “age floor,” meaning that no laws exist to establish the youngest age a minor can get married. Loopholes like this one are what allow minors to get married in the first place. The irony is that sexual abuse is “illegal,” yet the government is allowing minors to get married as young as 10 years old. What do these judges expect will occur in these marriages? This is not a way to protect these children, as child marriage can enable abuse and pedophilia.

It’s clear that child marriage isn’t just an issue in third-world countries. If we truly want to become leaders in this world and set the stage for other countries, we need to reflect that both in our laws and in our morals. Children deserve rights and protection, and this desperately needs to be reflected in our judiciary system.

36899662.review:
[h1][b] Introduction [/b][/h1]

A Hat in Time is one of those kickstarted games that took years to develop and release, but the wait was worth it as it completely delivers.
It's a 3D platformer-collectathon, inspired by the N64 and Gamecube 3D platformers, games like Super Mario 64, Super Mario Sunshine, The legend of Zelda: The windwaker, Banjo kazooie/Tooie, it's all here and the similarities are as clear as water.

[h1][b]The Game [/b][/h1]

The star of the game is this unnamed girl with a fancy top hat, who loses the time pieces that she uses as fuel for her spaceship in a confusing accident with a member of the mafia from the planet she was flying by. After landing on mafia town she meets this red-hooded girl with a mustache, who only seeks to bring justice to this world, but this friendship only lasts until the mysterious mustached girl discovers the powers hidden in the time pieces. 

[h1][b]Characters [/b][/h1]

A Hat in Time characters are full of charm, the mafia members are just a bunch of dummies and some of them don't even know how to react when a child confronts them. The red hooded mustache girl has a brave personality, her goal to bring justice to the world and defeat the mafia is a mentality that fits, after all she's just a child.
The characters from the next chapters are amazing too, full of personality, you just can't not love the conductor, even if he's just a prick to you.
The main character Hat Kid is full of charm, this cute "silent" protagonist shows a lot of expressions in her movements and actions, stuff like the using her finger as a gun in the detective level, her warcry agaisnt the mafia when she gets her umbrella and her reaction to the last contract in chapter 3 are some of the cutest moments this protagonist has.

[h1][b]Gameplay [/b][/h1]

The game controls are fantactic, Hat Kid controls like Mario in SM64 but with a fully functional controlled camera, you can wall jump, slide, double jump, slide after a double jump for maximum distance, you can cancel your air-slide by jumping and fix your landing, etc. The combat in this game isn't super deep, you got your close range umbrella to hit enemies and your homing glide attack, but at the end you don't need more than that as combat isn't this game main point.

[h1][b]Music [/b][/h1]

The game music is top notch, they fit really well in each chapter and fight, won't go deep into this category to avoid spoilers, but themes like Picture Perfect, Crazy Science Owls, Clock Towers Beneath the Sea and Your Contract has Expired are some of the best tunes you'll find in this game, and each of them fit so well in their chapter/level.


[b]Pros[/b]

+Amazing Gameplay, you have full control of Hat Kid and the camera around her
+Great music
+Fun levels, each with different and very unique objectives, you'll never play the same level twice.
+Devs are actively listening to the community, releasing patches and changes constantly.
+Modding support, if the main game and hats weren't enough for you then this will give you a lot of content to explore.


[b]Cons[/b]

-Game is pretty short, two extra chapters will be released in the future, but currently the game can be easily completed in a few hours.
-The game has quite a few bugs, thankfully most of them are just graphical and animation errors
-The game ending isn't very fulfilling (This may change with the release of the next chapters, but we'll see, until then it just doesn't feel like a good end to the story)


[h1][b]Final Words [/b][/h1]

A Hat in Time is one of the best platformers I've played and one of the best games that has been released in this year, if you grew up playing the firsts 3D platformer games from the N64 and PlayStation era, you'll love this game, definetly a must buy, and if you didn't, still, give this game a try, the cute-sie aesthetics and the character's charm is something that everyone with good taste will appreciate.

Definetly a must buy.

A Hat in Time is a simple, cute, light-hearted, fun, platformer that makes you realize that bad guys aren't so bad after all... 

Just kidding.

First of all, the game looks beautiful. Each world looks unique. From the landscape to its life-form, it's easy to distinguish one world from another. The maps are quite "large" and open-world; which encourages you to stray away from the main quest and explore, find secrets, and get those seemingly unreachable stuff. Main puzzles also vary among maps and worlds, where certain types of obstacles are emphasized. Beating these puzzles and their boss fights aren't that difficult. Maybe a bit easy, but they're enjoyable at most. 

The story is fairly simple but it isn't bad at all. There's nothing much to say on the characters except that they are a fun bunch even though they lack depth and backstory. At some point I also realized some characters aren't voiced at certain times where they should be, I hope the devs can fix them soon. 

A Hat in Time may not be that popular, partly because it came out the same time as Cuphead did; but I would still rate up this game. Anyway the soundtrack of this game is really amazing. Hats off to the composer.

36860332.review: Dear sweet lord where to begin, the game controls absolutely beautifully, I always feel like everything Im doing is what Im actually trying to input. Its wonderful both casually and as a speed game, you can easily beat everything in the game with your assortment of hats, your wallkicking, double jump and your dive and dive cancel. However the advanced movement options in this game lend it to also be run incredibly fast, sliding down hills to pick up speed, hitting the small window where you hit the ground and cancel your dive and shoot off with a burst of speed, the sprint hat and the level design, it all leads to wacky tricks and ways to navigate even the most seemingly linear levels. The music is absolutely captivating and has dominated my workout playlists for quite a while now, and most of the tracks in the game have official remixes that are just as excellent as the originals!! The characters are lovable and interesting and memorable, the conductor the snatcher and hat kid herself are very well ingrained in my mind. The graphics are good but not outstanding, they arent next gen crazy super realistic hyper textures, but it has that wonderful cell shaded charm that looks inviting and familiar, which does wonders combined with the games general atmosphere and charm. Howerver after updates there are still minor graphical glitches that can happen, and as said the graphics while they do have that nice appeal to them arent exactly anything new. The games length isnt all too loing in all honesty, I think my rushed playthorugh was maybe about 12 hours or so, but Ive since replayed the game and messed around with the community mods and tried speedrunning sections of the game, its just a genuienly fun time and I dont think Ive ever been happier with waiting for a game.

36857561.review: This game, though very short for what it is, it a heck of a lot of fun. It's a Kickstarter title in case you didn't know, but unlike a lot of the disaster scenarios that website produces, this game is a rousing success in that you can tell the developers were very careful in what they used their fixed budget on. The graphics, for instance, are simplistic, but stylized in a way that makes them vibrant and pleasing. Rather than desperately try for a "full-length" experience padded out with lackluster content, they put extra effort into fewer levels to really make the experience shine. This does leave you wanting more by the end, but that feeling is a testament to the quality of the content that is there. I might advise the more financially conservative to wait for a sale to ensure a good dollars-to-hours-of-fun ratio, but I'd advise anyone who likes 3D platforming to give this game a chance.

36849662.review:
It's been quite some time since I've played a 3D platformer that's put a smile on my face all the way through the game. So much of it oozes charm...from its visuals, music, characters, story and gameplay. The game is from the perspective of a small child and as a result the world is framed in a sense of childhood wonder, everything in the game is so bizarre but it's such a delight to go through that you'll be looking forward to what the next chapter has instore.

The game controls so well, it'll be a challenge to find 3D platformer outside of Nintendo that controls better. The camera also isn't a problem as you have free control of it, this can make judging the distance between platforms much easier than a lot of others in the genre. There's so much variety to find in this game, it  changes the gameplay style every few missions but it never becomes an irritation, everything in this game is so well thought out and has a purpose. It never feels like it's trying to pad the game out.

As for performance, the games visuals can look outdated but the artstyle carries the game so well that I doubt many will find it a distraction. As a result even outdated gaming PCs so be able to run it with no problems, the options menu also helps as you can dial back settings for a smoother experience. I only have 2 main problems with the game; due to the age of the engine almost every update is 2GB, this can be quite tiresome after some time. The other is the length of the game, it took me about 10 hours to 100% the game. It's not a long game but thanks to free updates in the future and mod support I doubt the length of the game will be a problem for most people.

3D platformers are now a niche genre so you don't see many being released but I'm glad that this game turned out to be one of the most entertaining platformers I've played in almost a decade.
