36749444.review:
Video Review: https://youtu.be/ZmxR99LCPlU

A Hat in Time is a collection of my favourite classic games condensed into a small perfected package. Taking inspiration from famous 3D platformers such as Super Mario Sunshine,  this game is a masterpiece of fun, fluid platforming. This mastery combined with the personality that has been imbued into every aspect of it, creates a game that is fun throughout

Basically, you play as the adorable space faring Hat Kid, who has lost the fuel to her spaceship in a parking toll incident and now has to traverse the world to reacquire her fuel so she can fly home. During her travels she interacts a number of people on the planet, such as helping Moustache Girl in her war against the Mafia of Cooks, participating in a Bird Film Festival and signing contracts with fucking Satan.

Levels are varied in objective, only the secret levels being a simple point A-B adventure. For example, in one level you work for my favourite character, the Conductor, on his Owl Express train to solve a murder mystery, and in a another you play a remastered version of Luigi’s Mansion. The movement Hat Kid can use to traverse these levels is tight and it’s basic to learn, hard to master nature makes for engaging platforming. 

And then there are the boss fights- Oh boy the boss fights. Never before did I think I would be fighting a TOILET OF DOOM to rock music in order to save the forest (A Hat in Time, sponsored by the National Forest foundation.) However, the bosses overall are teeny little bit too easy for my liking, the only difficulty being in figuring out what to do in certain battles, but the fun of the fights makes up for it. 

The icing on the cake is the music; Pascal Michael Stiefel or Plasma3Music composed an excellent soundtrack that rivals Banjo Kazooie and Donkey Kong Country in amazingness. I don’t really know how to describe the music in a way that does it justice, so go to the A Hat in Time official YouTube channel and have a listen. Just do it, you won’t regret it.

So with all that in consideration; the characters, the levels, the music, my addiction - do I recommend a Hat in Time? For $30 USD it’s entirely worth it.

36703479.review:
I don't often review games on Steam, so excuse the poor formating of this post please.

A Hat in Time is one of those few games that come out every once and a great while, and remind me how in our modern world of loot boxes and DLC, we can still have great complete games come out. Hat in Time not only exceeded my expectations, it built new ones for me to use in the future when judging new titles.

A Hat in Time is full of charm and all sorts of heart. This project was definitely a work of great passion from the devs, and for that I applaud them. Every level is bright, colorful, and unique, and the graphics and the wonderful music (props to composer) bring everything together to make this game a lovely jaunt. 

The only thing involving Hat in Time that I didn't like is the length. I feel as if the game was so great that I almost wish the devs do DLC so I can enjoy the game for more time. They have said that there will be content updates as well, adding co-op play and more. I can't wait.

It's truly ashame that this game released so close to Super Mario Oddysey. If it had been released much earlier, it might have gotten the publicity and praise it deserves. 

Thank you Gears for Breakfast for helping to bring 3D platformers back into the main stream. You folks did great work and I can't thank you enough. 

Strong reccomendation.

36688169.review:
This. Game. Is. Adorable.

I went in to this game expecting an indie budget title with fairly loose controls, passable graphics, and gameplay just interesting enough for a 4 hour playtime tops. What I got was so much more than that I was blown away. Not only does this game do a great job of capturing that collectathon platformer feel of old, but it does so much to stand above and beyond that. It has its own ideas, its own feel and its own charm that make it shine on its own.

I feel like the most important thing this game has is a great sense of world building. While it's 40 Time Pieces might seem small in comparison to Mario 64's 120 stars, Banjo-Kazooie's 100 Jiggies, or even Spyro 2's 64 Orbs, it's what you go through to collect these Time Pieces that make the game what it is. Every single Time Piece is its own story. Every last mission seems to have a plot connected to it. They'll take you through different sections of the level, introduce entirely new gameplay mechanics, captivate you with new characters, and charm you with all of the unique ideas this game is packed with.

Because of this the game never feels stale. You never feel like you're running through the same areas, repeating the same tasks, collecting things for the sake of collecting them. Every Time Piece is a joy to collect. From impressing millions of fans as a movie star, breaking into the Mafia's kitchen to fight the head chef, or even crawling your way through a mansion trying to hide from a surprisingly scary ghost, there's so much of this game you'll cherish and remember long after completing it.

The graphics are very cute overall. Worlds are huge and detailed with no noticible slowdown or struggle. The characters are well designed and memorable and while some corners have been cut in facial detail or animation, none of it ever detracts from the game's vivid, adorable style. The artwork that appears before every stage is another welcome addition to the game, looking stunning while lending even more charm and love to this game.

The controls are amazingly tight. Hat Kid moves exactly like you want her to. Turns and jumps never feel too floaty, special abilities are easy to cycle through and perform. Upgrades are easily equipped and never seem like a hassle to execute. Jumps and dives can be performed and cancelled out of with amazing percision. Everything from navigating Hat Kid's base to tackling the game's hardest platforming challenges never feel like the controls are holding you back. It's a welcome feeling in a genre full of hard to control indie titles.

The sound fits perfectly around the game's atmosphere, providing it with all sorts of adorable and fitting sound effects. For the most part, the voice acting is diverse and a great fit for the characters. Sound effects make collecting items, attacking enemies and interacting with the environments even more enjoyable (my favorite is hitting a friendly NPC and getting that squeeky toy sound). The music not only fits in well with the game's stages, but with the feel of the game and genre as a whole. I haven't caught myself humming any of the tunes personally, but certain songs like the beautiful Time Rift music, or the wonderfully Grant Kirkhope main lobby are a joy to listen to.

This game is oozing with charm and personality, but doesn't lean on it like a crutch. The gameplay, controls and mechanics hold up wonerfully on their own and it's nice to get a game like this that doesn't feel like you're sacrificing one poor aspect of the game to try and appreciate the others. While A Hat in Time isn't completely flawless, I'm struggling to think of any faults the game may have that's taken me out of the experience long enough to question loving this game.

Any 3D Platforming fan should give this game a shot. If you're a fan of the older collectathons like Mario or Banjo, looking for another new experience similar to (and arguably better than) Yooka-Laylee, or just think the game looks adorable and you're sitting on the fence due to gameplay concerns, jump right in and give it a shot. A Hat in Time has clearly put the effort into every aspect, coming together for a solid package that's well worth a playthrough.

36656688.review:
먼저, 게임에 대해 평가하기 앞서서 이전에 슈퍼마리오64를 재밌게 하셨던 분이라면 추천할만 합니다. 단, 삼만원이 조금 적지않은 돈이다 하시는 분은 세일할 때 구매해주세요. 게임이 나온지 별로 안되어 언제 할지는 모르겠습니다만 개인적으로는 2만원정도면 적당하지 않았나 싶었네요.
 
그럼 본론으로 들어가 세부적으로 설명해드리겠습니다. 물론 제 주관적인 의견이고 악의성인 의견도 있으니 참고만 해주세요.
 
[b]게임성 및 조작[/b]: ★★★☆☆
전체적으로 플레이타임은 약간 짧은편입니다. 수집하고 맵 열고, 수집하고 맵 열고 결국 엔딩을 보는것까지의 거리는 자신이 얼마나 이 게임에 몰입하는지에 달린것같습니다. 키보드보단 xbox패드가 있다면 그걸로 꼭 플레이 하시는걸 추천드립니다. 마우스 감도 및 키보드 조작이 생각보다 불편하거든요.. 그리고 이런 캐쥬얼 게임은 키보드보다 패드가 더 재밌고 조작이 편할 수 있습니다. 물론 이게임도요. 

두번째로는 조작감이 생각보다 안좋습니다. 시점 넘기는것도 힘들고 특히 어느부분에서는 시점이 고정되어 더욱 불편하게 만드네요. 보고싶은곳을 마음대로 못보는 이 느낌... 정말 힘들었습니다.
 
마지막으로 별점을 깎게만든 요인은 몰입할 수 있도록 하는 기능적 요소가 충분하지 않다고 생각합니다. 초반 액트와 후반부 보라색배경 늪 부분에서는 맵이 넓어서 내가 무엇을 해야하는지 찾기가 힘들고 그로인해 많은 지루함을 겪습니다. 저도 처음에 뭘 해야 하는거지? 설명하나 없이 이렇게 보내면 답이 나오는건지? 라고 생각만 했으니깐요. 그만큼 게임 내 미션을 이해하기 힘들고 찾아가기가 힘듭니다.

[b]재미[/b]: ★★★★☆
전에 슈퍼마리오64를 했던 플레이어로써 비슷한 장르의 게임이 나와서 그런지 흥미가 떨어지지는 않았습니다. 하지만 게임성 부분에서 언급했다싶이 맵은 큰데 찾아야하는건 모자 효과로도 찾지못하고 빙빙돌다가 액트 하나에 30분이상 낭비하였고 그로인해 재미가 떨어졌습니다. 그런데 그게 초반이라 더더욱 미치게 만들었네요; 하지만 다음 스테이지를 가면 갈수록 미션이 점점 쉬워졌으며 중간중간 나오는 보스 스테이지도 재밌었습니다. 공략을 보지 않고 패턴 하나하나 분석하여 직접 공략하는 묘미 말이죠
 
[b]스토리[/b]: ?
아직은 영어밖에 지원 안하지만 한글화를 하시는분들이 있기때문에 곧 나오겠지만 영어에 대해 아무것도 모르는 사람은 스토리를 이해하기가 약간 힘들 수 있습니다. 하지만, 게임의 특성상 사진과 이펙트 및 연출로 무엇을 하라는지 알아낼 수 있습니다. 나는 영어가 조금 무리가 있다 하시는분은 한글패치가 나왔을 때 플레이하시면 더욱 재밌게 플레이 할 수 있습니다. 그리고 무엇보다도 초반부분과 마지막 엔딩 빼고는 스토리가 거의 없으니 걱정마세요! 이 부분에 대해서는 호불호가 갈릴수 있기 때문에 평가를 하지 않았습니다.
 
[b]진입장벽[/b]: ★★★☆☆
처음에 뭘 해야 하는거지? 모자를 왜 주는거지? 이러면서 당황하기 시작하고 게임을 진행합니다. 물론 제 친구도 제 상황이랑 똑같이 겪어 제가 알려주기 전까지는 어느 방식으로 플레이 해야하는지도 모른채 맵만 이동하고 있었습니다. 그만큼 초반에 무엇을 해야하는지 잘 안알려주고 이게 무슨 효과가 있는지도 모릅니다. 맨 처음 모자를 꼈을때 설명도 키를 눌러 해야할것을 찾으세요 이런식이었으니깐요. 
 
[b]BGM[/b]: ★★★★★
작지도않고 크지도않은 적절한 ost, 마지막 엔딩에서는 더욱 빛을 내더군요.

36642402.review:
Controls: 10/10
Custom Gameplay: 10/10
Boss Battles: 9/10
Charm: 10/10
Bugs: 8/10
Mission Variety: 10/10
Exploration: 10/10
Combat: 8/10
Music: 10/10

I usually don't write reviews, but I feel people need to play this game.

An improvement on even the giant collectothons classics in many ways. Tightest controlling 3D platformer I've ever played-- It truly rises to the standards set by Banjo Kazooie and Super Mario 64. Tons of non-essential cosmetic rewards.

No collecting every single music note in the level shenanigans. (You are incentivized to collecting pons en mass, but the game balances around giving you enough if you are collecting them on your way. You don't have to resort to hunting down the 3 you might have missed in a single run.)

There are rewards for progress both in unlocking abilities, and many unlockables that don't impact the game but are still rewarding to earn.

There were occasional bugs, but they were unimportant and rare enough that I barely noticed them. Took me roughly 19 hours to 100%. In that way, the game is much shorter than the N64 bigger buget versions. Still worth every penny.

I never write reviews, but I can't sing my praises about this game enough.

As you may know, A Hat in Time is a callback to platformers such as Banjo-Kazooie and Mario 64.
It does what Yooka-Laylee [i]wishes[/i] it could do.

The controls are absolutely fantastic, the humor is incredibly on point and reminiscent if the aforementioned Banjo-Kazooie, and it runs absolutely fantastic on my not-so-modern rig. It doesn't get too challanging which is a tiny little gripe, but it's such a small complaint I won't remove any points.

It has really neat Workshop support, and really extends the life of this fun (if a little short) game.

It's cute-as-heck. 10/10

36635488.review:
Played this though with my girlfriend watching. We both througly enjoyed  the game. It's cute as heck, the controls are slick, and it's all in all a beatiful game. 
A quick and dirty pro and cons: 
Pros: 
+ Really good controls
+ Great soundtrack
+ Every world is different
+ Cute as heck, and a beautiful game
+ Took us 15 hours to complete the story and get all time pieces. (good value in my mind)

Cons: 
- Sometimes the wallrunning ability dosen't quite do what you want. But it is mostly when running up things that are not square. So most encounteted later on in the game, and not too many times. 
- We both enjoyed the first and the last world the most. The "Shadow" and "Movie" world it not as open, and you feel quite restricted in the movie one. Though, the shadow really opens up in the end. 
- Sometime you would get forced akward camera angles. 
- More hats that changes colour would be nice. 

Buy: YES! ABSOLUTELY! 

Longer version: The game is really one of the better ones I've played in a long time. The controls just feels right, and almost always does what you want. As noted in the cons, sometimes wallrunning fucks up, it's restricted to round objects in the "last" world, but still awarded me with ~10-20 lost lives. 
As noted aswell, It feels like the game mode changes though out the game, some will like this, others wont. While I didn't love the movie world, the writing was exellenct and really made me like it even so. 
other than that, just really enjoyable all around.

36616567.review:
[b]TL;DR below if you don't wanna read my gushing.[/b]

This game is honestly just magical. I can't exactly put my finger on what it is about it that makes me so happy, but I can try. I don't really leave reviews, but man, this game. While it lacks a bit of polish in some areas (a lot of it being worked on for some updates post-release, some already fixed) it makes up for all of it with the entire rest of the game.

The game oozes charm (in the least gross way possible) and the controls and platforming are tight and a load of fun. It's fun and responsive. Really just the result of what must amount to years of work and playtesting to get everything feeling good. I'm sure almost all players, be they new to 3D platformers or veterans of the genre, can easily pick up and have fun with the game. It teaches what you need to succeed, and there's plenty to challenge you if you let it.

In regards to the world and the design, it's [i]superb.[/i] Every character has just that. Character. Everyone's lively, fun, and sometimes chaotic. But it all feels like it belongs. There's never really anything that felt like it shouldn't have been there. While the story isn't extremely fleshed out with a tons of backstory and lore and such, I think the devs realized that, as a whole, it didn't really need to be. The world just needed feel fun and alive as you played. It's a platformer. You don't exactly stop and read hundreds of logs in a game like this. The witty dialogue along with great character and level design conveys all it needs to. The big, goofy, incompetent Mafia of Cooks. The timid Express Owls, snazzy Moon Penguins, and their loud, competitive bosses The Conductor and DJ Grooves. The Snatcher and all things spooky in his Subcon Forest. All of it comes together to give you something that's fun, varied, and interesting but that never really feels out of place.

To top it off, the developers are extremely friendly and active on forums and their discord and such. They respond to things like bug reports, questions, requests, etc. The game also has modding support (in beta as of this writing) that already has a bunch of neat little levels, custom hats and color schemes, and more. The devs have been helpful to players and modders alike to help keep this game alive, and I adore that. I can only imagine when workshop support fully releases that the surge in people will only mean more great content. This game has reinvigorated my interests in game design that I honestly thought I'd lost.

Now I can't just gloss over the flaws. It has quite a few, however minor they may be. Visually, some character models seem a little off, but it's hard to put your finger on why most of the time, though this is rare. And, while it may be a style choice, the 2D facial expression system isn't super polished in my opinion, as it feels very static and lacks a lot of the expression you get from some of the voice actors. You can also sometimes see eyes or mouths overlapping in certain expressions and cutscenes. There's also voice acting for almost the entire game, but eerily missing from certain sections where you'd expect them most. I believe the devs said they're going to add some of those lines post release, but I'm not certain.

I've also personally had some minor performance issues in certain sections of the game that I wouldn't expect given the seemingly non-demanding nature of the graphics. This on a somewhat more powerful machine sporting a GTX 1080 and plenty RAM. These instances happen rarely, but namely on Alpine Skyline (which seems to make sense given its open nature) and at the beginning of Subcon Forest when the walls of fire are still up. It's mostly fine later on in that level.

Regardless, while these flaws are noticeable, they never truly seemed to detract from what the rest of the game had to offer. I'd notice them and just go, "eh, oh well" and continue my game. In times of less than optimal performance, I just dropped the graphics a bit to help stabilize the framerate. Yet the wonderful environments didn't really seem to lose any of their vibrancy and charm. Nothing truly stopped me from wanting the see the rest of the game.

Oh, and about my hours, it's not all game time. I have an extremely bad habit of forgetting to exit games when multitasking and leaving them on when I put my computer to sleep. While I've definitely spent more time than the average player in this game (I'm guessing 40 or 50-ish?), I'd say average hours would likely be around 8-14 depending on how much time you spend exploring and doing things, as well as if you decide to 100% the game, which isn't a chore like it may sound in other games.

[b]TL;DR:[/b] An amazing little gem of a 3D platformer that hits a sweet spot that other recent attempts at revivals haven't managed. Cute, fun, witty, and just overall very charming, though with some minor bugs and flaws. You come for the tight, fun platforming and stay for the wonderful little world you've stumbled upon. And also the platforming again because it's still just as fun as when you started.

Damn solid 9/10. Can't wait for full workshop release and the 2018 DLC + co-op.

36608477.review:
I came into this game blindly and was blown away at everything. To start, the gameplay: Feels familiar to Super Mario 64 for me, the way the physics in the game along with how nice the controls feel is just something amazing (used a PS4 controller) and everything is very simplistic but you can do insane stuff with this. This is a game where almost everything can be done by sheer skill alone, there are things from the story that make things easier (as well as some that are necessary to progress) but you can get most things just by careful jumps and momentum. 

The atmosphere feels alive, the music is very well done and complimented each area very well along with the remixed versions of the songs. The art style brings everything to life, it can appropriately set the tone with keeping the cutesy art style, the animations look very nice and gets extra points for matching characters so well. There's very small details that this game gets done and I would have definitely missed if I rushed through, this game is one where I actively took my time as it felt rewarding for exploring.

The story is very captivating as the main arc is there but you still feel intrigued with all the side characters and their stories. I should mention the voice acting in the game is amazing, each actor nailed their character and conveyed the humour very well. 

This game should not be too difficult aside from a few parts for seasoned platformers, it has a fixed difficulty but there's a collectable that can make you die in 1-hit if you want to add more challenge which the game does reward. The bosses in the game suit each area very well with each having their own little gimmicks so each fight doesn't feel repetitive.

The only real downsides I have with this game is that there was a few areas where the game restricts the movement with certain walls and a few times where a very specific spot didn't work on one or two occasions. The other thing was I experienced 2 game crashes but they were minor and this game has a very good checkpoint system so I didn't really lose that much progress and for me 2 crashes in the time I played is very good.

Overall in combination with the story, the art, animation, voice acting, gameplay, soundtrack, comes together and creates an experience which I won't forget any time soon. This sets a good example of what a 3D platformer should be like and I'm proud to give this game a 10/10, you should definitely buy this game and give it a chance to impress you.

Certain saut demandant de la précision sont assez retord.
Peut-être un peu court mais.

En conclusion, un excellent jeu où on ne voit pas le temps passer quand on y joue. Si vous êtes fan de mario 64, banjo&kazooie ou encore mario sunshine, vous pouvez vous jetez sur ce jeu les yeux fermé.

36598448.review:
I got that game, expecting a weak Mario 64 clone, so I wasn't expecting much, since I'm not really into 3D platformer.
Long story short, I ended up liking it far more than I should. You probably don't care about my story, so I'll keep it short.

Flaws :
- controls take some time to get used to, especially if you're used to Mario. The controls are similar to these, but not identical, so until you have them down, you're going to land in a lava a few times,
- the voice acting is not that good. Some voices are nice, others are below average. Apparently, people who backed the developpement voiced the game, so it's more an issue of fanservice than hiring professional,
- a bit too short, and maybe too easy. The former is an issue, the latter is a matter of taste. Just be warned that it's not Super Meat Boy 3D.

Now, for the good parts :
- once you have the controls figured out, it's a real pleasure to jump around,
- the levels are memorable, and every one of them is unique,
- the musics are nice, some of them even good enough to be listened outside of the game,
- you have numerous interactions that serve no gameplay purpose, but help you get immersed in the game,
- the characters are charming, the protagonist's movement and poses constantly remind you that she's a kid and that she's (mostly) having fun,
- the game is quite easy, so it fits for a relaxing afternoon or after a hard day of work.
And finally, what I think is really important in a game like this : you, in most cases, have a way around obstacles. You can decide to go over it, to slide under it, or to go around it. It's something that I really liked. For example, in one time rift, there's a fence in the way. You're supposed to jump under it, and use the double jump to reach the platform. Instead of that, I jumped to the pylon supporting the fence, slided down until I was on the small platform supporting said pylon, then I walked around it, and from here, jumped to my goal. I haven't played a lot of platforming games, but I do enjoy the liberty of taking on a challenge as I see fit instead of trying to find the "right" way.

36581124.review:
[h1] Hats off to: A Hat in Time, an amazing callback to an old era of 3D platformers [/h1]

A Hat in Time is game that is a call back to earlier 3D platform collectatons such as Super Mario Sunshine. Now, I know what you're thinking: "It's a kickstarter game, it can't be good. It's just another example of devs who have half-heartedly made a game just to run away with the money." But, as someone who has 100% the game, collecting all Time pieces and unlocking the Steam achievements, I can gladly say that this is not another Yooka-Laylee which tries to sell it to you with obvious nostalgia pandering. But rather an original expereince that makes you remember how great that era was with it's amazing levels and tight controls.


[h1] The Good [/h1]

[b] Tight Controls [/b] - I cannot stress enough how amazing the controls are. You really need to try it yourself if you wish take my word for it. Hat Girl feels amazing to move around, with very reponsive controls and a variety of movement options to really give you a chance to get creative on how you want to move from Point A to Point B. You're giving a double jump, a dive, wall running, triangle jump, you can cancel the dive, a speed boost when you time your dive on the group giving you extra momentum, a sprint which gives you a long jump. Each and every option beautifully transitioning into the other. Its simply super satisfying to move her around and I would go as far to say it's almost good as Mario. 

[b] Creative level design [/b] - Albeit, some more than others. This game has kept my attention through it's immense creativity. It has that Mario 64/Sunshine asthetic for some levels where it's just a world that changes depending on the mission objectives. However each world is a well made playground, every step of the way complimenting how Hat girl moves around. It just fun to just run around the world, sometimes straying off the path of the main goal to grab a few extra collectables or find a couple of secrets. For example: [spoiler] One moment you're playing a pseudo-stealth mission, then a murder mystery, then a speed running challenge to escape a train on the brink of destruction, to brief surival horror section [/spoiler] Each world simply breaths atmosphere, never once the level felt bland. I should also mention there are levels that are similar to the "secret" levels in Sunshine, for that standard, but fun platforming challenge for added variety.

[b] Amazing Soundtrack [/b] - The sound track is simply great. Each song feeling wimsical to really bring out the sense of adventure. Also there's a unique track to every world, each being vibrant and lively to fit its surroundings. If you're curious, i'd recommend looking some of the tracks yourself.

[h1] The Bad [/h1]

[b] The game is short [/b] - Just as the subject says, it's fairly short. There's 40 in total time pieces to collect with 25 being enough to reach the finale. In addition, i've 100% it in a mostly leisure pace in around 14 hours. This may break it for some who wish to have a longer expereince for a $30 price. I too wished the game was longer as I wanted to continue playing, however I must say that within those 14 hours, I have yet to met a dull moment. So take it as you will

[b] It's fairly easy [/b] - Again, another deal breaker for some. The game plays pretty easy. There wasn't a moment in which I felt necessarily frustrated as it was mostly smooth sailing. You can make the game harder by equipping a badge that makes it so you have 1 health instead of 4, but that really doesn't excuse how easy this game was in its vanilla form. For those wishing for a challenging platformer, i'm sorry but this may be a bit disappointing for you in that department. However for those who just want a fun and sometimes challenging expereince, this game is for you. 

[b] "The Indie Polish" [/b] - This part is a bit subjective, so again, take it as you will. The game really has that indie polish in a negative sense. For instance, the faces look like images that weren't properly meshed onto their models and sometimes you can see the eyes clipping out of their head and other technical tidbits. This doesn't hinder gameplay in any sense, but it just leaves more to be desired, and I wish they fixed this.

[h1] The Result [/h1] 

The game, is fun. Not a moment in which I felt bored while playing this. I'd definately recommend to get this game if you are a fan of 3D mario games, or wish to have a fun platforming expereince. I promise you, you won't regret it.

36561528.review:
Diantre, j'avais jamais autant adoré un jeu depuis fort longtemps. D'aussi loin que je me souvienne, c'est d'ailleurs le seul jeu que j'ai laissé autant traîner dans la durée avant de le conclure, et qui m'a un peu pincé le coeur quand lui et moi nous sommes séparés.

Commençons par ses défauts:
- la caméra peut être dure à prendre en main pour certains (perso, je n'ai JAMAIS eu ce souci, mais un pote oui.)
- les sauts sont assez minutieux et le rebond contre les parois est un peu énervant tant qu'on ne l'a pas maîtrisé.
- le niveau de la parade est vraiment agaçant. (EDIT: agaçant la première fois, parce qu'une fois que tu le maîtrises, il est aussi fun que le reste.)

Voilà, c'est tout ! TOUT, vous dis-je, parce que du côté des points positifs, on a:
- Une bande son qui est au top du top ! (non, vraiment, il n'y a que de la bonne, même les remix)
- un très bon level design qui utilise intelligement les mécaniques qu'il met à disposition le long du jeu et donne envie d'y rejouer sans te forcer la main (j'ai eu envie de collecter tout les objets possibles, tellement il m'offrait de possibilités), et offre une courbe de progression bien jaugée (pas dure du tout, mais pas généreuse pour rien).
- Une histoire simple mais efficace (Le contexte et le prétexte jouent bien leur rôle, et ça suffit amplement pour ce jeu là).
- Une héroïne Cute as heck !!!!! (Hat Kid is best kid).
- Des personnages ni inutiles, ni trop important (hormis quelques uns qui servent la narration), avec des répliques qui font bien le café. (Les VA ont dû se taper une bonne barre, tout comme ceux qui ont écrit les répliques).
- Une ambiance... parfaite ! Désolé mais y a pas d'autres mots ! ça jongle entre plusieurs ambiances et décors (ville loufoque, forêt spooky, Nature dominante,...), et à chaque fois ça met en plein dans le mille. Tout comme la petite fille, on vit notre aventure à 300% à chaque instant tellement on est dedans. (Mention spéciale à l'héroïne justement qui change de mimiques selon l'endroit où elle se trouve: c'était une TRES BONNE idée).
- Graphismes et décors qui déboîtent dans son style cartoonesque.
- Le système des power-ups bien pensé (Chapeaux & Badges) et qui rend une bonne partie des collectables nécessaire. (seuls les jetons sont du pur bonus en fait), ce qui améliore la durée de vie du jeu et pousse à l'explorer davantage, sans te trop te forcer non plus (puisque la quasi totalité de ce dont on a absolument besoin se trouve assez instinctivement).

En résumé, un plateformer vraiment excellent que j'ai torché sans la moindre pitié et dont la durée de vie un peu courte me laisse un petit sentiment de tristesse, tant je m'amusais beaucoup. Je suis certain que nous rejouerons bientôt ensemble, petite fille au chapeau ! :'(

36557025.review:
This game accomplished to bring back for me the vivid experience of the early platformers, and is a throwback to the old platformers like banjo kazooie and super Mario 64. The game's graphics are very pleasant to look at, and its artstyle appears detailess. but as with many games that have proven, they aren't required to have an engine with all the bales and whistles of  advanced physics and a weather system to look good. And it's cartoonish look has a one that can withstand the test of time very well. It's difficulty, which besides it's first world that wasn't on par with the others, I would say brought quite a challenge, with segments incorporating either  precision platforming or fighting to others segments bringing them both in harmony. The pacing in the game is a little inconsistent, with a couple of levels of the same daunting run of the mill tasks of ''go send all these letters to these dead spirits'' or ''go to all these points in the map to close the lava taps'', but otherwise the game doesn't have plenty of these levels. however, there are other levels which you'd feel really engrossed in them, and would give you quite a satisfaction and a challenge for completing them, that would feel more like an adventure. Of all the five chapters, I found the fourth one ''alpine skyline'' to have kept the game at its highs, with a couple of levels with a very good set of spectacle that fascinated me, and still attaining the quite challenging platforming combined with fighting. In addition, The game's also not lacking in its collectables and hidden levels to find with all the time pieces' wonders. Though, I found the hidden time rifts levels a bit easy, considerably for the type of these levels, which are usually not mandatory in many other platformers and serve rather as a bonus for you.  In this game these bonus levels are the hard to find type and not the easy to access ones  (e.g super Mario galaxy, and its bonus levels available through the menu). The controls are responsive and precise, and are of the type I've had hoped of a game of this calibre. I liked the route the game took with its storyline, in the way that it doesn't take itself too seriously, with the good dialogues that gave me a good chuckle.

In conclusion, I think the game has done a great job at living up to the classics platformers, and could manage to influence other developers, as a proof that the game's genre is still relevant and fun. A score of 8.3/10 from me

36525690.review:
This is the most fun I've had with a game in years. A Hat in Time is a platformer that takes its inspiration from games like Super Mario 64, Banjo Kazooie, and Psychonauts, and beats them at their own game.  You play as Hat Kid, a girl on a quest to recover the time-pieces that fuel her ship so she can return to her home.  The game is pretty light on story, but it serves as a good setup to send you to exotic locations and meet charming and funny characters.  The upbeat lightheartedness of the game is a refershing change of pace from what a lot of games have on offer these days.

The level design is brilliant and varied. Each chapter throws something new at you, so the gamplay never gets repetitive.  For example, in one act, you bounce around the rooftops of a sunny island town collecting tickets to open a safe.  In another, you're solving a murder on a train full of anthropomorphic owls and crows.  Later, you're playing cat and mouse with a spectre in a haunted house.  

I love the artstyle.  It's cheerful and bright, matching the tone of the game perfectly.  The graphics are very well done, with lots of options in the menu, and the game runs great on my modest system.  My PC (Intel 3570k, GTX 770, 8GB RAM, Windows 7) was able to run it in 1080p at a steady 60fps with all settings on high or max.

The soundtrack is another winner.  I'm no music connoisseur, but I can't think of a single track (and there are many many tracks) that I thought was bad or didn't mesh with the game.  In fact, I've found myself whistling or humming several tracks from the game over the last week or so. "Picture Perfect," "Train Rush,"  "The Big Parade," and "Alpine Skyline" are a few of my personal favorites.  I went ahead and bought the soundtrack so I could stop burning through my mobile data on YouTube!

As to be expected in a platformer, the controls are great.  Your jumps, wall jumps, air dashes, etc. all feel precise and in the later levels it's second nature to string them togehter to get where you need to go.  You also receive several hats and hat pins that grant you abilities such as throwing bombs, grappling hooks, sprinting, and stopping time, to name just a few,  These abilities are necessary to progress through the levels and give you access to areas you couldn't reach in previous chapters.  

My only complaints about the game are fairly minor.  The camera could use some fine tuning, especially in Chapter 3.  90% of the time it's fine, but there were a few instances when I had to wrestle with it to see a jump from the angle I wanted to see it from, making it hard to judge distance / depth.  There were also times I couldn't see my shadow on a dark texture or in low lighting, making it hard to tell where I was going to land.  Some of the hats feel underused.  Particularly the time-stop hat.  You can use it as much as you want, but there are only a few situations where it's absoultely necessary to use it.  The ice hat lets you perform a ground pound, but you really only need it to launch yourself from springboards.  Hopefully these will get more use when the adidtional (free!) DLC chapters are released.

Overall, A Hat in Time is a home run, and even more impressive when you consider that this was the developer's first game.  It's definitely in my top 10 favorite games since 2010, and anyone with even a passing interest in it should check it out.  I bought it shortly after release at full price ($30 USD) and got every cent worth of enjoyment out of it, with more to come, thanks to the Steam Workshop support and aforementioned DLC!

36520367.review:
Even though it has few new game mechanics to show off the game mechanics that exist is well implemented and feels good. You get rewarded for being skilled and you can have some very fast and awesome movement if executed correctly.

However, I dont find the good implementation to be the selling point of this game. This game has some of the most charming, adorable traits that make you feel like you are not enjoying an adventure FOR a child, but an advanture made BY a child. The music, the level and character design and the many small details in animation that reflect the current situation is simply fantastic. The main character is a lovable bundle of childish energy and smiles that appeal to the natural instinct of humans when seeing a normal child. The enemies and NPCs are well designed and unique with memorable personalities. I loved just watching her express herself throughout her different missions because she feels so genuine.

Finally, the story is so refreshing and authentic I could not help but smile and press on to see what new adventure she will have in the next chapter. In a game industry where grit and Skinner box gameplay allow for only generic and boring stories (Like Destiny 2) it is so wonderful to play a game with a nonsensical story that is just interesting and fun to follow. 

All in all the gameplay is the weakest aspect of the game as it is only well executed. If the game was a bit more challenging and had a few more major characters to flesh out the worlds a bit then this game would easily be a contender for game of the year for me. I have not had this much fun just enjoying a game for a long time. I cannot recommend this game enough.

The only "bad" thing about the game, is the length of it (roughly 6 hours if you're not going to 100% it), and some graphical issues (which I never noticed in my first playthrough, and from what I've seen are very minor).

Definitely a game I would recommend to anyone who likes platformers.

A Hat In Time is a really great game, one of the best games I've played in quite awhile. 

If you enjoyed SuperMario Sunshine, Galaxy or the newest Mario game Super Mario Odyssey your going to love this game. The Story is good, The art will remind you of The Legend of Zelda: The Windwaker and the music is extremely enjoyable. 

There's a few boss fights that are really awsome, they're not plain like marios bosses aka 3 hits to beat them and same rotation of skills used throughout the battle. The bosses feel more like MMO bosses if you've played games like Tera, BNS, Revelations and other MMO's, basicly what I mean by that is after a certian % of their health is gone things start to change and you get different skills and rotations. 

All the characters in the game are voice acted! This is rare and I loved all the voice acting, every voice fit with each character. You can change the color of your clothing for free by obtaining tokens ingame or change the look and quality of your hats

For the amount of fun and content I've had with this game i would have easily paid double the asking price for this game!

36456518.review:
Phenomenal!!!

A Hat In Time is absoultely one of the best games i've played in a long time.  The game has charm, colorful vibe, a sense of humor, and outstanding artwork!  A Hat In Time is a game where you play a small girl simply named Hat Kid. You are a being from Space travling the galaxy trying to make your way home, when you are one day interupted by a Mafia Member from Mafia Town. He tries to get into your ship, and you two get caught up in a scuffle, landing you on their planet, losing all of your Time Pieces, and needing to get them all back!  Buckle up friends, because you do not want to miss this game!!

Gameplay
A Hat In Time takes many inspirations from some of the finest platformers around, coming from Super Mario Sunshine, to Banjo Kazooe.  In the game, you have to platform to collect all sorts of Collectables, such as Time Pieces, Pons, Tokens, and more.  You travel to collect Hats and Stickers in the game to gain skills to progress further, and and even colors, so you can customize your look. The game is very open to customizing and trying new things, without faulting the player. You also have the ability to quick change Hats on the spot with LB to keep the pace moving. 

Graphics
Using the Unreal Engine, A Hat In Time has a very nice clean design that comes off a safe, yet beautiful. The backgrounds look amazing with their own animations running at all times, making them a joy to look at. The game is in 3D with no Cellshading or too much hardcore detail, hence, playing Safe, but it is by far not terrible to look at, and infact will leave you in a very comfy mood to play.

Sound
This is where it hits home. This is why I can't get enough of it. The sound is A+ material!   This might be one of the best soundtracks I've heard in gaming. Almost every track is well placed, and sounds just right. The boss tracks are fun, and get you pumped, the Time Warp area is soothing and relaxing, and Mafia Island gives you a feel like you are on vacation, and that's just a few to name off. I can't praise the sound department enough for this. You deseve all praise and all credit for your work!  Thank you for such a wonderful creative set!  I should also mention, the voice acting is not to bad either, and some of the characters are fun to listen to, and some, you may even recognize..... I hear you JonTron. ;)

Controls. 
Controls work very well!  It might take some getting used to for a few moments, because adding to the usual platforming controls, you can climb walls as well.   My ONLY gripe, and I know it's always being updated with fixes, but I must mention, is the camera. The camera works well in a lot of places, but if you get into a small tight spot, it gets to be a pain, and can end of making you die at times. I hope this will be fixed more in the future. 

Overall
Overall, A Hat In Time is the standard many platforms should take note from. It wasn't a heavily promoted title, but came up swinging hard, and to me in my opinion, knocked down titles like Yooka-Laylee, and while didn't kill, did step on the toes of Mario here. Hat Kid needs to become an icon in gaming. This is something that we need more of in platforming, and I can say, has been an outstanding experience!   While, i'm not finished with the game, I have seen enough to say that I want to see more, and want this to become a series and continue to shoot for the moon in quality like it did here.  If you love Platformers, you NEED this game. I HIGHLY RECOMMEND A Hat In Time, and congratulate Gears For Breakfast on such an amazing title!   2017, has been such a rise of great action games,  and here's to many more! 

9.5/10

36449140.review:
[h1] Playtime and Time/money [/h1]
15-30 hours of gameplay easily (I played not on steam for the first 3 worlds). Although compared to a lot of other games, 1-2$ an hour for a game is a hefty price. 
Theres a great scale that someone else used and it compares a 1$ taco to that price point. In my opinion, the experience while you're playing this game is well worth the 30 tacos and I doubt you would get nearly the same satisfaction with this amazing platformer as the tacos, although the time of playing the game is short, there will soon:tm: be mods for the game which will allow players to utilize this FANTASTIC game to make AMAZING LEVELS, the community seems to also think devs will make more levels in the future, if this is all true it becomes even more worth it, but as it stands today (Mafia world, Subcon forest, Dead Bird studios, Alpine peaks, final level) it still holds up very well.

[h1] Exactly what is this game? [/h1]
[b] The Good: [/b][list]
[*][u]Tight controls.[/u]
 Never have I played a platformer to date where I've [u]felt more in control of the character[/u], the game is so fun to move around in, it would simply be worth it if it was only challenge levels to be quite honest
[*][u]Cute as (heck).[/u]
 This one might seem like a minor thing to love, but you really have to trust me when I say that this game reaches an all time high of adorableness for the whole game in the best way possible, it gives the world so much flavour and really makes you want to play more than anything. unlike other cute games btw, you can actually beat up the baddies without feeling bad, and the last thing I want is a game judging me for my actions right now, it's so refreshing to just be able to play a game without having to worry about fighting against the game and the game dev to play how I want.
[*][u]Freedom[/u]
 The game is so open for you to take in. You can complete the game with 25/40 of the hourglasses (comparable to stars in Mario 64) which allows you to mess around and do whatever you want, and play how you want, in fact it's such leeway that [u]you can completely skip levels if you think they're stupid[/u], like whole entire worlds. Theres so many ways to complete everything in the game too, the speedrun strats of this game are a ton of fun, but [u]thats not to even say that everything is mindlessly easy either[/u], in order to do a lot of the cooler things you should be thinking outside of the box and should have a good grasp on how to control your character.
All and all just makes for a free experience, you just play.... and you get to experience the game on your own terms.
[/list]
[b] The Bad: [/b][list]
[*][u]Short.[/u]

[*]also bad if you [u]hate cute stuff[/u].
(monster)

[*]also I'm very worried that this will become the new undertale, such a great game that will [u]likely be corrupted by a terrible fanbase[/u], I certainly hope that this doesnt happen here.
[/list]
[h1]So now the standard game rating:[/h1][list]
[*][b]Story: 10/10[/b] (Full on story thats put into action and keeps you caring the entire time.)
[*][b]Gameplay: 10/10 + 🎮[/b] (induces weak knees due to the sheer pleasure you get from the controls and fluidity of the game)
[*][b]Presentation: 10/10[/b] (??? does this really need that much explained? just take a look at the video up at the top of the page, and tell me that the game doesn't just look amazing.)
[*][b]Soundtrack: 9/10[/b] (It's great, and it's amazing at times, but it just doesn't stick with you forever, which isn't bad, just not TOPTIER, you know what I mean?)
[*][b]Replayability: 9/10[/b] (mods soon? new levels soon? actually anything will make this replayable, the controls and the whole base of the game is rock solid. Getting all the collectables is fun, getting all the achievements is fun, you don't have to grind and it somehow fills out the entire game with meaningful content anyway)

[list][list][i]as a final note, this is the first game in a long time that I've enjoyed playing, it's sparked my flame of loving games again after this whole dull year.
[list][list] -Zyga

36419772.review:
TL;DR :  Greatest game I've played in a while.  Most likely to be my game of the year, maybe even the decade.

A Hat in Time is a 3D platformer which draws inspiration from games like Super Mario Sunshine and the early Paper Mario titles.  It takes some noticable things from those games like the writing style and the slide move and also adds some things of its own, like the ability to climb up a wall for a short period before sliding down.  As the title would suggest, the game also sports six different hats with their own abilities to help you get around the levels.  On top of the hats, you can also have up to three different badges equipped at once, which all have either a passive or active effect, and are applied no matter what hat youre using.  The game controls are a bit floatier compared to Sunshine, but are ultimately alot smoother in the long run.  The game's level design is great, and offers a fair challenge in every stage.  The soundtrack for the game is very memorable, as each level will have its own tracks unique to it, instead of one theme for a world.  The game isnt that long if you're just trying to beat it (it took me roughly nine hours), but the experience is very enjoyable and memorable, which makes up for its short length.  I give A Hat in Time a 10/10, and I would highly reccomend it to anybody looking for a game that they will remember as fondly as their childhood games.

36413028.review:
You know, it's hard to fully express what I feel about this game. It makes me so happy for so many reasons it's hard to know where to start. It is adorable, enjoyable, interesting, endlessly charming, and extremely nostalgic, in all the right ways.

It's way too common for developers to attempt to revive a nostalgic genre by exactly emulating the classic titles, qualities and flaws alike. Thankfully, the devs of A Hat in Time were smarter than that: they took the 3D platformer collect-a-thon genre, took away many of the annoying things that were characteristic to it, and delivered a lovable polished piece.

The first thing you'll notice, as you start the game, is that the music is absolutely awesome. It feels constantly fun and adventurous, with many awesome tunes that fit many different themes with something of a child-like wonder to them. It's awesome how the music changes depending on what part of a level you're in, with some instruments fading in or out, I love this kind of dynamic music. 

The sound effects that accompany the soundtrack are also excellent. Adorable childish interjections, some cute short sentences like "you're free!" or "all mine" that make you go "aww <3", some ambient sounds at times that range from soothing to creepy and, of course, satisfying "slam" and explosion sound effects for combat. The voice acting is also awesome, with every character full of this caricaturesque charm and personality that I simply adore. I particularly love Mustache Girl's voice, it's equal parts rebellious and adorable.

Which brings us to the graphics, and oh boy, this game is teeming with charm in there as well. First of all, there are the characters. Hat Kid is head-exploding levels of adorable, with her silly face, cutesy outfit, precious idle animations, and a fine selection of hats. Every other character is just as cool: you get some awesomely funny mafia thugs, an adorably energetic Mustache Girl, stylish musical penguins, western train riding owls, an evil demonic queen, some cute mountain dwellers, and many other sweet, sweet characters.

The sceneries are also full of that same charm the characters have. Starting with the adorable spaceship that looks like a mix between a proper spaceship and a child's playground, moving to a very colorful town of mafia thugs, a busy and secretive movie studio, a mysterious train, a happy musical moon city, an awesomely dark and creepy forest full of bizarre things, a haunted mansion, a lovely mountain range full of villages and bushes with a wide variety of landscapes, and the absolutely foreboding final dungeon that is very... foreboding, every level has a cartoony thematic style.

Then, of course, there's the game. The controls are deliciously fluid, it's so fun and satisfying to just run and jump around, and the camera works great as well, which is rare in 3D platformers (in fact, the devs took camera development to a level many AAA games don't take). There's a great variety of special powers you can equip Hat Kid with which apply to many different situations, giving the game a bit of a "key and keyhole" aspect while providing the player with a plethora of options on how to solve a problem.

No collect-a-thon is complete without collectibles, right? The collectibles in this game come in five main types: the yarns, which are used to knit hats, the relics, that unlock certain special stages, the rift tokens that operate this crazy slot machine that gives out pretty cool cosmetic prizes, and, of course, the Time Pieces, this game's main collectible (like puzzle pieces in Banjo-Kazooie or stars in Super Mario 64). There are also badges you can buy (and sometimes find) to give you all kinds of different skills, making pons (the game's currency) worth collecting, and inviting the player to try all kinds of different stuff. I particularly adore the one that gives Hat Kid a little scooter (it's so, so adorable how Hat Kid just dangles her little feet when she's on it).

Then there's the level design. First of all, the platforming in every level is great, making worlds satisfying to jump around and explore, giving the player a selection of different paths to traverse. Even in the more linear levels, there are clever ways to skip sections if you're smart and quick enough. 

This being a 3D collect-a-thon, most levels follow a "semi-open" structure where there's a handful of main objectives, but a lot of free range to run around looking for optional tokens and collectibles. Mafia Town is perfectly representative of that, with a ton of things to collect around town right away, even as you're just starting the game, headed towards your first Time Piece through the convoluted landscape of square buildings and giant-meat-rolling streets. Subcon Forest is probably my favorite, due to the amount of optional sections full of stuff to find, combined with the sweet, sweet dark atmosphere that I'm just in love with. Alpine Skyline is an awesome level overall, but it kinda falls short of its main promise: it promises us a free roaming experience, but in practice it's pretty much a glorified hub world, with a decent amount of things to explore, but with every time piece clearly contained in the "dead ends" of the paths, in which there are "tiny levels" of their own (awesome tiny levels, but tiny levels nonetheless).

In Battle of the Birds, instead of giving us one large world to explore, the game gives us a series of tinier levels, each with their own themes and objectives. The first level involves infiltrating a movie studio and retrieving some Time Pieces that are being used as props. Then there's Murder in the Owl Express, where you need to gather clues and open up new paths by solving small puzzles to solve a murder mystery, and Train Rush, which is an intense linear race against the clock to get to the end. On the other side of things, there's Picture Perfect, where you have to explore a tiny moon city getting penguin people to become your fans and take pics of you, and The Big Parade, where you run around the same moon city, but this time with a crowd on ground level that hurts you if you touch them, with a band of birds that follow you around playing a very satisfying song (seriously, that song makes me so damn happy). In the end, you get to fight a boss depending on which set of levels you were the best at. Battle of the Birds is a pretty awesome change of style.

Then there's the Time Rift levels, which come in two forms: the "blue" form, consisting of fun linear platforming challenges with a surreal atmosphere, and the "purple" forms, which have you traverse a sequence of interesting explorable mini-maps collecting "rift pons" and a set of pictures that tell a little story.

The final level is a linear challenge of epic proportions that's as hard as it is tense, culminating in an epic battle against your arch-nemesis. 

Which brings us to bosses: the bosses in this game mostly follow the same formula of "avoid attacks, wait for an opening, attack", which is okay in my book. They are mostly fun, throwing deadly attacks and changing patterns as the battle intensifies, but they feel a bit redundant at times, taking way more hits than they should.

For a game in a genre that was born with consoles in mind, this game controls surprisingly well with keyboard and mouse. Accurately controlling the camera with the mouse while using the keyboard for movement feels so natural I'm impressed there weren't more 3D platformers for the PC back in the day.

So, to sum it all up, this game is awesome. It's full of heart, charm and enjoyment, bringing 3D platformers back with a cute as heck vengeance. It makes me so happy I can barely fit all my thoughts in this tiny review form. My only complaint is that the game is waaaay too short, unfortunately. Oh, how I wish this was longer :(

36394333.review:
I want to start by saying that A Hat in Time, despite being really solid and legitimately fun to play, isn't greatest platformer to have ever existed, as some might attest. It is, however, the best platformer I've played in quite a long time, and as a veteran of "ye olde golden age of 3D platformers of yore", I want to review this game as fairly as I can.
If you're on the fence and are looking for the short answer of whether to get the game or not, the answer is yes, get it.

A Hat in Time, as advertised, is indeed cute-as-heck, with Hat Kid being adorable and easy to fall in love with, despite knowing very little about her save that she's some space-faring alien kid trying to get home. The visual stylization is reminiscent of the games long passed that myself and many others are nostalgic of, but still establishes and maintains its own identity (also, despite the recommendation in the options, I suggest turning depth of field off to better view and appreciate the work that went into the scenery). Everything is bright and colorful without overdoing it, and the environments are fun to explore.

The controls feel tight and responsive, and the mouse and 'board controls feel good, despite not being able to re-map anything to other keys. They're not perfect though, and something as small as not being able to change the direction you're facing mid jump, despite being a minor complaint, can be annoying at times. And very much like the games AHiT pays homage to, some of the platforming in the game can be absolutely frustrating. This, unfortunately, is partly attributed to certain platforming mechanics (wall jumping in particular) being a little wonky at times, and not consistantly working the way you'd like. Despite all this, the controls handle very well, and the game starts to require some level of understanding and mastery of the various nuances moving throughout your environment entails, which is satisfying when you finally have the hang of things.

The game also requires a bit more skill and mastery over your character than its super-cutesy finish might make one think, with some levels, bosses and encounters being surprisingly difficult to overcome. The pacing feels just right though, and the eneny placement is logical and well established, with no real instances of wondering "why is this thing even here?". The hats and badges you acquire throughout the game maintain their usefulness, and nothing you pick up ever feels useless or pointless, with exception maybe to pons (the game's currency) and excess yarn if you go out of your way to get absolutely everything like I happened to do. The soundtrack is absolutely fantastic, and remains memorable even after putting the game down.

While there are bugs in the game, they're few and far between, and none of them are game-breaking. The game is also woefully short, although additional content and a couple more chapters will be made available in the near future. And while I stand behind my statement that this game isn't the greatest platformer ever, I do share the sentiment that it does what it sets out to do and it does it right. It does it really well even. It only took a few hours of play to decide that the game, despite its current length and slight array of bugs and problems, was 100% worth the money, and I'm glad I decided to make the purchase. It really is a lot of fun to play.

It's an impressive piece of work, especially considering the size of the studio that produced it, and I wholeheartedly recommend it to platformer fans new and old alike.

10/10
One of my favorite games. Moving feels really good. I don't know how to describe it, but it feels intentional, and fluid, but you can stop when you want to. Its just really nice. The game has a multitude of very charming levels. It's the kind of polish and character that goes to an excessive end, where the a player speeding through will miss some details about characters that make the world more inviting. I guess the term I'd use is "Nintendo Charm," which is weird, because it seems to deliver on "Nintendo" charm more than Nintendo's own Mario Odyssey. The best analogy is Paper Mario: The Thousand Year Door. 

So the game controls well, and has a nice aesthetic, which are the only real requirements of a platformer. Some sections are fairly difficult, but most of the game can be skipped to finish it. The biggest complaint I have is that the main game is too short. There are only 40 levels, and most take around 15 minutes to finish and gather the collectibles, which leaves you at around 10 hours of game, assuming youre rushing from objective to objective without doing anything else. Some sections are much more difficult, and there are some places where I was looking for a collectible, and I just missed it in my first glance at an area, so it took me about 16 hours to beat the main game, 100%. The additional 5 hours on my profile are from the community created content made in the first month. I expect more, but I have not searched for them recently. 

TL;DR

Movement, aesthetics, and challenge are good. It is short, but the community made maps make up for that.

36378944.review:
It's games like this that remind you what "fun" really means.

A Hat in Time is a kickstarted retro-revival 3D platformer in a similar vein to Yooka-Laylee. However, unlike that game, AHiT actually delivers on what it set out to acheive, and it does this not by riding on the coattails of its inspirations, but learning from them and creating something new and something very special. The most obvious inspiration here is Super Mario Sunshine, and that's most evident through the game's frankly incredible controls. Hat Kid, the protagonist, has a ridiculous amount of mobility in the form of double jumps, dashes, dives, wall runs, and much more that make simply moving around the levels an enjoyable experience in itself. There are numerous other unlockable abilities in the form of hats and badges, which gives the game a sense of real character progression and allows you to experiment with which powers you find most useful during gameplay. 

Another aspect A Hat in Time has that gives it an edge over other similar platformers is its level/world design. There are only four worlds, but each world is completely unique in story, aesthetic, and mission design. The first world has a lot of verticality, and simple but fun platforming challenges allow you to learn the controls at your own pace. The second world takes a more story-driven approach, with a movie studio intrigue plot that bears similarities to something you might see in a Paper Mario game. The third world, probably the strongest overall, is a horror-themed plot that has you completing contracts to recover your soul from a demon, and contains one chapter so legitimately scary that I panicked and Alt-F4'd out of the game the first time I experienced it. I won't spoil the premise for the fourth world, since it was a pleasant surprise for me and I'd like it to be one for others as well. All these worlds contain interesting missions and subplots, and surprisingly difficult boss fights during the story's climactic moments. Some may complain that the game lacks focus or a central gameplay theme, but I think the variety adds a lot to the fun factor, and it kept me interested in what was in store next.

Another thing I can't fail to mention is the art and music. A Hat in Time is charming above all else, and the characters and environments certainly bring that home. Everything is very colorful and vibrant, and all the characters are extremely expressive. Hat Kid herself is the poster child (literally) for this, as her design is so adorable that found myself grinning during every scene in which she played a significant role. And as for the music... I would say that I enjoy video game music more than others, and more than should be deemed socially acceptable, and I can say that this game's soundtrack is absolutely stunning, in no small part because it has been touched by the hand of our god Grant Kirkhope.  Plasma3Music, with his help, have crafted perfectly fitting songs for every level and every boss that I find myself listening to even when not playing the game. There are even a bunch of unlockable remixes for songs that I enjoyed very much.

I've completed all 40 levels of the game in just under 10 hours, but I don't regret a single penny of the $30 I spent on this game. It's easily one of the best games of the year, and a must-play for anyone who loves platformers or simply wants a fun, cute experience to get lost in. My hat's off to you, Gears for Breakfast, you guys made me smile again.

36333455.review:
Before I start, I want to say one thing.  

I was not a fan of, nor did I play most of the iconic collectathons and 3d platformers that this game takes inspiration from.  
And I can say, without a shadow of a doubt that I completely missed out on playing those when they were popular and relevant.  I would say it's hard to make a game that accurately captures the spirit of a by-gone era/genre/theme, and successfully convey that to someone who knows the source material.  I had very little reference for how these kinds of games played, and I can say I enjoyed every second of it.  It just kept me going back for more!  I dusted off my old Gamecube and borrowed a friends Super Mario Sunshine just to get some more perspective.  A Hat in Time is just in simplest terms, charming.  To keep myself from rambling further, i'll just go into strengths and weaknesses.

Strengths:
1. Music- From the first theme, it'll pull you in and have you humming it later when you least expect it.
2. The platforming- It has a very nice difficulty curve for those unused to actual platformers, like myself, but it can, and will throw complete curveballs at you if you're not paying attention.  And the almost perfect blend of all the different kinds of platforming abilities Hat Kid has to use in the final level is a great way to showcase what you've aquired and to poke at your mastery of the abilities themselves.  It's not without its... quirks, which I'll get into later.
3. Characters-  I love every single one of these characters, both good guys and bad guys.  I can only recall a couple that I didn't particularly care for, (Looking at you, world 4) but none of them I hated.  

Weaknesses:
1. Glitches- Not actually its biggest problem, but I'm saving that for last so I can expand upon it.  Nothing game breaking here, unless you fall out of the map which did happen to me once.  It does get bothersome if it happens while you're trying to platform, making the quirks (like the wall jump not always clicking to the right surface) absolutely hilarious, or infuriating.
2. Characters- Yep, both a strength and a weakness.  I love these characters, but at the same time, they don't feel as fleshed out or get as much screen time as they should, and that's because...
3. It's a short game-  At 11ish hours in, I have all the Time Pieces, most of the yarn, all the relics, and went back for a couple of acheivements.  There's not really a whole lot here, which is a DAMN shame because what is here is interesting, colorful, and as the game says itself; cute as heck.  I never got a true sense of mastery over the different hats or the platforming until I was pretty much forced to by searching for the last remaining time pieces outside of the immediate story, which is where the real pros can pull off some pretty awesome platforming tricks.  

TL;DR  With a bit more polish, and perhaps a new level or two for each world, you could have something really amazing here.  What's here is fantastic, it just needs more time and love put into it to shine so bright your eyeballs bleed.

36314652.review:
I don't seriously review games very often, I'll do the occasional joke review for Garfield Kart or whatever, but this is one I really wanted to review. 

Short Version:
If you're reading this review, you're probably considering buying it. In that case, definitely get it, if you're even considering it you won't be disappointed.

Long Version:
This game is near perfect, I can barely think of any flaws. But I'm gonna go over what makes it so great anyway.

Story:
The story is actually surprisingly nice. Each world has it's own self-contained story, and they're all entertaining. Also the writing is hilarious.

Music:
Most of the overworld themes are fairly forgettable, (besides Time Rift, which is beautiful) but the boss themes are some of the best I've heard, they really feel intense and fit the bosses perfectly.

Movement:
This might control better than any other game I've played. It feels so fluid and satisfying. Hat Kid has a double jump and a mid-air dash (which you can cancel out of by jumping again). The dash really lends itself to some genius platforming. This game is made for speedrunning, and the dash compliments that perfectly. It allows you to completely skip some platforms, making things much quicker, and oh man its so satisfying to pull off.

Graphics:
This game looks so good on max settings, I haven't seen what it looks like below that but man it's beautiful. The graphics are colorful and really set the mood for each area. Subcon Forest is dark with mostly dark colors, while Mafia Town is colorful and bright.

Bosses:
I LOVE these bosses, they're all up there with some of my favorite video game bosses. Especially the main boss of Subcon Forest, which just bleeds personality.

Overall, definitely get this game if you have any interest in it, I can only think of one flaw; it's too short, I just want to keep playing because the game is so much fun. But they are coming out with 2 free DLC worlds later on, which I can't wait for.

36314027.review:
So I got a $20 Steam gift card from someone, and said "hey, I'm gonna go buy Cuphead!"
Scrolling down in the store, I stumbled upon A Hat In Time.
I looked once at the store page, read a couple sentences of the description, and before I knew it I was selling a bunch of TF2 junk to get the extra $15 to grab this game instead. I don't even know what I was expecting, really. I sort of assumed it would be this neat 2D platformer, because I didn't really know anything about it. Then I booted it up, and... holy shit, dude. As someone whose favorite 3D platformer has long been Super Mario 64, I think it may have just been dethroned.

Everything about this game is awesome, save for its length - which is mostly remedied anyway because two more worlds are on the way, not to mention Workshop support. The characters are all memorable, everything is goddamn adorable, the controls are tight and do what you want when you want, the levels are vast and detailed, the customization is absurd, the list goes on. If you have ever played a 3D Mario platformer, or similar games like Banjo-Kazooie, Sonic Adventure, or Haven: Call of the King (does anybody else remember that game? no?), then this is for you.

tl;dr:
+Great gameplay
+Great physics
+Beautiful art style
+Awesome characters
+Loads of customization
+Well-designed levels

-Shorter than I would like (this kind of thing is why I never want to finish games, it leaves a hole in my heart where that game once was)

=Also kind of on the easy side so far, but that can be a blessing or a curse.

36308184.review:
The main menu contains icons and links to both Twitter and Facebook.

I searched for about 15 minutes online for a way to disable these icons, but could not discern anyway to do so. Why would the developer taint their game with such garbage in the main menu? What's the point in putting so much care and effort into a game as the developers clearly did if you're going to ruining with a spurious decision to gain more advertising? You could have put up request to spam all our social media friends on your store page or website, but isntead you built it into the game. This is now a core part of the game experience.

When someone attempts to replay this game in 20 years, will they still see the dead Twitter and Facebook links on the main menu, reminding them that this isn't a fun experience that it is instead a consumer transactions where you are simply supposed to spend and "Tell all your friends to buy too!"

I like the game, but it would be immoral to recommend this game so long as these icons exist in the main menu. I know many others will take issue with this choice and see it as superificial. I understand their perspective completely and also why it is wrong.

Please reconsider ruining your game with such a simple attention grab.

36306021.review:
I've never been much of a fan of Mario, Banjo-Kazooie, or other platformers. But I backed it on Kickstarter anyway (the only thing I ever have) because of the great art and the devs seemed to have their stuff together. And boy, did that turn out to be a good investment - I love this game!

The art, music, writing, and voice acting are all incredible, and fit together perfectly. The atmosphere reminds me most of Banjo-Kazooie, but really stands on its own. It's a great feel-good game (with the possible exception of one particularly spooky level) but avoids cliches and remains thoroughly entertaining and funny throughout the whole story.

The gameplay is just plain fun! The controls feel really tight, and the abilities and challenges are introduced at just the right pace - no mechanic feels overused, any every level has a nice balance of all of the mechanics unlocked so far. Some elements come back in later levels in fun, unexpected ways. Most importantly (in my opinion) for a platformer, it has a perfect difficulty curve. I'm no platforming veteran, yet I rarely found myself retrying something multiple times (mostly the boss fights, and never more than twice) and checkpoints are forgiving. The level design is also great - I genuinly enjoyed exploring and looking for secrets, while I'm usually a straight-for-the-objective kind of player.

I cannot recommend this game enough. Even if platformers aren't usually your thing, the amazing presentation and story will definitely keep you entertained!

36297642.review:
Par où commencer pour parler de cette petite pépite des jeux de plateforme 3D qui se font de plus en plus rares de nos jours? 


Tout d'abord, parlons du plus négatif pour s'en débarasser: le jeu est assez mal adapté sur Mac. Même en ayant mis les configurations au minimal, il m'est souvent arrivé d'avoir des baisses de framerates. Et il y a aussi un bug concernant les succès, ils ne se débloquent pas sur Mac. Autre chose, le jeu est un peu trop court: uniquement 4 chapitres, plus le 5ème qui est en réalité 1 seul niveau, comptez une dizaine d'heures pour terminer le jeu sans chercher à faire du 100% et en prenant son temps. Cependant, je ne crache pas complètement sur ce défaut puisqu'une mise à jour est prévue pour ajouter 2 chapitres supplémentaires et d'autres choses. Et enfin, la caméra, qui bien que correcte la majorité du temps, m'a joué de mauvais tours parfois dans certains moments cruciaux, du genre avant de sauter sur une autre plateforme, où elle a décidé de partir dans l'autre sens. 


Maintenant attaquons-nous à la partie la plus importante qui est le jeu en lui-même. Vous aimez Super Mario Sunshine ou Psychonauts? Vous serez servi. Les environnements sont très agréables à parcourir et sont variés, l'univers du jeu est attrayant, chaque monde m'a marqué d'une manière différente, de la ville des Mafieux cuisiniers à la sinistre forêt hantée, (qui est de loin mon chapitre préféré, l'explorer est un vrai régale) et les personnages sont tous attachants, voire même avec un passé assez triste (ceux qui ont fait le jeu savent de qui je parle, je ne dirais pas son nom pour éviter le spoil). Les contrôles répondent très bien, Hat Kid est nerveuse dans ses mouvements, bien que parfois, cela peut aussi conduire à de légers soucis de contrôles; il m'est arrivé plusieurs fois de mourir parce que HK n'arrivait pas à grimper correctement les murs. Le gameplay reposant sur l'utilisation des chapeaux et de leurs différentes capacités marchent très bien, et sont tous très fun à utiliser (mention spéciale au Sprint Hat).
Enfin, la bande son du jeu est juste excellente, j'ai aimé toutes les tracks du jeu, et elles collent très bien aux niveaux où elles sont entendues. 

En conclusion, malgré les défauts que j'ai cité précédemment j'ai adoré ce jeu: je me suis amusé, j'ai ressenti ce fun que je ressentais en jouant aux jeux comme Super Mario Sunshine autrefois. Si vous avez l'occasion de pouvoir y jouer, allez-y, vous ne le regretterez pas.

36296545.review:
Das Banjo-Kazooie/Super Mario Sunshine seiner Generation... mit Hüten!

Mal ehrlich, viele Spieler trifft A Hat in Time mitten in die Nostalgie. Mich eingeschlossen. Und dann noch Hüte (mit zusätzlichen freischaltbaren Designs!) - das sind schonmal gute Vorraussetzungen. Was das Spiel wirklich exzellent macht, ist das, was es darüber hinaus leistet.

Obwohl vereinzelte Bugs bleiben, merkt man, das viel Zeit und Hirnschmalz in die technische Umsetzung (Kamera, Bewegung, Koordination und Kombination von Fähigkeiten) geflossen ist. Die Bewegungs-Prinzipien sind einfach und nah an den Platforming-Klassikern (Hechtsprung, Wandsprung, etc. pp). Wenn man diese einfachen Moves kombiniert wird jedoch schnell klar: unsere Protagonistin ist ganz schön mobil und es macht Spaß.

Das Design muss ich fast noch mehr loben als den Rest des Spiels. 
Ein langweiligerer Platformer hätte vielleicht gesagt: Ok, wir haben das Moveset. Graslevel, Eislevel, Lavalevel, Wasserlevel, Wüstenlevel. 
A Hat in Time sagt: Erste Welt Homage an Super Mario Sunshine, danach lassen wir unserer Kreativität freien Lauf. Wir müssen uns nicht zu streng ans Genre halten. Wir enwerfen für jede Welt völlig neue Charaktere, die nur so vor Charme sprühen.

36295692.review:
Uma coisa sem dúvida sobre esse jogo , ele pegou muita coisa boa em jogos de plataforma de antigamente como Mario 64, Banjo Kazooie e Zelda The Ocarina of Time , e isso foi uma sacada genial , conseguiram aplicar muito bem no jogo , as fases e os boses são muito bem desenvolvidas.
Você olha para um mundo e pensa: " Vou explorar isso tudo " , o jogo em nenhum momento se torna repetitivo ou saturado , todo mundo tem uma inovação seja pelos Hat's ou pela mecânica da fase , os boses são todos um diferente do outro , boses muito bem desenvolvidos com uma soundtrack incrível , a jogabilidade é fluída e responde muito bem aos comandos , os coletáveis são divertidos de se pegar e foram muito bem aplicados. 
Você pode pensar que esse jogo é para criança por ser fofo ou bonitinho , mas ele tem umas pegadas "creepy" em algumas fases , o único pé atrás sobre esse game é que ele é caro para 10 horas de campanha e 15 horas ou mais para fazer os 100% , dá até pra entender que é um jogo indie que está a desenvolvimento á mais de 4 anos e foi adiado várias vezes , mas tá carinho em.
Apesar disso eu achei que meus 50 reais foram muito bem gastos nesse jogo.

It took me apparoximately 10 hours, 25 minutes to beat this game while appreciating its beauty and not skipping cutscenes or dialogue. Either way, most of the game is gameplay anyways, cutscenes are short and descriptive, and honestly, some of them are so good, they don't need dialogue typically.
