The only thing I wouldn't reccomend doing is playing with a controler. It beats the purpouse of why this game is still currently a PC exclusive. Fantastic storyline
Easy to use mechanics and controls

Boop

Overall, this is a great game, and I would reccomend upping the price of this game to $60. It's worth that much in my opinion (Please don't, prove that $30 games are good too)

May God hope for A Hat in Time 2.

36282708.review:
A Hat in Time is easily one of the best 3D platformers ive played this year and is now one of my favorite platform games of all time. If the cute style of the game dosn't catch your eye, then the fun and unique gameplay and level design that fits perfectly for an N64 platform game definatly well. While the N64 might not be powerful enough to process a game like this, if this was released during it's lifespan, it would be one the best games on the system.
You play as a little girl (she doesn't have a name so we just call her Hat Girl) who lives in outer space on a spaceship trying to get home, while suddenly the fuel for her ship (hourglasses) scatter around on the planet below after a freak accident, an now she has to go and get them back while meeting tons of memerable and wacky characters that happen to come across them. It starts' off weak, but the story get's more into detail the more you dive into it. The main character is super adorable and sweet and makes me want to give her a hug the more I play. She fit's all the criteria of an N64 mascot, and the characters that help her on her journey are suprisingly unforgetable. I just wish their was more information about them, especially Hat Girl. The clever writing and humor makes up for this though.
While their isin't a whole lot of worlds to explore, the game makes up for it by making them huge, filled with collectables, npcs to interact with, and plenty of things to do to keep you busy. Through out the game you can create hats and find badges to help give Hat Girl special abilities and powerups, but most of them aren't necessary to beat the game so the game dosen't force you to keep exploring areas you've already been to. The amount of level verioty does add bits of sprinkles into the game so exploring different worlds isn't the only thing you do through out the whole game. One minute you could be an action movie star, while another you could be jumping around numerous platform sections that test's your skills, or you could be running away and hiding from a ghost while she stalkes and taunts you while your just a defenseless little girl, hiding from the scary monster tracking your every move. They're are also a handfull of bosses to, while they might not be the most challenging type, they may manage to kill you once or twice and they're pretty cool to look at. It's stuff like this that makes A Hat in Time a memerable and fun experience for me. I also loved the cute artwork that show's up during the loading screens it's so cute and makes it perfect for a cartoon show based on the story of the game. At least in my opinion.
The game isin't perfect though. Depending on the computer your using, your probably gonna find yourself tinkering with the settings just to get the best performance it could give you, which wouldn't be a bad thing if i hadn't had to do this every time i boot up the game. I also encountered a few screen glitches, but none of them were game breaking.

Overall, this game is a must play for fans of the 3D platforming genre, or for those who has fond memories of Mario and Banjo-Kazooie. While I wish it was a bit longer and did a better job explaining the lore behind the main character. And probably did a better job on the presentation. developer Gears for Breakfast made a very successful example of what 3D platform games should be, and i really hope they make this game into a full fledge series with sequels, merchandise, and more. (Please get to work on that)

Pros:
Super kawaii.
Lovable main character.
great platforming and level design.
A simple yet overall enjoyable story.
Captures the feel of an N64 platformer perfectly.
Great writing and funny family-friendly humor.
Tons of things to do and collect.

Cons: 
Some performance issues.
Bugs.

overall score: 9/10.

36267128.review:
So, A Hat in Time. This is a Kickstarter game that was in a development for 5 years and promised to bring back the memories of classic 3D platformer games... No, come back, please! This one is actually good, I promise!

*Ahem* So. It's surprisingly good. So far all content that the game offered me was great and it's one of the few games that I actually wanted to replay right after I completed it.

In this game you play as a girl whose name we don't know and is nicknamed Hat Kid. The game starts with you waking up on the spaceship on which you are flying back to your home. It uses hourglass thingies called time pieces as a fuel. On your way home you are flying past a planet from which a person who claimes to be a part of Mafia came to take a toll from you for passing over their town. Instead he manages to break the glass window on your ship and it results in losing all your time pieces as they fall on the planet and now you need to take them back so you could have enough fuel to fly back to your home.

The controls are good and tight. You have a variety of moves including a wall run, double jump and a dive which are pretty standart for a 3D platformer. You also have a variety of hats that have different abilities that help you to explore the levels. Also also, similar to Psychonauts you can buy and equip badges that add new abilities to your character or improve the abilites of the hats.

The game features 4 big worlds for you to explore (there are 5 worlds actually but the fifth one is just a bossfight) and they differ greatly in style and atmospere which helps to keep the game fresh and fun. For example, the first world named "Mafia Town" is a Mario Sunshine-esque world in which you are given the main objective you need to do but you can freely explore the map. The second world named Dead Bird Studio in which you are caught in battle between two movie directors that managed to get their hands on some time pieces is a more linear experience compared to the first world and so on. Each world also features bonus levels called "Time Rifts" which are pure platforming segments similar to Mario Sunshine. 

The art style of this game is very good and cute, can't really say anything else about it.

The characters in this game are very good and memorable. You have the Mafia with thick russian accent who punch barrels who are dressed as old ladies to keep the town in fear, you have a scottish owl who likes to film western movies on his own train with innocent owls that just want to get to their destination on his train and a sassy penguin who is a former owner of night club who decided to film movies too, and many more.

I also want to point out the voice acting in this game. It's one of the best I've heard in a game and it adds a lot of personality to the characters and makes them much better (you also have an option to turn off the voice acting if you do not like it). Voice actors did a really great job.

The music in this game is amazing. So far every piece of music the game offered me was a delight to my ears. The game musician really needs to get an extra credit for his work.
Here's an example:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2XUw1NxJS2k

While there are a lot of good things in the game, there are some problems too. The game also brought back some cons from old platformers like strangely placed and fixed cameras which can mess with your view and thus it makes navigating the level harder, controls sometimes can be a wee bit wonky, some rough edges when it comes to graphics and animations and a story is a bit shallow in some places.

[h1]Verdict.[/h1]

A Hat in Time is a really good and solid game that managed to bring back the feeling of the classic platformers (and some problems) while mixing in some new stuff. I highly recommend to buy this game and try it out. For me this game was one the best gaming experiences (if not the best) I had in last couple of years and definitely my favorite game of 2017.

I like A Hat in Time. I enjoyed the time I spent with it, though I'm left with a bit of a nagging feeling in the back of my head that its only okay. Having followed the kickstarter, I've seen the passion that has gone into the project. The worlds are nice and varied and fun to explore. When A Hat in Time is at its best, I felt like I was playing a spiritual successor to my favorite 3D Mario games with some engaging, if sometimes simple, platforming.

I think my hangups come largely from a significant number of nitpicks that were largely inconsequential to the gameplay but stuck out to me (strangely positioned models, disjointed story, minimal animation on NPC faces to name a few). None of these were deal breakers but I think they made the game a little rough around the edges.

At the current price of $30, I'm hesitant to recommend it. Definitely look out for a sale. Good buy overall though.

36253182.review:
We all remember the good old days of 3D platformers. SM64 kicked it all off, Banjo-Kazooie brought the idea of hunting for items with much less linearity, we know the drill. Shame that they seem to be dying out now, replaced with boring old black, grey and brown shooters. A Hat In Time easily captures everything that was good about games like Sunshine, yet bolstered them further with brilliant gameplay and a charming design.
First of all, I freaking love this game's cartoony art style. It fits the game amazingly well, and makes every world a treat to look at. The diverse colour pallette is on par with Nintendo themselves, giving us everything ranging from vibrant Mafia Town to the hilariously old-school Conductor's Train to the gloomy Subcon Forest. The visuals make the game pure eye candy. Calling it 'Cute As Heck' is a massive understatement.
Next, the game is a blast to play. Hat Kid handles so well that every slip genuinely feels like your fault, and this game has probably the most cooperative camera I've ever seen in a 3D platformer, almost never screwing you over like Lakitu loved to do oh so many times in SM64. Hat Kid's moveset is beautifully diverse, giving you the run-of-the-mill basic platforming abilities like double jumps and Sunshine-esque dives, but they've been spiced with control. Hat Kid can run up walls she jumps onto, letting her pull off much longer jumps, and can cancel out of dives, meaning that you'll never overshoot your targets. Combat is surprisingly fun, giving Hat Kid an umbrella to beat the tar out of enemies with (or unleash huge lasers with if you're a Yuuka Kazami junkie like me and used the projectile badge the whole game) and pairing it with Sonic-style airborne homing attacks. Its hilarious to see a Mafia grunt block your brella swipes, only to recieve a bonk to the head and get all confused. Combine this with the brilliant hat abilities, ranging from the par for the course sprint hat (Bunny Hood flair when) to the useful Brewing Hat for chucking explosive potions at breakables and baddies alike, to the ridiculous Time Stop Hat, which literally slows time to a crawl (unfortunately, you don't get to beat people up with Za Warudo, but that's what Workshop support is for- did I mention Workshop support?) and you have an amazingly varied moveset that lets you deal with anything the game throws at you.
The stages themselves are brilliant. Dividing one world into stages is genius, as you can change each stage to fit. One level in Mafia Town, for example, has you covering yourself in mud to scare the bejeebus out of one of the Mafia until he gives you the Time Piece. Another level has you closing taps to curb a lava flow flooding the whole town, meaning you have to think about how to get to areas when your old routes are now full of child-melting lava. Battle Of The Birds has you solving a murder, getting attention from fans, defusing a bomb on a train, all sorts. And Don't even get me started on Subcon Forest. Bring spare underwear. Trust me.
Finally, the music is incredible. Smaller/Indie game franchises always have good soundtracks, the main examples being Super Meat Boy, Undertale and Touhou. This is no execption. Every track fits the game's current setting like a glove, from the calm yet uneasy Mafia Town, to the old-movie-esque Murder on Owl Express, to the blood-pumping frenzy of [spoiler] Your Contract Has Expired [/spoiler] (go play the game and then come back), this game's soundtrack is utterly beautiful. I'm listening to it right now, in fact. As well as that, they put voice acting in this. And somehow, ITS ACTUALLY GOOD! With The Conductor's irritatingly likeable accent, to the goon voices of the Mafia, to a very welcome cameo of JonTron in the Dead Bird Studio receptionist (also, that doesn't make this game racist, for god's sake. Stop forcing your opinions onto everyone, you whiny SJWs)  it exhumes professional voice acting, and I utterly love it.
I cannot praise this game enough. Where Yooka-Laylee tried (and failed) to re-imagine the Banjo-Kazooie style of platforming, A Hat In Time makes the perfect balance between exploration and linearity. There's usually one main path to the Time Piece, but you're free to explore the areas at your own pace. With all the hidden goodies scattered around the worlds, it's an explorer's paradise.
This game is a love letter to the days of the 3D platformer and I love it. I guarantee that you will too. Hats off to this game.

36250827.review:
Short review:

This is a very cute game with tons of charm. It's a bit on the short side, especially if you try to blast through the levels, but I think the game would be appreciated much more if you took some time to read through the funny dialogue and run around exploring the worlds.

In a game where exploration is one of the main focuses, I'd have to say movement is really important. Luckily, it feels great and with a little practice you can have complete control of Hat Kid and her abilities. It offers a really good balance of casual to precise platforming and all the movement options allow for advanced players to really push their speed and dexterity to greater heights.

I enjoyed my whole playthrough and I was sad knowing it was coming to an end. The good news is that this game will support the Steam Workshop, so with talented content creators, we can get more worlds, more obstacle course, and more fun.

36231782.review:
When I first heard about this game I looked at the Steam Store page for it and walked away thinking "It's big gimick is that it's cute? So what?" After watching someone else play it for all of about 10 minutes, I realized how much more there was to this game, and how amazingly it was underselling itself by simply calling itself "cute" and "an homage to the GameCube". A Hat In Time is so much more than that. It's everything I ever loved about the Banjo games, Spyro, Mario 64, Mario Galaxy, etc. etc. It is an homage to the 3D platformer as a genre and will hopefully become every bit as influential and well known in this genre as Shovel Knight did for the 2D platformer. 

-Collectibles are satisfying to grab, meaningful, and never become tedious to find or collect
-Controls are tight
-Camera is responsive and helpful
-Characters are quirky and delightful to interact with
-Best portrayal of the Mafia I have ever seen
-Game is neither too long or too short, it ends where it should and leaves you wanting more
-Cutest game on Steam
-Has fantastic Steam Workshop support, with fun mods, dyes, and worlds being made by the community

This game is an absolute delight. 10/10 plan to play again.

36219907.review:
Este juego es rompedor e increíblemente inteligente.

Recoge los aspectos de un juego de plataformas en 3D y un collecthaton y los lleva al extremo, piensa en el jugador y en la experiencia y realmente disfrutas con cada hora que le echas. 

Siempre me han gustado los plataformas 3D, desde Super Mario 64, a Banjo Kazzoie, Banjo Tooie, Super Mario Sunshine, Super Mario 3D Land... Y este es un sucesor más que digno. Es una grata sorpresa después del varapalo de Yooka Laylee, repetitivo, insulso y te insulta continuamente con minijuegos con un control poco adecuado y confuso.

¿Qué cosas podría decir que me han llamado la atención?

Para no hacer muchos spoilers, cada "misión" es casi totalmente diferente de las anteriores, y cada mundo te rompe los esquemas de lo que esperabas. La forma de enfocar y resolver los problemas de cada zona es diferente en cada uno de ellas y como conectan y desarrollan su historia es maravilloso.

En cuanto al control, a pesar de ser muy simple es intuitivo y responde genial, te da oportunidades de rectificar y de hacer cosas avanzadas al mismo tiempo. Sientes que si algo sale mal es culpa tuya, y que con habilidad puedes conseguirlo (maneja muy bien la frustración)

Muchos de los coleccionables no tienen un número específico prefijado. Tienes objetivos, y para llegar a estos objetivos necesitas cierto número de ellos, pero los puedes encontrar o ilimitadamente o en número que sobrepasan esa cantidad. Y para conseguir muchos de ellos, a pesar de decir que hay más de los que necesitas, tienes que afrontar un reto o necesitas cierta habilidad con el juego y los controles. Esto hace que no tengas los coleccionables como un checklist de cosas por recoger, y estés buscando continuamente para ver si te dejas algo, sino que hace que conectes más con el mundo y su historia, y dejes los coleccionables, aún siendo parte importante (obviamente), en un plano más secundario.

Para terminar, y en general, el juego tiene mucho carisma y se nota el cuidado y el cariño que han puesto.

Después de completarlo al 100% (salvo los objetos estéticos), lo recomiendo totalmente, incluso por encima del Mario Odyssey (he jugado a ambos)

36214555.review:
A Hat In Time doesn’t attempt to innovate or change the 3D Platformer. What it offers is tight responsive platforming with different levels around every corner. It’s problems never ruin the experience as the usual feeling of fun is overwhelming. A Hat In Time has challenging bosses and worlds worth exploring in a game you’ll find hard to put down.

If you hate reading -  [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=P6FinCPOIRM] Youtube Review[/url]

(Full Review Below)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Kickstarted games have a history of not meeting expectations, from Mighty No. 9 to Yooka-Laylee. Thankfully this doesn’t apply to A Hat In Time, a 3D Platformer taking inspiration from the Nintendo 64’s greatest platformers. A Hat In Time differs as worlds share few similarities, feeling like it’s unsure of what it truly wants to be. However, it also makes each world a uniquely different adventure, keeping it fresh and exciting as you never know what's next.

The game opens as Hat Kid wakes up to another day on her way home in her spaceship. Disaster soon strikes, as a man from the Mafia appears outside her window and demands she pay a toll as her ship is considered a boat. The window soon breaks as Hat Kid, alongside her 40 hourglasses which fuel the ship, falls from space. It’s enough to give you a purpose and sets the tone for the game, an absurd adventure.

A Hat In Time follows the Super Mario 64 formula with a hub world, in this case, a spaceship, connecting each of the game's worlds. It’s a small area that feels too compact and lacking in detail like that of Peach’s Castle or Isle Delfino. Locked worlds require hourglasses to progress, A Hat In Time’s star equivalent.

Hats play a key part, as you’d probably expect from a game called A Hat In Time, with each hat offering different abilities. The original hat points you to the level’s objective, while the Witch hat allows you to throw explosive potions. Unlocking hats is done by finding yarn throughout the level then crafting the hat of your choice.

Additionally, some levels require green orbs to open, acting like notes from Banjo Kazooie. These orbs are easy to collect, are found everywhere, and seem to respawn as you return to a level. The orbs main purpose is to purchase badges. Badges are modifiers and abilities that can change many factors, such as a badge that makes you die in a single hit (for those who seek an additional challenge) or turn your sprint into a scooter.

The responsive and precise platforming is easily the greatest part of A Hat In Time as you double jump, leap forward, run up a wall and explore. The camera wasn’t ever a focal point, as it adjusted throughout leaving platforming as the focus.

Each world and level is varied, offering many different scenarios. Mafia Town is the first world you visit, which is a coastal village surrounding a volcano which holds up an Italian restaurant in the sky. It's formed from a chaotic combination that often feels like a mess of ideas that never quite fit together.

The second world is a Movie Studio and is an easy improvement, featuring 3 very distinct types of levels which all have vastly different goals, such as stealth focused level through a studio or a dangerous timed run through an exploding train. The Subcon Forest is a horror-themed world complete with a demon forcing contracts and a haunted mansion providing a sense of dread as you are hunted by a terrifying ghost.

Alpine Skyline is unlike the rest of the game as it’s a large connected world featuring a jaw-dropping opening as you fly through the clouds into the mountains above. Smaller sections found here feel like levels themselves as you ascend a windmill, or climb a lava covered “cake”.

The varied levels and worlds found in A Hat In Time show a mix of really great ideas and some that don’t hit their mark. Every minute I spent in Alpine Skyline was a blast, feeling like a combination of everything good about 3d platformers. It was an adventure exploring the mountain peaks where each area took advantage of the mechanics and abilities, from riding across the skies using the Hookshot to exploring a mystical temple using a ghostly ability from a hat found in Subcon Forest. Some levels had an uninteresting hook, such as in the Subcon forest you deliver mail or in the movie studio where you lead a parade. Luckily there are so many great levels that they don’t take from what the game does well.

Boss encounters are challenging, often requiring precision and patience to conquer. Generous checkpoints help avoid frustration as the fights are never over quickly, offering many phases and attacks to watch out for. Each fight is very different but each is visually identifiable when a boss is damageable by a blue glow, the game even references this fact during a boss fight.

The game also has hidden time rifts which are very similar to Super Mario Sunshine’s "secret" levels, focusing on pure platforming. These are far easier then what Sunshine had, and aren’t a requirement to complete the game. You are given a photo of the location where it's hidden before entering a level to find it. You better hope you remember where it is though, as the only way to see the photo is to go to the level select screen. They are never too hidden but can be frustrating if you simply forget where it was.

A Hat In Time doesn’t attempt to innovate or change the 3D Platformer. What it offers is tight responsive platforming with different levels around every corner. It’s problems never ruin the experience as the usual feeling of fun is overwhelming. A Hat In Time has challenging bosses and worlds worth exploring in a game you’ll find hard to put down.

There is an item in the game that makes you a one hit kill to anything that also puts a dent on the abilities that are available to you, reminding you to always follow Cranky's medical perscription of GET GUD! The only complaint I can serve is while this game is beautiful, well built, and well thought out. I simply wish that it had been longer as to make the experience last, or even making a few more diverse characters as while you gave the illusion to a big world, there was alot of reused character models in this game, so if ever you do decide to make an expansion for this game (be it that you are going to serve it DLC style or just add it in an update) Id perhaps go by making more parts to the world or next world you develope as I feel that had you been given more time there would be so much more for us to experience. But do with this what you will, If you take anything from this... it's why are you still reading and not putting your money into this?

36209084.review:
This review contains spoilers.

Please, put your pitch forks and torches down. Before I say anything, this is a good game. I liked it. I thought it was quite fun and had such a blast with the platforming mechanics. I definitely want to see more platformers with gameplay similar to this that just make it so fun to just... move. Seriously, it's so fun to just move Hat Kid around and it's so easy to jump from platform to platform. If you ever happen to miss and fall to your death, it's your own fault about 99.9% of the time.

But the reason I'm not recommending the game... at this time... is because it's just way too short and lacks a lot of... just... something. Like... it has 4 worlds plus one final Bowser level + boss fight. There are 40 collectable hourglasses in total, which are akin to Mario's collectable stars or Banjo-Kazooie's collectable jiggies. And you only need 25 of them in order to take on the final boss. 25 out of 40 hourglasses... that is not a big number. Not when you compare the number of collectable items within early 3D platformers like Super Mario 64's 120 stars... and 15 worlds as opposed to A Hat in Time's measely 4 worlds plus a final boss. Now, I'm not saying that a small indie studio like this should have double that... I'm not even saying that they should have had around the same number. But... I mean... they could have had quite a few more items to collect and levels to explore, even if there weren't 120 items within 15 levels. And it's possibly one of the easiest games I have ever gotten 100%. I usually never 100% games usually because there's just... so much to do in them. It would take ages. This is the opposite where it's just way too easy to 100% it because there's just not enough to do. Even the achievements are pretty easy to obtain... sure, there are some annoying ones to get such as getting through Dead Bird Studio without being seen at all. The point of view of those birds is a little... questionable at some points. HOW THE HECK DID YOU SEE ME FROM OVER THERE?! TIME TO RESTART... AGAIN! But that, aside, super easy to 100%.

Gameplay and shortness, aside, I also feel as though the 'story' wasn't fleshed out enough. Yes, yes, I know... it's a platformer. Stories tend to not be the best when it comes to platformers, but I would have still liked a bit more to it, you know? Like, I want to get to know the characters a bit more. Flesh them out a bit more and make them feel like actual people. Get to know them more. Feel for them. Mustache Girl seemed like she had an interesting story just waiting to surface, but it never came. You meet her a few times in Mafia Town and then... that's it. She disappears for the rest of the game until the very end. Wouldn't it have made sense for there to be a few moments in other worlds when Hat Kid and Mustache Girl would cross paths? Maybe some mini boss fights could take place during these moments. Or perhaps they could be, "race to the hourglass," sort of moments where you have to race Mustache Girl to the hourglass or you fail and have to start it over. That could have also lended nicely to some extra worlds and it could have also added some variety to the missions you have to do. Variety was also kind of lacking since a lot of the missions were just, "get to the end of this place to get an hourglass." And some of the missions that did change things up just seemed overly long just for the sake of trying to artificially extend gameplay, such as the parade with DJ Grooves. It just felt like it dragged on for way longer than it should have. At the very least, there should have been perhaps a special stage specifically designed for the parade. Maybe something similar to Conductor's exploding train stage where you have to follow a certain path to get to the end while also performing tricks and stunts on the way to your destination. I don't know. Anything but what was actually done for that particular stage. I will say, though, that I did love that depending on who won the movie award, they would become the villain you would have to fight at the end. That was genius.

That also kind of extends back to my, "characters aren't fleshed out enough," complaint earlier. DJ Grooves and Conductor were great characters. Really charming. But they, too, weren't really fleshed out quite enough. I want to know more about their rivalry. Okay, yeah, I know that they were once friends and their rivalry started shortly after they both bought the same exact movie studio (how does that even happen?) but what... sparked it? And what sparked such heavy hatred for one or the other to want to steal an hourglass in order to rewind time and earn the rewards that they lost out on? I want to know. All the characters clearly have a lot of personality... they clearly have a lot of baggage that they wish to show us, but don't because... well... the game's super short and only has 4 worlds. I want to know more about Subcon Forest. Was it always so dark, creepy, and depressing? I'd love to know more about the soul taking demon. Was he always like that or did something push him in that direction? I think it was implied that he was Queen Vanessa's prince at one point. And if so, what exactly turned him into what he is now? And how did Queen Vanessa's jealousy and rage turn her into what she is now?

So many characters who deserve to be fleshed out more...

And now, for cut content... now, I know that content tends to always be cut out in games. It doesn't matter what game it is, content will surely be cut out. But there's quite a bit of content that I feel should have definitely been left in that would have just added to the experience. At least I think it would have. Now, I never played the alpha or beta, so I don't know what ALL the cut content was (other than JonTron voicing a penguin that seemed to honestly fit him way more than what he voices in the final game) so I can't really speak for it all. What I have seen, though, seemed really interesting and it just disappoints me so much that it got removed. Such as... being able to dive underwater. It's such a small nitpick, but it's one nonetheless. I would have loved to be able to dive underwater. I know there isn't a water level in the game, so it wouldn't have really been too necessary, but it was still a feature I would have loved to have seen. There could have been collectables hidden in the water in levels that did contain water that could only be gotten if you dove for them. Maybe even make it so that you could only dive with a certain badge equipped.

And speaking of badges, there seemed to be a pretty cool cut feature where you had to... craft badges, I believe, after finding the pieces on certain worlds? That seemed awesome and would have added even more to find! I love that. And there was a cut electric badge which seemed like it could have been useful and just added more to Hat Kid's arsenal.
Finally, that cut Mafia race with you riding on a rocket seemed like a pretty awesome idea. Another way that variety could have been added instead of the race that was in the full game with the Mafia guy on the rocket while you raced him on foot.
That cut content may be super minor when compared to other pieces of cut content... I wouldn't know since, again, never played the alpha or beta. But it's still rather interesting cut content, nonetheless, and it's cut content that I would have loved to see in the full game. Definitely would have given more incentive to explore.

But like I said... the game's good. I like it for what it is. But I feel like it could be much better. And I definitely do not recommend it for its current $30 price tag. Maybe once it drops in price or after the free content DLC is added, my thoughts might change. But until then, I definitely don't recommend it at the current price. I do hope that they make a sequel, though, and possibly improve on everything that was already good in this game as well as adding a butt load of new stuff.

36205401.review:
A Hat in Time is a fun and adorable collectathon game in the style of Mario 64 or Spyro, although unfortunately not quite as long as some games in the genre.  You can expect around 10 hours to beat the game, and perhaps 15-20 to collect everything.

Every world is colorful and unique, containing many vibrant characters some of which are endearing and some of which are lovably loathesome.  It is a pleasure to explore every area, and doing so often involves challenging platforming!  You may add to this a generous sprinkling of secrets and special items which make exploration quite rewarding as well.

Although normal enemies are easily dispatched, Bosses are given a surprising amount of focus!  Each boss has many unique attack patterns plus several phases, and all of them will give you a thrilling challenge.  What's more, there are actually several stealth portions in the game.  This came as a surprise to me, and a welcome one that gives this game an interesting added flavor.

I had a blast playing A Hat in Time, and despite the shortness of the game, I'd say it's well worth the asking price.  I highly recommend it!

36201752.review:
This'll be a quick review which actually makes me feel terrible, because this game deserves essays upon essays of pure praise raining down upon it's developers. And money. Lot's of money. To make new games and expansions, obviously. Because if they don't, I may very well slaughter the whole team.

Pros:

+Awesome music
+Responsive controls
+Sadly no Danny DeVito
+Extremely fun and smooth gameplay
+Hilarious writing
+Somewhat challenging and fun boss fights
+The worlds and their aesthetics
+Steam Workshop and modding
+Hits all the strings that Yooka-Laylee desperately needed to hit

+Memes will be born
+Proper, quality voice acting
+Didn't kick out JonTron
+THE CHARM. THE FEELS
+F*cking everything else

Cons:

-It's a bit short. Current WR when it comes to a glitchless speedrun is around 40-50 minutes I believe. There are only 4 worlds in total.
-It suffers from a severe case of identity crisis. This is not a bad thing per se, it gives the worlds variety however I would have preferred more worlds of the same type. The first world is my favorite, and it would have been nice to see more kinds of large open worlds with a constant flow of things to do. That is not to say any of the other levels are lackluster, not at all. They are all fantastic, however, some of them are heavily scripted. I would rather stumble upon collectables
and challenges myself than have it shoved in my face.
-Could use some more challenging puzzles and combat
-The yarn collectables become practically obsolete inbetween the second and third world, depending on how you tackle them
-Could see some more use of the "pons" collectable. I ended up with thousands of them even after buying all the badges and acts

Very few games leave me with a smile on my face. Fewer manage to capture that feeling of childhood innocence. Even fewer make me feel like a kid again. A Hat in Time manages to do the near impossible and captures all three feelings at the same time. 

The game looks like Legend of Zelda Wind Waker meets Banjo Kazooie; but it plays like Super Mario 64 meets Banjo Kazzoie.

36179423.review:
A crowdfunded game with a lot to live up to, A Hat In Time is a fun and basic action platformer. Controlling Hat Kid feels great in almost every aspect, and in many cases my mistakes were my own. There is a certain...light jankiness to the game as a whole, as from time to time you see the seams in the level geometry, character models, and textures. But it's actually a well-designed game and it reminds me of Psychonauts in a lot of ways. Powers are implemented well into the core mechanics, and the bosses are all fun to fight, and a couple of them provide a decent challenge. It's all on the easy side of things overall, but it's a game that doesn't treat you like an idiot while also not ever ramping the difficulty to stupid levels. The characters in it are colorful and weird, but they have a sense of originality to them as well. Even each world's level progression behaves a little differently from the other, so there's a nice variety here.

And the humor lands well in most cases, too. The second and third worlds in particular do a great job at creating a light-hearted tone. 

Oh, and the game isn't super short, but it isn't exactly long. I vied for all of the time pieces in the game, and doing so on top of beating the game took me only 12 hours or so. I imagine that rushing through to the end would take only a handful of hours.

Aaaaaaaand it operates really well on my aging PC. Unreal Engine doing good work, for sure. You could probably run it easily on a wide range of systems.

But yeah, it's honestly a really fun game with a cute story. It has twists and turns and great gameplay and some decent challenge at times. It's definitely worth a look.

36179263.review: A little 3d platformer stock full of character, with fun at it's core.

36177845.review:
Now this, this is beautiful.

I never really grew up with platformers when I was a child, the only thing close to a platformer i played was the Sly series on my PS2 so I don't really have any nostalgia for collectathon platformers like Banjo Kazooie and Crash Bandicoot so this review comes from someone without any nostalgia goggles for these kind of games.

This game is simply brilliant, almost everything about it is great. The graphics are pretty good and the stylish cartoony look of the game is brilliant, the characters you meet on the way are memorable and unique, the voice acting is great overall and absolutely brilliant in chapter 2 and 3, the level design is great and never gets repetive, the gameplay is fast paced and fun to play and the soundtrack is just simply amazing.

The story isn't anything really advanced but it doesn't need to be, you only really need an excuse to get out there and collect your items needed for the 100% completion. But that doesn't mean that you should just ignore it because what little story there is is kinda cute and interesting and becomes better thanks to the colorful cast of characters you meet on the way. There are even collectibles hidden away in every chapters unique purple time rift that tells a short comic book story about what happened that makes the world in that chapter and the characters in it the way they are.

What makes this game so much fun to play though must be the movement. Hat Kid has a big arsenal of movement abilities at her disposal and exploring each level is so much fun thanks to fluid the controls are and how fun it is to combo together moves to reach a certain platform with a collectible on it. What expands this even more is all the hats you can collect to unlock certain abilities that help you in fighting enemies or traverse the enviroment in new fun ways. There's the hat you begin the game with called the Kid's Hat and it gives you the ability to look at where you need to go in the level to progress, there's the Sprint Hat that gives you the ability to run even faster and jump farther to reach platforms you couldn't reach before, there's the Brewing Hat that gives you the ability to pull out an explosive potion that can destroy certain objects or do AOE damage on enemies, there's the Ice Hat that gives you the ability to use certain launch pad labeled with a Snow Flake icon to launch yourself to otherwise unreachable places, there's the Dweller Mask that makes certain transparent platforms solid so you can traverse them and there's the Time Stop Hat that temporarily stops time for you. You can tweak your gameplay experience a tiny bit more too with badges that you can buy that you put on your hat to give you certain abilities you either need to complete the game or just something to suit your fancy.

Now so far it sounds like this game is nothing but perfect and it almost is but there are some few problems here and there that are noticable and can be annoying and the two biggest problems I had where some bugs and the camera. Now I don't know why the developers decided to be so restrictive with the camera because in other platformers I've played you pretty much get free range with what you can do with the camera, if I need to look above me to see what's up there I can in any other platformer but not in A Hat In Time for some reason. Several times I've run into that problem where I needed to look above to see what's up there but just not being able too because of the restrictive camera controls. If they would update the game to give the player more control over the camera I think a lot of people would get happy because that's something I just don't understand why it's not in the game. When it comes to the bugs it has for the most part not been that awful, the biggest one I had was a hardcrash to desktop early on in the game but thankfully that only happened once, other bugs I encountered were that some command prompts did not appear when they should have and resulting in me taking damage, the jumping around could sometimes be a little glitchy too and there are some times where I even ended up outside of the map. Thankfully all this happened rarely and my journey through this game was 99% of the time smooth as butter.

Another strange thing in this game is that most of the faces on the characters in the game don't have their face modeled on and instead the developers have plastered on a .PNG that hovers slight infront of their face. Now it looks fine most of the time but in certain angles from the side the face disappears and all you have left is a faceless model and sometimes the .PNG even clips through some things on the model. This is just a really minor complaint and really don't impact anything about the game. The last things I want to talk about that could have improved the game slightly more is that the game is really easy, I barely died in this game and when I did it was to either some bug or me just being lazy and seeing how quickly and recklessly I could complete the platforming session, and when you do die you don't even have to restart the level, you only need to retry from the last checkpoint most of the time which is also where you end up when you fall down from the platforming session. The bosses are pretty easy too but that doesn't mean they are bad, all of them have some gimmick you need to figure out to beat them and when you do figure it out it is fun but I think the bosses could still be slightly harder and not so forgiving when it comes to player mistakes. The last boss in the game is especially very easy and I was a bit disappointed with it overall. The other thing that could seriously benefit from a difficulty increase is the collecting in the game, the only thing you need to collect to get a 100% in the game are the Time Pieces which are very easy to get, you get one for every act you do in each chapter and if you complete every act in every chapter plus every time rift in each chapter you will get them all with minimum effort. Now compare this game to another game that I have completed to a 100% like Ty The Tasmanian Tiger 1 then you can see how really easy this game is, in Ty 1 you need to find over 300 hundred picture frames scattered around and hidden on every level, you need to get every Boomerang in the game, find all the Golden Cogs, save all the Bilbies and much much more. There's a lot of stuff to find and collect in that game and it takes some real effort and it feels super rewarding once you do it, a feeling that is sadly not here in A Hat In Time. Also some things in this game feels kinda out of place and that is blood that they decided would be appropriate in a few places and I mean FEW places, there's like two times blood is on the screen which feels weird thank to the games cartoony friendly aesthetic. Plus in one of the purple time warps in a hidden area there is a book that is called something like "Good ethic reasons for capitalist consumption" and it's followed by "All the pages are blank", now I don't know why there's socialist propaganda in my cartoony platformer collectathon game about a space traveling girl with magical hats but that definitely broke my immersion by reminding me of all the terrible things in this world.

Even though I have some complaints about the game that I think could have improved the experience much more I still think that this game is really really phenomenal and worth your time and money, even on full asking price it's worth every cent and I don't regret my purchase at all. This game is definitely a contender for my game of the year award and I'm sure I'll play it again some day when they've added more content and fixed up the game more.

tl;dr
Positive:
+Great gameplay
+Colorful and nice graphics
+Great characters
+Great voice acting
+Cute as all hell
+Amazing soundtrack

Negative:
-Stiff and restrictive camera controls
-Some unpolished bugs
-Too easy
-Could use better faces

36155971.review:
A Hat in Time is easily one of my top games of 2017.  I purchased the Deluxe Edition, while it was still available, from the [url=http://hatintime.com/]A Hat in Time website[/url] in the early summer of 2017.  I purchased it early since the game was looking like something I'd really enjoy and to get the bonuses that were part of the Deluxe Edition. 

[b]Best played with a controller.[/b]

[h1]The Good, the Bad and the Middle Ground[/h1]

[b]Good[/b][list]
[*]Story: the story suits the game well and there is enough balance to make it enjoyable.  There are parts and world settings that are more mature, making the game less kid friendly.
[*]Exploring: exploring the worlds is fun and the worlds are different enough that they are each unique.
[*]Characters: the characters are each unique and enjoyable. 
[*]Music: the music is great and suits the game and stages well.
[*]Mature themes: the game has a number of story bits and settings that are more mature.  Nothing too mature, but not kid friendly.
[*]3D Platforming: the platforming is done really well with the camera cooperating reasonably with your movements.
[*]Controls: the controls are responsive.
[*]Graphics: the graphics are enjoyable and suit the story and game well.
[*]Voice Acting: all the voiced lines are well done.
[*]Hats: the hats are each unique.
[/list]

[b]Middle Ground[/b][list]
[*]Antagonist: the interactions you have with the main antagonist are quite limited.  I would've liked to have had more interactions with the main antagonist throughout the worlds, even if those interactions were small.
[*]Badges: badges are added to hats to give little bonuses or added powers, in total you get 3 slots when you have the pins to add them.  Some of the powers, like hookshot, should have been added in a different way as to not have them take up a badge slot.  Perhaps the weapon could have had slots as well to power it up in different ways.  Overall, there aren't enough badges and the variety is somewhat limited.
[*]Hub: the hub is fairly simple, which is great in my opinion (makes for quick navigation), but there is very limited things to do besides going to the different telescopes (world access).  I would've liked to have seen more interactions with the various characters in the hub.
[*]Rift Tokens: through the game you collect rift tokens might are used to collect cosmetic variations of the hats, colours (change your outfit colour) and remixed soundtracks through a randomized roulette machine.  There are not enough of them in the game, unless you use the developer console, to acquire all the token rewards.  This was intentional as the developers are adding in more tokens through playing Steam Workshop mods (when available) and future DLCs.
[*]Alpine Skyline: one of the worlds, Alpine Skyline, is a giant 3D platforming section that is divided out into small islands.  The world does have some variety in the platforming and what you're doing, but I would have liked to have seen completely different islands.  Examples could be downhill skiing, caves or a thick snowy forest.
[*]Camera: the camera can be a little frustrating at times, nothing extremely bad, at least from what I found and put it through.
[*]Non-voiced lines: there are lines that aren't voiced.  They are mostly fine, but it is somewhat odd when they are next to fully voiced dialogue.
[/list] 

Nothing in the Middle Ground is bad, just things I would like to see improved upon in sequels.

[b]Bad[/b]
Nothing stood out as bad. 

[h1]Playtime[/h1]
My first playthrough is ~20 hours and included 100% completion, minus a handful of collectibles (yawn and rift tokens) that don't show up on the relic map and aren't apart of the completion status.  I'll be going back to do second playthrough soon.

[h1]Rating[/h1]
Highly recommended and well worth full price. 

I'll be picking up any future DLCs that are released and definitely any sequels.  

Thank you Gears for Breakfast for creating a great game.  I look forward to the continuing adventures of Hat Kid.

36136982.review:
I don't usually leave reviews for games that I play, but I feel that this absolutely needs one. First off, I'd like to say that I recommend this game with no reservations. That being said, there are some cons to consider.
 
Largely because this is a fairly low budget game, there are a few graphical bugs and invisible walls in inconvenient places, however these are almost entirely harmless as far as enjoyment goes. The achievements are, arguably, too easy to get. While they were by no means a cakewalk, the majority took half an hour or so of playtime to get. 

The voice acting is somewhat low quality, although I'm putting this as a pro and a con because it adds to the overall experience in an amazing way.

The pros, unlike the cons, would take a very long time to list. 
-The aesthetic is one of the best I've seen
-the atmosphere changes perfectly from area to area
-there is a large amount of variation in environment and gameplay based on context. This is mainly in regards switching from parkour to fighting to swinging, but there is a noticeable amount of change.
-the difficulty has a very good curve, while leaving potential to find difficulty even in the easy areas... strengthening replayability
-the controls are very intuitive, and are a very nice mix in between snappy and forgiving. Basically, they're comfortable without handholding you, and you will always go where you tell the game to go.

I had to search for the cons in this game. If it looks interesting in the least to you, I'd recommend springing for it. You won't regret it.

36132181.review:
This game made me so happy. From its loveable characters to its great platforming, this game was simply so much fun to play even when you were stuck on a jump or a boss. This game was beautiful and everything i wanted it to be.

Pros
+ Both keyboard and controller friendly (I used both and found the controls to be crisp on both methods)
+ Amazing soundtrack. The OST is over 5 hours long and each enviroment has unique and vibrant music.
+ The game stands on it own two feet, it has its own unique and loveable characters and settings
+ All of the game is replayable to collect that last item or revisit a world to explore new areas
+ Some levels are fast and easy and some are extremely complex
+ Pure simple fun

Cons
+ Sometimes the platforming controls can be a bit anoying (Wall jumps not going how you want them to)
+ Clipping can be a problem but i assume this will be patched in future (Mafia boss bugged several times in my run)

If you loved 3D platformers like Super Mario, Banjo Kazooie, and other iconic N64 games of the same style i would encourage you to give this game a go.

36127192.review:
[h1] Did you have anything to do with the junk falling from the sky? [/h1]

This is without a doubt one of the best platformers I have ever played. Gears for Breakfast really delivered on this game and I can't wait to see what they do in the future! A Hat in Time offers simplistic, Banjo-Kazooie esque combat, smooth platforming, quirky characters, and cartoony, gorgeous worlds to explore and collect in. The game stars a nameless protagonist given the nickname Hat Kid by the devs as she is travelling back home on her weirdly, lined-shaped spaceship. After her spaceship slows down by an interesting-looking planet, either because the ship needs to cool down or plot, a member of the Mafia found on that same planet breaks in to her ship and accidentally releases all of her fuel (Time Pieces) out into space and then scattered on the interesting, Earth-like planet. Hat Kid must then go on a grand adventure to recover her missing Time Pieces and return home. Along the way she meets many interesting characters. From air-headed Mafia members to jazzy Moon Penguins to a soul-taking entity in the woods. They are all quirky and never fail to warm my heart and make me laugh uncontrollably. The areas Hat Kid travels through are all so unique, colorful, and filled with things to collect and places to explore. Collecting things in this game is similar to Banjo Kazooie, but not as grand and more simplified. A Hat In Time feels like Super Mario Galaxy, plays like Super Mario Sunshine and has many of the elements and dark humor of N64 era Rare platformers. I hope the things I said above have convinced you to buy this masterpiece but if you need a more in-depth look at what the game offers, I'll make a pros/cons list below. 

[b] [u] Pros [/u]

[list]
[*] Great voice-acting
[*] Simplistic but intriguing combat
[*] Beautiful visuals
[*] Lots of charm
[*] Quirky, loveable characters
[*] Unique areas to explore and to collect 
[*] Awesome bosses
[*] A godlike soundtrack
[*] Great sound design 
[*] Witty, dark-humored jokes
[*] Fantastic dialouge
[*] Smooth platforming/tight controls
[*] Well-placed secrets and easter eggs
[*] A good over-arching plot 
[*] Good subplots and stories in each area 
[*] Doesn't take itself too seriously
[*] Outstanding animation
[*] Mod Support
[/list]

[b] [u] Cons [/u]

[*] Had a texture bug but was resolved when I turned up my graphics
[*] Ocassional glitches
[*] Alpine Skyline can be a little confusing to navigate at times
[*] Very short for a 3D platformer

[b] [u] Overall Score [/u]
        [h1] 9.7/10 [/h1]

36126951.review:
A Hat in Time, was an absolutely wonderful experience that has earned it's place as being one of my favorite games to date, drowning in charm and polish.
**I highly suggest this game to anyone who loves the platforming games of yore like Banjo Kazooie and Super Mario Sunshine!**
  --Pros!--
- An action platformer with multiple abilities tied to different Hats and Badges.
- Chapters where the game transcends it's own genre by adding Stealth elements, boss fights, and even horror/thrillers!
- A vast amount of customization options for you to unlock in the form of Paint for different color schemes for Hat Kid, and different appearances for your Ability Hats.
- A largely voice acted game with loads of witty and fun writing!
- More free DLC in the future(?)
- Steam Workshop supported for community creations!
     --Cons!--
- Wish it were a little longer.   (But it felt like a great amount to play and explore!)

I managed to 100% complete the current game and all it's Steam achievements in under 20 hours, whilst still being fun and exciting to the very last drop! I'm very much looking forward to whatever project Gears For Breakfast has next!

36107839.review:
Have your Lava Cake and eat it

is the line that best describes A Hat in Time. It defies the genre that it's in, whilst also being a fantastic entry in it. It manages to give you both big open collectathon levels AND keep the experience linear and guided, tell interesting stories, and provide good boss fights. And when I say "good boss fights", I mean the [i]BEST[/i] bossfights the genre has ever seen! The kind you never think about when you hear the words "3D platformer".

Another thing you will notice immediately is that it does not hold back most of its movement abilities behind unlocks. Not by a long shot! The moment you start the first level, you have a double jump, which you can chain into a dive, which resets your double jump. Oh, and you also get parkour on walls, as a cherry on top. This immediate wealth of movement means you do not have to wait for collectables to make the game good. You can zip across rooftops, platforms, and enemies like a ninja mere minutes into the game, to the tune of great music and whimsy of a good sense of humor.

The only shortcoming that holds it back is that parts of it feel... unfinished. Where's the story and boss of level 4? Why is the last level so short? Why is it that most unlocks hardly ever get used as level mechanics? Oh, and no, there is no replay value in the base game - once you collect everything there's not much else to do. Thankfully, the game has good mod support to solve that.

36107454.review: This is actually the game that you were hoping Yooka-Laylee would have been.

36106686.review:
Video Review: Coming Soon

[b]Written Review:[/b]

A Hat in Time is a 3D Collectathon Platformer, developed by Gear for Breakfast (god I love that name)

The game follows the absolutely adorable and aptly named Hat Kid who must travel from world to world in order to collect each of her 40 missing Time Pieces that have been scattered thanks to the meddling of the Mafia from a nearby planet while Hat Kid is on her way home….from somewhere?

The game follows a structure very similar to Super Mario Sunshine and Super Mario Galaxy, in which you have a basic hub that will allow you to select a world to visit alongside each mission that each world contains.

Each and every mission changes up the world in some minor or major way depending, for example in the first world of the game “Mafia Town” you begin chasing after the mysterious Mustache girl, while later on you can find yourself in a literal game of the floor is lava.

The worlds are all for the most part extremely open ended, allowing you to quite easily be able to branch off from the beaten path and explore the admittedly large and imaginative environments at your own will.

Hell the first world in particular, I am convinced it’s inspired by the hub world from Super Mario Sunshine “Delfino Plaza” simply due to how open it is alongside the general aesthetic of the place.

Now A lot of folk would be concerned however about large and vast levels in these type of games, as they can tend to be confusing to navigate in a lot of instances and even easy to lose track of your objective. Thankfully in A Hat in Time, this is not an issue, the game is very cleverly designed to the point that I never found myself lost, even after I went off the path to do my own exploring.

Not only that but via the use of Hat kids…..well….hat, you can instantly locate your objective at any time to get right back on track if you lose where you are meant to go!

The controls here are simply magnificent and very free-flowing, it’s very easy to not only make very long and wide jumps easily, you can also do pinpoint precise jumps without ANY issue whatsoever.

This is only helped through the double jump and dive abilities too which give hat kid an insane level of control, that very few platformers can reach.

On top of her basic jumping moveset, Hat kid can also pull off a basic 3 hit combo to attack enemies, and perform a Sonic Adventure esque homing attack on nearby foes, though this is a little fiddly to perform correctly I feel.

Littered throughout your adventure too you will usually come across Yarn balls, these will allow you to construct new hats to utilise, that all offer unique abilities and powers, for example you can get an ice cap to perform ground pound abilities, that also allow you to springboard from specific points in the world, or have a dwellers mask that makes transparent objects interactable for a few seconds for platforming challenges.

This isn’t even getting into the badges you can buy from a very creepy glitchy looking fellow that offer gameplay modifiers such as item magnetism or the ability to fall far without taking damage.

Hell you even get a grappling hook later in the game for spider-man style action!

The presentation here is also absolutely top notch, with some FANTASTIC visuals that are reminiscent of the gamecube era of games, all the games dialogue voice acting, jokes and music are extremely amazing through and through.

The game clearly has a lot of love put into it here, with every single part simply oozing character, whether from the shady crows that ask for personal details in the Agatha Christie esque murder mystery level(yes you heard me right) or from simple things such as Hat Kid wearing an adorable raincoat in poor weather.

I’m not even going into the boss battles which I think it’s safe to say, I think these are some of the best fights i’ve ever seen in a 3D platformer!

There’s even a number of Raw platforming challenges in the form or “Time Rifts” littered about that offer challenges very much like the fluddless challenges from Super Mario Sunshine which are all an absolute blast to play!

Sadly the game isn’t perfect, there are occasional camera issues to be found here and there (much like most platformers tbh), and sometimes Hat Kids little climbing ability can get stuck on certain objects from time to time, plus the homing attack issue I mentioned earlier in the review...but in the grand scheme of the game, these are very minor niggles at worst and really don’t affect my experience all that much in the grand scheme of things!

Ultimately A Hat in Time is without a doubt one of the greatest platforming titles I have ever played, and a game I think that any platforming fan simply owes themselves to play through!







RANK A

Pros:
Adorable
Extremely fun
Dat Presentation

Cons:
Fiddly Homing Attack
Minor camera hiccups

36088879.review:
[b]Short Summary:[/b] Hat in Time is a lovably crafted, adorable platformer about the equivalent of an alien girl getting into Hijinks recovering her time-altering ship fuel. It can be completed in about a day or two if one were to sit down and mainline it, longer if they go after the bonuses. $30 might be a bit much to ask for with its short span, but anything less would be a bargain.

[b]Longer Sumary:[/b] Hat in time is a platformer game that sees its roots from platformers of similar Genre's such as Psychonauts. It follows a young girl often referredd to as just 'kid' who, after a run-in with the mafia; has her fuel scattered across the planet. Time-altering hourglasses, making your journey to recover them and the people you meet along the way. A girl with a mustache, a possessive contract demon. Even two warring 'bird' movie directors.

[b]Bullet Points.[/b]
------------------------------------
[b]+[/b] Incredible soundtrack. Boss music sounds energized and upbeat, stages fit their music thematically. And even through challenge stage prizes you can earn remixed versions of songs you can have play instead.

[b]+[/b] Adorable artwork. Each of the stage Act's come with their own splash artwork that portrays Hat kid and her situation in appealing light. This shows up especially in Chapter 2, I'd like to believe.

[b]+[/b] Level Variety. Chapter one gives you the sense that things are going to be open-world hunts similar to how Super Mario Sunshine may have done, but later on the type of game each stage illustrates changes that fact dramatically. Chapter 2 has sidescroller segments, Chapter 3 has a hide-and-seek Clock tower Horror segment. And so on.

[b]+[/b] Extensive mod support. Coming from modded routes, the devs havee every intention to let one create and insert content for just about everything available in the game. Levels, hats, color palettes, you name it.

[b]+[/b] Great subtext humor. "THIS IS INSULTING! IM GONNA SUE!" and many other comedic bits exist in things in all stages as well as your ship, providing comedic quirks that'll get a chuckle or two out of most.

However, there are a few nitpicks.

[b]-[/b] Performance. While the game does have fantastic settings options - enough to make even people on an awful HD3000 like me - run the game playable, some places can't quite escape the framerate drops. VFX in Chapter's 2 and 3 were especially bad at this, resulting me having to take some serious measures to get playable framerates for important boss fights.

[b]-[/b] Controls. While sharp and responsive, they can also be deemed the most hindering example for when wall climbing/jumping. Numerous times have I died in a challenge run because the wall that I was auto-jumping on top of was instead hurdled over with too much zeal. Unless you can train yourself to stop touching the movement as you're making the hop, you will [b]die[/b] nine out of ten times.

[b]-[/b] Hitboxes. While on the topic, hitboxes for certain things such as tightropes can be a bit nitpicky. Sometimes you land on them from a meter away, and sometimes they'll ignore you entirely screwing up your whole flow. There's also an occasion where people with abyssmal FPS (7-15) will have pickups bugged, making you need to pause and unpause the game to make them valid for picking up.

[b]-[/b] Short. Regrettably, with five chapters and a 25 (of 40) hourglass minimum to complete the game. It won't take you much longer than me (About 6-8 hours) to complete the game if you aren't trying to shoot for absolutely everything everywhere. Atleast more content is planned!

[b]OVERALL:[/b] Hat in Time is definitely worth the money if you can't wait for a sale - if it is on sale, there's literally no reason to not get it if you enjoy platformers such as Psychonauts or Mario Sunshine.

36087702.review:
(Una review en español para variar)
Despues de 20 hs y haber sacado todos los logros, finalmente puedo hacer una mini review:
A hat in time es uno de los mejores juegos indies del 2017.
[u]Historia[/u]
Usas a esta chica "hat kid" (ya que su verdadero nombre nunca se revela) que a pesar de verse como una niña normal, es en realidad una alien, que realizaba un viaje a su hogar, en su nave, cuyo combustible (por alguna razon) son relojes de arena magicos, y por X motivos termina sufriendo un accidente que termina con todos sus relojes perdidos en ese planeta, de ahi en mas comienza toda la aventura recorriendo ese mundo bastante extraño.
[u]Gameplay[/u]
Si tenes mas de 20 años recordaras cualquier juego plataformero 3d de finales de los 90 y comienzos del 2000, basicamente AHIT es eso, como muchos lo comparan con Banjo-Kazooie o hasta los mario 3d de esa epoca (64/sunshine) y no es mala comparacion por que es verdad, los controles son perfectos, ni muy sensibles  ni muy toscos, manejar a hat kid es totalmente comodo, y otro de los puntos principales en la jugabilidad, son los sombreros que vas desbloqueando a medida que avanzas en el juego, que otorgan diferentes habilidades clave para poder avanzar en algunas partes, y tambien a estos sombreros se les equipan parches/insignias que otorgan habilidades extras tanto a algunos sombreros como a hat kid (van desde cosas simples como hacerte correr rapido, lanzar pociones o cosas mas bizarras como convertirte en una estatua de hielo o detener el tiempo), y por ultimo el juego es poco lineal ya que varios capitulos se desarrollan en mundos gigantes, donde se te da la opcion de que hacer primero sin que afecte a los otros capitulos del juego.
[u]Graficos[/u]
Decentes (no quiero decir que sean malos pero tampoco son espectaculares), totalmente estilo "cartoon" coloridos, con varios efectos que le dan mas vida a todo el ambiente, cada mundo tiene una ambientacion totalmente diferente al anterior, desde una ciudad en una isla con playas y brillante sol, hasta un bosque tetrico lleno de diversos monstruos y fantasmas, cabe resaltar que el juego permite una gran variedad en la configuracion grafica, para ayudar a cualquiera con pc de gama baja.
[u]Musica[/u]
Muy buen reportorio de musica, totalmente variada, no puedo juzgar mucho desde este aspecto ya que no tengo gran conocimiento, pero puedo decir que es de esos juegos donde el ost no te aburre, muchas melodias pegajosas, y siempre ayudan para la ambientacion de cada nivel, desde musica totalmente alegre y festiva, hasta musica tetrica sacada de algun juego de horror.
[b]En resumen[/b],vale la pena 30 dls? no sabria decirlo con seguridad, la duracion del juego reuniendo la mayoria de coleccionables y sacando todos los logros no es mas de 15 o 17 hs, si te gustan los plataformeros 3d bien hechos y con un buen diseño de personajes y su mundo en general, vale la pena, pero si con eso no te alcanza o tenes dudas, espera a alguna de las rebajas de steam, puedo decir que por 20 dls el juego es totalmente recomendable. Y como algo que olvide, el juego viene con workshop, asi que pueden encontrar una gran cantidad de mods hechos por la comunidad, desde sombreros hasta niveles, cosa que le da aun mas valor al juego.

36087600.review:
You know what my first review was not good enough to really detail what I think of this game, so let me get it out there. Also I'm updating the review so that I can get the steam awards stuff.

Tl,dr;
This game is fun. You should get this game. It's fun, satisfying, and just charming in every aspect of the word. I want more. (This is basically every review out there reworded like you do with a High School  history essay.) 

For Funny Points and so when you actually do play the game you can laugh at this:

I once had a friend. This mafia guy warned me about her, but I thought she was chill. Then time broke. The end. 

Actual review:

I would buy this game 3 times over if I could, no scratch that 4. 

Basic Summary:
     You play as the adorable Hat Girl (yes that is her name, there's really nothing else to it) going around Super Mario Sunshine/64 style collecting the main collectable of the game, Time Pieces. If you're even considering buying this game you should've known that by now. If you even have seen one review you would know that this game is by far one of the most cutesy/charming 3D platforms out there, and you can tell Gears for Breakfast put so much damn love into this game it almost is like it was their own child. Now onto a basic Pro's and Con's List.

Pro:
- Art Style (and yes that is my own objective opinion)
- Hat Girl is the most satisfying thing to control ever, it's like a combination of the best parts of 3D Sonic (being the homing attack she has), and the movement control of 64/Sunshine Mario. The moveset is also very forgiving and quick to pick up; you can probably learn the entire control scheme on a controler within minutes of playing the game. 
  - She might even be more satsifying to control than Mario in Super Mario Oddesy (which is a 
    really bold statement but her moveset is simpler so it could just be the symplicity over the 
    variety and motion based commands of Mario)
- Level Design is fun, and is very clear and consise when it wants to be, or open and free when it lets you. The levels also don't feel copy-pasted, and each protrays it's theme very well so I never get bored going to different areas.
- Grant Kirkhope and Plasma3Music are wonderful composers and really have brought a lot of life into this world through the sounds, I cannot tell you how much I've just listened to the soundtrack in a level over and over again.
- Tons of little dialoge and actions that really just bring life to the world. It's so refreshing to find little tiny details everywhere.
- Speedrunning stuff is accsessable and really satisfying due to the simple control scheme that can be used to do more complex manuvers.
- Active modding community makes it so that the game, even when you beat it 100%, will never become dull.
- Did I mention cute characters? I think I did. They're cute, and have good interactions.

Neutral Points:
- Voice Acting is kinda a mixed bag, you go from annoying girl to really funny and enthusastic soul stealing ghost. But if you don't want Voice Acting you could always buy the plug your ear's badge or just turn off the volume for character voices.

Negative (more like nitpicking) Points:
- Some animations aren't really that polished as they could be (i.e. theres one scene when Hat Girl closes her eyes and you can still see her eyes in the eyelid).
- Hats overall feel somewhat gimicky (besides the speed hat, which actually is quite nice) and somewhat hinder fluidity from time to time. Other times it's perfectly fine though because they serve the purpose of blocking off a section until you have propper equipment. [spoiler] The time slow hat is actually suprisingly useful in boss fights if you're trying not to get hit, and can help timed sections along with being able to take certain things with a bit more leisure. [/spoiler]
- I want more of this game, that's the real nitpick here, I JUST WANT MORE OF THIS STELLAR GAME. 

In conclusion, A Hat in Time is a stellar product that is fun, charming, and just overwelmingly a great game. Gears for Breakfast obviously put love and care into this game and I hope they recieve the goal they wanted when they released this game. Also hopefully they have enough funding to make more games like this or free content updates or DLC for it or SOMETHING.

Also if someone at Gears for Breakfast is out there can you just tell us if you plan to bring this wonderful game to the Nintendo Switch? It just seems like such a perfect platform to do this cause playing this game on the go would be great.
