36086919.review:
Solid 3D-platformer with a great amount of polish and character; definitely memorable and enjoyable. Strange/dividing design choices in certain parts of the game, and with certain characters. Seems like a game that could have used another 6-9 months of QA/focus testing.
Recommended for anyone who enjoyed Super Mario 64, Super Mario Sunshine, or Super Mario Galaxy.
Charming characters, quirky, funny voice-acting, interesting levels, and exceptional music. Every one of the four worlds feels unique. 
Level pacing can feel a bit scatter-brained at times, and level design varies from excellent to poor. Expect to find glitches, bugs, an occasional stuck camera. Nothing that impedes the game, or any crashes. Strangely enough, the segregated Time Rift levels can sometimes be the most enjoyable part of play session. 
Overall, a welcomed title to the starved genre. The community-created levels/mods are so far excellent, and promise immense content for the time to come. The devs are also working on post-release content for 2018.

36085422.review:
If you'd like to watch this review instead of read it, you can find the video here:
https://youtu.be/z16m-Oy4Sbs

True to the collectathon genre's name, A Hat In Time's core gameplay is based around exploration and discovery. You're given large worlds to poke around in that contain all manner of items and doodads that either make your journey easier by themselves, or can be combined into and traded for powerups. In this case, you can either find yarn to stitch new hats together, or Pons, which act as the universal currency for everything from new passive abilities and game modifiers to a way to unlock new levels. There are also the key items that are not only integral to every act, but also to beating the game itself. They're called Time Pieces here, and they're the driving motivator behind the story. Your ship uses time as fuel, you see, and after an incident, they're scattered all over this mysterious nearby planet. So, Hat Kid needs to postpone her journey home to collect them all back up and continue on her way. With great power comes great responsibility, though, and when the denizens of the planet discover what these little magical hourglasses can do, it leads to all kinds of problems cropping up. Needless to say, they're important. So important that you're sent back to the hub every time you collect one. That way, the next act can be tailored to make the quest for its Time Piece have its own set of events and storylines.

So yes, it is a collectathon platformer, but it's more akin to a Mario game than Banjo Kazooie. Specifically, World 1 feels very reminiscent of Super Mario Sunshine. And from there on, it revels in doing its own thing. The worlds just keep getting better as they go, literally reaching their peak at the fantastic Alpine Skyline. Because of the previously mentioned yarn and pons, though, it strikes a nice balance between the two styles. You get to have the fantastic setpieces and different mission types that only a customized version of the same area could have, but that doesn't mean you can't just go off the rails at any time and do your own thing. It's up to you what's important at that particular moment: do you advance the game's story, or go make your own? Do you want to add to your vault of time pieces, or hunt down some of those relics that open bonus stages? Yeah, speaking of Mario Sunshine, when you progress far enough in any given world, Time Rifts start showing up, and these come in two flavors.

The ones that pop up naturally with progression are platforming challenges that test your skills against some really cool 3D obstacle courses. They're just the right amount of difficult; never pushing you to the point of pulling your hair out, but still challenging you to approach the abilities you're used to in clever ways. Meanwhile, the relic rifts result when a time piece lands on someONE, not someTHING, and they're designed around that person's past experiences and memories. These are more like mini-collectathons, asking you to scour relatively small areas for special pons that open the hatch to the next floor, and eventually giving way to another time piece. You'll find pieces of picture books in these rifts that (when put back together), fill in the details of what the story is behind the more important characters in each area. Completing a rift also gives you a spin on a bonus wheel that rewards your skills with new color palettes and variant hats for your character, as well as remixed level tracks that you can swap out in the main hub. You can get more spins by finding rift tokens in the worlds as well, giving you one more reason to poke around in ALL the nooks and crannies.

The last big collectible item worth mention are the badges. These are equippable items that offer modifiers to either your base abilities or the game itself, such as immunity to fall damage, no bonking when you accidentally dash into a wall, or even fun things like replacing the voice acting with Banjo-Kazooie style mubling. Special mention must go to the free-roam screenshot camera (which is a wonderful addition to what is already an incredibly screenshot-able game). One weird design decision is that a key skill is tied to one of your badges. You get pins that let you equip up to 3 badges at a time eventually, but the added luxury feels a little hollow when one of those slots is always going to be taken up. It feels kinda limiting, especially when a lot of these are quality of life upgrades that make the act of playing much easier, like magnetizing pons and health restoring items to yourself. Oh, and I'm going to say this right now: prepare yourself for glitches. Plural. As in, more than one; at least two more than none. This was an indie game after all, so the coding isn't as air-tight as it could be. And you know what? I don't care.

I'm gonna sound like such an apologist tool for saying this, but I don't actually mind the glitches in this game because they're amusing. They don't corrupt my save file or make the stage unplayable or anything; they're mostly just hiccups in collision that lead to very entertaining results. I found a way to break a sequence in the very first level. I had a moment on stream where I collected a time piece, and Hat Kid fell through the universe. And this one time, Cooking Cat learned how to levitate, so not to be outdone, I sat on a chair while on top of my roomba so I could join her. Remember that camera badge I mentioned earlier? Well, if you put the normal camera between you and a wall, you can actually force the free-roam camera beyond the collision and see the level from the other side.

I mean this in the best possible way: A Hat In Time feels like it was designed by a 7-year old. What I mean by that is everything has this child-like whimsy to it; this magical perspective that comes along with that period in your life where everything is amazing. Even the hub world is a joy to explore. You can dive into a pool of candy-shaped pillows. The walls and floors are covered in bright and wonderful designs that make it look like the world's most awesome clubhouse more than a spaceship. Even the non-playable characters are fantastic and lively. They're genuinely written well, and bursting with so much personality that you could learn a lot about them just from a single box of dialogue. Some are even voiced by my fellow internet personalities. Deserving of particular mention is Yungtown's amazing performance as The Snatcher; a character who's having so much fun being evil that he actually tricks you into liking him at times. It's great! And it all retains that child-like innocence throughout. Most of the random mooks you beat up are Mafia memebers and yucky things like spiders. There's no malice behind it; they're just bad guys. You beat up bad guys; it's what you do. At least, that's what would make sense to somebody that young.

A Hat In time is easily worth the mid-range asking price. There is no doubt in my mind about that. Without any reservations, I can recommend this game to anybody who's even remotely interested in what it's got going on.

36092011.review:
How do I begin with A Hat in TIme? I was not there when they revealed their idea to the world, nor did I donate to the kickstarter, nor did I even know what it was exactly until I saw it on here and watched the trailer. But it struck home, even disregarding me not knowing a thing about it. I had grown to be sick and tired of my grind games, and the barren wasteland that is steam's library as a whole, but as  soon as I saw what was offered, I was immediately hooked. If there was one thing I needed, it was a well polished platformer where you could feel the developers putting their blood, sweat, tears, and love into it. 

 A Hat in Time follows a silent, but plucky young girl and her hat through an adventure on a large, gorgeous looking planet. You explore this planet using your space ship as the main hub world, with the space ship itself holding many interesting nooks and crannies for you to explore and re-explore as the game goes on. The game itself looks good, the animated style coupled with the top notch platforming who's design allows for play styles of all speeds (I personally started off a little slow but eventually I was zooming through as if I had never stopped playing platformers) all while exploring a world with plenty of NPC's to talk to, hidden things to find, and collectibles ranging from humorous souvenirs of the planet to yarn balls that will let you create more unique hats with their own special powers, all the way to coins to attempt to play a slot machine for various hats skins, song remixes, and alternate costume colors. There are also badges you can buy ingame that also increase utility for the hats, but sadly there are too few for myself, with about 12 or so, but in this case the number is plenty to go through your adventure. 

The story itself is simple enough. You as a plucky hero have lost through certain means the ability to make it back home, and when the going get's tough, you get going. For a platformer, this is perfectly fine, especially as the colorful cast and voice acting really bring the story home. The voice acting makes everything endearing and through the gameplay makes you really want to complete and collect everything. Every level has it's own little story line and, this was a nice touch to me personally, it's own artistic preview of what you're going to be doing for every level. This touch was great to me as it really made me feel like the Devs cared about their game. Add in bonus levels, the ingame backstory goodies to collect in them, the great music and intersting concepts for each level, and an enjoyable final boss fight, and this game easily becomes one of my favorites of this year.

My only gripes is getting used to certain controls, which honestly was a learn to play issue on my part (certain actions require getting used to, for instance press the jump button when you climb up something will make you vault over it, unless I'm actually wrong, but pressing forward allowed you to climb up just fine) and for any hitting your face into a wall (which actually causes recoil, which I'll get a bit more into in a second but also  has a badge that gets rid of this feature) is quickly overcome and just not getting enough game for myself. The latter part will apparently be answered for with free DLC for two additional chapters, which makes me more than happy to hear.

As for the praises I can only begin to shower on this game, where do I even start? The music is great, with various remixes to spice things up, the platforming is great, your character has weight, and has trouble hitting things early on (hitting a large enemy will cause you to recoil until you get your actual weapon or use a particular jump atttack). When you hit a wall, you will not just stop in place, your girl will hit the wall, recoil and fall a distance away from said wall, depending on how hard you hit it. The boss fights are great, often done in different styles, the levels are beautiful, each one being more fun than the next, and your character and everyone else in it have their own great personalities, even regular run of the mill npcs.

And what sucks is that I know I'm missing more and more praises to give this game. This game is great, heads and shoulders above others, and certainly will get rid of any bad taste Yooka-Laylee might have given you. This is the kind of game that really restores your faith in game developers to deliver fun, quality games without ridiculous pay to win garbage, grind, or subpar, shallow  gameplay under the excuse of, "People will still buy it, right?". And like most anything good, it's over far too soon. If you get the chance I highly suggest picking it up, especially with the DLC on the way. 

To the Devs: Thanks for making a game that doesn't suck. Keep up the good work

So, when my husband gifted this game to me, I had no idea what to expect. I honestly was like "okay, whatever." and gave it an honest try to humor him.

36063757.review:
Undoubtedly my favorite 3D platformer since 'Super Mario Sunshine'. I 100% recommend anyone who loves platformers, or anyone who loves well-made games period, to check this out. I don't buy many games at full price, but I'm glad I did here. There are hundreds of well worded positive reviews out there already (that I totally agree with). I'm not sure what else I could add to the chorus there, so I'm going to do something unexpected for how much I love this game: I'm going to gripe about a couple of minor things. 

1- This one is just personal: I genuinely disliked almost all of one world, the Alpine Skyline (except 'The Windmill'. That part was awesome). I found it tedious, stressful, and nausea-inducing. The camera did not work nearly as well in this area as it did in the rest of the game. 

2- I wish there were a LOT more of the 'Time Rift' levels, these were by far my favorite part of the game but there's only a few, and they are quite short.

3- The game gets frequent 1.5-2 gigabyte updates, apparently due to the way Unreal Engine 3 updates work (if they update one small thing, an entire large chunk has to be re-downloaded). This is no fault of the devs, but still, if you have slow internet or data caps, watch out. I've gotten 10 gigs of updates in 2 weeks. Additionally, every update resets your in-game settings, potentially leaving you with a lot of adjustments to make every time.


This game is as good as, or possibly better than Super Mario Sunshine, and I think I would label it the BEST 3D Platformer ever (keeping in mind that I haven't played Super Mario Odyssey yet, which of course looks outstanding). This isn't another 'Yooka-Laylee' disappointment. Buy it immediately.

You have an activatable ability based on the hat you are wearing, so there's a bit of puzzling your way through the platforming. The worlds are unique and they really do a good job making each of them fun and entertaining, with a splash of humor that actually got me to laugh.

The windmill was the only part of the game that sucked. That could have used more polish. But it was only for one hourglass so no big deal.

12 hours to collect all the hourglasses, and I was disappointed there wasn't more.

36061453.review:
A Hat in Time is a really good start in a hopeful return to 3d platformers of the N64 era. It isn't perfect and very rough around the edges, but when the movement, colorful environments, silly characters, all mesh together, it makes for one of the best platformers in years. It's a shame it isn't getting the sales and exposure it deserves. Overall its a great effort and should purchased at its asking price. I look forward to seeing more official worlds, mods from the commmunity, and hopefully one day a more fully fleshed out sequel.

Pros
[list]
[*] Hat girl is amazing. Her movement, expressions, manuerisms, are all perfectly done
[*] The levels are diverse and colorful with intresting colletables and bosses
[*] Captures the feel of some of the better parts of SM64 and SMS
[*] The characters are very expresive and unique. They remind me of the style of Paper Mario
[*] Well optimized. Runs very well.
[*] Fairly priced
[/list]

Cons
[list]
[*] The pacing is very bad early on. The first few time pieces and first "boss" are absolutely terrible. It's clear that they were done very early and later levels improve on the formula
[*] Some time pieces are throwaways; very easy levels to complte in less than 5 minutes
[*] You will get stuck in the environment in the worst of times (seen worst on the parade level)
[*] Aiming, landing on, and using ropes are really janky
[*] The badge system isn't that well fleshed out. Badges like hookshot should be always active to give a change for more fun badges.
[*] Not enough badges, weapons, hats.
[*] Not enough characters on the hub world
[*] Not enough hidden timepieces on hub world.
[*] Game is very short. Needs several more worlds.
[*] The game is very easy. Deaths will be due to buggy interactions with the environment.
[*] Updates are poorly dealt with. 2GB every time and all settings will be reset on first run.
[*] Poor controller support. PS4 Controller (newer) has is not detected at all in this game. Works fine out of the box everywhere else.
[/list]

36028442.review:
No other game that's come out in recent memory captures the nostalgia of playing Super Mario 64 and Sunshine on the weekends. Everything about this game, from the title screen, to the end credits is filled with ridiculous amounts of charm and character. Exploring the worlds this game has to offer is just... Fun. You're going to be finding yourself enjoying the scenery from time to time rather than playing towards the objective. All the different worlds the game has to offer are colorful, and pretty large. Every area in this game is a joy to look at and explore. Not once did I feel like skipping out on an act. Every mission was extremely enjoyable, which is not something I can say for other 3d platformers. Oh, and the music. MY GOODNESS, THE MUSIC! The soundtrack for each level perfectly fits in with the theme of the world, and most exhibit such a great sense of wonder and adventure. 

While A Hat in Time takes a lot of inspiration from games like Mario 64, Sunshine, and Banjo kazooie, none of the characters or levels will make you think of those games, aside from maybe the time rift levels. Every character you meet has such a distinct personality, great designs, and (mostly) great voice acting. Which, if you dislike, you can buy a badge that will change the regular voice acting to mumbles. It's a completely separate thing, something they didn't need to add at all, but it's a nice homage to some older games of the genre, and very welcome in my eyes. Also unlike some older games, the camera and controls are easy to understand, and make the gameplay very enjoyable. There were very few times that the camera was a hassle to deal with, and when it was, it generally only lasted a few seconds before returning to normal. Every move you can make in this game, be it the double jump, or the mid air dash feels great, and it adds a lot of depth to the gameplay. Canceling your dash makes for easy placement correction, wall climbing and wall jumps are easy to pull off, with a very generous timing. A Hat in Time simply plays like a dream.

Oh, and if you're a speedrunner, this game has you covered. The main story is relatively short, only requiring a little over half of the total amount of time pieces there are to collect. Not to mention, the full controller support and in-game speedrun timer, making it easy for anyone to just hop in and start running without having to download any other programs. Even if you don't have the top time, it can still be great fun to just casually seeing how fast you can complete a certain level or even the whole game.

If you love 3D platformers, and you want to feel nostalgic while also enjoying a new, fresh experience, do yourself a favor and buy this game. Seriously. This is not a game you want to pass up if you're a fan of platformers. And for just $30, this game is a steal.

36025987.review:
Ever wanted to play a Super Mario game where you consort with the Mafia, make bird movies, command a spaceship and get a strong feeling that you might be an underage Time Lord while collecting ALL the shiny hats? Well, here you go.

A Hat in Time is an all-out great experience and might be the first true contender to be the Shovel Knight of 3D Platformers. You know, the game that actually plays like your nostalgia-riddled brain makes you think the old classics played like? A fuzzy, joyful adventure with witty writing, absurd characters and controls that aren't clunky at all and don't make you rage-quit into oblivion. If we were talking about some of said old classics, my previous sentence could be understood to be sarcastic - but luckily we are talking about A Hat in Time and in this case, it is a factual statement. While pushing all the right buttons to take you on a trip down memory lane, the game provides you with smooth controls, good camera placement and all the cosy comfort functions you are used to from modern titles that keep you from accidentally killing your neighbour by throwing your controller through the wall. Did I mention haunted mansions, train heists and demonic toilets?

A Hat in Time is without a doubt worth its full price.

I can't stress how much fun I've had playing this game.  It has been one of the most enjoyable games I've played in a long time.  It takes about an hour or so to really figure out some of the game mechanics, but once you do the game just sort of opens up in what it offers.  The puzzles aren't overly challenging but some of them are, so the game is the right balance of difficult, but the joy of the game is just in running around wherever you want to go on a level and exploring while finding yarn, etc.  

The humor in the game is amazing, honestly, I've laughed so many times throughout the game and keep doing so!  The voice acting is really wonderful, the music is superb.  I have never wanted to buy the soundtrack to a game but I think I would here this one!  

The only real CON I can come up with is the camera has some flaws at times.  You can fix this by changing the distance, and turning off the camera assist option, but other times you need it on.  It just kind of depends, but I mostly keep it off and keep the distance at 'very far'.  The other thing that would be an improvement is having Hat Kid have a darker shadow allowing you to judge some distances better when coming down from a jump, but again, it's nothing that takes away from the game.

On a scale of 1-10 I give the game a 9.5, with the only real problem being the camera at times and difficulty in judging distances that could benefit from a darker shadow.  Plus I would like to see an option to 'lock' the camera in place at different times.  These negatives hardly take away from the game though, it has been of the absolute best gaming experiences I've ever had.  Buy this game, buy this game!  I even stream and record some of my playthroughs so look up Offlawnn on youtube and you can see the game more.  Did I mention... BUY THIS GAME!

35997073.review:
To get the most important thing sorted right off the bat: This is a good game, you should buy it, you will enjoy it.

In more detail, the enjoyable parts are the fun writing, the great art, the ABSOLUTELY INCREDIBLE MUSIC, the wonderful boss fights and the platforming which manages to make a platforming casual like myself to not throw his controller while yelling.

Oh wait hang on, that's everything about it that's enjoyable, isn't it? By and large, yes. There are a few parts that could be criticized, though, mostly that the game lacks a bit of polish here and there in the actual platforming that makes up most of the levels. The game sometimes doesn't want to grab ledges, a few jumps are punishingly pixel-perfect(though really only a few) and the game sometimes helps you, sometimes ignores you and lets you plummet to your doom. Conversely, the boss fights are all amazingly well-done.

It's like someone inverted Shantae, which has tons of mood and good writing and art, well-polished actual levels, and then kind of hits its head and waddles around in confusion when you say "boss fight." Hat In Time, on the other hand, could've done with about another 500 boss fights without boring me, while I could see a few places to tighten up the levels themselves.

It's also a bit short on content, about 12 hours of play for me, which involved just toodling around Mafia Town for about an hour because I was enjoying jumping on things, wearing hats and listening to the music. But supposedly we're getting another two acts in the start of 2018, so I think that's a bit of a minor thing to pick on. Besides, 12 hours of very solid entertainment is good value for money considering that it's a game with essentially no random generation at all, everything about it being hand-crafted.

I'd say that the SubCon Forest and Dead Bird Studio both feel like they could've had another couple of stages in there, though. But if I had to choose, I'd rather that they stopped while I wanted more and felt like they could've done more, rather than another eight stages down the road where I groaned every time I saw the Conductor or DJ Grooves(not the Snatcher, though, good luck ever making me tired of him, nerds.).

Ultimately I'd give it a 9 out of 10. It would've been 11 out of 10, but I have to subtract two points for the ending. Very minor spoilers ahoy.

[spoiler]Losing one point because I wanted to sign another contract, and losing one point because I wanted to make another movie![/spoiler]

So if you're still reading this review: BUY THE DAMN GAME ALREADY. OH, AND DON'T BE CHEAP, GET THE SOUNDTRACK, TOO. YOU WILL NOT REGRET IT.

35993747.review:
What exactly triggered the extinction of the 3D platformer? Like survival horror games, there seemed to be no real catalyst – right up until the end of the PS2’s life cycle they were still relatively popular, and then they just disappeared overnight, destroyed by a digital meteorite or possibly evolving into the feathered grey sludge that is the modern AAA game.

Resurrected with some fossilised code found in amber, A Hat in Time is a pure bred, exploratory 3D platformer and almost by default is the best of its kind made in the last decade. I say almost, as A Hat in Time is not the first game this year to try to put the paddles to the unbeating heart of the 3D platformer – Yooka Laylie launched in March to rapturous shrugs, and while it wasn’t horrible it was somehow worse than the 20 year game it was slavishly imitating.

Thankfully a Hat in Time is very much its own man, and it is far better for it – while it obviously takes inspiration from earlier games (notably Mario Sunshine), it also appreciates what DIDN’T work, especially in those later bloated Rare titles. Banjo Tooie, Donkey Kong 64 and by extension Yooka Laylee all suffered from enormous, empty worlds that were frankly a chore to navigate. A Hat in Time is much closer to the smaller, tightly designed levels of Banjo Kazooie and Mario 64, and the fluid controls and carefully calibrated difficulty curve make those worlds a joy to play around in.

The four worlds themselves are largely very well designed and have an admirable degree of variety, though the quality of individual missions and challenges can be variable. There’s definite improvement as the game goes on – the 3rd world, the obligatory Haunted House level is definitely a high point as it’s here that the exploration, challenges and humour all come together perfectly – whoever played Snatcher, the fabulous soul stealing tsundere ghost just sells the shit out of it. The early game as well as being less interesting to play also suffers from some dubious acting and writing, and the whole “Mafia island resort” gag just doesn’t land with any conviction.

In addition to the main areas, there are also “blocks in space” levels that are inspired by those in Mario Sunshine, in the same way that Chinese toy factories are inspired by the moulds that mysteriously go missing. Those were notable high points in the otherwise lukewarmly received Mario Sunshine and they’re just as welcome here, pure linear platforming challenges that are a nice counterpoint to the broader exploration in the main levels.

It should be pretty evident that I kind of loved a Hat in Time –thanks to its amazing controls it’s just a joy to play, despite its flaws. Really the biggest concern is that it’s possibly a little pricey – I personally found the 23 quid asking price to be very fair for the 12 or so hours I got out of it, but if you put a bigger priority than I do on hour/dollar it might be worth waiting for a sale. If that’s not a concern for you, then I totally recommend pulling the trigger, if just to support an incredibly promising and talented dev team. Speaking of triggers (of the squishy clicky kind), the game natively supports gamecube pads with correct on screen prompts if you have an appropriate adapter, which is almost worthy of a recommendation by itself.

35991726.review:
Antes de hacer el análisis simplemente te diré que te compres este juego.

Desde que lo vi anunciado en Humble Bundle supe que me gustaría, y a pesar de que normalmente suelen decepcionar en un aspecto o en otro los juegos que generan hype, para mí, este juego ha sido justo lo que yo esperaba.

Se ve que es un juego creado con muchisimo cariño y eso se nota en el resultado final. Pero vayamos por partes:

Jugabilidad: Es una mezcla entre Super Mario Sunshine, Crash Bandicoot y otros juegos del género. También le veo tintes a The Legend of Zelda Wind Waker en algunos puntos. Es un juego de plataformeo, de modo que es importante que los controles respondan bien, la cámara sea manejable y no interfiera y no haya puntos imposibles de alcanzar. En este aspecto todo está bien pulido, pudiendo incluso llegar a escalar a zonas a las que quizá no deberías llegar porque son sólo de adorno. Por otro lado el combate no tiene demasiada profundidad, siendo los bosses quizá la piedra angular de este aspecto y aunque no son super fáciles, todos se pueden superar sin morir demasiado. Sobre todo si consigues el último sombrero.

Puedes ir consiguiendo sombreros, que te dan poderes para poder seguir avanzando, y excepto en puntos específicos, le darás prioridad al primero y al último que desbloqueas. Adicionalmente puedes ponerles parches para potenciar, adquirir o dificultar tus habilidades.

Gráficos: Tiene esos gráficos cartoon que tanto molan en este tipo de juegos. Los personajes están diseñados de forma muy carismática. Tampoco me pararé mucho en este punto ya que hay fotos, videos y de todo en steam.

Sonido: La banda sonora es muy agradable, en algunos puntos como en bosses se vuelve bastante cañera cosa que aporta tension y es de agradecer.

Historia: La historia no es nada del otro mundo, pero es una buena excusa para desarrollar todo el juego y encaja perfectamente en el tono desenfadado del juego.

Duración: El juego puede completarse en unas 6 horas si juegas a tu ritmo, pero cuenta  con muchísimos desbloqueables, niveles secretos, y en el futuro contará (he leido por ahí) con split screen lo que usaré como pretesto para rejugarlo con alguien.

Conclusión: Yo he pagado los 28€ que cuesta el juego, y me los he gastado a gusto. No suelo gastarme el dinero en juegos tan caros, pero yo creo que es un juego que vas a disfrutar de punta a punta. No te lo pienses y adelante!

Level design is great, each level is distinctly different, beautiful, and fairly large. 

Soundtrack is so good, Ive been listening to it in the car every day.

35980829.review:
OOOOOOOOH boy where do I start

Ok so I have been following this game's development since around 2015 when it was in its earliest stages of development and I can honestly say without any doubt in my mind that A Hat in Time lives up to the expectations the developers (Gears for Breakfast) and We, the fans have built up.

This game is a lovely 3D collectathon platformer that harkens back to the olden glory days of mascot based Collectathon 3D Platformers in the Nintendo 64, GameCube, Playstation and Dreamcast days.

It is not just a throwback though as this game has SEVERAL unique features that other games in the same vain do not, Take the focus on hats for example. The default hat is very boring and only points you to where you need to go, but once you get that sprint visor you know you are in for a true ride. The focus on different abilities unlocked through different hats is for what I say is just simply cool.

This game also DECIMATES Yooka-Laylee (another 3D collectathon indie platformer) and takes all the ideas and concepts which that game should have had, and increases them and expands upon them tenfold (just check the Yooka-Laylee reviews)

AND THE ART STYLE DUDE its so beautiful. It may not be the most graphically impressive art style ever to exist, but it looks DAMN good and everything looks so absolutely cartoony, fun, bright and childish, it just adds this charm to an already charming game that will have it age wonderfully.

All I can say is this is one of the most remarkable 3D platformers I have played in the past decade and this is a MUST BUY for anyone who grew up in the late 90s and early 2000s or to anyone who just simply wants to have a fun game to play

35959851.review:
This game is easily my favorite platformer of 2017. I give it a solid 9.9/10, where that .1 is controls. While the controls are very tight and offer extremely fluid movement around the world, there were times where Hat Girl could definitely had made that jump or grabbed that ledge, but simply refused.

Elements of the Game:

Story - A highly creative story. You can really feel the spirit of older platformer collect-a-thons that inspired this gem. Personally, I felt immersed in Hat Girl's universe and thoroughly enjoyed the original characters.

Art - I loved the stylized, anime-inspired graphic direction that the game went with. The characters were chibi in stature, which added to the game's adorable charm. Personally, I would love to see a graphic novel in the spirit of A Hat in Time.

Sound/Music - Very tight sound direction. The composers did an excellent job of creating music which only added to the fast-paced fun of A Hat in Time's game world. The title song is easily my favorite piece.

Mechanics - As stated before, there were a few -- albeit small -- issues I had with the game's mechanics. Sometimes Hat Girl would not climb ledges she clearly could reach. Sometimes, Hat Girl would get stuck in the floor of some ledges (the game was very quick to eject her and reposition her to where she was supposed to be, however). Other than these issues, the mechanics are very tight and responsive and extremely easy to pick up and master. Anyone can become a pro speed-runner of A Hat in Time! 

All in all, I highly, highly, HIGHLY recommend this game to any fans of the platformer genre, fans of anime/chibi style art, or those looking for a charming story in to which to get immersed. It's a very short game (I beat the game in around 10 hours, and that was on and off running errands) and you can definitely beat it in a single sitting. Please give this game a try; you definitely will NOT regret it! :)

35953846.review:
I don't write reviews terribly often so I'll try to be brief but clear. Sorry in advance.

This game is the perfect old-style collectibles centered platformer. It's essentially a perfect mix of what made Banjo-Kazooie, Super Mario Sunshine, and Super Mario Galaxy such great games.

The level design is charming and even when you get lost in the levels, you don't care because there's always something new to discover. New NPCs, more Yarn for your new hats, new little puzzles for you to solve. Every level is unique and an absolute blast to be in.

The soundtrack and the voice acting (managed by Chris 'Kirbopher' Niosi, one of my old favorite content creators from Newgrounds) are phenomenal and wholely entertaining. The fact that you have the option to listen to voice acted lines or equip a Badge to make the voice lines sound like classic Banjo-Kazooie mumbling is the perfect mix of modern game style and nod-off to the legendary classic that essentially defined the genre.

Every single collectible FEELS good to get and FEELS like you're making progress towards something. It's not like in Banjo-Kazooie where you collect the Jinjos and you only find out what they do for you at the VERY end of the game, so they feel like a chore to collect all the way until the end.

The controls and the mechanics of the powers you get (which come in the form of cute hats) all feel tight and well designed. You never find yourself blaming the power you're using for why something bad happened to you (unlike Yooka-Laylee where some of the move mechanics feel like they're fighting against you). The powers are all easy to understand and to use and change the dynamics of the game appropriately. None of them feel useless or broken (the Time Stop Hat is arguably the only exception, when used in tandem with the Fast Hatter Badge). The controls never get muddled up by having to hold one button and press another to use a given power. Instead, you can quickly swap through your powers by quick swapping hats with either the radial menu (set to the Left Bumper) or by scrolling through with the D-Pad. 

Badges give you access to cool little perks that allow you to customize your Hat Kid and play your way. 

There are so many options for aesthetics in this game that you will always look forward to the next style of your Sprint Hat or the next Color Palette you get from the Rift Coin Machine.

Overall, this game is filled to the brim with personality and charm. If you or someone you know abandoned this game because of the Jontron cameo (literally only two lines, by the way and completely missable if you don't talk to everyone), please reconsider. This game redefined the Collectible Platformer genre in my opinion and is exactly what people wanted out of Yooka-Laylee (no disrespect to that game either), and more. 

Give it a shot. I've shown this game to friends of mine that don't even enjoy games 98% of the time and now I have trouble getting them out of my house because all they want to do is borrow my laptop to play A Hat in Time (seriously, send help, they won't leave).

35940018.review:
There's something to be said about games that just make you feel happy.

A Hat in Time isn't perfect by any means, but it's a hopelessly cute and absurdly fun, with all the blemishes and unpolished bits being few and far between. The game borrows heavily from a lot of 1996-2005 3D Platformer games era, you'll draw comparisons from the obvious Super Mario 64 and Sunshine (main suspects) to the more obscure Sly Cooper and Pyschonauts games. Every chapter is structured completely different from one another, which eases the feel of repetition but might throw others in for a loop. One Chapter you'll be on an little happy greek-esque sunny island, and few dairy entries later you'll be in a surreal spooky forest under a dark and gloomy moonlit sky with somber melancholy undertones. A lot of the characters you'll encounter are brimming with personality with a few particular characters standing out more than others but with an overall a very humble and tight knit cast of creatures and friends for you meet and play with. And this soundtrack is one for the ages... You get a vast arrangement styles of music. Did anyone mention the Grandpapa of Whimsical Adventure OSTs Grant Kirkhope makes an appearance in some of these tracks?

Overall A Hat in Time is an awesome game that restores faith to the 3D platformer genre and draws faithful and quirky twists to old classic games from the yesteryear. It's a game that I'd recommend to anyone who is interested in playing for a laid back, play at your once pace, hecka adorbs space adventure.

This is easily one of (if not) my favourite game of the year and it exceeded my expectations.

35937690.review:
It reminds me of my favorite 3D platformers like Spyro and Psychonauts. It's nice to see a great new game like those. The controls aren't quite *perfectly* tight in this game, so I sometimes felt out of control, though it was still very good. It feels good to be able to go very far and fast by applying skill; in fact, I wish that there were more racing maps. The game is fairly easy overall, but there are challenging bits. It does a good job at avoiding being *frustratingly* difficult.

The maps are highly varied and interesting. Some are very large. The collect-a-thon was a bit weak, though. You'd almost have to go out of your way *not* to get the required yarn, and there aren't enough relics to pose much of a challenege. I 100%ed the game in about 18 hours. The hat mechanic was fine, but it seems underused; I didn't change hats or badges all that often. I kinda feel like they could've doubled the length of the game just by exploiting existing content/features more, without reducing overall quality. Maybe the upcoming user-created maps feature will sort of provide this.

The story and models are super cute. I love the different hats flairs and colors. The story is interesting, with lively and memorable characters. I like how Hat Girl comes across as devious, if benevolent -- it's a bit different than usual.

The music is excellent, and perfectly complements what's going on in the game. I love how as you advance in a level, often the music will flow into a different flavor of the same general song.

9.5/10, highly recommended to anyone who likes old-school 3D platformers.

35915331.review:
A Hat in Time is a pretty decent 3D-Platformer.

+ Game rarely gets repetitive. Every level has a different flavor to it with interesting obstacles and challenges.
+ Story is alright. Enough to keep players interested
+ Level design is pretty decent, they do appeal to different player types. Shortcuts, secrets, hidden goodies.
+ Humor is definitely there, the character dialogues made me smile a couple of times.
+ Excellent soundtrack and voice acting. Clear, easy to understand voice acting and catchy tunes.

- Design wise, it is an intense platformer, perhaps due to heavy influence of successful platformers the dev-team was following closely. I wouldn't recommend it to people who did not play a 3D-platformer before. If some mechanics were explained a bit more properly and the player was given a chance to practice the newly acquired knowledge with some easy challenges beforehand, that could have made the game more newby-friendly. Although, that is also quite hard to accomplish in a free-roam 3D-platformer as well.
- There are a handful visual glitches and bugs within the game. It is understandable, with the manpower the development team had there were no dedicated teams to finding and fixing glitches. They also do not impair the overall experience thus when you see them you just start to ignore them.

In conclusion, game is fun, visually appealing, humorous and successfuly delivers a good 3D-platforming experience.

35909550.review:
I love this game. As of writing this review, I've 100%'d it twice, and never once felt bored or annoyed (besides moments where I was just being stupid and failed to solve a puzzle that was actually really simple). I'll go over my thoughts on each area a game is typically judged on, but the TL;DR is that this game is awesome, and if you can ignore a couple minor issues that don't impact the gameplay whatsoever and are to be expected of an indie game (for example, there are some places where you can turn the camera in such a way that the platform you're on becomes invisible) then this game is, in my opinion, absolutely flawless.

STORY
The story of the game is rather light, but it manages to avoid being bland. You're given a genuine reason for your quest, and each individual world has its own story arc that you follow along, not to mention the backstory and lore of the worlds and characters. It doesn't constantly bombard you with plot twists or drama, but it also isn't dull enough that you completely ignore it.

GAMEPLAY
The standard gameplay is 3D platforming, and it's done very well, and the game never forgets that's what it's meant to be. But it also isn't tiring with it. Just when you feel like every level is going to be platform-to-platform jumping and avoiding pits, hey look, this one's spiced up with a bit of stealth! This one's got puzzles! This one's platforming based around a new item! It never stays samey, and while some people may find the sudden additions jarring, they tend to be small enough that they add new flavor but don't completely detract from why we're here in the first place.

WRITING
This game's humor is probably one of its best parts for me, if not THE best part. Just about every NPC you can talk to has something funny or interesting to say, and you'll find yourself wanting to go out of your way to talk to them all. Just one example, and my absolute favorite bit of writing in the whole game, comes when you examine Hat Kid's microwave in her kitchen: "It's a microwave! You use it to punish food that has been bad." Even the non-dialogue parts are incredible, such as when a stare-off between Hat Kid and a Mafia man is suddenly interrupted by Hat Kid blowing a raspberry. "This awkward for Mafia!" indeed.

BOSS FIGHTS
Does "dodge the same two attacks, get a hit in, repeat two more times to win" sound familiar? Probably does. Mostly because so many games rely on that for their boss fights. Not this game! Each boss and miniboss has its own unique way of being fought, and they have a TON of attacks that require quick reflexes to get around. They're not too easy or too hard, and they always throw something in that makes each fight different from the last.

CONTROLS
The controls are very responsive. And... okay, let's face it: I have nothing else to add in this section. Because the controls function exactly like you expect and want them to. So I really don't have much to add in this department!

GRAPHICS
Oh. My. God. This game looks AMAZING. The environments are so diverse and well-made, and I frequently just stopped to admire how beautiful it looked. (Or how creepy it looked, if that was what they were going for.) The attention to detail is absolutely staggering; just as an example, a singular wall in a singular area that can be easily ignored has unique signs on it that you have to stop and look at to actually notice, and those signs aren't anywhere else. If that isn't attention to detail, what is? And nothing in the game looks out-of-place, either (unless it's supposed to). And, well, as the developers already said, the game is CUTE AS HECK, and the graphics certainly help!

SOUND
The music. The music. THE. MUSIC. Every single composer (NOT just Grant Kirkhope, for the record - Pascal Michael Stiefel did most of the composing, but other people, Kirkhope included, contributed) forged masterpieces. It's not often I actually buy the game's soundtrack, but I did it without a second thought here and I don't regret it. Whether you want to listen to something epic that gets your blood pumping, or something calm to help you relax, this game has it. And their associated areas in the game fit the music so well, you won't be able to listen to the music by itself without imagining the area or fight it's from.

FINAL THOUGHTS
Once again, in my opinion: flawless game. Besides the parts that aren't actually a problem, but just spots where you can notice a missed slight graphical issue. You could easily go through the whole game without even encountering one of those. Basically, if the description for this game at all interested you: buy it. You won't be disappointed.

35908845.review:
Growing up around the Mario platformers of the late 90s and early 2000s (and recent with the Galaxy series and upcoming Odyssey), there's a special place in me for these types of games, and A Hat in Time reminds me of the classic Mario platformers.  The five different worlds are all each unique, including a "traditional" world, a movie studio (which then forks into 2 other level types), a horror/ghost world (with one of the more terrifying levels I have seen, which REALLY changed the tone of the game), a free-roam world, and then the final world which felt somewhat like a Bowser level from the Mario series.

Unlike Yooka-Laylee, each "act" in a world provides a basic idea of what the theme of each time piece is (such as "train rush", indicating that there will be a timed event on a train level).  With Yooka-Laylee, I felt as if I was just thrown into a large level, and somehow had to go around and find each pagie, which felt tedious, especially when you may have not had everything required to accomplish the goal. This was not the case in A Hat in Time.

There is a vast soundtrack to the game (78 tracks), proving a unique audio experience to each level and event that fits the level's atmosphere well.  If you appreciate the music as well as I did, buying the soundtrack DLC is a no-brainer; having the MP3s to listen to whenever is a nice touch to have.

The main issue I had in the end was the length of the game.  There are only 40 time pieces in the entire game (only 25 needed to complete the full story), and I was able to complete the game with 100% completion in about 17 hours.  Having more worlds (and therefore more time pieces) would have been nice.

35901379.review:
[u]EDIT[/u]
[h1]Just wanted to add more thoughts that I originally left out.[/h1]

I'll admit, I wasn't really planning on getting this game; I actually haven't heard of this title before, but Eric and Dan told me to purchase it since it's had some nice devs and a work-in-progress history--

Let's just say that I haven't regretted playing this for one minute. It's a Gamecube loveletter nobody asked for, but it somehow achieves at grasping the nostalgia of great titles like Super Mario Sunshine. In some cases, this actually better represents Banjo-Kazooie better than Yooka-Laylee in some perspectives.

A Hat in Time started out as a one-man project. It soon evolved into a small team that wanted $30k to make the game (at one point, they doubted themselves and lowered it to $20k). After their initial goal, they soon raised over $250k to make the game with tons of bonuses coming in the future.

The music is also fantastic. I feel like every track fits in with each level and objective perfectly. I was blown away just by the sheer loading screen, and it just got better from there on out.

My only complaint would be the short-ish length (there's even a speedrun timer built into the game). If you really wanted to complete this game quickly, it's possible, but since it's had so much support on Kickstarter, the devs have promised more content: 2 new worlds, online multiplayer co-op, and they even put mod support despite being very busy with the game's recent launch (I'm very thankful I'm able to mod-play Trucy Wright).

I've heard nothing but great things about this game; the only """legit""" complaint I've heard from Gamespot is that it has "too much voice-acting" which 1.) you can turn off and 2.) there's an upgrade where you can make the characters mumble in a nonsense fashion like in the original Banjo-Kazooie.

I can tell the devs were very supportive of users that purchased this game. They honestly deserve every penny their way. 

I am not disappointed, and if you were to purchase this game, neither would you.

Lastly, the amazing soundtrack of this game is used to its fullest. Moments are punctuated with music that will leave a lasting impression. If you've ever enjoyed a 3D platformer, play this game. In my opinion it's one of the best in the genre, right up there with Super Mario 64.

Pros:
+ Adorable artstyle and character design. Seriously, it's cute as heck.
+ The game isn't just smooth and responsive, it also looks great in motion. The animation here is top-notch.
+ Wonderful soundtrack. It feels like something straight out of an animated film, which perfectly fits the style.
+ The story is fun, the characters are all very distinct and fun to interact with.
+ There's loads of variety in the moment-to-moment gameplay. One level will have you frolicking around a brightly-lit city, the next will have you crawling for dear life from hiding spot to hiding spot in a haunted mansion.
+ There's a lot of little interactions within the levels that make them feel alive. Walking passed a discarded can? Hat Kid kicks it. See a mafia goon? Hat Kid will stick her tongue out at him. Step in a mud puddle? Hat Kid slips and faceplants.
+ Mod support.

Cons:
- It's a bit short at around 15-20 hours, and that's including mods. That said, I've heard whispers of new content on the way.
- Minor performance problems on some of the levels. This really depends on your rig. Mine's a bit outdated, so take that as you will.


I know a game is good when my biggest complaint is that there isn't more of it. This is a solid 10/10, it perfectly accomplishes what it set out to do and there's more on the way.

35888609.review:
EDIT: Caught a spelling mistake.

[h1]Overview[/h1]

A Hat in Time is a 3D platforming collect-a-thon that evokes memories of games like Mario Sunshine, whilst also being able to assert an identity all of its own. The game is spread across just four main levels, but each of these is split into numerous lengthy acts and shorter side challenges. The focus of the game is very much old-school platforming, with little emphasis on combat or overarching plot (though each level has its own contained story to contextualise the platforming challenges).

[h1]Good things[/h1]

[list]
[*]Hat kid controls beautifully. She is really responsive, and landing on small platforms is easier in this game than any other platformer I've played. Because I feel so confient moving around, I am able to play much faster and more fluidly than most other platformers.
[*]Every inch of the game is filled with cute details and shows obvious passion from the devs. Hat Kid is easily the most adorable video game character ever - no contest.
[*]It looks gorgeous! The final main level felt like a 3D Rayman Origins - and I can offer no greater praise when it comes to visuals.
[*]The music is consistently excellent. The main theme is a stand-out leitmotif.
[*]Each level has its own unique gimmicks (even on the act-select screen), which keeps things constantly fresh.
[*]Speaking of which, the game does a great job of avoiding platformer level tropes - like 'The Ice Level','The Desert Level'. The first level is an island fishing town populated by Mafia goons who are bad at cooking!
[*]The writing is Undertale-tier excellent, somethimes invoking the likes of Douglas Adams.
[/list]

[h1]Things that could be improved[/h1]

[list]
[*]You can sometimes see the rough around the edges. The odd texture that's not as detailed as the ones around it. The occasional camera clipping through solid objects and breaking the illusion of solid space. Seriously, these aren't things worth worrying about though.
[*]I feel like most of the levels are just a little bit too big. There's generally stuff to collect everywhere, but you don't need all of it to get 100%. In particular, I think the forest level could do with the areas between the landmarks being removed, to make navigation faster and easier.
[*]Final boss spoilers: [spoiler]While the battle was fun, I feel like the whole heartfelt 'everyone pitches in to help you win' was kinda undeserved. With the exception of Cooking Cat, I don't think any named character hasn't tried to kill Hat Kid. So it feels kinda insincere for everyone to suddenly grow some morals, when they've shown themselves to be completely nasty people (without remorse) just hours before. Maybe give them redemption arcs in their chapters if you want to do this.[/spoiler]
[/list]

[h1]Things that you may like or hate[/h1]

[list]
[*]The voice acting...isn't the best. You might find this really distracting, but it reminded me of the cheap UK children's shows I watched when I was younger, and I [i]loved[/i] that feeling.
[/list]

[h1]Closing thoughts[/h1]

I think that A Hat in Time is a charming, wonderful game that absolutely deserves to be considered alongside the greats like Mario and Spyro (PS1-era spyro, anyway :P). If you have any interest in platformers, you owe it to yourself to give this game a try. No problems I have with the game are significant enough to actually impact my enjoyment of it, and when it is good, it is simply excellent.

35888347.review: A fantastic game that I would highly recommend to practically everyone; I was smiling through many parts of this game thanks to its designs, music, and varying gameplay. It's not super technical, the graphics aren't the best and the platforming controls can be frustrating at times, especially when trying to make certain jumps and not all the music is good; some of its wears after a while. While the graphics aren't the greatest, they don't need to be; this game does very well with its designs to the point that I'd say they might even be timeless and hold up years later, which in my opinion is much better than trying to display thousands of different shades of brown. The game has five worlds, but each one plays very differently from the last, quality over quantity. The story is also quite good, never bothering to sit the player down and explain everything to you, rather you are left to your own devices and can figure stuff out on your own, it left me with a sense of wonder about the locations in the game. I managed to complete the game in 13 hours, but I enjoyed every hour of it and wish there was more, but that's what a good game does: leaves you wanting more.

35882904.review:
(Key received from the Humble Store, Got that 10% discount)

Finally, a love letter that the GameCube deserves. A Hat in Time isn't ashamed of its roots as you'll probably see some direct inspirations. That being said, this game isn't a Frankenstein monster of Nintendo games and has its own original ideas that provide a whole experience for those who aren't nostalgic for the GameCube. 

With Super Mario Sunshine's creative platforming, LOZ: Windwaker's energetic art style and Paper Mario TYD's charming comedic tone, A Hat in Time is a joy to play through. 

It's not without its drawbacks though. The difficulty is usually interesting but safe. The platforming is never really challenging and the bosses can be annoying at times. The structure of the worlds can feel a bit restrictive at times as you can only collect a timepiece (star/jiggy equivalent) in its respective level. Disappointedly, the level design, for the most part, is linear. Also, the $30 price tag for 10-20 hours might be asking too much for some.

However, the positives absolutely steal the spotlight from the negatives.  While the difficulty of the platforming may not reach the height of classicly difficult games, it's never boring. Hat Kid is flat out fun to control. Double jumping, wall climbing, and diving to land tight jumps is satisfying. The different hats also grant unique ways tackle both platforming and combat. The worlds can be restrictive but they're always fun and diverse. The cartoonish colorful art style makes the worlds pop and compliment their unique gameplay arcs. While the experience is short, you can tell that the developers put a lot of effort and a world of heart into this game. It is rare to see that much endearing charm put into a game.

I'd recommend this game to people who love the GameCube or Colectathons. Even anyone who wants a charming experience might want to give it a look. A Hat in Time will make you smile.

This is an overall great game, and you can tell it was made with love! The controls are very concise and most issues with platforming have to do with your own abilities. There are many hats which give special powers and abilities that shake things up in gameplay, though I will say there are some hats *cough* ice hat *cough* that are really underutilized. There is one hat that really opens up the game and it can create (kind of, they already exist so it kind is like phasing) platforms. It is a really cutesy game with delightful visuals and colorful dialogue. It can be pretty funny, I would say my favorite character would be the owl train conductor who speaks with a really exagerated scottish accent and is pretty self centered. Everything is either about his "beautiful train" or the bird movie awards with him.

Another thing I absolutely love is the way hatgirl can be customized. She can have the colors of her clothes and hair changed to your liking (you have to unlock them though) and can utilize badges which further your own abilities. Hatgirl you can change the way hatgirl plays and I think that it is pretty neat!

There are some negatives and in particular I have some issues with the glitches in the game. Sometimes you fall off a ledge and teleport or things don't seem to quite match up. Fortunately it isn't as bad as it seems and is still definitely playable. From what I understand this game is the developer's (Gears for Breakfast) first one so these glitches are to be expected. It is also rather short and can be finished within a couple hours. Replayability is expanded with a few hidden collectibles, secret levels, and "relics".

I hear there may be dlc and steam workshop support so I can only expect the game to improve over time! I expect great things from Gears for Breakfast in the future.

Overall I give it 8.5/10

35867436.review:
WOW... Where do I begin with this one...
I LOVE this game! (Yeah thats a good start XP) 
This game is an amazing nood to games like Super Mario Sunshine, Banjo and Kazooie, and Mario 64. With WindWaker style graphics, an AMAZING soundtrack, cute charactors (Most of the time *shudders*) and wonderful level design. This game is one that makes me remember why I loved platformers in the first place. This game is packed FULL of charm. I havent felt this attacted to a game in a long time. In fact I felt like I needed to get everything in this game to experience all I could because I love the world and charactors soo much. It takes alot to make me want to complete a game but this one pulled me in and wouldnt let go. People that say platformers are dead (especially after some recent additions to the genre) NEED to play this game. The controls while they were a bit wonky for me at first are easy to pick up and fun to master. You'll be jumping, sliding, and swinging around with ease in no time. The hats add more variety to the game with offering different ways to get around the environment and deal with hazards. The levels are well designed and full of style, but aren't too big that you will find yourself lost in them. But now for some problems that some may have with the game.

The game in my opinion isnt short... But its not very long either. I completed everything in the game in about eleven and a half hours. Of course you can play any level you previously completed again if you wish. But I feel like there could have been a bit more each level. So I can see $30 being a bit to high a price for some. But I think its well worth it for the effort and charm in the game alone. So if its too much in your opinion I would wait for a sale to pick it up. Maybe at $25 or $20.

The game while it is wonderful and full of things to do at first, leave you with little end game content to play. It has replay value sure, but it leaves me wanting more. Tho that is coming with 2 more worlds as DLC and Co-op down the line.

Another thing I heard people complain about is the voice acting being "cringy" or "horrible". I LOVED the voice acting in this game. It has that cheesy charm that I love from games of the past. Im glad this game has voice acting. It makes the world feel more alive. And if you cant stand it there is a option in the form of a button that turns the games voices into mumbles ala Banjo and Kazooie.

Alittle nit-pik of mine is the main rival of the game. While I love her (and her stache) I feel like they could have done more with her. I guess I was expecting a "Shadow Mario" type of rival where once a world she comes in messing with things and you have to try and stop her. Other than her being in the first hour of the game, after she truley becomes your rival she disappears only being mentioned in one other mission. Only to show up at the end game like she was the big master mind behind everything, but the moment I saw her I could only think "What was she doing all this time?". Like I said I love her and her being a rival is set up well enough. But I feel like she could be a more prominent role in the game other than "that one girl that turned into a badguy near the beginning of the game".

All in all tho I feel like I spent my money well with this game. I love it and cant wait to see what DLC brings. Not to mention Split screen/Online Co-op with a friend!~ *girly screams* This game is so charming and full of effort and love that if you like platformers you NEED to play this game. Pick it up whenever you can. Its worth a play I assure you. ^-^

Platforming:

Cons:

Gameplay:
5/5
Pros

35865575.review:
¿Amante de los plataformeros en 3D? ¡No busques más! ¡ESTE es tu juego!

-Lo diré primero porque lo considero importante: solamente está disponible en inglés. No manejarlo hará que te pierdas la historia y los diálogos, pero aún puede ser muy disfrutable por su jugabilidad.
-Gráficos preciocísimos sin necesidad de un PC demasiado poderoso.
-Control de personaje casi perfecto.
-Excelente plataformeo. Accesible pero con su dosis justa de desafío, especialmente para conseguir ciertos items.
-Diversos sombreros desbloqueables que te darán acceso a nuevas habilidades.
-Medallas que mejoran tus sombreros, otorgan nuevas habilidades o dificultan el juego.
-Miles de coleccionables para juntar en cada nivel. Se te pueden ir horas simplemente paseando por los mapas juntando lo que veas.
-Mundo semi-abierto. Cada capítulo (mundo) tiene su propio mapa compartido, pero ciertas zonas solamente son accesibles al jugar un acto (nivel) determinado.
-Personajes muy carismáticos. Jefes, NPCs, personajes de relleno, y sobre todo la protagonista le dan mucha personalidad al juego, y puedo asegurarte que te sacarán más de una sonrisa.
-Los rift "secretos" son algo maravilloso.
-Variedad de niveles. Cada mundo tiene su propio estilo. Los niveles incluyen exploración, sigilo, carrera a contrarreloj, terror, etc.
-La dificultad para completar la historia en sí no es muy elevada, pero si eso te disgusta, existe una medalla que se puede comprar para convertirlo en un juego MUY desafiante.
-Los niveles están diseñados de tal manera que es casi imposible perderse y no saber qué hay que hacer.
-Los jefes finales son realmente memorables.
-Ligera personalización a través de una tragaperras. Esquemas de colores, skins para tus sombreros o remix de la OST se pueden desbloquear con ese elemento.
-A mi gusto, excelente humor.

35859171.review: It's everything I've ever wanted in a 3D platformer! The amazing platforming, the amazing level design (Loved the Murder on the Owl Express, that was absolutely brilliant, and the I could see the reference to a murder of crows. This is the 3D platformer I've been waiting for! For years I've been waiting for a game to revive that lost genre of N64 style 3D platformer. A Hat in Time is the game I've been waiting for, the chosen one! Absolutely incredible game! The only complaints I really have about this game are a few technical issues that pop up from time to time, and the camera can get slightly annoying at certain points, plus I wish there was a way to look at your surroundings in first or second person, like you could in games like Mario 64 and Banjo-Kazooie, but these flaws don't ruin the experience for me at all. I enjoyed every second of my time with this game, and it does so many things right! The developers of this game clearly gave this game a lot of care and polish, and it definitely shows. I cannot wait to see more of A Hat in Time! This game definitely deserves more attention than it's getting!

35858688.review:
Absolutely wonderful. 
This game has some of the best controls I've seen in recent years. Doing simple platforming with Hat Kid feels extremely rewarding because of how good the movement is. That, coupled with the extremely creative and varied level design, makes this game have some of the best gameplay I've seen. While it is true that it is a short game, it's an incredibly entertaining experience that will charm you with its humor, characters, and crazy missions throughout. The music and atmosphere are nothing short of incredible, and those two alone might keep me coming back to replay this game.
My only critique of this game is that it lacks a bit of polish. I don't have the most powerful PC, but it is still quite good, and I still experienced some severe frame drops in a few spots in the game (even at lowest settings). On top of that, there were some weird animation bugs and clipping happening in a few spots.
Regardless, these are just minor complaints in a fantastic game otherwise. Easily glides to my top 5 games this year (which is impressive considering how stacked this year has been). 
My score would overall be 9.5/10.
If you are even mildly considering this game, go for it. The developers definitely deserve every sale they get.

PLEASE. GET. THIS. GAME.

A Hat in Time I feel does most things better, even in what feels like a smaller package.  The music is wonderful, the characters and humor are charming and fun, it's the right kind of enjoyable gameplay, and I was just entertained all the way through.

35855380.review:
TLDR: Just buy the game and play it. It's that simple.

There are a lot of games of steam, some of which are good but I'll never get around to buying. There are a lot of games I own on steam, some of which are good but I'll never get around to playing (Witcher 3 for example). There are a lot of game I play on steam for awhile, but I'll never get around to completing even though I really enjoy them. There are a few game I play on steam and I just play until I've beaten the main story, but I'll never get around to beating all the sidequests and unlocking everything even though I really enjoy those games. There are some games on steam that I own all DLC expansions but never got around to interacting with them despite playing the game enough to beat the main story, and I'll never get around to playing those parts despite how easy going back would be.

Then, there is A Hat in Time. As soon as the game was released I played it for every hour I could spare. All the time I spent away from Hat in Time was time I wished I could play more Hat in Time. I beat the final level in around 15 horus. As soon as I finished watching the credits roll I leapt right back in to get a 100% clear of the game, which took about 4 more hours.

A Hat in Time does everything right, and I mean that. Movement is tight and responsive, the music fits levels perfectly, all the characters have fun things to hear, the levels have enough room for you to explore but not so much that parts of levels feel empty or making the trek between areas a chore. Platforming finds a sweet spot where a novice doesn't have to worry about making continous, insane, pixel perfect jumps but the movement lets veterens question how much of a level they can skillfully avoid. A Hat in Time has no low points to the game, and this almost brings me to tears. This is a game that decided to only give you the it's very best instead of add boring, samey, uninspired content just to pad the game out. There is content that was in the beta but isn't in the full release, the example of this was a part of Mafia Town where Hat Kid had to jump and swing across the ocean and if she ever touched water a robo shark would eat her. This isn't in the full game because it wasn't good enough.

Visually, I'd say that this game looks better than most AAA games despite the fact that A Hat in Time looks like a gamecube game. The reason for this is because Hat in Time didn't have the money, manpower, or time to given every object in the game a million polygons, so instead of doing something stupid like that it filled the game with environments that are interesting to look at and visually distinct from each other. Instead of making something highly detailed but boring to look at, an artist put their soul into every nook and crany of the game.

Now, why did I say earlier that the game makes me tear up? Because A Hat in Time release a week after Cuphead, and gaming communities were still busy exploding over Cuphead, and two weeks before the launch of Super Mario Odyssy. A Hat in Time has two weeks before Mario obliterates it. Now, Hat in Time has full steam workshop support and DLC on the way, but nothing Hat Kid does will let it beat the giant that is Mario, who has a history of quality, a strong advertising campaign, and an enormous fanbase who already love Mario. What makes me tear up is that I'm afraid that A Hat in Time will become a hidden gem of gaming and that the world that barely took notice will soon forget Hat Kid every existed.
