35853375.review:
A Hat In Time is honesty a work of art. Every nook and crany of this game has been filled to the brim with charm and pure love. The characters feel complete and leave a mark on you long after you have moved on past their story arc. Movement is swift and responsive, the camera is rarely a problem, all the hats and powerups are used evenly, and theres just enough freedom within the mechanics for the player to feel rewarded after completing a platforming section the way it may not have been intended. The only drawback is that A Hat in Time isn't longer, but with a couple dlc chapters on the way, that may not be a problem in the future. 

TLDR: Amazing game full of fun and life. Worth the $30 price tag. 9.5/10.

35853222.review: Oh boy, this game is very, very good! It's been a while since I've seen a game this creative and fun. A Hat in Time is a collect-a-ton that actually does the job well (different from some chamelleon and bat around there), It consists on trying to find these time pieces so the little girl you control can go back home, these time pieces are all scattered around 5 different chapters that have each a little story of their own, I found these little stories to be a cool thing to add in the game, because it's nothing that you need to pain much attention to, but it's fun and it gives more life to the world, for example, the whole story on chapter 3 goes like having to do some obligations for the devil, because you signed some contracts and he's got your soul. The game is not that repetitive either, normally, these kind of games tend to be fun but to also get boring and repetitive fast, but that's not the case with A Hat in Time, because this game constantly give new things to you like new power ups, and the levels are very different from each other too (I mean, there's a level that literally turns into a puzzle horror game, that's not that spooky but still a thing I didn't expect from the game, and I absolutelly loved it), the boss fights are all very fun and intuitive too. But enough of details, this is going on for too long now, I just can say I totally recommend this game, even if it's not that long, you will have a fun time, well, at least I did.

35853048.review:
The best and worst thing I can say about A Hat in Time is there simply isn't enough of it.

The game's strength is not its cute visuals, delicious audio, tight controls, varied levels or witty writing but in how well they mesh together to form something so much greater. It's fun right from the start and it rarely falters.

With that in mind I have a laundry list of minor issues, lets hope the devs trawl these reviews
[list][*]Chapter four obviously had far less dev time than every other chapter
[*]A restart level button is sorely needed, especially for the levels players might want to repeat for a higher score or an achievement
[*]The radial hat menu works unlike and I've used before and exactly how it works is never explained (you need to flick the left stick, or hold the stick and release LB)
[*]Unlocking cosmetics randomly means many players won't find their favourite combo until very late into the game
[*]Remixes should really be unlocked after level completion, right now the player can unlock music for levels they have completely finished.
[*]There's no way to track or view % completion for photos, yarn or rift coins.
[*]The hookshot should really be rolled into the umbrella instead of taking up a badge slot.
[/list]

9/10 can't wait for more

35852316.review:
I didn't know about this game before it had come out, much to my shame, but as soon as I saw the trailer I fell in love with the game. The colorful visuals, the orgasmic soundtrack, the return to the almost non-existent 3D collect-a-thon. I was ready to sink my teeth into this adorable game and suck everything it had to offer, but then I played it.

I realize I am going to get a lot of negativity because of my review, but I really feel like I should warn people like myself who are in love with old-school platformers and collect-a-thons. Beware, this game, while deceptively cute has many problems. 

The game isn't bad. At times it's great even. Most of the times, however, the flaws almost ruin the experience.

The game has beautiful visuals. The cute main character is adorable and the game never stops placing her in cute situations. The same can be said for the rest of the games visuals. The enemies and the levels look great as well. The graphics were one of the things that made me buy this game so hastily. I guess I am a sucker for cartoony visuals.

The soundtrack. Oh my god, the soundtrack. It's just divine. I absolutely love every single track I have heard ever since I frist launched the game. The tunes are catchy and fit in perfectly with whichever scenario the game throws at you.

The voice acting is also nice. The cast consists of great voice actors who really try their best to stay memorable. It's great that many of the characters also have different accents.

The game also doesn't lack in the creativity department. One mintue you will be leaping from rooftops in Mafia town and the next you will be running throug a train on a movie set. The game never seems to stop surprising us with it's colorful and interesting locations. 

Unfortunately, this is where the pros end and the cons begin.

The controls are OK, they are not perfect but they work as best as they could considering the engine the game was made in. Unreal Engine just isn't a great choice to make such a game but, to the developers' credit, they did make it as best as they could, which I can respect.

However, this brings us to my biggest problem with the game. When I saw the trailer, I immediately thought of Banjo Kazooie, Yooka Laylee and Super Mario 64. A 3D collect-a-thon. And sure enough, that is what the game wants you to belive it is. 

The main goal of the game is to collect 40 collectables. As I mentioned before, I love games where the main objective is to collect things, so I was very surprised that the very first world, Mafia Town, was so big, vast, beautiful and yet, there was little point in exploring it.

 The case is the same with all other levels. They are begging to be filled with collectables, things to do, side-quests and activities, yet they all have one goal, which can sometimes be completed in less than 5 minutes. 

You have hourglasses, which are your main objectives and once you collect one, the level ends. Scattered around the level are marbles, which act as a currency. You use these marbles to buy badges. Scattered around are also yarn balls which are used to make hats.

 While it seems like a lot, only the hourglasses are important. The rest of the things are just kinda, there. For instance, the yarn balls are needed to make hats which give you powers, that you need. I never counted but I would say that there are about 20-30 yarn balls on each level. The sad thing is, you only need about 3-5 of them to build most of your hats and collecting the rest just gives you extra yarn, which feels a bit dissapointing.

 During my first few hours, I was collecting everything and in the end, I felt like I had only wasted time because only the Hourglasses mattered. So, quite honestly, this game isn't really a collecta-a-thon, but a 3D platformer and there is nothing wrong with a 3D platformer, provided it's done well, and it isn't, at least in my opinion.

Like I said before, the controls are as best as they could be on the engine the game was based on. This makes the controls great for exploring but not so great for platforming. The main character moves like her feet are made of butter. She zips everywhere really fast and the jumping controls are sometimes too... jumpy. Often at times, I was able to find an easier, chepear way to get to my destination just by exploiting the flowyness of the controls. There were sections that required me to use power-ups I din't have to get over long gaps, but I was able to do it with a well timed running jump followed with a dash. It doesn't sound so bad, but when you notice that the game wants to be restrictive and yet you find a way around it, your immersion starts to fade. 

This is especially noticable during the middle of the game, where the game becomes much more linear and the platforming takes a bigger focus. There are sections made much harder than they look simply because of the controls. 
Climbing a large three in word 3 was much harder than it should have been because of the controls. 

I want to mention that the controls work the same way as they do in Yooka Laylee. In Yooka Laylee, such controls weren't the problem because the majority of the game didn't have tight platforming like A Hat in Time has, thus I couldn't complain about them, even if they were flowy just like they are here.

Another thing that bothered me more than it should have were the boss fights. The bosses aren't hard. They all have predicatble patterns just like in most games of this type. They are memorable and fun to do, but they take way too long. One boss fight can go on for around 10 minutes because of how much hits they can take.Seriously, it's ridiculous. I found myself shouting at the screen going "How is this boss still not dead?" after hitting several bosses over 20 times and yet they just kept getting up and getting more powerful. 

The badges you collect range from useless to essential. The hook-shot badge, for example, is essential for progressing through the game while the one-hit-death badge just makes the game harder. Unfortunately, most of them fall in the latter category and feel like a wasted opportunity. 

The game, only has a couple of power ups, which seems dissapointing. I really thought that the game would have more. The power ups come in form of hats, which look cute and are an interesting way of showing which power up you currently have equiped. Out of all of them, I only ever seemed to use the speed power up, just to get through the levels faster. The rest of them were just context sensitive.

As far game optimization is concerned I don't have too many complaints. I experienced some frame-rate dips (one time, the character wentinto an elevator and the game froze and continued to run at 2 fps, but it continued running fine afterwards) and there were no game crashes. I am surprised that the game has a bunch of graphical options but not an option to redifine keys (still, nothing a patch can't fix).

The game is also short. With only 40 levels (some of which can be done in less than 10 minutes) and only 4 words, it feels very short. Especially when you consider the price.

My biggest issue with this game is the praise it is getting. While this game does deserve some of the praise it is getting, nobody should be able to say that it's better than Yooka Laylee, beacause it simply isn't. Don't get me wrong, Yooka-Laylee wasn't perfect and it had problems but so does this game. Let's at least be fair and acknowledge that "A hat in time" has just as many, if not more, problms just like Yooka-Laylee. 

That's my review of this game. It's not bad, but it's not great either. Honestly, if you are in the mood for a 3D platformer, you could do so much worse than this one. If you can handle the loose controls and aren't too bothered by collecatbles (or their lack off) you might just find a somewhat exciting adventure. 

But for the price I paid (28 euros), this game is simply NOT WORTH IT. For HALF that price, the game is worth it.

35836230.review:
Even though this is a new game, as soon as I started it up I was immediately hit with wave after wave of nostalgia for hours on end.

A Hat In Time is a 3D platformer that takes very heavy inspiration from the 3D super mario games as well as having nods to banjo kazooie. The game follows the aptly named Hat Kid as she searches for her ship's lost power supply on an alien planet so that she can return home from... somewhere to...somewhere. It isn't ever actually explained. The game's gimmicks are hats that grant different abilities when worn, offering things like increased movement speed and different attacks, along with badges that add new abilites or enhance old ones.

I'll list the game's pros first, then cons.

First off, the graphics. The game is beautifully stylized, especially when running on uncapped frames, really making you feel as if you've travelled back to the gamecube days. From haunted forests to seaside cities, the game offers the perfect mix of old and new. The level of care that went into the visuals can be truly impressive sometimes, even to the point where nearly every mission has its own unique artwork on the loading screen before it. The sound design is excellent too, with punchy, fitting effects for everything from smacking an enemy to simply running around. 

Each Level is completely distinct, standing in stark contrast to one another and adding amazing variety to a somewhat shorter game. You'll traipse through movie sets, coastal towns, haunted woods and more to retrieve the time pieces, which then extend the areas by adding bonus levels whose entrances are hidden somewhere in the overworld to find. Even more interestingly, during certain bonus levels you can hunt for pictures during each stage. Collecting every one unlocks an expositional slideshow a la psychonauts, telling the stories of certain charcters you meet on your journey. 
(A godsend for a game with such a thin plotline) (also, prepare for feels)

The voice acting is (for the most part) really good for an indie game, with some characters sounding better than some characters in big AAA games. (Looking at you, Mass Effect: Andromeda.) And since a good 90% of all dialogue in the game is spoken, having bad acting could have crippled its humor by forcing players to skip through it.

The game has a ton of wit sewn into everything, with self aware humor and tongue-in-cheek laughs galour, with some simple stuff mixed in as well to keep everyone giggling all throughout with very few jokes that fall flat. Also kudos to the devs for making a horror sequence in a cute 3D platformer that actually manages to be quite terrifying. 

And the MUSIC. Amazing, one of the best game soundtracks I've ever heard. Every song fits the situation perfectly and occasionally had me standing still for a few minutes or replaying missions just to hear every note.

Now for The gameplay.

Simply put, this game is DAMN fun to play.

The controls for every facet of gameplay are near flawless, while feeling familiar to anyone who have played the 3D mario games. (Especially with the dive move that looks and feels eerily similar to that of a certain plumber.) Platforming also has the the right amount of weight, striking a perfect balance for every precarious platform you'll jump accross. 

Next, the main character is friggin' adorable. Whether making faces at the mafia or running around posing for pictures, to skipping along as she leads a parade, Hat Kid is sure to make you smile whenever she's on screen from her sheer cuteness. (So no false advertising in that regard) She even shows a more sarcastic and jaded side in some of her musings and character interactions, which makes her all the more endearing. You know you've designed a good character when they can scream "Down with the mafia!" and start beating people to death with an umbrella and still have it be adorable.

Now the cons.

If you're looking for a gripping story, you won't find one here. Like the games before it, this game doesn't just put narrative in the back seat to gameplay, it hits narrative with a shovel, ties it up and stuffs it in the trunk, having very little story other than "You see that shiny thing? Go grab it!" While this does keep it in ranks with games like mario in this regard, it's a shame that the story wasn't more flushed out, as not only did it have potential, but let's be honest, thin narrative gets old after 30 years. Also, if you peer between the cracks, you can see they were trying a bit too hard to be the next undertale, [spoiler] which is made more apparent when the game culminates into an incredibly corny ending that smells a bit too similar to be coincidence. But since the characters are only seen in a max of 6 short levels, their supposed sacrifices lose any weight they could have had and instead just come accross as forced and clichéd [/spoiler]

 The side characters are flat and simple, but they do their purpose well and have good acting, so I can give them a pass in that regard. (Except for mustache girl, whose teeth marks you can see all over the scenery) But unfortunately, Hat Kid is a kind of character that I cannot excuse after they've been around this long: A silent protagonist. That means that her only communication during cutscenes are nods and facial expressions and in normal conversations, she just stands there with a dumb look on her face, robbing her of a ton of potential character. And the thing is, she speaks full sentences during gameplay, has a journal you can read, and even narrates the game's steam trading cards, so there's no excuse for this trope to be continuing in a non-rpg game.

Some animations in places look awful, with such notable examples as characters that open their mouths to speak during cutscenes, keeping them open all throughout, and then flail around like they're having a stroke, as well as Hat Kid's facial features looking like stickers stuck to a blank face. I know it's supposed to be stylized, but at one point she stuck her tongue out in a cutscene and it looked as if she just slapped some red tape down her face.

While the gameplay is near flawless, there are some poor desisions that keep it from being so. Games that take staple abilities such as a magnet effect for picking up drops or negating fall damage in a game about jumping and falling and making them unlockable abilites that take up slots to equip are unneccesarily complicating things. At the very least, if you're going to make the abilites unlockable, make it so you can equip them all rather than a maximum of 3 at a time. Also, while the platforming itself is tight and fluid, wall jumping can be tedious. When wall jumping, your movement is locked in place with you being unable to jump away in any direction other than dead straight, which can lead to some frustrating deaths and time-consuming falls. 

Also, bugs. obviously with indie games the devs can't spend nearly as much on playtesting as larger companies, but that being said, the game is still full of game breaking stuck-spots, especially in Mafia Town. Spots in the environment you can end up in accidentally that stick you in place are frustrating to deal with, and while most of these spots can be escaped by wiggling and button mashing, some lock you in for good, forcing you to quit back to the hub and abandon all your progress on your current mission and start over.

Alright, time to recap, (puns intended)
The Pros:
+tight, fun, responsive gameplay
+amazing level design
+good amount of content for the price
+near perfect soundtrack
+quirky side chars
+adorable main char
+stylized graphics
+constant nostalgia rush

Cons:
-gameplay needlessly complicated at times
-mustache girl's scenery chewing
-silent protagonist
-some ugly animations
-thin, cheesy story

I give A Hat In Time a 9/10, as it sets the bar high for modern 3D platformers and indie games in general with very few significant slip ups. You've earned yourselves a fan, Gears for Breakfast, Keep at it!

35827088.review:
For those that lived through the late 90s as a child/teen they would know the 3d platforming collectathons of the era, beginning with Mario 64, and argubly killed and put on its way out by Donkey Kong 64 (while more 3d platformers existed past this time, DK64 was the one that started to cause the decline in my humble opinion). Its a genre thats very picky to have a good experience in.

A hat in times' biggest secret is its length and overall presentation. By the time the game was starting to feel too long and wearing out its welcome I was at the end of the game facing the final boss with all time pieces in tow. My first play through lasted 13 hours and I am likely one of the slower ones. Instead of having a million collectables  and padding out the middle, aHiT focuses on a formula closer to mario 64 with its core collectable, Time pieces being the "stars" of this game and only two other collectables, gems and yarn.

Lets talk about the yarn and gems, because this is another thing kind of unique that makes this a more casual fun 3d platformer. gems are needed to do most basic unlocking tasks, but as long as you're pretty much collecting them as you see them, you should almost never have to farm these as I just collected them as I saw them and had bought everything out plus having about 2400 extra by the end of the game. 

Yarn is another aspect, they are used to make hats which are your powers in this game, the powers overall are fun to use but one complaint I have is most of them are a one trick horse, which results in you switching hats constantly to get to places, I'll chalk it up to this being the best way they could do the powers in hats but it would have been neat to have some combined hats later, overall this is a minor complaint. To unlock a hat you need to locate atleast one of its hat type's yarn.

Which brings us to the most interesting thing about these collectables, in most collectathons any collectable is finite and you clear the map looking for these reasources, but in this game gems respawn infinitely everytime a world is loaded and yarn only needs atleast one of the hat type, the rest can be made up of all other kinds of yarn with the game having finite but almost double the amount of yarn in the game it takes to make all the hats. This allows a very leisurely approach to the power-up and collection system which is not a perfect solution to the collectathon woes but its definitely not a bad idea either.

The game only currently boasts 4 worlds with more planned as kick starter stretch goals are finished, right around the 4th world is were I was getting a little tired of the game, but it also wasn't my favorite world to be honest also lacking a great boss fight. The other 3 worlds have interesting things going on with very fun boss fights and music tracks to go with them, I don't want to underplay the bosses so I'll say it twice, the boss fights are awesome.

With Yooka and now this coming out being excellent, are we in a 3d platforming renaissance? Time will tell but even if this was a one off shoot game, I highly recommend this game.

35826921.review: This game is a wonderful game, It makes the 3D movement based collectathon genre perfectly. this game is so fun with all the collectables and and tons of different abilities. the game may be short but the workshop is starting to open up and you'll have a wonderful time, I suggest you play this game as soon as possible.

35823744.review:
A Hat In Time harkens back to the era of classic n64 collect-a-thons. The game starts you off in a hub world and you use time pieces you collect throughout the various levels to unlock new areas. A Hat In Time has 5 worlds: mafia town, battle of the birds, subcon forest, alpine skyline, and time's end. These worlds have multiple acts that take place in the same stages but with slight alterations. This design choice reminds me of super mario sunshine and mario sunshine is a very apt comparison to A Hat In Time.

The most important aspect of a collect-a-thon platformer is by far good controls and a good camera. A Hat In Time has wicked slick and tight controls. Precise jumps are easy to land and when you get accustomed to your jump distances the game rewards fast, technical movement. Each of the levels feel like they have super clean movement flow when you run, jump, dive, dive-cancel, and wall jump through them. The camera is also stellar for the most part and the options menu even has camera distance preferences you can set. I never changed the camera settings because I thought they were fine but you may get more enjoyment out of tweaking the camera. A hat in time nails it's controls and it feels great to play.

The levels in a hat in time are generally really good. I think battle of the birds is the weakest segment platforming wise because the levels are too linear and too boxed in. This setup works great in one level of battle of the birds but the rest of the act is pretty underwhelming. Boss fights are hit and miss. None of the boss fights are hard or even challenging, but some are definitely more fun than others.

The sound is great. the music is pretty good.

On to the bad,
the game has some technical issues. I experienced a crash right before I landed the final hit on the first boss(Chef Mafia.) I noticed the water in mafia town would sometimes just freak out for no reason. Also I got stuck inside one of chef mafia's attacks and I couldn't take damage and I couldn't get out so I had to restart the whole level. luckily boss levels are usually short so at least it didn't take awhile to get back but it was annoying.

Overall, A Hat In Time is an 8.5/10 game. the experience is great and I 100%-ed the game but I can't gelp but feel like the design of battle of the birds was a little underwhelming and the technical issues dampened the experience for me a little. Overall this game is worth your time if you like collect-a-thons.

35823477.review:
[h1]A Hat in Time: Eins meiner absoluten Lieblingsspiele[/h1]
A Hat in Time ist ein 3D-Plattformer ähnlich Super Mario 64.
Eine gute Steuerung, abwechslungsreiche Welten und tolle Charaktere machen es zu einem sehr gelungenen Abenteuer.
Das Hauptfeature des Spiels sind die unterschiedlichen Hüte, die Hat Kid, der Spielercharakter, herstellen und für unterschiedliche zwecke verwenden kann. Um einen Hut herzustellen werden Wollknäule benötigt, die in allen Welten zu finden sind. Die Fähigkeiten der Hüte sind allesamt nützlich und unterscheiden sich voneinander. Zusätzlich gibt es auch noch Orden, die unterschiedliche Effekte haben, wie kürzere cool-down-Zeiten für die Hüte. Mit den vielen kosmetischen Items, ist ein hoher Grad an personalisierung gelassen.
Es gibt insgesamt 4 Welten, die alle ein Unterschiedliches System für die Progression verwenden, sodass sich jede Welt dadurch schon anders anfühlt. Die Welten haben ein schönes Design und fühlen sich dank der NPCs, Gegner und Collectibles auch nicht leer an. Die einzelnen Akte unterscheiden sich auch genug voneinander, sodass diese keinen Einheitsbrei abgeben.
Einziges Problem ist die Länge des Spiels. Ich habe das Spiel zu 100% durchgespielt mit 14 Spielstunden. Ich hätte gerne noch mehr gesehen und gespielt, doch man soll ja dann aufhören, wenn es am schönsten ist.
Somit besteht meinerseits Hoffnung auf eine Fortsetzung. Jedoch wird mein Hunger nach mehr mit dem Steam-Workshop gestillt werden, da die Entwickler in nächster Zeit einen direkten Mod-Support einbauen und heute schon Mods über die Entwicklerkonsole gestartet werden können.
A Hat in Time gehört zu meinen absoluten Lieblingsspielen und ich kann es nur weiterempfehlen.

35822935.review:
I can't really say anything good about this game that hasn't been said a hundred times already. The game is almost flawless, beside the occasional hiccup in platforming (i.e. wallrunning sometimes not working) and how difficult it can be to find the challenge areas to 100% the game.

If you enjoy platformers like Mario Sunshine or the games from the good ol' days of Rare Software, then pick this game up. You'll have a blast.

35817990.review:
I'm a backer.

Mechanically, this game is a love letter to Mario Sunshine and Banjo Kazooie. If you enjoy oldschool 3D platformer collectathons, this is the game for you. Very sweet, endearing and polished as heck.

This is probably my favourite game of 2017.

The addition of the badges goes a long way to making each playstyle matter but I did find myself only ever using the same three. 

The voice-over babble badge should have been an option in the settings menu. It's silly to have to forego a badge slot just for that. I do understand the developer wanted to value the voice-actors they've paid to have but options should always be "free", so to speak. There is no sense in having mechanical implications in this case.

While I do miss the Mario triple jump -- which I think should have been added -- I still think the freedom of movement and diversity of approaches to all situations make this game immensely fun to replay and speedrun. 

I think some Rifts / Artifacts could use a little bit of polishing in regards to conveyance: The purple rift in Subcon Forest stumped me for quite a while and for no good reason, in my opinion.

The game is wonderfully well optimized, running incredibly well even on my mid-low-end laptop. It plays awesome at minimum settings and it looks absolutely beautiful at max.

The only thing I should say that I didn't like is that Moustache Girl doesn't really pop up very often in the story at all. If she had more speaking roles or showed up to be a nuissance more often, it would really go a long way toward making her a cool little rival. As it stands, it kinda feels like she just shows up, is implied to be important to the plot, and then shows up again at the end for no reason. Of course, this game's story is not very important since its mechanics, visuals, polish and overall fun factor really do carry it, but regardless of that, if Moustache Girl had seen some more involvement, the game would be that little bit more superior.

If you like cute as heck characters and if you enjoy enthralling platformers and miss the old days of Mario Sunshine, Banjo Kazooie, Super Mario 64 and even a little bit of Spyro, grab this pronto. You really don't need to question that anymore.

---

I do feel compelled to state that the developer was recently implicated in some drama regarding theft of artistic property as well as doxxing of a fellow developer. If that's a turn-off for you, then there it is. However, I personally still recommend supporting the game, if not for the lead dev, at least for the amazingly talented team and beautiful game.

35814710.review:
If you like games like platformers like Mario Sunshine / Galaxy or colectathons like Banjo Kazooie / Donkey Kong 64, you will enjoy this game.  The controls are fluid and very responsive.  I never had an instance where I felt that I messed up because of crappy controls.  

Unlike what people have said about Yooka Laylee and how souless and bland that game seemed to be (I have not yet played Yooka Laylee when I wrote this, I'm going off the general consensus on that game) this game has plenty of diversity and soul.  Each chapter in the game has unique gameplay aspects to keep each chapter feeling fresh.  The collectables are well placed and actually have a point.  

Hat kid is extremely expressive and adorable.  Despite being the pilot of a space ship and from what I can tell, advanced intellect based on the stuff in her ships Machine Room, she still has the childish attitude that you would expect from her.  

 The voice acting is very well done.  Yes, unimportant characters share the same voice actor, but in a way, it kinda adds more charm to the game.  The unique characters you meet in the game are voiced fantastically.  (if you would rather have the blabbering from Banjo Kazooie, there is an item in the game that makes everyone talk like that, and if you hate voice acting, then turn it off!)  

Yes, some people are saying the game is a bit light on content, but keep in mind that there will be 2 free expansions that will come later that will add a few hours on to the game.  And in addition to that, there is also Workshop support now, so provided that the modding community stays active, you will have plenty of content to play around with.  

I can understand why people arent happy with the 30 dollar price tag on the game.  But in my mind, it is worth the 30$.  If the price puts you off buying this game, at least consider buying it when it goes on sale.  You wont regret it

35814578.review: Super cute artstyle and tight controls, varied worlds with lots of platforming fun, If you like 3d platformers in general it's worth trying out.

35814541.review:
I'm [i]really[/i] glad this game exists. Both to be enjoyed on its own merits, and so that when I complain about Yooka-Laylee and people retort with "well, what did you expect", I can point to [b]THIS.[/b] Playtonic's lukewarm showing was enough to make people start questioning whether the 3D collectathon platformer genre really was so fundamentally overwrought in design that it could only truly have been successful in the 90's, but thanks to this we finally have proof positive to the contrary.

The worlds are actually populated with well written characters who feel like they belong in their respective environments. There's a reasonable population of fodder enemies who aren't a chore to engage with, and pickups that draw your eye to unexplored areas. There are unique setpieces all over the place that flow naturally with the game design rather than sticking out like a sore thumb. Worlds are large without feeling barren. The platforming is quite snappy and precise (even while sprinting, and you don't need to worry about a dumb stamina meter). It's just plain [i]fun.[/i] On top of this, there's a crazy amount of modding support, and the promise of co-op and two MORE worlds in free future updates!

There are minor issues like lack of control remapping, a better-yet-imperfect camera system, and getting stuck on odd bits of geometry. Some of the voice acting grates a little bit. I can sympathize with the people who followed this through its alpha stages and lament the content that ended up on the cutting room floor; some of that stuff sounded pretty awesome. Perhaps most gratingly, objective markers will lead you by the nose to some places that you'll want to find for yourself. Yet with exactly the same number of worlds as Yooka-Laylee had, Hat in Time manages to be ten times more engaging, demonstrates much more competence and creativity with its design, and has singlehandedly given hope for the revival of this genre.

Get it now, get it on sale, or just silently appreciate it in passing -- A Hat in Time is a game of [i]significance,[/i] and I applaud it for that.

35812595.review:
A Kickstarter revival game with a Jontron cameo that's actually good. 

The aesthetic of the game is very bubbly and cute from the soundtrack, to the design of the levels, to the little cute flourishes Hatgirl does. 

The design of the spaceship hub is very soft and comfortable, it reminds me of that old live-action McDonald's tv show, or Bill Nye, or Sesame Street, where you were willing to suspend your disbelief and believe that a felt-covered world exists where grown people live in pillow forts. The game has a sort of childish innocence about it, looking at the world without cynicism. You could plop your kid in front of this game and they'd LOVE it, BUT it still has jokes for adults. My favorites are about "ethical consumption under capitalism" and some wanna-be writer's failing marriage.

The game is fun, I beat it in about 14 hours with a controller (39 hourglasses), though on the whole it's pretty easy. The hardest parts are where the game locks the camera and it disorients and works against you. The camera angles aren't janky and are manageable, which put me off of Pyschonauts. There are a couple camera issues, and most of the difficulty actually comes from the jarring difference between locked and unlocked camera. 

The game controls and performs pretty smoothly most of the time, though there was some stuttering and buggy hitboxes during some of the boss battles, especially the Mafia don. Also there are times when it's hard to tell the trajectory of a jump due to weird depth perception. This is most apparent in the Forest level (AND THAT FUCKING BIG TREE).

Th.e level design is decent, each of the worlds you can access from the hub have their own "thing" so each level doesn't get repetitive. The later levels start to get really large and spread-out, like the forest and Alpine Heights get pretty confusing to navigate.

The soundtrack by Grant Kirkhope is AMAZING. All in all, this game is well worth the money, and fun for all ages.

Someone's definitely going to make Hatgirl rule 34 though.

35810294.review: It's supposed to be a sort of homage to N64 era platformers, but it feels more like an homage to some of the finest of the Gamecube era. It has the art style of Windwaker, the humor of Paper Mario TTYD, and the platforming of the good parts of Super Mario Sunshine. It's cute and fun and good, even though it feels a bit unpolished at times. I'm honestly in love with this game. Everything from the bright aesthetics to the tight controls and gameplay.

35806006.review:
What can I say? When I first heard about the game I saw a few gameplay videos but it was still in beta. I decided to wait until the game officially released and forgot about it. When the game finally came out it was time to try it out.

First off, the overall look and feel of the game is amazing. Aesthetically the graphics are nothing short of gorgeous, gameplay wise everything feels responsive and the controls are tight. It feels really satisfying to play.
The game features different worlds which all have different chapters and themes. You'll find there is a good mixture of visual/audio design going on which can create a breathtaking atmosphere in some cases.

The story isn't particularly complex, but it has a few very nice moments. For this type of game I don't think a deep story is needed anyway. Again, the atmosphere in the game does a nice job of setting the stage for those moments to shine through.

As far as the actual gameplay goes, I can't stress enough how good it is. It borrows elements from other classic games and mashes them together in a good way. You'll never feel stuff is just in for nostalgic reasons because it works really well. But it also brings in a bunch of new gameplay mechanics. What I'm trying to say here is that this game doesn't try too hard to be Retro, it just takes all the right things from older games and builds upon that. The chapters are all unique enough and it never gets repetitive. Really great game design.

All in all, there is plenty of fun to be had in A Hat In Time and there's still more coming at the time of writing. 2 new worlds will be added next year and online + local co-op is planned as well. This game also welcomes mods, so I assume we're going to see a lot of cool custom levels in the future.
At the price it's selling for it's an absolute steal. If you love the oldschool platformers from the N64 you will most definitely enjoy A Hat In Time.

tl;dr: Get it. It's really good.

I've been playing video games for a long time and rarely write reviews, but I felt I needed to say something here. This game is well made and crafted with a stromg love of 3D platformers. The environemnts are fun to explore, there are plenty of collectibles and the story is well told and funny. That's the positive.

My biggest gripe is that the camera is pretty awful, it rarely allowed me look where I wanted and was a large struggle. This should not be a problem with plaformers, If I need to look down the camera should allow it without too much fuss. Yooka-Laylee defintely did not have as large of a problem here on release. I hope they come back and patch the camera to operate with more of a free view than a wonky limited camera. A few other things worth noting; as a collect-a-thon the game has no way to track what you've collected in levels. A bit of an oversigjht, I believe, especially for a game where you're running around collecting a variety of stuff in each level. My last point is that there is no mini-map aside from one badge you can get, which is crazily cryptic. I still managed my way around most levels fine. The map would only really be useful in a couple of the larger worlds like the first and fourth, which are more open world and less linear. 

Overall, there isn't a whole lot more to say. The game for the most part is well made. The controls are fairly tight aside from the camera issues, the music blends seemlessly with the every level, the npc's are a blast to interact with, the environments are fun to explore for collecables, and the game ran fantastically. I was easily getting well over 300fps in every level. The game is also shorter with less variety than Yooka-Laylee. I was expecting a little more considering its development time, but what is there is a lot of fun. I would certainly recommend this game, even with my gripes, it's a blast to play.

35792268.review:
Overall, I found A Hat in Time to be an enjoyable game worth completing in its entirety. However, it is certainly not without its fair share of faults. So, let's begin with those:

[list]
[*]The game feels like it was cut short. Had there been 1-2 extra worlds it would've had a perfect length, but with only 4 present it seems like you finish just as you've gotten the hang of it. Knowing that there are plans to release extra worlds as free DLC, it seems to me that this was the initial intention of the developer, but they ran out of time (and/or money).

[*]The controls aren't as responsive as I would've liked. They're certainly not the worst I've ever experienced, however they do feel rather "floaty".

[*]There is no real difficulty in the game, everything is fairly easy. This is extended to boss fights too, as health is constantly dished out without any further thought.

[*]The design of some of the time rifts (A sort of 'bonus' level) is rather repetitive, and the recycled aesthetic quickly becomes boring.

[*]There are plently of collectable yarn balls, with a variety of small challenges to go with them. But there's seemingly no way of tracking how many are left in the level, and there's no reward for collecting them. They appear to be solely for making hats, which is really disappointing. Similarly, not all rift tokens show up on the map, and there seems to be no way of tracking how many are in a level.

[*]The message "You're missing a key item" is used before some levels. This is incredibly unhelpful, as it provides no indicator of what the item is, where to get it, or when you will get it. Thus, players are left wondering whether they missed something, or when they will even be able to play that level to complete the world.

[*]There seems to be a few minor polish issues. When playing the game at 4K I noticed artifacts on the main logo shown during loading screens, and in-game some icons had white borders as if they were dodgy photoshop cutouts. Towards the later parts of the game, dialogue seems to be missing at random points. I am unsure whether or not this is a bug, or because the developers ran out of time. Lastly, in the final level a collectable fell out of a breakable crate into the lava and was seemingly unrecoverable after that, even when quitting and re-entering the level.

[/list]

Now for the good:

[list]

[*]The music is pretty spot-on, and fits in well with each location. It could be argued that perhaps it's a tad generic at times, but that's better than not fitting at all.

[*]Though somewhat spoiled by providing too much health, the boss fights are creative and well-designed.

[*]The levels are very well thought out. Nothing is placed haphazardly, and paths are clearly defined. The theme of the fourth world was particularly creative, and visually impressive. Worlds are sized very well;  they're large enough to encourage exploration, but small enough to prevent getting lost.

[*]There was restraint in terms of the number of and types of hats. Some games seem to go completely over the top with different abilities, but I think A Hat in Time struck a very good balance in the selection provided.

[*]A hub world was included with plenty of nooks and crannies to explore. An absolute must for any good platformer.

[/list]

So to sum up, for those who buy this game expecting a modern-day platformer markedly better than Yooka-Laylee, I'm afraid you've set yourself up for disappointment. Both games have flaws, just as they have their high points. For some it may be easy to look past these issues, simply because of their love for platforming games. However, for others, I would recommend perhaps waiting for a price drop before purchasing this game.

This is one of the best games I have played in a very long time. It has been years since I have been so engrossed in a game that I beat it in one sitting like I did this one (minus having to stop to go to work).

overall I payed 30 for this game but I would still be happy if I had played a full 60, infact this is a game i would have bought an entire console just to play.

35787736.review: Best of the genre since Mario Sunshine,

35787278.review:
TL;DR: Buy this game. Seriously. If you've ever loved 3D platformers, you will love this game.


The long review:
I can't remember when the last time a game made me feel like a kid again. I seriously got a punch of nostalgia, like I was sitting in front of my gamecube booting up super mario sunshine for the first time. This game was worth every cent, and I will buy /ANY/ DLC that comes out in a heartbeat.   

The four worlds mix up gameplay in such creative formulas- If you think every level is just hopping around trying to collect items, you will be pleasantly surprised to find out there is so much more than that. From popularity contests, murder mysteries, boss fights, and a god DAMN stealth horror level (seriously, that was terrifying), this game mixes up the classic "hop and collect" formula in so many delightful ways. The level design is creative and the artistic direction is beautiful, seriously, the first time you go into Alpine Skyline your breath will be taken away- And it's not just for show, hopping through the gorgeous level is just as delightful. 

The music suits each and every level perfectly, and the way the music's instruments smoothly transition as you switch areas without changing the tune is delightful. Some of the most impactful audio moments for me was in the memory-rift levels, where every time you complete a section a new instrument is added to the tune. It actually made me feel nostalgic for the level, even though I had just been in it minutes ago. 

And jesus christ, this game is funny. The voice actors all have unique tinges to their voice to carry out their hilarious lines. The characters are all super lovable, the one that stands out to me is the Ghost... Guy, you'll know him when you see him, and all the Mafia men. Applause to the VAs, you guys did a wonderful job. 

There were quite a few small issues, such as the quality of the character models of the two girls being a little awkward, some bugs here and there (a few frustrated me such as my hits not registering to bosses, but it's nothing unplayable), and those GOD DAMN BAND OWLS THAT FOLLOW YOU AND SMACK INTO YOU FHJDSLFS, but they don't impact the experience in any severe way (but you will notice them.)

Anyway, consider me a new huge fan of Gears for Breakfast. I've seriously already begged my friends to buy this game, and if you've made it this far in my review, please pretend I'm begging you to buy it too. Support this studio. This indie game proves to be just as fun as 3D platformers produced by massive companies like Nintendo- And that's amazing. I can't wait to see the 2DLC worlds and any future games!!

35783693.review:
OK, so, I've only finished the first location so far, so this will be my first impressions. I will update this review as I play the game, leaving old things I've said in. Anyways, here we go. 

A Hat in Time is a 3-D collectathon platformer. It is highly reminescent of the N-64/PS1 era of videogames. I've never actually played Banjo Kazooie or it's sequels, but I do get some serious Mario-64 vibes from this game. The plot is pretty simple, you play as the Hat Girl, who's spaceship has lost it's power source over a strange planet. You have to go through various levels, earning magic hourglasses. 
The levels are very well designed, and don't feel tedious in the respect of finding collectibles. The only thing you NEED to complete it is the hourglass at the end. However, levels are worth exploring, as  you can buy new abilities, craft new hats, and open safes to find treasure. There are also relics you can find, they unlock stuff on your ship. If you don't explore, you'll breeze through the levels, but that's sort of missing the point. 
As for gameplay, the devs pretty much nailed it. The controls are easy to learn and feel really fluid, but I can't seem to find a way to change them for keyboard and mouse. Anyways, hat girl controls super well, in and out of combat. The parkour elements are actually fun, not an N64 nightmare. Combat is pretty basic, focusing on using your umbrella to smack foes, and finishing them by jump attacking. This element of the game gets a little old, but isn't frequent enough to matter. 
To wrap this review up, I'd like to talk style. This game has it. It feels like an honest homage to an earlier generation of games, not a forced emulation of it like some other newer games *cough* Yooka Laylee *cough*. The levels are appealing on the eyes, characters are all entertaining, there's a good sense of humor at work. Also they're actually voiced, not annoying mumbling over text. 
In conclusion (for now) A Hat in Time is fun, colorful, and genuinely charming. If you enjoyed the "wild west" of gaming, than you will enjoy this. Whether you're old or young, this game is easily the second best (at least) game to have goombas as the first enemy on screen. 

Update 1: I have now played through two whole chapters. There isn't much else to say, besides that the soundtrack for bosses is pretty rad. The snatcher's music is easily best part of his fight.

35781707.review:
[h1]Specific Mac Release Review[/h1]

I'm so sorry that I have to write this, because the game is absolutely adorable and has shown itself as such during the first few minutes that I spent with it, but [b] in the current state of the game, I cannot recommend you to buy the Mac release. [/b]


My experience with gaming on the Mac is that usually, developers take some extra time to release for the Mac or even let other companies like Feral Interactive port it for them to make sure that everything works without issues. Here, it's clear that the developers wanted the product out of the door too quickly and didn't have time to do proper quality control, which unfortunately leaves a number of technical issues open that really make it hard to enjoy at this stage:

[list]
[*] Menu doesn't work properly: Forward and Back buttons are invisible most of the time and don't work. I had to find out by trial and error that a right click will take you back one menu. This makes me wonder if there has been [i] any [/i] testing done before release?!

[*] Completely broken controller support: Although advertised as having controller support, this game failed to recognise both my Sony brand PS4 controller and non-Microsoft XBox 360 type controller, both of which work perfectly fine in other games. For a 3D platformer controller support should be nothing less than flawless. I still played for a few minutes with mouse and keyboard just to see at least something, which brings me to a minor point...

[*] Mouse sensitivity and control issues: I can't get the sensitivity down to a well playable level, even with my variable DPI mouse set to slowest level. It doesn't help that sometimes the game drops a couple frames just as you try to move, making slick movement impossible.

[*] Graphics glitch: When setting graphics to "high performance", the screen gets littered with pixely, green stains, as if a Space Invader just sneezed on your monitor.

[*] Excessively long loading times: I have yet to play a game that was this bad with loading times. Good grief. My SSD reading speed clocks in at 1.8 GB/s, so what the hell are you doing? Even worse, the game is completely frozen when it's loading, with loading screen music cutting out randomly. Even quitting the game takes forever, at some point I just force-quit the sucker because I wasn't sure if it was frozen for good or not.

[/list]

That's just what I observed during a first couple of minutes of play. I choose to just wait for the devs to fix things before I play any further. When things are fixed and the game is enjoyable from the technical side, I will edit this review accordingly.

35781318.review:
Woah. 

Just woah.

Its like Windwaker, Super Mario Sunshine, and Mario Galaxy got together and made a game... that's A Hat in Time.

The art style is amazing and easy on the eyes, as well as "cute as heck" as it is advertised. The platforming element is responsive and sticks well with controls that make sense. Some levels may make you want to rip your hair out, but once you get past them, you feel like a million bucks. The soundtrack? Man, I have never heard of the composer, but his work is truly amazing and rivals the like of Jake Kaufman in quality.

I do have a small complaint however; the price. I think $30 is a little steep for a game that can be completed if you work hard in about 6 or so hours, but that's just me. If you go slow and enjoy the game and story, there's a fair chance you can make it last many more hours than 6. 

Buy this game.


Do it.

35781062.review:
A great game that has found its solid identity in this inflated market of platformer franchises. I can honestly say that A Hat in Time has paved its way to nest itself up in the category of what I consider to be legendary platformers - that of the Super Mario series, Crash Bandicoot, and parts from The Legend of Zelda. A Hat in Time is both a visual and audible pleasure to play with its minimalistic depth, intricate and interesting level design, and dynamic atmosphere. I'll be going through most of its strong and weak points to give the game a fair review. In short, the game is a great addition to your platformer library whether you're a newcomer or a veteran to games like this.


[h1][b]Graphics: ( 4.5 / 5 )[/b][/h1]

A visual pleasure to go through. From the cool, sky blue skies of Mafia Town to the spooky Fire Spirits of the Subcon Forest, to the flashy stages of Dead Bird Studios to the endless artscapes of the many Time Rifts you'll explore throughout the game, A Hat in Time understands its own identity when it comes to graphics. While some characters feel truly eye-boggling in their own power respect, all of them feel like they truly "belong there." Explosions release simple particle effects, sprinting has its own nice cloud of dust left behind, and water effects are reminiscent of that of an upgraded Zelda's "Windwaker" vibe. It's amazingly well done that players may feel a sense of visual overload at times, trying to register all of the events happening at once. I'm having no issue playing the game at a consistent 60 frames. Overall, it looks really damn good.


[h1][b]Sound: ( 5 / 5 )[/b][/h1]

Absolutely top-notch sound quality and design. The voice acting is well-done, though nothing jutted out as being absolutely amazing. Your character has very little dialogue, albeit to simple grunts and the occasional "hey!" or "give it back!" Moustache girl's voice is piercingly arrogant, and the Snatcher of the Sub-con forest has a nice whimsical tone to shatter his menacing design. Queen Vanessa's voice has the fitting misty, scary screech many of us fear. Combat noises are also incredibly impactful. Punches and umbrella hits have a satisfying "thud" noise when hitting enemies. Explosions have a toonish quality to them.

And then we come to the music. Oh, the adoring music of the game. Breezy tracks of Mafia Town to the serene pianoscape of the Time Rift. The game never hesitates to establish its atmosphere with music. I can honestly say that the soundtrack is one of its saving graces. The synths in Vanessa's Manor give the game a soothing, yet ominous vibe. The strings in Mafia Town give the game a nice "oasis-like" quality. The developers have amassed sounds that resonate quality and quantity of both serene and frightening atmospheres that should be appreciated. 


[h1][b]Gameplay: ( 5 / 5 )[/b][/h1]

The game follows the great formula of level-design. It isn't difficult to the point you need to drop your controller frustratingly and take some time off away from it. It doesn't hold your hand through every nook and cranny and give you a railing to lean on every time you're in danger of falling. It "teaches" you how the level is supposed to work. The beginning of the level always has a catalyst or key that lays out the rest of the level for you, albeit the difficulty of the level scaling in conjunction with what you're expecting. For example, in the beginning of one level, the game teaches you to hit a certain plant to make certain platforms disappear and others appear. The player learns from that experience and understands, "ah, so that's how it works."

It's high praise for the game; I personally don't like games that have you choose from three scales of difficulty - easy, normal, and hard. It becomes too strict and only allows for scaling to reach a minimum of certain values, rather than formulates a universal difficulty system where platformer veterans have some adequate challenge to them, while newcomers to the genre don't feel too challenged. No one feels as though the game is too hard. 

Every single level has its own gimmick and idea. Nothing feels repetitive at any time. You could be sneaking through a studio of security guards, or scaring off macho Mafia men. You could be trying to disarm an explosive at the front of a train or running from a ghastly queen. You could be trying to solve a murder mystery in twenty minutes or leading a parade of owls through the rooftops of town. It's an assortment of things to that keep the game feeling fresh and new. I have great respect for the level design and how much fun and depth there is. It's simple, cute, and a blast to play.

I will give the game some critique in its boss fights however. Most of them feel drawn out. There are moments in which I feel as though I've defeated a boss, only to have him continue fighting for another three minutes. While it does provide adequate levels of challenge for the player, it feels more dragged out than it does "just right." There have been multiple times in which I've hit the boss a number of times, and exclaimed "He's STILL alive?!" after thinking the fight was pretty much over. 

Platforming, climbing, and jumping controls are smooth, though not always perfect. Rarely do the controls get a bit wonky when navigating a wall or a path, but the "flow" of movement is extremely well-done. The game doesn't make mistakes when you're navigating a path. At times you'll even be amazed with how well it flows and how well you perform in doing some interesting stunts with a "wow, that was pretty cool, did I really do that?" when controlling Hat Kid.


[h1][b]Overall: ( 14.5 / 15 ) = 96%.[/b][/h1]

Definitely a must-buy. I'd like to even take a step further and say this game is quite possibly a contender for one of my top 5 favorite games of 2017. There's so much depth, fun, and atmosphere with the characters, sounds, and level design. It easily is worth the money it is asking for. The music and movement is a great pleasure to experience, and for the time the game took to develop, it was worth it for the fervent response it is getting today. 

Thumbs up to the developers and their patience. A Hat in Time has really earned its pedestal as one of the greatest platformers of all 'time.'

35780336.review: i strongly feel like everyone needs to play a game like this. from beginning to end, this game give the childish nostalgia of just getting into mischief, but also truly encompasses what it means to be a fun platformer. it's never insanely hard where you need to stop playing to calm down, or too easy so that you breeze through it. it packs down the formula for funny jokes, random humor, and witty dialogue beginning to end. the game never falls short of excitement as you try to make a jump, find a secret, or fight a boss. and the boss fights are so fun, with so many flashing lights and things moving in the background, the fights don't feel like a pain to get through. and some bosses have some pretty unique dialogue throughout the fight. some of them just want to talk it out, and it's that type of uniqueness that makes me believe that this game the pinnacle of gaming. just from the picture, everything is lively and pops, not one thing sits still ever. speaking of sitting still, you're never still solving puzzles in the game, it's all quick and fun like a video game should be. i genuinely enjoyed this game, especially the fact that grinding means nothing in this game, and even if it did the power ups you get by using your points actually do stuff, not slightly but significantly. you never realize just how slow you're moving until you pull a scooter out of thin air for you to ride around. Another thing, the characters are just wonderful and cool to be around. yeah they may want to kill you but that's what makes the game even more fun, that you don't realize they want to kill you until they say it, and even then they don't just say "i want to kill you" (with the exception of one boss) they usually say it in really witty lines and amazing voice acting. i give this game a very serious 4.4/5 for its reimagination of what 3d platformers are. the ending could've been a little better, but other than that gears for breakfast, you've made a masterpiece

35766441.review:
A Hat in Time is a great time.
I'm a big fan of platformers, and I was very skeptical of this game - I decided to buy it due to the overwhelming positive feedback from the fans. This is a game that needs to be played to understand why so many people like it.
I'm not going to say this is the best platformer in a long time, but it is certainly a lot more fun than some others I have played this year. It's full of personality, and doesn't feel like a knock-off - instead it finds its own identity through use of unique mechanics and characters.

The controls are tight, and the level design is, for the most part, solid. The difficulty feels just right for this kind of game. The graphics and presentation are well done - it's not going to "wow" anyone, but it has a cute exterior that is pleasing to the eyes. The music is fun and delightful, along with some fairly good voice acting - albeit a bit over-the-top.

However, it's not without its faults. I don't feel the hat-switching mechanic is very well thought out - I wish the hats that you stitch were more of an added extension of your abilities that you retain at all times, instead of having to switch between them. Similar to how the hookshot works - even though it's required to have that equipped as well (as a "badge" upgrade). It's not a huge problem, but it's something I feel would've helped the flow at times. 

In terms of badges, I'm not a fan of their inclusion either. It doesn't really feel like it belongs, and felt more like a way to pad out the game with more features, or to make it unique. Many of the badges feel rather pointless, making the gems that you collect to buy them lose their value somewhat. You may as well have a spot reserved just for the hookshot, considering how often you need it once you acquire it. Again, not a huge problem, but something I feel is worth noting. There are also only 4 major worlds to visit, which may as a disappointment to some. I wasn't too bothered by it, seeing as this is a fairly ambitious indie game, but it's worth putting out there.

Overall, I don't have a whole lot of problems with the game. There are very clear design choices that were made to evoke memories of past 3D platformers (Mario Sunshine especially), so every now and then it feels a little like something I've already done before. But the game isn't plagued by it, and it's more unique than it is a clone of any sort. I wouldn't say I loved the game, but I thoroughly enjoyed it. I'm looking forward to the cooperative play to see how that works.

It's a cute and fun game, and I'd definitely recommend it to any fan of 3D platformers.

I backed this in 2014 when the kickstarter first went live, so I was pretty happy when this finally dropped. The characters are fun and interesting, the game handles very well, each of the worlds feel like my favorite parts of Mario Sunshine, AND it works with a gamecube controller. 
My only gripes are that the voice acting feels a little awkward and amateur at times (but there's also more points where it's very on-point and hilarious), the 'claim prize' button on the rift token machine is B instead of A (which feels counter-intuitive and i've claimed the wrong prize a few times because I'm an idiot that never learns), and there's only like, 40 hourglasses. 35762013.review:
I just don't understand the love for this game.

TL;DR: Low quality game but not the worst. Music is good.

It suffers from bad design and lack of polish in a worse way than Yooka did (presentation, camera, controls, boss fights) yet for some reason I don't see people talking about this because 'omg, hat kid is so cute.' Cute graphics do not a good game make. The whole thing feels janky and unfished. Story wise; very boring to me and poorly written. On top of this, there isn't really any challenge to this game, and I felt myself getting bored with it very early on. Sometimes the platforming works, sometimes it doesn't, leaving me very frustrated. Smooth platforming is incredibly vital to a 3D platformer as we should all know. Many, many parts of this game were an excersize in frustration.

It can also get confusing to find where to go next, especially in Subcon Forest and the sky world. At one point in the sky world, I used the hat to find my next time piece, and I went through all the trouble to get it (despite the fact that it looked like the exact route I used to find a previous piece) and after finally getting there, I find that it is indeed a time piece I had already gotten but blacked out. I had no idea that this game would send me to a piece I had already gotten as there was no clear indication. This just makes no sense to me because the "Finale" level for the world still isn't accessible and yet the game is sending me to collect time pieces I already have. I have no idea what to do at this point. This is an example of just bad design and confusion that is so pervasive in this game.

The boss fights were poorly designed as well, especially one which seemed straight up broken to me. It was the second fight in Mafia town, with the cook. There are certain points where you are meant to jump over his head and then press X to dive into it and hurt him. Most of the time this trigger just didn't work, and I ended up having to just touch his hat with my body and also take damage in the process. During the ball rolling phase, I was doing the right thing by climbing up the little crater to get to him and would still take random damage for seemingly no reason. The whole experience felt poorly designed and untested and served to be an incredibly frustrating experience. The other bosses in the game, while not quite as broken as this one, were not well designed either. 

It wasn't all bad, however. There were some fun parts too. Some of the levels looked great, especially the sky world, but many of them (especially world one) felt cluttered and confusing. The game's music is its strongest point. Even if you decide not to play the game, it would be worth it just to give the soundtrack a listen. Really, it's very rare for games these days to have a soundtrack this good. The character design is pretty good overall as well. Some of the voice acting was good, but it was also painful to hear them read the many poorly worded lines.

Overall, I really do not recommend this game and didn't find it worth the frustration or the price tag. If you are a fan of old school platformers, I would recommend getting Yooka-Laylee instead because I found that game much more enjoyable. Very flawed as well, yes, but when it was fun it was a lot more fun than this game. To the general gaming public, I wouldn't recommend either of these games. Save your money for something with better quality.

It really feels like there's something missing when I'm playing this game knowing it has 98% positive; every time I start it up I get frustrated. It honestly feels like I am playing a different game than the rest of you. I understand that they had little funding and are an indie studio, but they also spent 5 years on this, and that price does NOT reflect the quality. I had followed this game for some time and was excited for it but the final product is disappointing. Kickstarter game with kickstarter quality.

This game is fantastic. Hat Girl is too cute. Movement feels /so/ good. The 3d jumping just feels /natural/ and flows so well, it works how your mind just assumes it should work. So without even thinking about it you can double jump into dash into jumping out of the dash to reach platforms so far away. There's a forgivingness to the controls that make it so you don't accidentally run off platforms - or you can catch yourself and recover even if you do. At the same time it gives you great precision while also not being punishing for little mistakes like holding forwards a little too long after landing from a jump.

The game is also charming as heck and looks beautiful. I felt compelled to collect every time piece and go after every ball of yarn, just because it was fun to do so.

I would highly recommend this game, especially if you remember the good ol' days of 3d platformers like Mario 64/Sunshine and Banjo Kazooie, or if you'd like to see a modern take on 'that kind of game'.
And if you don't have experience with previous-gen 3d platformers, playing A Hat in Time may give you a good insight into what the fuss was all about!

This game is filled with heart and I love it.

35760905.review:
As a platformer fan cannot recommend this enough. Throwback to times when 3D platformers were good. Huge interesting levels with a unique artstyle and imaginative gameplay besides just collecting things. In a lot of places it's giving me a lot of Psychonauts vibes. It also runs super smooth, looks pretty as heck (and too damn cute :P) and it's fast and fluid to control. Overall just very refreshing and fun to play. Doesn't cease to run out of steam and amaze with all the new worlds it's thrown at me.

EDIT: Since I beat the game and I'm still playing it, thought this review deserved a re-write:

For a small indie team and a kickstarter game this is amazing. Best platformer I've played in a very long time, and it rekindled my interest in 3D platforming all over again, probably since Psychonauts.
Art direction and soundtrack are fantastic and the controls are very fluid, bouncy and never managed to annoy me through the course of the game. There's some learning curve to get used to the sliding and such but it feels rewarding to master.
I think the real highlights of the game are its creative worlds however, no world plays the same and you're really missing out if you only play through the first one. While the core gameplay stays the same, level design varies massively from open-ended, exploration focused levels with a single goal to more scripted puzzle-like interiors, mysterious forests to even horror sequences, or complete free roam in a massive mountain. For a super cutesy game there's quite a lot of dark humour in it as well, and the game never fails to make you smile. And the Hat Kid is just the best, I love her personality how she's just going around doing whatever she wants and doesn't even let such things as (spoiler?) losing her soul get in her way :P  

You even get some choices in places which was surprising (I don't recall a platformer where I questioned 'if I did the right thing'), and you are free to progress the game in whatever pace you like. I was never bored and if I felt like switching to a different world, I could do so anytime.
I got a lot of Psychonauts vibes from the game in places and that's even intended with "memory vaults" at the end of certain time rifts unlocking additional backstory to the worlds and overall the level design felt similar, the time rifts might as well be mental worlds, not to mention the crow agents in various levels.
There's just something about the game that hooked me into playing it, and very few games have managed that. I wanted to 100% it immediately on my first playthrough and may even start a second just to see what I missed. It's just fun and refreshing to play for the heck of it and made with love, as games should be.

Workshop support for the game already looks solid and there's quite a few very nice user created levels. Hoping to possibly try editing some myself later.

This game is an absolute treat to play!
It's effectively a love letter to the gamecube era style of platformers, and features a lot of elements from that time.
It even has the little dedicated platforming level sections like Super Mario Sunshine had!
The controls feel tight and very comfortable to use, so again if you're used to the Mario style of platforming you'll feel right at home here.
My only real complaint about the controls is sometimes they can feel a little bit wonky on tight ropes, as jumping off of them or trying to get extra height can sometimes lead to your demise since Hat Girl doesn't seem to stick to them as much as Mario does in Sunshine or Galaxy.

A fun throwback to the old hub world style platformers like Mario 64, DK 64, Banjo Kazooie, etc. Game feels a little short since there's not as many levels like in older games of the same genre, but at least the camera in this game doesn't make me want to throw my controller out my window (I'm looking at you DK 64).

35758550.review:
As soon as I booted up the game, I was met with adorable and goofy story and characters, which compelled me to continue playing. Hat kid controls like a dream. Soon I discovered how satisfying it was to jump around the world and explore every nook and cranny. First I was jumping on suprisingly funny mafia members, and in the next moment sneaking around in a bird movie studio. As I was going on my merry way and the following part https://youtu.be/YQy9_J-9F7o?t=1m12s (1:12) of the bird studio song hit my ears, I knew this game was going to be very memorable.

It took me back to the days I explored Super Mario 64, Super Mario Sunshine, Banjo and Kazooie, Wind Waker,  Spyro, even jack and dexter to some extent, for the first time again. All while being something new, not a copy cat, nor a nostalgic cashgrab. A Hat in Time is very much it's own game, and builds on all the good characteristics of the games I adore.  

The game features some puzzles akin to those one might see in good nintendo games by being very creative and adding layers of complexity as you progress. The third chapter was my favourite. It had great atmosphere, platforming, missions, dialouge and polish. I'll not spoil anything, but trust me it's great.

As of the time of writing, it has some minor flaws in form the form of some small bugs and minor polish at the later sections of the game, but the team is currently patching that stuff it seems. Having said that, the team is also working on adding in the strech goals from their kickstarter campaign, which includes free updates with co-op. They're even going to add two extra worlds later on, which makes me happy as I'm now severly hungry for more.

I highly recommend this game. It was entertaining, cute, and embodies all the good parts of past 3d-platformers and "collect-a-thons". The music is great, the controls are tight and excellent when combined with the many diffrent moves you can execute. The visuals are also nice. 

Thanks for the experience Gears for Breakfast, I really hope this game does well for you, and that you are able to iron out the bugs!
