35753922.review:
Indeed, the game has beautiful aesthetics in all of its levels, great music and awesome humour in many characters' dialogues (when interacting with them in gameplay at least). However, there are just so many, in my opinion, downsides to this game:

First of, the controls and movement
[list]
    [*]The developer recognized how important a good [b]camera[/b] is in a 3D platformer, so they decided to dedicate a lot of resources into making one. It is supposed to predict your movement and adapt to fit it as best as it could. Whether it does it or not, I never noticed. I did noticed how at times, it just zooms in when you are in tight spaces and close to a higher ground ledge, so it becomes impossible to traverse without opportunity to look at your surroundings. Furthermore, you can't look up or down, so forget about wanting to see what is below you when jumping or what would be a good way up unless you get really far away. 

    [*]Hat kid will automatically run up a wall if you give the slightest nodge in that direction. And then, pressing the jump button will only make her jump in the opposite direction, which makes you lose a lot of control unless you take your time moving around. This leads more often than not, to many cheap deaths especially in the Time Rift levels.

    [*]One of the greates challenges in 3D platformers is guessing how much deep you are moving into the camera plane, Mario 64 did a good try at solving this by making your shadow perfectly visible in every surface beneath him. Needless to say, in A Hat In Time, it is extremely hard to do so when the ground or platform you are aiming at is of any dark color or shade. You will notice this when trying to bounce from ballons. 

[/list]

Even though it is not officially advertised as a "collect-a-thon" game, many people categorized it like such. I fail to understand why, however

[list]

    [*]The game breaks the most important convention for a  "collect-a-thon": it doesn't allow you to just go into a level and collect stuff. You have to select a mission and deviate from it if you want to see the entire level, hoping the story doesn't make sections innacessible (For example, at some point the Mafia island floods with lava, leaving all the lowest part innaccesible).

    [*]There isn't really much to collect, just yarn. The game does try to add other stuff to grab, but even at that it fails to make it worthwhile. The tickets for vaults won't save between sessions, so you have to pick them in one go. Not that it is hard, given that if you touch the vault, it will lead you to all the ticket locations. Sadly, there is nothing especial inside them. The green stuff that is used as currency just respawns, so you can't collect it entirely from one level. You can grind it easily, so there is no need to run around looking for it. 

[/list]

Story and handholding
[list]
    
    [*]The game wants to push its story telling far, which is nice. Some beats are enjoyable, even if all are extremely short. This however, is done in a manner that makes an open world useless, given that you have to pick a story act/mission to get into the level. The open world can't even be used as a way to get to the objective as you get dropped right in front of it anyway.

    [*]Speaking of objectives, reaching them is not satisfying at all, because you have your hat that just shows you where it is, there is a huge icon always visible indicating the same information, and characters also tell what you have to do. You will be following this like a zombie that gets handholded by the developers throught the tiny beats of story. 
  
[/list]

The price tag isn't really justifiable for me, I never really had much fun and became frustrated after a couple hours. Levels (unlike what is said in the store description) are not big...at all. And there is only 5 of them. Wait for a sale if you are really a fan of the genre. I could propably keep finding details like those I mentioned after more hours, but the experience is just not worth for me.

35753457.review: Even though there's still a lot more to A Hat in Time than I have played so far, I must admit, I have enjoyed it so far. True, it's not as big as, say, Super Mario Galaxy, but each of the current four chapters (and the final one, Time's End) feels unique just as the developers intended. Be it signing your soul away to open access to new Acts in Subcon Forest, fueling the feud between Grooves and the Conductor in Battle of the Birds, or even exploring the wide-open areas of Alpine Skyway's free-roaming level, each chapter beings something new to the table. And it has helpful tools for both casuals and speedrunners alike, including an in-game timer which shows both game time and indivual level times, auto-skipping cutscreens (Which is a bit bugged when it comes to getting the badge pins as of the current build) and the upcomming modding support currently being worked on. It's not a perfect game, though, with some lines of dialog which could be voiced not being voiced, but those are minor gripes for an otherwise amazing game.

35751486.review:
Oh boy.

First off let me say I don't often take the effort to write a review (whether positive or negative) or even go out of my way to recommend a game unless they're seriously exceptional.. but A Hat in Time was more of an experience than a game.



As an avid Nintendo fanboy I was both looking forward to and very skeptical of A Hat in Time, often advertised as a homage/tribute/throwback to Super Mario Sunshine (probably my favourite game of all time). 

I never played the beta and/or watched content and I'm glad I didn't. From the moment I started playing until the moment I completed the final level I've had nothing but good ol' fun with this game.

All levels are different and clearly a lot of thought and passion went into creating them. And when I say "different", I really do mean many of the levels will make you think you stepped into a different game. Gameplay, Music, Enemies, Atmosphere. Gears for Breakfast nailed every aspect of the game.


A Hat in Time doesn't try to be anything except fun. But when it tries to be a scary game, it's scarier than most. When it tries to be "stealthy", the mechanics are more fun than most stealth games. And when the game tries to be funny, it's funnier than most.

Although the game isn't particularly long (it took me 10 hours to get to 100% completion), it's more than worth it. If the developers had priced the game at 60 dollars and I knew what I was buying, I would be more than happy to pay that amount.



Definitely one of my favourite games and probably one of the only games I'll bother getting the Steam achievements for.

Not a very constructive review, but I wanted to give this amazing game its due credit.

35748742.review:
I specifically bought this game because I heard some people are upset about jontron having a voice in it. The fact that the developers are not spineless cowards, letting themselves being bullied by an overemotional minority of crybabies earns them my respect!

Now to the game itself:
I started playing it with absolutely no expectations whatsoever, but I knew that I enjoyed Rayman 2 and 3 in the past and A Hat in Time reminded me very much of these games as I watched the clips in the shop. After playing it for 20 minutes, I was immediately fond of the cute characters and the crazy setting and I soon found myself rushing through the levels.

Gameplay:
The gameplay of A Hat in Time is very smooth and I had almost no problems with it. I played through the whole game with an Xbox One controller, without experiencing any frustration, which was often the case with other jump and run titles. The only part in the game, where I had some problems, was with some platforming in the Great Windmill level. I tried to jump on a moving wall piece, where I slipped off and ended up reactivating a checkpoint way below me and I had to replay that whole part again. Other than that, I had absolutely no issues. 

Like the title of the game suggests, you must use a variety of different hats to advance. These hats can then be upgraded by buying pins which give you unique powers. As you proceed through the game, you will get more hats and the game will get more complex.

Boss Battles: 
There is combat in this game, but fighting against regular enemies, is smoothly combined with the rest of the gameplay so I won’t address this any further. 

The real deal when it comes to combat though, are the Boss Battles in this game. When I encountered the first Boss, I was completely surprised. I wasn’t sure what to expect, but whatever I thought it would be, it was like 20 times better! THE MUSIC! THE FAST PACE! THE SETTING! This is where this game is shining the brightest. 

I have 1 complaint about the last boss of the game though: The time slowing hat is kind of OP… I was using it throughout the whole boss fight and it ended up being way too easy. I’ll have to try it another time without the hat I guess.
 
Art & Music:
As I already hinted at in the Boss Battle part of this review, I absolutely love the Music! I am pretty sure that if you would remove the music from this game, it wouldn’t even be half as good. No matter where you go, you will always be followed by a catchy tune to hum along.

Then there is the colorful & warm art style, which gives the game a powerful atmosphere. I can’t really say much about it though, since I think everyone has his own taste when it comes to graphics 😊

Story:
The story is very simple: You are traveling home in your spaceship and are flying over a strange planet. An unfortunate event happens and you lose all your “fuel”, which you then have to regain in order to get home. On your way of regaining all your “fuel”, you will encounter a lot of funny, diverse and interesting characters that accompany you throughout numerous adventures.

Length/Content:
I took 13-14 hours to finish the game with 97%. For my taste, the length of this game is just right, as I rather replay the game a bunch of times instead of playing an eternity to finish it once. But I think this is up to debate, as some people would enjoy it to be a bit longer.

Conclusion:
Positives:
- MUSIC!
- Smooth Gameplay
- Boss Battles
- Gadgets & Customization

Negatives:
- Maybe the length for some people???

The game was more than worth it’s price and I will probably try to get myself some merch. I really hope that there will be a sequel to this game. 
Please? 
Pretty Please???

35735807.review:
A Hat in Time - Review by Jams Bolero

A Hat in Time is exceptional.  Besides a few notable details, this game is very finely polished.  Hat Kid moves like a dream, and the entirety of Gears for Breakfast's final product is just filled with charm.  This is a game I could come back to time and again just to get a piece of the platforming action.


*SPOILERS*
If you do not want to be spoiled, you have been warned.
*SPOILERS*


The Things I Liked:
-CONTROLS: Playing this game is just divine.  Hat Kid looks floaty from gameplay footage but she controls with great precision.  Her base moveset is simple but versitile, allowing for some really rewarding challenges throughout the game (i.e. beating Train Rush without time bonuses).  Controls are one of those things that can completely ruin a game, but let it be known that A Hat in Time has them down pat.

-STYLE: Hat Kid is freaking adorable and I would buy a plush of her as soon as I could.  From playing patty cake with the mafia before getting her headlights punched out to signing her soul away with a cute smiley face at the end, this child is wonderful to behold.  This is also helped by the fact that our protagonist, over the course of the game, will become friends with the mafia, competitive movie directors, a demon who coaxes souls from his victims, and enlightened goat people.  That is just hilarious on so many levels it cannot even be described.

-VARIETY: There is quite a bit of variety in the game in many aspects.  Hats obtained all have unique effects, and with only one exception I found myself using all of them rather regularly.  Badges also have variety, while not stepping on the toes of whatever hats there are but rather just changing how the game works.  Even the missions are unique; one minute Hat Kid will be hanging around the islandic Mafia Town, then the next said island is surrounded and drenched in lava.  The boss of Chapter 2 differs depending on the ending the player gets, and world layouts per chapter are all uniquely tailored to said chapter.

-CHAPTER STRUCTURE: This is by far the one thing that worried me most and impressed me incredibly upon getting my hands on this copy.  Chapter 1 gives you a rather large world tailored to beginners that holds rather specific objectives. Chapter 2 has unique settings and objectives for each mission that have a big impact on the chapter's finale.  Chapter 3 also has specific missions, but most of these have to be found via contracts in the world, and because said world is so enigmatic and vast there is tons and tons to explore even after having found all the contracts.  Chapter 4 completely forgoes mission predictions and relies on the player to explore and find each time piece themselves.  This variety in chapters is incredibly inspiring, and completely justifies to me why they took so long to make only a 4.2 world game.  When each world is so unique and each chapter has such a unique impact on the player, it really does show the love and care the developers put into this title.


The Things I Didn't Like
-GENERAL POLISH: About the only gripe I have with the game is that there are a few really iffy areas in which the quality falters a bit.  Most notably- and I noticed this immediately- the characters in Chapter 1 do not have lip syncing.  It doesn't have to be much!  It could just be like Snatcher, where it is just the mouth moving out of sync with their lines as they say it.  Anything is better than the muscular mafia talking to me without any mouth movement at all
Also, I noticed several people say the game is fully voiced.  No it is not.  It is mostly voiced, yes, especially in the parts that count, but in the finale- that is, the last chapter- a good deal of characters have no voices at all.  In fact, there's this nice cat lady who cooks with the stove on Hat Kid's spaceship who has a sweet southern accent, but while she has lines in the final battle, talk to her before then and all you get is a text bubble.
These may seem like nitpicks, but I do feel like they take away from the experience a tad.  It does not ruin the game at all, but I feel this would have helped all the more to really solidify A Hat in Time's quality.  After all, it's the small details that really count.

35734518.review:
Yeeeeey a good 3D platformer!

Pleasant surprise doesn't even describe it! ... No wait that does pretty much describe it.... Anyway.

Long story short, it controls relatively well (a few issues when you want to aim at specific things) on both kb/m and a controller, it runs fairly well, there are a few drops on max settings on my system but nothing too bad, and you exist in an extremely adorable creative world.

BUT, to elaborate... A [strike]Cat in a Hat[/strike] Hat in Time does enough things right to be a very fun game and feel cutely unique.

Let's start world building! Your spaceship was attacked by the Mafia ... in space.. without a suit... and because of that all your time traveling fuel is scattered around the planet. Mild inconvenience as the main character thinks. So, using your hat powers and I guess also your time traveling powers, but who needs that, right? You are on your way to fix your ship and... do whatever you are going to do after that.

From there you go in many different sets, all being incredibly imaginative but still down to Earth at the same time. You never get to feel alienated or confused. And a lot of light-hearted darkish humour, if that even makes sense.

TONS of unlockables. Apart from your main hats and whatnot, you also get to, via certain side missions (that are not so side but whatever), you get to unlock randomly different customization for your character, be it colours for your outfit or different skins for your hats, and many other things like different BGM for the stages. Really adds to the repliability, even if I doubt many people will be interested enough to play that much.

Graphically the game really sets the mood regarding the situation. A fairly simplistic cartoony environment with many details in the world for you to have 5 seconds of fun every time you go past them, not even realising it. Oooone minor issue that I have there is that a few character models after the first stage are not that well made. And certain animations from NPCs. It's not too bad, but noticeable.

Audio... Yeah they pretty much nailed that part. I have no complaints for the most part, the design of the sound effects, music, whatever. It all works really damn well! I'd even go as far as to recommend buying the soundtrack.

Controlling your character might seem a bit frustrating at the start. You are actually ... well.. a child in a way. If you slide on a wall you will be dazed for a second. If you fall from a bit too high height you will again be dazed for a moment. But then comes the fun part, cause there's ways in the controls to avoid all those things. It does add a lot of character in the game however. BUT with all that said, if you want to target your ranged attacks, or sometimes even the melee attacks, it tends to be a bit too precise, attacking exactly where your character is looking, so you can miss stuff by a small distance. It's possible to get used to it but still an inconvenience. Except the wallrunning mechanic. That takes a while to get used to and it can still be annoying afterwards in some places.

WORKSHOP! For some reason the game has this, so if you like mods... Unreal Engine so easy to make stuff for it. I am not sure how much they allow through the workshop, but a lot of customization is already in place.

Even if this game, as any game, has flaws, I really do recommend it. It's enjoyable, it's adorable, it's a satisfying experience.

35733505.review:
A Hat in Time is a game that is described on their main website as a 'cute-as-heck 3D platformer', and I think that's a fitting description. It was originally shown to the public on Kickstarter (as many indie games these days are), and it raised $296,360, destroying it's original goal. That was 4 years ago, and now the game is out, and it is truly something special.

As stated before, it's a 3D platformer: unlike Yooka-Laylee, which was clearly trying to replicate the magic of Banjo-Kazooie, A Hat in Time borrows the best elements of many 3D platformers from yester-year, and mashes them together to create a short but sweet adventure.

Firstly, there's movement. Hat Kid (the main protagonist) is a joy to control, and her moves are very simple: jump, double jump, a mid-air dive and the ability that your hat provides. There are a handful of hats to enjoy, and each offer a very useful ability. There wasn't a single hat that I didn't find useful.

The story is also very simple: your spaceship is flying by a planet, when one of the residents pops by, who destroys your ship and scattering the fuel (Time Pieces) across the world. It's pretty simple, but the characters all have charming personalities and voice acting that's actually pretty good (and you can turn it off if it's not your fancy).

The presentation is also top-notch: even when playing on the lowest settings (I have a pretty bad computer), the game looked great and sounded better. The soundtrack is exquisite also, and prefectly compliments each scenario.

The only problems are that the game can occasionally hiccup, I had a lot of technical issues (frame drops, clipping, etc.) and the game is pretty short (about 10 hours) but the game is so good I can really overlook all these things. 

I really can't sing this game's praises enough: I loved it so much I went and got every achievement. Don't wait for a price drop or sale, go buy so we can have more amazing games from Gears for Breakfast.

35721265.review:
I could go on for hours about what this game does right. It captures the exact feel of the old great 3D platformers you grew up with (or maybe didn't, if you're a young'n). Its music is superb, sometimes almost choking me up on how good it is. The art style is charming, the sound design is lovely, the controls are airtight and an absolute joy to play, the humor had me genuinely laughing so many times, and Hat Kid is so precious that it ought to be criminal. I could go on and on, but it's easier to just say that A Hat in Time is simply fantastic.

It is however, unpolished. As much as I'd love to say the game is perfect, there are occasional bugs here and there that aren't exactly hard to replicate. Ledges that you feel like you really, REALLY should have reached from wall-running from what seemed like the "intended" jumping point (lookin' at you, Alpine Skyline), and invisible geometry sprinkled throughout. A certain bell in a certain dreamscape refused to activate as I relentlessly swung at it. A lot of characters that aren't Hat Kid or a Mafia goon are animated as though they belong in a bargain bin game, and ones that aren't simply don't have many animations to begin with.

That sounds like a lot of complaining compiled into that one paragraph, but only because I didn't subject you to 10 paragraphs singing the game's praise, which I could have easily done and I have to physically restrain myself from doing. Most problems that have any affect on gameplay are honestly minor, USUALLY don't end up with you falling in a pit, and only give brief "what the-? oh well" moments that you'll likely forget within half a second, and the complaints with character animations are just that. They don't hurt the game as a GAME, it's just something you notice and think "eh, that looks kinda janky, doesn't it?"

That said, some things like the invisible geometry (some of which is harder to avoid than to accidentally bump into) or Hat Kid just plummeting to her (non-gameplay affecting) death during a cutscene feel like things that just shouldn't be happening. They're problems I have no trouble replicating every single time, and have seen other people experiencing every single time in the same places, so it comes across as strange to me that such flaws would make it through development.

Despite the gears needing a little oil, A Hat in Time is still one of the best platformers to be made in recent memory. It honestly stands up to the classics in terms of gameplay, and may even surpass them in terms of technical gameplay, and definitely dwarfs them in terms of adorableness. I'd never tell anyone to not get this game due to the small issues. In the 12 hours I was messing around getting all 40 time pieces, and for all the extra hours I've spent just dorking around because it's genuinely fun enough just to play for FUN (what a concept!), I recall maybe two instances that I was honestly frustrated by those minor flaws. If updates in the future were to smooth out those bumps, then as a game, A Hat in Time would be very near perfect, held back only by some "meh" NPC animations.

Get this game. Its gameplay is fantastic, it has more heart than a blue whale, it's so cute that you'll question whether or not you ever had a single spit of testosterone in your body at all, and it may even move you to tears with how simply enjoyable the experience is.

A really basic story, hat kid loses time pieces, she now has to go recover them, not a deep story but it works for a platformer.

The gameplay is fantastic, the levels are fun to play, they are creative and well thought out, the boss fights are not too challenging but each boss fight is different from the other.

The game's controls and movement are very smooth and responsive, it feels great to just run and jump around.

Lots of good things can be said about the game but there is one major flaw in the game, it is just so damn short.
you can easily get 100% on your playthrough and get all of the achivements in less than 15hours which is not enough.

[b] TLDR [/b]
Overall the game itself is a masterpiece, aside from it being really short, it is definitely worth your money and time.

35716234.review:
A Hat in Time was a bit different from what I expected gameplay wise, I though it would be more open world (or open area) but instead was more akin to mario 64 of various areas with selectable missions that slightly change the area's layout. The goal also being similar to mario games in that you're looking for timepieces that are essentially stars (with 40 in the game). There are 4 "worlds" though some are less of areas and more like linear levels. Even the world that is labeled "freeroam" is one of the most linear areas. Each area also comes with bonus "rift" levels where you find the rift in the world and try to complete the level. As for gameplay, you have a rediculous range of motion and can get from one place to a fairly far away place without touching the ground. You have a double jump, a mario 64 style dive/cancel, a homing attack, short vertical wall run and wall jump, as well as a "wind waker" grapple (and crawl) along with other utilities. The only thing is that with such a wide range of movement and the game being a 3D platformer, you're expected to make full use out of it which (along with the less then perfect camera) can sometime make it difficult to figure out which way you're expected to go (a few times, your best way to counter this is just not to underestimate the jumps you can make). The camera could definately use some work and if I had one peice of advice to give, it would be to turn off "camera assist" otherwise, once it starts turning on its own, you'll be forced to match it's movement with your jump angle which got me killed more times than I can count before checking to see if I could turn it off. It can also be a little hard to determine depth which can make certain jumps difficult. That all being said, once you grasp all the movement mechanics, the levels are fun and interesting with little puzzles here and there and some really interesting platforming mechanics with new things being introduced at a good pace. 

Outside of the mechanical aspects, the game advertises as being cute as heck but heck doesn't even begin to describe the level of cuteness in the game. Similar to how you might this of "Nintendo polish", this game has little bits and peices to add to the cuteness to the character and the world. There were too many moments to count where the game just made me feel happy. The story it also very entertaining and funny (albiet a bit weird towards the end) and there are many levels that do different and neat things. The only thing is that the same levels after played, won't have the same effect after being experienced the first time thought that in no way means they won't still be fun, just not the same. Boss battles are also fun and interesting and can also be played over and over without losing their touch. The graphics are beautiful making exploring and looking for collectables just an overall enjoyable experience. The soundtrack is amazing and enhances the experience even more. I was sitting on the title screen like "I want to hit A but Ill just wait for the title music to finish it's loop". The area music perfectly suits the setting and the boss themes are epic and so fun to listen to. There are also a number of customization items that you can unlock with said collectables. If I were to recomend it to anybody, I would recomend it to anyone who likes fun, cute things, or is horribly depressed and needs some happiness in their life.

35716133.review:
This game is aimed squarely at a generation of gamers that grew up with anthropomorphic duos and critically important shiny gold things. And boy howdy, does it deliver. I've been pining for a proper 3D platformer for years now, and, indeed, have wondered why it hasn't happened yet. But it's finally, *finally* here.

For those who don't really understand the collectathon genre, it's not really about the collecting. Mario 64 wasn't a game about collecting stars. What made it great (aside from being a novelty at the time due to pioneering several mechanics and concepts still used today) is losing yourself exploring the levels and slowly chewing through the game as you unlock things. The old adage holds true; it's about the journey, not the destination. Banjo-Kazooie expanded on this by adding lovable characters (eekum bokum), a real story, and a bunch more stuff to collect to unlock abilities, making you feel more powerful as you progress. A Hat in Time is a mashup of this, with a modern flare.

In short, 10/10 would hug Hat Kid again.

35708485.review:
Note: I am very much aware of drama behind the creator and the fact JonTron is on the game, but one, I kinda don't care in the grand scheme of things (yes harassment and unfavorable political standings and blah blah blah but I play games to get away from that kind of shit) plus it's not fair to the other people who worked on the game. Gotta know when to seperate the product from the person sometimes.

I enjoyed it. It reminds me of those old N64 Platformers without being massive collectathons. In that sense it leans toward Mario 64/Sunshine rather than any of the Rareware ones thankfully.

It's charming, it's cute, it's quicky and has a lot of character. Each world differs nicely from each other with lovely variety and creativity. There's really only one level/act I don't like (I dislike the parade) and the rest were all a treat to play, and the bosses are pretty neat too.

And most importantly, it controls extremely well. Very responsive, jumping feels good and the movement options are great and the game doesn't keep any of that a secret from you either.

There can be some performance issues but there's a plethora of graphical options to get the game running smooth like butter.

Only downsides I'd give is that jumps can feel "leap-of-faith"y sometimes; nothing that can't be fixed with tweaking the drop shadows. Wall clinging can feel a bit "sticky" and it might be a tad short (which suits me cause so many games, so little time) but overall I say it's worth the purchase.

If you're on the fence, wait for a sale. $30 might be a bit much, but I think $20 is more fair.

35708351.review:
tl;dr A Hat in Time is a flawed first outting for an indie platformer that makes up for its numerous small deficits with a boatload of character, heart, nostalgia, and most importantly, fun.

A Hat in Time is short but sweet and can be completed 100% with all achievements in about fifteen hours. That said, that fifteen hours manages to encompass most if not all of the positive aspects of the collectathon games of yore without any of the bloat or filler that those games could often be bogged down by. This game most closely resembles games like Mario 64 and Mario Sunshine in that each level typically houses 8-10 Hourglass Pieces that you can obtain, while unlocking new levels requires that you hit a certain threshold before they're unlocked.

The platforming and movement feel incredibly crisp, mixing double jumping, a dash, and wall climbing to create easily controlled speediness that meshes well with the design of the environments. Three of the four worlds are fairly open in design and afford areas that are large enough to explore but not large enough to illicit boredom or undue traveling times. Time Rifts, which are self-contained levels that can be found throughout the worlds, provide some of the most engaging platforming challenges in the game while showing off some really great linear level design that provides a break from exploration.

The music is phenomenal and ranges from cheery tunes for exploration, frantic melodies for more intense moments, and especially memorable boss music that brings the action of each world to a satisfying and energetic climax. The voice acting does just enough to set the tone of the game. Hat Kid doesn't talk much, but her face is occasionally quite expressive during cutscenes. A Hat in Time chooses its voiced characters well, though, and really hammers in a lot of character for the fairly small amount of voiceover work. 

Overall, A Hat in Time has a metric ton of character, but it's riddled with small issues that could potentially inhibit the experience:

-- Unlike Mario games, each chapter in a world is tied to a specific hourglass. The level typically changes in some way to encompass this, but A Hat in Time is lacking the free roam feeling of exploration and the excitement of finding secrets that older collectathons are famous for because hourglasses can't be find by exploration.
-- Most of the platforming surprises or secrets outside of Time Rifts either afford you thread for creating hats or coins for getting music remixes and cosmetic changes, so the sense of accomplishment from roaming an area can quickly dwindle.
-- Hats afford special abilities, but only two feel like they have any real impact on the game or platforming. Even then, their impact is fairly minimal. There's not a lot of back tracking or using hats to unlock secrets. As a counter-point, this does make the game feel more focused and less bloated by filler despite lacking the joy of discovering new ways to use hats.
-- I encountered several collision issues throughout the game, particularly when it came to rounded objects. The game's way of fixing these issues is to teleport you to your last safe spot, which can be jarring.
-- The last third of the game feels rushed and the main antagonist feels underbaked. 

These might seem like a lot of negatives for a game, but these were things that I felt compelled to nitpick after my stellar experience. I can't stress enough how much fun this game was to play through despite its flaws and length; I haven't been this enthralled by a collectathon since the N64 era. A Hat in Time captures all the best aspects of those games without falling into the pitfall of being iterative or boring, allowing you to spend just enough time with its characters and worlds before pushing you onto the next experience. While there are issues with the polish, none of those problems threatened to ruin my enchantment with A Hat in Time while I was playing. The sheer amount of heart this game has is incredible, and I was enthralled throughout.

A final important note is that the developers are planning on releasing two new FREE DLC worlds in the future. A modding toolkit will also be readily available to players in due time. It's very clear that the devs have a strong commitment to community, and that means a lot for the game's longevity. It's a great thing to see from a group of folks in the modding community who put out their first game with Kickstarter.

35706500.review:
Pros:
- This game is oozing charme like very few do.
- Entertaining and colorful cast of characters and enemies.
- Hammy and/or entertaining voiceacting, as it should be. If needed, it can be turned off by buying a specific badge.
- Platforming that is highly inspired by Super Mario 64. It feels and plays, however, very closely to Mario Sunshine during the extra-levels where Flood is missing. This game also features time rift levels which are extremely similiar to these bonus levels from Super Mario Sunshinel
- Artstyle very reminiscent of The Legend of Zelda: Wind Waker, which simply adds to the charme of this game.
- Environmental Design is perfect for this type of 3d plattformer, it offers a lot of variety and each chapter/world has its own, clear identity.
- A+ Soundtrack, it's really good, especially the boss-themes.
- Speaking of boss-fights: These are somewhat more intense than I expected from a 3d-plattformer, they're as silly as they are flashy and fun, making them very memorable and fun to replay while trying to go for a no-hit run with the 1-Hit Hero Badge.
- Featurres a murder, a spooky mansion, the mafia, a girl with a moustache and a kid with a hat.
- Quests for hourglasses are very different from one another. While they are fewer in number (40 total) the ones that are part of a chapter have a clear identity.



Cons:
- The game feels a little short. 
The worst part about this game is that it ends. I collected almost everything in-game and got all the steam-achievements, clocking in at only 20 hours now. 
However, we will see two additional chapters during updates and hopefully more due to steamworks and maybe other updates the developers have planned, who knows.
- A bit too easy sometimes, only an item that makes you get oneshot to increase difficulty. Nitpick, but I'd like anything that could increase difficulty so I could replay it in its entirety in that difficulty :)
- minor camera annoyances. Nothing on the main-path to an hourglass and nothing major, it's something I noticed in a few sections in the upper part of subcon forest, usually when there is an object in the way.
- Timestop hat with fast hatter badge is overpowered.

Do I recommend this game?
Is water wet? Is hat kid absolutely adorable?
Why are you still down here instead of buying the game and playing it? If enjoy oldschool 3d-plattformers a la Mario 64 or Banjoy Kazooie or 3d-plattformers in general, then this game is certainly something you'd enjoy playing. Maybe watch a video featuring the first world if you have doubts.
I played this for 20 hours and those were twenty extremely fun and satisfying hours that left me very happy. There are few games that I'd consider to complete to 100%, or even near-100%, this is one of them because I love it and therefore I rate it cute-as-heck/10, it's a must-buy.

35705325.review:
Change can be scary. Familiarity breeds comfort, and nowhere is this notion of familiarity greater than in our memories. Nostalgia is a powerful sentiment that has the potential to inspire or to hold back. Jonas Kaerlev, the creator of A Hat in Time, understands this keenly. He and his team at Gears for Breakfast hearken back to an older, beloved generation of games while developing their own sense of identity and fun. A Hat in Time doesn’t reinvent the wheel; it turns it into a brightly colored, well-designed, cute-as-heck unicycle.

Gears for Breakfast has done a fantastic job of revisiting an old genre with a new, fresh perspective. Featuring tight controls, a whimsically colorful universe and characters, and a gorgeous soundtrack, 'A Hat in Time' hits all the right notes to become an instant classic. Despite the content being on the shorter side for the moment, future updates will add more to an already great game. For collect-a-thon veterans and platformer newbies alike, there’s something for everyone to enjoy in this heckin’ cute adventure.

read more at https://www.goombastomp.com/hat-in-time-review/

or dont im not your stepdad

35705163.review:
After countless delays A Hat in Time finally arrived on October 5th with little fanfare, especially after the world had been burned by several failed kickstarter projects that never delivered or simply wanted to bank-in on nostalgia without putting soul into it. And yet there was someone that was still pushing for more, that wanted to recapture that feeling that we all had when we played games such as mario, banjo or psyconauts. 

The absolute mad men did it, Gears for Breakfast created one of the most charming, tight and lovable platformer in the last decade.

The fantastic movement mechanics that inch you to experiment and break sequences, finding alternate routes and exploting Hat Kid's abilities coupled with pin point perfect camera controls make for what might be the best platforming ever made since mario 64.
The witty and clever writing mixed with the cute charm of the lovable characters form a brilliant world that will make you want to explore every inch of it and talk to everyone, just to see what funny thing they'll say next.
The genius soundtrack composed by Pascal Michael Stiefel perfectly frames the adventure and tone of each chapter and stage with a dynamic music that will always set the mood for the scene with masterful precision.
The level design shifts and churns every chapter, always stimulating with new ideas and crazy settings that keep throwing you off balance changing the rules and keeping it engaging and interesting.
A Hat in Time succeeds because it expands on old formulas. It mixes an repackages tried and true mechanics and then combines them while giving a coat of polish that makes the game its own unique thing, able to stand on its two legs against the ancient platformer giants of yore.

Like a thunderstorm on a sunny day A Hat in Time invaded our world after seemingly going off the radars for years.
A quiet, solitary release by a small team of humble yet surprisingly inventive bunch that I'm sure we'll hear a lot more from in the future.
It is a brilliant game and an instant classic.


*The modder background of the development team ensures the game will have full modding support and a level editor. I hunger for more Hat Kid adventures and can't wait to see what the community and GfB will cook up next.*

A hat in time is a cute 3D platformer, and ive been told it is an homage to old Nintendo 64 platformers like Super mario 64, ive never really played many collect-a-thons and certainly not any of the older ones but i'll admit this game has got me hooked.
I'll start with the many pros this game has and then list a couple of nitpicks i have with the game.

Pros:
- Cute graphics.
- Fun and well constructed levels and worlds.
- Amazing and catchy soundtrack.
- Workshop support A.K.A endless hours of community made levels and mods.
- It's incredibly fun to just swing around aimlessly in the world and get lost.
- Collectibles actually matter, you collect hourglasses to ofcourse progress in the story but aside from that you collect yarn to make new hats A.K.A abilities and rift tokens to unlock new cosmetics.
- A Kickstarter project that was actually not a massive dissapointment A+

Now i don't really have many "cons" to list but i have atleast a few things i would have liked to see in the game.
- A new game+ mode where you carry all your items from your safe file over to a new game, maybe even add some exclusive NG+ items to be collected (To be fair it is listed as a stretch goal on their kickstarter so a NG+ will most likely be added at some point.)
- Free roam for all worlds, There is one particular world where you start out with just wandering around with no clear goal, id have liked this as a feature for all the worlds especially the first and third. Now i can easily just pick any act in a chapter and just not do the goal but it feels sorta awkward, it's hard to explain, in any case maybe just add it when you 100% a certain world?
- Restart mission button, this one is really low on the agenda and it's more of a luxury i wish was there when i was chasing certain achievements so it's not really that big a deal, could be nice for speedrunners? if they are only speedrunning a certain level or practicing speedrunning certain levels maybe?

TL;DR 
game is great with minor nitpicks, this is a cute 3D platformer that will give you hours of fun if you're into these sorts of things.

A Hat in Time progresses similiar to Mario64 and - I hear, Mario Sunshine. The game is separated into chapters, which are further separated into different acts. You can do them in the order you want and return to them at any time, assuming you have enough stars - I mean, timepieces to unlock them. 
The game has huge worlds that are filled to the brim with content and collectibles, the soundtrack adjusts according to the area you are in to set the mood, the visuals are excellent and the gameplay is what I really enjoy in this game.

It's a cute-as-heck 3D Platformer and the way the camera and your character move in the game are excellent. The controls are tight and the character handles well, you can make long jumps and flips from the tiniest branch of a tree to the next with no trouble. You almost have too much movement as you can skip most of the puzzles and long platforming sections with no upgrades or abilities, just the basic jumping and diving abilities.

A Hat in Time shows what a kickstarter project can be when done right.

35695819.review:
I have been craving a good action/platformer for a very, very long while, and this game delivered expertly on that promise and more.

It feels like the end of 2017 might just mark a new renaissance for platforming games, what with titles like Cuphead, Mario Oddysey, and now this coming out. This game is a breath of fresh air which executes incredibly well on the promise of being a 3D platformer of the highest quality.

For starters, no non-Steam DRM or microtransactions here. Unlike many AAA publishers known for evading taxes and nickel-diming their customers at every opportunity, Gears for Breakfast decided that you get what you pay for and chose not to inconvenience paying customers with DRM or shove microtransactions down the players' throat in an attempt to milk every customer's pennies. That alone is deserving of praise, but there's a lot more to this game than reasonably consumer-friendly business practices.

It's a title dripping with charm and character. Many of the character moments left a goofy grin on my face and the writing style and palpable atmosphere present in each mission really add to that. Several levels have whole areas of the map designed for just one or two missions, and a couple even change up the mechanics just enough to make each new mission feel like a different adventure.

The controls feel amazing, and Hat Kid's unique hat abilities add a lot to the platforming. Your character feels incredibly light, yet the game's controls never reach "floaty" territory or become too loose. Everything feels consistently tight here, and your character has just the right kit to make what is probably the most "acrobatic" platformer on the market. The wall running particularly makes you feel like the environment is your playground. The well put together levels and challenge stages(called Time Rifts) do a great job at accentuating the characters' absolutely joyous moveset.

I could see why some would think the game lacks in length - There are 40 time pieces, and as of writing this review I've collected 26 of them and beaten the final boss in just seven hours of gameplay, and I like to take my time. Compared to the 120 star standard of the Mario games, it may sound a bit lacking at first, but each individual mission has more "meat" than your average 3D Mario mission, and with Workshop support and rumors that the game will allow mod stages through said workshop in the future, I predict this game will feel more than satisfying for buyers now, and only grow in content over time.

While the characters *could* be fleshed out more, and there *could've* been some more hat abilities in the game, and while the game is *sometimes* lacking in visual polish(despite maintaining an immaculate art style), these things rarely detract actively from your experience with the game.


In the end, I would recommend this game to anyone, especially those who are feeling more and more jaded with regards to the industry today. It is absolutely worth the $30 asking price and more. I would encourage anyone who wants the game and has the spare cash to pick this game up at its advertised price rather than waiting for a sale, as these developers absolutely deserve every penny in my opinion, but I will, of course, not chide anybody for waiting, as I tried to, for a sale.

This is a quality experience, and may just lead the charge into a new wave of platforming games to come. I cannot sing this game's praises highly enough and have nothing but excitement for the next adventure that might be delivered to us by Gears for Breakfast.

35683855.review:
An absolute must buy if you are a fan of 3D platforming genre. Everything in this game is done as close to flawlessly as you can get. The art style is absurdly cute and extremely well done, the soundtrack is absolutely incredible, the characters are all fun and memorable as are the levels. Each level is extremely well put together and paired well with the excellent controls, which are tight, responsive, and smooth. I haven't enjoyed just moving around in a game as much as I have in A Hat In Time in quite a while. 

Although it's a little short, especially if not going for 100% completion, it justifies its price by being as fun as enjoyable as it is. As for difficulty its nothing crazy, but its not easy either, hitting that sweet spot for casual players and completionists alike. A couple of the achievements are pretty brutal, however it won't take you too long to do if you are persistent and paitent.

For those concerned with the length of the game they are adding workshop capabilty right now, with two hats being available at the time of writing this review. Workshop will add some extra content to go play around with if you want more!

I can confidently give this game a 10/10, and a spot on my GOTY contenders for this year.

35682077.review: Well, this is just figgin fantastic. In spite of all the technical issues I've had with the game it more than makes up for it with good controls, gameplay and comedy.

35682059.review:
A Hat in Time... man oh man, what a journey it has been. Discovered this game two years a go I think; I became a "slacker backer" for it as soon as I discovered it. I've been following it ever since; played the heck out of Beta, played their Speedrunning Demo, and even though I have 100% this game already, I continue to keep playing it.

In A Hat in Time, you take control of an adorable protagonist simply named "Hat Kid." Hat Kid is stopped at a fairly unusual world as her fuel for her space ship, the Time Pieces, are taken from her. Hat Kid will have to jump and sprint her way across the planet to retrieve all of her Time Pieces, meeting a lot of whimsical characters along the way.

The game is a collectathon, so you'll find a variety of treasures in each level; some you'll find in large quantities, some you'll have to purchase, and others you'll have to hunt for.

If you've ever played literally any 3D Mario game, get this. You will be far from disappointed.

35681099.review:
I have a pretty decent history with 3D Platformers from the late 90s/early 00s era, 2 of those being my top 2 games of all time because of how memorable they were. These 2 games were bursting full of character, and had great gameplay and soundtrack to accompany that.

I've played 'A Hat In Time' for around 20 hours now after getting it 4 or 5 days ago. I think it's safe to say that this game might be my new favourite game. It's exploding with character, the movement flows so well and the gameplay is great.
Sure, there are a few mishaps here and there. But they are few and very far between.

If you enjoyed any platform game from the early 90s/late 00s, I fully recommend 'A Hat In Time'.

35681011.review:
A Hat In Time is a fantastic platformer.  I never thought that any platformer would dethrone Voodoo Vince as my favorite, but after fourteen years it has happened.  A Hat In Time is a wonderfully cute game where no planets are the same.  You can be riding a train for one act, and the next one you are leading a marching band in a parade.  If I had to describe A Hat In Time, I would say it is a combination of Super Mario Sunshine, Mario Galaxy, and Banjo Kazooie.  The game takes what makes those three great and leaves out all that doesn't.  The soundtrack is so wonderful that I felt that I had to go and purchase it so I can listen to it while I play other games.  The upbeat nature of all the characters and music is enough to get anybody hooked.  At the time of writing this review, I only have eight hours and I have beat the story.  I usually consider story length to decide if a game is worth it, but in this case I judged the game's value off of fun factor.  I am currently working on hitting 100 percent, and I am having a fantastic time fooling around in the acts as I do so.

If I had to give this game a score, it would be a 10/10.  I absolutely love platformers, and this game has all the characteristics of a fantastic one.  The soundtrack, the characters, and the comedy all come together wonderfully.  For me, this has absolute potential to be my game of the year.

Edit : I have now gotten 100 percent completion, but not all the achievements.  I'm very excited for the community to start creating things for this game.

35680166.review:
[list]
[*][b] Background Info: [/b]

At the time of this review I've completed the main campaign (26 Time Pieces), meaning I still have 14 missions to experience. I'll update my review if/when I 100% the game.

I played the game using a Steam Controller.

Edit: Review Updated now that i've collected all 40 Time pieces.


[*][b] Gameplay: [/b]

While inspired by various 3D platformers of the past, A Hat in Time first a formost plays like Super Mario Sunshine.
Hat Kid has a comparable moveset to Mario (sans Flood) with a handful of extra tricks up her sleave and several unlockable new moves tied to swapable Hats and Badges.

Hat Kid is pulled towards context important objects (like tightrope or grabable walls) slightly more than Mario.
This means the game's platforming is more forgiving that Super Mario Sunshine, but can also be less responsive.
(But never to the point of becoming an Assasins Creed-esque issue)

The game is intended to be speed-running friendly and encourages sequence breaking (even giving an achievement in one isntance), but punishes players several times for doing so- bypassing certain objectives resulting in invisible walls, broken NPCs and  the like.

Controlling Hat Kid is ultimatly fun; as is sending her through the game's varried levels.
The game contains a hub-world, 4 worlds to explore (with various objectives), and a final boss stage; the quality of which are inconstent but tend to remain atleast "okay" when not "fantastic".


[*][b] Audio and Visuals: [/b]

A Hat in Time's soundtrack is not enough that I would listen to it outside the game, but serves it's purpose to a T: complimenting the varied environments players will explore. Each track nails it's setting perfectly, and never fualters or distracts.

Visuals are more hit or miss. Certain locations, escpecially the first world, are much less apealling when compared to some of the fanstastic environments experience further into the game. While never eyesores, the improvement in the developer's skills as development progressed is apperant.

Voice acting also an issue. Once again in the first world, the voice acting can quickly becoming grating and distracting with its poor quality. I made it one of my first goals in the game to unlock the (unnecessarily dificult to obtain) Unlock that replaces voice acting with Banjo-Kazooie-esque mumbling.
And yet, by the time I could use the Unlock I had descovered that the voice acting improves immensly! By the half way point nearly all voice acting gripes were forgotten, with roles being extremely well done (even featuring youtube tallents like JonTron and YoungTown), and their acompanying dialogue being both smart and humorous.


[*][b] Story: [/b]

A Hat in Time's overarching narrative is probably its largest missstep. Without spoiling any plot, the game awkwardly introduces both the Hat Kid and the game's villian in the first world. A compasionate backstory is attemtped for the villian, but it falls flat- worse, even painting Hat Kid in a slightly sinister light.

For the next 3 worlds absolutely NO advances are made to the main-plot, which is thrown to the background to give lime-light to smaller side stories. (and to the game's credit these side stories are for the most part both funny and well executed).

We don't encounter or even hear word of the main villian again until unlocking the final boss stage. Here an emotional story arc is attempted, but fails since the primary motivations of several characters were either poorly explained or skipped entirely- making it feel like the second act of the game is missing in its entirety...


[*][b]Closing remarks: [/b]

...and in the final cinematic I encountered a gamebreaking bug resulting in a PC crash.
Having to watch the game's final moments on youtube rather than experiencing it myself certainly sours the my final thoughts with the game.

To the developers credit, they have been deploying patches that address the game's various (mostly minor) issues every few days since the game's launch.

The game is also noticibly short, requiring less than 10 hours to complete the campaign- even while taking levels at a slow and exploratory pace. 100%ing the game requires a little over 15 hours. While certainly not an issue in and of it's self, it's worth mentioning when added with the game's price. While AHiT may ensure it doesn't overstay its welcome- it probably could have explored its potential over a few more stages.


Ultimatley I still genuinly recommend A Hat in Time. At it's core its a spiritual successor to Mario Sunshine that kept me extremly entertained during it's brief run. Unlike Yooka-Laylee, a game I feel had more stumbles and pratfalls than even the mediocre platformers of old, A Hat in Time succeeds in reminding players what a good 3D platform game looks like and has me eager to keep playing, regardless of a subpar story.


[/list]

35680124.review:
Hey! A playable demo of Super Mario Odyssey before it comes out! Seems to include a big portion of the game. Few complaints about this demo. First, Mario doesn't really look like Mario. Also, what happened to Cappy? It's just replaced with other hats to cover it up. I was excited for the mechanic of Capturing! Why did they remove it?

Although, I must say I am intrigued by all of the new characters it brings. This demo makes it seem like a completely different aesthetic! Adding a Mafia that are just a bunch of bad cooks? Ingenious! This game also features full voice acting, even for Mario! And most of it seems to give you a general idea on who a character is, which is needed considering the ton of new characters like DJ Grooves and the Snatcher. Not to mention the plethora of cosmetics that Mario can wear. The sound is also a great feature, and it goes the full mile to be great.

All in all, I think this Odyssey demo is definitely what the fans want. It expands greatly upon the Mario Universe, with a new planet in play. This game DOES have a few graphical errors, though. Not what I expected from a triple-a Mario title. but I'll live. Get this 30 dollar demo. You won't regret it.

35679834.review:
My first little "review" on Steam, even though I won't be going into that much detail.

I grew up with 3D platformers on N64 and really still love these kinds of games the most. Nowadays I usually have a hard time getting excited to play any kind of game, but I really really liked Yooka-Laylee, which is also a new nostalgic like 3d platformer. Many people spoke badly of that game and while I can understand the flaws, I really enjoed it.

Anyway, now my good friend told me about this and even gave his second steam code he had for free. Thanks so much again! I will probably support later myself and buy the PS4 version eventually!
So I heard it was also a traditional platformer, but a bit more modern.
And that's just what this is! Very much feels like games in the old days, but more modern when it comes to objectvies and less collectables! Not that I hate collecting things in these games.

So what aspects stand out in this game? One important aspect that will have a lot of influence in the enjoyment of a game like this, the controls! And they are perfect! They just feel natural and you are just in control. Nothing more to add, turned out very good. Even the dreaded camera for games like these is very solid at least! Rarely and problems at all!

Then, the artstyle! Very cute, by the way I really liked the main character, so adorable and with a lot of charm. The colors just pop and...you just feel at home in the worlds. Great atmosphere. The music is very fitting too!

The missions in the game are for the most part very creative and the concepts change all the time! Some have you exlpre mainly, others mix things up a lot by having you confronted with creepy characters that even claim your soul, or a murder mystery! Funny writing too!

The challenges this game offers are enjoyable and very fair, in fact I could say one of the slightly negative aspects is that this game is a bit too easy. Other than some of the bosses, but I really am not good at them, they stress me out and in general I hate bosses in video games, I rarely had any issues. I even went for all achievements which offered some nice challenges!
Also, the game is unfortunately a bit on the short side, a few more worlds would have been nice, but apparently DLC is coming! Same as a Co-Op mode? Can't wait to play this again together with my friend! 

So yeah, amazing game with a lot of charme, I am so glad this was recommended to me, so well here you go, I do the same by sharing my opinion in this review.
Thanks for reading! Please go try out this game!
Rating: 9.5/10
The most fun I had with a game for a long time! Even enjoyed it more than Yooka-Laylee, which I would rate 9/10

35669511.review:
Ha pasado un tiempo desde Yooka-Laylee. Cuando este salió levantó críticas positivas y negativas. Yo pienso que es un juego poco pulido en casi todos sus apartados, y con un diseño un tanto anticuado. Esto último sirvió a muchos para enterrar el género de los plataformas 3D collectathon como un género "de otra época" y de "diseños arcaicos".

Nada de esto es cierto si sabes diseñar tu juego como debes, y lo arcaico era un problema de Yooka-Laylee, no del género en sí. Ahí tenemos a Mario, sosteniendo el género prácticamente él solito.

El Kickstarter de A Hat In Time comenzó en 2013. Ha llovido muchísimo desde entonces. El juego se retrasó en varias ocasiones debido a querer mejorarlo y pulirlo para sacar al mercado un producto digno. Y vaya si lo han hecho...

¿Les ha pasado factura todo este tiempo? No lo sé, tampoco es que hiciera mucho ruido durante su Kickstarter, simplemente, aunque no esté oyendo hablar nada de él, espero que venda muy bien.

Paso a dar mi opinión.

A Hat in Time es un juego que rebosa calidad y personalidad por todos lados. Cada diálogo, cada personaje, cada situación nos sacará siempre una sonrisa y nos invitará a seguir jugando para ver con qué nos encontraremos la próxima vez. La protagonista, sin ir más lejos, a parte de ser jodidamente adorable, tiene muchos puntos de humor, y mucho carisma.

La variedad de situaciones que nos presenta el videojuego a cada misión que realizamos es brillante. Así, encontramos desde una investigación de asesinato en un tren, pasando por una criatura fantasmagórica (mi personaje favorito) que nos obliga a firmar un contrato a cambio de nuestra alma para ir desbloqueando misiones, hasta una infiltración en una mansión encantada... y todo esto sin desprenderse ni un solo momento de su identidad como plataformas. No es que de repente el juego deje de ser un plataformas y se convierta en un juego de infiltración, como ya ha pasado en otras ocasiones. No, nada de eso. La jugabilidad se mezcla de maravilla con las diferentes situaciones que nos presentan.

Cada mundo al que viajamos trata de contarnos una pequeña historia y en muchas ocasiones me ha recordado al storytelling de Paper Mario o Psychonauts. Las interacciones que tiene Hat Kid con los personajes y el mundo y como esta se involucra en sus historias está muy bien llevado y nos ofrece algunos de los mejores villanos que he podido disfrutar en este tipo de videojuegos.

Hablando de villanos... los jefes finales son de lo mejor que he jugado en todo el género. Magníficos todos y cada uno de ellos. Todos explotan al 100% las diferentes habilidades de Hat Kid. Que, por cierto, hablando de sus habilidades... creo sin dudarlo que lo mejor de A Hat in Time es el movimiento.

En este juego tenemos un salto y un doble salto, un "dive jump" (a lo Super Mario Sunshine) y un salto de pared, con la posibilidad de escalarlas un breve periodo de tiempo, pudiendo así agarrarnos a bordes a los que no llegaríamos de otra forma. Lo mejor del control de Hat Kid es poder moverse por el mundo con la velocidad y la libertad que ofrecen estos movimientos. Tremendamente intuitivos y divertidos de utilizar. Me he encontrado en muchas ocasiones ignorando el objetivo principal de la misión para dar vueltas por el mundo encontrando coleccionables, simplemente por el gusto de hacerlo, por lo fácil y divertido que es moverse por el mundo.

Hablando de coleccionables, en este juego tienen todos y cada uno de ellos una o varias funciones y es bastante satisfactorio encontrarlos. Además, aquí no está el típico "premio" por conseguir las típicas 100 monedas de un nivel, las cuales están siempre escondidas en los rincones más ridículos. Aquí los coleccionables "moneda" sirven para guiarte por el nivel (basicamente como en casi todos los plataformas) y para desbloquear nuevas habilidades. Recolectar objetos no es un dolor en este juego y creo que es la primera vez que me planteo conseguir todos los coleccionables de un juego de este tipo, cuando por lo general, conseguirlos todos no merece la pena y muchos son horribles de obtener. No es el caso en este juego. Coleccionar es divertido y útil aquí.

No todo son elogios, tengo 2 quejas. La primera es que es demasiado corto (aunque vienen de camino 2 mundos más, la historia principal ya está acabada). La segunda es el nivel técnico del juego. Si bien la mayor parte del tiempo se ve bien, y cosas como la cámara, los diseños o la banda sonora son sobresalientes, no puedo pasar algunos errores en los modelos y que los gráficos a veces no terminan de convencerme. Aún así son errores puntuales y no me han molestado, precisamente por la calidad general que tiene el videojuego.

En general, desde el momento que lo empecé a jugar, me he hallado francamente sorprendido en todo momento por lo bien diseñado que está el juego. Y podría tirarme aquí escribiendo horas, pero simplemente diré: COMPRADLO. Merece cada maldito euro.

35665587.review:
Hats off to Gears For Breakfast!

Very rarely does a game make me feel like a kid again, but A Hat In Time has done it. There is nothing about this game which I don't find either charming, funny, adorable or just plain fun. It's like a cross between Zelda: The Wind Waker and Super Mario Galaxy, and it is gorgeous in every possible way. Where Yooka-Laylee relied very heavily on nostalgia, AHIT proves that you don't need to flawlessly emulate the classics to make a good new 3D platformer. Be you a classic gamer who loved the old N64 platformers or a new gamer, hands down you will enjoy AHIT.

35665466.review:
To put it simply: A Hat in Time makes Yooka Laylee look like a Newgrounds game.

To be more exact: This game is a masterpiece and without a doubt the best game of 2017. It is one of the rare occurances of a Kickstarter game succeeding. It might even be the best Kickstarted game ever. 

There was never a point in this game where I wasnt compeled or bored. There are things in every act that you didn't see before, or didn't explore a certain way and things will leave you having eureka moments constantly. The controls are to the point and feel amazing with an Xbox One controller. Any time I messed up a jump or missed a ledge, it was my own fault and not the game. When you made a hard jump you felt rewarded and usually were rewarded. The difficulty progressed with you, and the game opened up to multiple acts, allowing you to tackle harder objectives early if you wanted. Each boss took about 2-3 tries for me, mainly due to not paying attention or not knowing the mechanics the first time. The boss battles can be a little long. 

The story is cute and the characters are fun, unique and engaging. The acts all differ and have their own stories, charm and mechanics. Subcon forest is one that I think back to a lot. It's impressive. This game is everything Super Mario Sunshine is and could ever be. I dare say that A Hat in Time could rival Super Mario Odyssey (a game im looking forward to) as the best collectathon platformer this year.

10/10

Pros:
-Amazing fluid controls
-Cute fulfilling story
-Awesome memorable characters
-Replayability out the @$$
-Price:Gameplay value +++++
-Great game changing hats and useful hat pins
-Difficulty is fair
-JonTron voices a penguin

Cons:
-The camera HATES roofs and tight spaces
-A little short, took under 10 hours to get all 40 time pieces
-The Time Rift with the owls that follow you is GARBAGE
-Elvis Bird+Exploding Egg is a bad time

35664934.review:
This game has been on my mind ever since I bought it, so I felt like I need to get everything out about how much I love this game and what needs to be improved. Mild spoilers, although there isn't much to spoil at all.

Also, TLDR; Feels like a Super Mario Sunshine sequel, movement is the best part, music is great, felt like it was too short and there wasn't much to do besides completing the game and getting 100%, questionable level designs, overall solid game but needs a few tweaks + more content (plz give me DLC I will give you all my money). 8/10

The Pros:
- this game is so fucking cute. 'nuff said.
- the music is very well put together. The songs are catchy and well orchastrated and fit the theme of whatever level you are on.
- speedrunning is something I love watching, but I haven't really got myself into it. This game, I would say, has actually peaked my interest in speedrunning because of the amount of options that can help you with a speedrun, such as timers, auto-skip cutscenes, etc.
- the movement is a solid 10/10. So incredibly satisfying and definitely the best part of this game. I could very easily waste a few hours doing parkour around a level on my cute little moped.
- the subtle references to pop culture and other games is an incredibly nice touch. For example, in one instance, you have to collect a few gems in a certain amount of time. If you do, a flight of stairs raises from the ground that is very similar to how it is done in SMS (Super Mario Sunshine). It even had a red X on it! (one that you could spray with FLUDD in SMS). On the same note, I'm pretty sure this game is SMS 2 with how similar it is, which is very nostalgic for me.
- the levels have so much variety and are very thematic. Each level is also extremely different from one another and sticks to that theme throughout.
- lootboxes contain really cool rewards, like appearences and mask variations. Any customisation for such a cute protagonist should be mandatory.
- on the point of lootboxes, it's always refreshing to have a game reasonably cheap and have no microtransactions. I absolutely despise the lootbox systems other games have *cough* Shadow of War *cough* and I feel like if I support games like this (which I feel genuinely care about their consumers and don't try to milk as much money out of them as possible), I am promoting this type of business practice, and I hope more publishers are like this.
- some decisions in the game, which feel minor at first, will come up again in the future. For example, giving the bird detectives your pet's name, in which your pet will be mentioned later on, or drawing on your face and have that be used as your save file picture. They're very minor details, but they are nice details nevertheless.

Unfortunately, I have a few Cons:
- a lot (nearly all of them) of the mechanics/hats in this game were very short lived. You'd use them when you first got them and then used them again once or twice in the same way with hardly any variation on how you use them. I felt like all the hats (except the dweller/fox hat, some very good puzzles with this hat) were not very well utilised and I felt like they should have had more a spotlight. For example, maybe puzzles similar to shrines in Breath of the Wild would've been good.
- this is probably due to personal preference (or maybe I'm just a wimp), but the mansion level was scary for the wrong reasons. I hate jumpscares, and the game adds this intense, loud tune whenever you aggrovate the monster. The tune appears so suddenly and is so loud that I eventually got annoyed whenever I got jumped. Couple it with the questionable AI and bad decisions the monster made (you would expect the monster to do something, and it didn't, and it ended up feeling weird), and the level was by far the worst and was so glad it was over.
- the yarn is pretty much useless to my knowledge, besides 100%ing the game and crafting hats, in which you only need one or a few. The rest are useless.
- I feel the Banjo voice badge should be default. To me, I think the voice acting is bad, but bearable. However, for those who absolutely despise it, I feel like a Banjo style voice acting route would work much better. It is nice to have full voice acting, though.
- the game was very short. 3 story based planets, 1 free-roam/story planet and a finale, plus secret levels. I felt like there should've been so much more. 
- I'm a perfectionist, so I like to finish an area before I move on to the next. I felt like when I completed a level, there were so many more secrets I hadn't discovered yet. However, I only had to do one secret level (purely because I couldn't find it) to 100% the game after the final level. There is only the main story and the secret levels. I don't feel like there's anything else apart from that.
- the game just is easy. The only challenging parts for me were the purple secret levels and the boss battles. The levels felt unchallenging and puzzles are generally obvious. Would've definitely liked more challenging blue secret levels and harder/more complex puzzles
- the characters were forgettable. You'd banter with them for a few seconds at a time and after you'd completed that planet, the only time you'd see them again is at the end of the game. 

Overall, I liked this game alot. I don't usually like ratings, but I'd probably give it a solid 8/10.

35664767.review:
A Hat in Time is one of my favorite games I have played in a long time. You can tell the developers really put a lot of love into this game. Every level is different and always brings something new to the table. It does a fantastic job at keeping things fresh by giving you new abilities and introducing new mechanics at the right time. The gameplay is perfect, the controls feel tight and responsive and for the most part Hat Girl did exactly what I wanted. (I only played with a Xbox One controller) The art design is great and most of all super cute! It reminded me of Costume Quest mixed with a Nintendo game. Speaking of Nintendo games A Hat in Time is clearly inspired by games like Super Mario 64 and Banjo Kazooie which for me is a good thing because I love old school 3d platforms. You will be going back to previous levels frequently to find things you missed or couldn't access becouse you didnt have the right ability yet. The writing is good for the most part but isn't quite as good near the end. The whole ending seems a little rushed. I was able to beat it in about 10 hours and I was taking my time. I was able to 100% it in nearly 13 hours. It is not the most challenging game so if you're looking for a hard 3d platformer this definitely isn't it. It should also be noted that coop should be coming soon. As for performance I had a issue with stuttering until I forced SLI off. After that it ran impressively smooth. It's also nice to see a game explain what the graphics options actually do and there's plenty to tweak.

Pros:
- Gameplay is superb and feels great
- Writing is good for the most part
- Lots of level variety
- Good unlocking pace
- Great soundtrack
- Good performance on my machine
- Super Cute! 
- No microtransactions

Cons:
- Short and left me wanting more
- Very easy
- Seems rushed towards the end

Overall this is one of the best games I have played in a long time and definitely the best current 3d platformer. I just wish there was more of it and that the ending didn't feel so rushed. If you enjoy old 3d platformers I would definitely recommend this! If you don't I would still recommend this because it is an amazing game and you can tell the developers really put a lot of passion into it. If I had to rate this I would give it a 9.5/10! Definitely worth full price!

35663722.review:
I love it. It's the game I wanted Yooka Laylee to be; it's a fun, inventive,  and colorful world  that's also increadibly fun to move around in. The worlds are imaginative not only in design, but in function which is something I've never seen before in a 3rd person platformer. It makes me excited for the DLC worlds and for more than just a new map to walk around in! It's so creative and novel! Not to mention the design of everything is so adorable I can't take my eyes off of them for a second. 

A few gripes, I can't customize controls. My only gripe is that I wish I could switch RMB with Ctrl. I'd rather have right click be dive. It's easier to contort my fingers around. I'd also like the right thumb stick's camera contorl to be better. Attempting to look up ends up zooming me in and I can't move around while pressing Y. Also, on lower graphics settings, Subcon Forest looks really bad. Stumps don't have tops, polygons from the fire spirits' trail things to the paintings stretch across huge parts of the map. And when you turn the settings down, textures have a tendency to get corrupted.

I know my critical paragraph was a little longer than the praise, but the fact that I'm a grown man who has a job and responsibilities and I still managed to already 100% the time pieces and start a new file is a sign that I am truely in love and only want the game to be better. Thanks so much for making something so great!
