35662999.review:
[quote][b]A Hat in Time[/b] is absolutely adorable, fiendishly funny, and completely charming. It's not without a few missteps, but none of those are enough to stop it from being one of my favorite games of the last few years.

[b]★★★★★, Great Game[/b][/quote]

[b]A Hat in Time[/b] is a wonderful 3D platformer, but I wouldn't call it a "collect-a-thon" as others seem apt to because there isn't [i]that[/i] much to collect. It is basically a love-letter to Gamecube-era Nintendo; the game structure is like Mario 64/Sunshine and the art style is very Windwaker.

[h1]Story / Theme:[/h1]

The overall story of A Hat in Time is simple: Hat Girl lost all her magical hourglass Time Pieces and she needs to explore and do missions to get them back. Getting them back opens up new worlds to do more missions, and eventually you fight the final boss. It's short, sweet, and (importantly) gets you into the action really fast. The only qualm I have with the overarching story is that it introduces the big villain early in a largely linear selection of missions, and forgets about them entirely until you're ready to fight them in the end.

Individual Chapter / Act (World / Level) themes are an incredibly strong point in this game. Each Chapter is unique and imaginative so you never know what's around the next corner. Starting in a very Mario Sunshine-esque island town, you move to another chapter where you complete meta goals to settle a dispute between two bird producers, anoter is a horror romp complete with a straight horror-game level, to a large sandbox level that almost completely abandons the Chapter / Act structure of the rest of the game. Each of these chapters is filled with top-notch humor that had me laughing out loud on many, many occasions as well. I highly recommend checking every interactable object you can.

Overall, the story, world, and humor are probably the game's strongest assets but the gameplay's no slouch either.

[h1]Gameplay:[/h1]

A Hat in Time is a shockingly solid platformer. Hat Girl has all sorts of tricks like running up walls, double jumps, dashes, and dives and it is a treat to control her. Extra care is put into a lot of little things, too: Hat Girl has a small hop when she lands from a jump, giving her a nice bouncy weight, and she's got a dedicated "make a :steammocking: face" and can blow kisses, to boot. 

Control-wise I only have a few wishes that, while they don't break the great feeling, would've still been nice. I wish she at least had an animation for chaining jumps on the ground, they don't need to be a Mario-style triple jump or anything, but connecting jumps like that is always great. Otherwise, I don't really see a reason sliding to a stop in a dive means you cannot move until you hop out of it, it'd be nice if input on the stick caused her to auto-hop out of it. Neither of these things are deal-breakers and are very nitpicky, but I think they'd help more than they'd hurt.

The "Hat" part of A Hat in Time comes in the Hat system where, throughout the game, Hat Girl collects new hats that give her new powers while wearing [b]that[/b] hat like simple sprinting, turning into a block of ice, and momentarily slowing down time. This is an incredibly cute theme, but breaks the breakneck pacing of the gameplay with the constant need to switch between them. In addition, some of the hats are so specific in their use that oftentimes the game needs to put in that hat's specific obstacle just to remind you that you have it. The Ice Hat is the chief offender here, where its obstacle is just a springboard that will launch Hat Girl a place she could otherwise not reach, no platforming involved, just a check to make sure you didn't somehow lose that hat.

Badges are another thing Hat Girl collects that give her varying passive powers, up to three different slots. These powers range from the entirely-non-optional hookshot that lets you grapple from grapple points, to other useful abilities like not colliding with and being knocked back by platforms if you jump-dive into them, to a magnet that attracts nearby pickups. This system suffers from a few issues similar to the hat system where, because you can change them anytime you want, it occasionally slows down gameplay just to have to put on one badge for a specific type of obstacle and then change back when you complete it. It's incredibly irritating that the grapple ability is a badge you basically have to always have equipped as well, if only because changing back and forth between it and another badge whenever you see a grapple point is so tedious.

[h1]Technical:[/h1]

A Hat in Time is, unsurprisingly, not without bugs. Most of these are small and handled well-enough in game. For example, if the engine doesn't ever know exactly what's happening after a jump, it simply returns Hat Girl to where she started it. This is definitely preferable to getting stuck, falling out of bounds, or crashing and I commend the simple way it was handled.

Other bugs are a little less graceful and there's one cannon in particular that can never seem to shoot me facing the right direction to then grapple from the intended grapple hook. It takes a bit of finnagling to try and get Hat Girl turned around so it works.

Otherwise, the game ran at a smooth 1080p60 with no noticeable hitches. I hear there are strange issues at ~144Hz when using a controller, but I am unable to confirm nor deny that as I only play at 60.

[h1]Conclusion:[/h1]

A Hat in Time is one of those games that had me questioning my cliched 5 star rating system. It's incredibly fun and I really enjoyed every minute of playing it, but it's definitely neither perfect or a genre redefining piece of innovation. In the end, though, I still consider it a great game, making it 5/5 Stars. If it where a 1-10 rating, however, it'd probably be a high 8 to 9.

Either way, I fully recommend A Hat in Time to anyone, it is truly a great game. Especially give it a look if you like 3D platformers, or things that are way too cute for this world.

35660796.review: I love this game. Feels very similar to Super Mario Sunshine, which is one of my favorite 3D games of all time. Bright colors, fun environments, and great humor in the dialogue. A Hat in Time has it all and you can just feel the love that the devs have for this game. Highly recommend!

35660793.review:
A Hat in Time is a 3D Platformer, developed by Gears for Breakfast, based on the old areas of Super Mario 64, Sunshine, and alike. Built in the Unreal Engine 3, you take control of the cute as heck Hat Kid, which got all of her Time Pieces lost from an incident when crossing a planet. The Mafia has broken a window and created a vacuum, which sprayed all 40 Time Pieces over the planet. She needs all to get home. This is already a good explanation on why you need Time Pieces, since they belong to you. 

You will find different yarn to make new hats which give new abilities to play with. A ground pound with the ice hat, a sprint hat, time slow down... You get the idea. A simple, yet efficient mechanic. 

The game covers all around 5 chapters, with plenty to explore and goodies for the progress of the game. I don't want to say too much about what they are all about, because... 

Pros: 
This game is incredibly charming and just bursting out with character. From the very first start you open up this software, you get bombarded with an explosion, and a whole showcase on what you can expect from the world. This sets the mark for the game already quite high without making a button press and tells you, this is a hell of a ride! When you see Hat Kid the first time, the opening animation already was adorable. This just makes you care for these things, and this image gets strong uphold for the entire adventure. 

A Platformer that should work need tight controls that should work and oh boy, do they work. Tight controls with homing attacks, grapple hooks, dashing and even more. It's so well done and I very rarely got the feeling that one jump was not manage-able or was unfair. Gears for Breakfast really understood what they were doing. Level Design is super creative. In the first chapter there are so many possibilities to explore. Everything is tied together and let's you have a good sense of the game mechanics. It's just perfect. All abilities get very well used, for the exception maybe of the Time Hat which slows time down and you only need pretty much for one Act. 

This game in general just gets me super excited and happy throughout the entire experience. It has so many unique ideas and doesn't shy away from changing a setting completely. It's sometimes incredibly disturbing, referencing murder, torture, and all alike. The voice acting is just giving more charm than ever to it and I love it. 

Cons:
A game comes without it's cons. It's pretty buggy from what I could gather. Sometimes grappling didn't work as intended, climbing up aswell, tiny animation errors, clipping through some objects. You will definitely notice them, but they are so tiny and minor it won't break the the flow at all. 

This is more of a personal taste, but I would have wished if we were able to complete one Chapter fully and then move on to the next. While I can understand the vision of the developers, I thought it was kind of annoying having to start the next first. 

A cute as heck platformer, with incredible charm and love put in it. 
89/100

35660696.review: I love this game. Seriously, from the great soundtrack to the smooth controls, it feels good to actually play a real platformer for once. The characters are really cute or funny in most cases, and while I wish the game was longer, for the price you pay, you get your money's worth. It's a fantastic platformer that feels great to play, and honestly will bring a smile to your face.

35660603.review:
This game is fantastic. I can't give it justice in a review, but playing the game feels so smooth and fluid, you're meant to keep moving and jumping and platforming in one smooth motion, and every area in the game is packed with things to explore with these mechanics. Some games try to blend gameplay and visual direction, where movement can become sluggish to make way for proper momentum or animation- This game, it's alll about the gameplay. Sure, Hat Kid might move a little stiff or janky, but she's simply an avatar for you to move around and have fun with, and it excels at that.

The music is phenominal, and sets the tone for the entire game. There isn't one song even close to "average". The worlds are so pleasing to the eye, from the jam-packed Mafia Town island, to the dark and sinister woods of Subcon. Each world is uniquely different, and the cast is full of interesting and humorously dark characters.

Let's also be frank. The game isn't made by some giant studio with professionals and a giant budget. The animations aren't perfect, there's clipping, there's bugs- But nothing game breaking from what I've seen. For what they have to work with, Gears for Breakfast made a very polished game that's filled to the brim with content. And any small visual glitches add to the charm, I feel. Gears for Breakfast are very interactive and open with players, having a public discord where they interact with their fans, and are very active with supporting people with any issues they may have.

There are a few issues I had with the game, a lot of people point out the awkwardness of Hat Kid's model face, and the faces in Mafia Town in general, and I can agree- But don't let that hinder your enjoyment (you rarely see human faces after the first Chapter anyway). The worst part for me was probably the tightrope platforming found in a few stages, otherwise the game excels at platforming. Voice acting is a mixed bag, but honestly I was pretty impressed overall, and a lot if not all of the major characters have great performances. Some minor characters do sound awkward though- Not BAD, but definitely an odd choice for their character design. But hey, you could even turn voices off if you wanted, or set them to a mumble with an unlockable joke badge.

I managed to hundred percent the game in just shy of 24 hours, having prior experience with the Alpha and Beta (for a total of 35.5 hours as of this review). It's the kind of game you can easily go back to, with no objective, and just wander around and explore all the details the world has to offer. I can't stress enough that the game is an exploration game that feels fantastic mechanically, visually, and audibly to explore. A 3D equivalent to a Metroidvania, almost. It has a lot of influences from the GameCube era, it gives people a very N64 feel in terms of how the worlds are laid out and the focus on gameplay, and it has a timeless feel. Don't let the N64-comparisons overshadow it though- It definitely stands on it's own for being very original.

Most importantly, this game is just fun. It's the most fun I've had with a video game in years. Thank you, Gears for Breakfast.

A Hat in Time has me hooked like few games before. I spend all day thinking about the next time I'll be able to play. I'm consistently surprised by the mission structures and have had a lot of time. 35659951.review:
Having just completed this game, I can honestly say that it is probably my favorite game of this year. It's really nostalgic, bringing to mind old action/platformer/collect-a-thon games like Banjo-Kazooie or Spyro. Even more so, this game is fun. It's far too rare these days to find games designed purely for fun. I spent time just exploring all of the worlds because there were so many ways to get around that it was consistently enjoyable. 

Granted, I did notice a few flaws. For starters, the camera is really intrusive at times. It either zooms too far into the character that you cannot be aware of hazards, or it gets stuck on walls and jolts which makes you lose your sense of direction. This makes platforming incredibly difficult when it occurs, but thankfully that isn't too often. Speaking of platforming, there was one other issue I noticed whilst platforming. This may just be me, as I haven't read any other reviews mentioning it. There were instances when I had trouble performing jumps because the camera wasn't really displaying any sense of depth. I would think I was dead-centered on a platform and realize far too late that I had drastically over-shot it. I checked this on multiple graphics settings, and didn't really notice any change. Again, this may have just been me. 
One other minor grievance is that the game is a little short. If you just play through the chapters without getting any bonuses save for the hats, this game could feasibly be finished in as little as 5 hours, perhaps less. Granted, what is here is great. I just wish there were a little more.

That all being said, I absolutely adore this game. No matter what I was doing while playing, I was having fun. 
... Except for that owl band... fuck the owl band...

35656776.review:
중절모를 쓴 시간 속 소녀가 전해준 3D 플랫포머의 부활.
 
우주선을 몰고 우주를 순항하는 귀여운 소녀 모자 꼬마가 주인공으로 등장하는 게임이며, 모종의 사고로 인해 잃어버린 모래시계들을 다섯 구역을 돌아다니며 한 개씩 찾으러 다녀야 한다. 각 챕터의 액트마다 특정한 미션이 주어지며, 특정 액트를 제외하면 주어진 스테이지를 자유롭게 돌아다니는 것이 가능하다. 이는 3D로 나온 슈퍼마리오 시리즈와 유사한 방식이며, 전반적으로는 슈퍼마리오 64와 썬샤인을 적절히 섞은 느낌이다.
 
총 5개의 챕터가 준비되있으며, 각 챕터마다 개성이 뚜렷해 새로운 챕터에 돌입할 때마다 새로운 느낌을 받게된다. (이를테면 영화 촬영장을 배경으로 한 2챕터는 퀘스트를 위주로 진행되는 방식인가 하면, 넓은 하늘 고원을 배경으로 한 4챕터는 아예 오픈월드 게임 같은 엄청난 크기의 스테이지를 선보인다.) 또한 단순히 수집과 보스전만 준비되있는 것이 아니라, 각 챕터의 액트별로 다양한 컨셉을 선보이기도 한다. 이것들 이외에 각 챕터마다 타임 리프트라는 별도의 스테이지까지 꼼꼼하게 준비되어 있다. 여러모로 스테이지 디자인에 상당히 공을 들인 모습이다.
 
기본적인 게임의 목적이 흩어진 모래시계를 모아 우주선을 고치는 것인 만큼 기본적인 게임플레이는 모래시계와 털실, 유물 모으기가 위주가 된다. 그래도 모래시계의 경우 확실한 미션과 퀘스트 그리고 적절한 난이도의 보스전을 통한 보상의 방식으로 주어지고, 털실이나 유물 역시 이후의 진행과 추가 요소를 위해 활용된다. 수집요소가 중심이 되긴 하지만, 너무 강압적인 방식은 아닌 것이다. 덕분에 게임을 흥미롭게, 그리고 지속적으로 즐길 수 있게 된다. 유카-레일리가 수집에 지나치게 집착했다가 게임의 균형을 완전히 말아먹은 것과는 대조되는 부분이다.
 
게임의 다른 요소들도 매우 훌륭하다. 닌텐도 64 내지는 게임큐브가 떠오르는 그래픽은 어딘가 익숙하면서도 정겨움이 느껴진다. 음악 역시 매우 수준급. (특히 챕터2의 기차 액트 곡인 Trainwreck의 리믹스 곡은 역대급!) 스토리는 살짝 유치한 감이 있고 익숙하게 느껴지긴 해도 너무 부담스럽게 다가오진 않는다. 게임패드 기준으로 게임의 인터페이스도 상당히 깔끔하며 조작 역시 손에 착착 감긴다고 할 수 있을 정도로 잘 갖춰져 있다. 모든 요소들이 부족함 없이 잘 갖춰져 있는, 명작의 자격을 갖춘 게임인 것이다!

몇 안 되는 단점을 꼽아보자면, 간혹 카메라 시점이 조금 이상하게 잡히고 줄 같은 거 탈 때 착지가 잘 안 되고 바닥으로 추락할 때가 있다. (다만 이건 TPS 계열 게임들이라면 어쩔 수 없는 숙명같은 부분이라 햇 인 타임만의 단점이라고 하기엔 조금 그렇다.) 플레이타임도 살짝 짧은 감이 없잖아 있긴 한데, 딱 챕터 하나만 더 있었으면 플레이타임으로도 부족함이 없었을 것 같다.
 
유카-레일리를 기점으로 3D 플랫포머라는 장르가 힘을 못 쓰는 타이밍에 나와준 너무나 훌륭한 3D 플랫포머 게임. 개인적으로 2017년 GOTY를 하나 고르라고 한다면 주저없이 이 게임을 선택하고 싶다.

http://blog.naver.com/kitpage/221119890717

35653912.review:
Play this game!  Its not perfect, but its ridiculously fun.  I've been itching for a proper 3d platformer for a while, and this is right up there with my favorite ever.  Its absolutely adorable and one of the most cheerful games I've ever played.  There are 40 total time pieces to collect(Think Mario stars) spread across 4.5 worlds.  That's 81 less than Mario 64, so this isn't going to be as long a game.  If you don't go for 100% (in-game, not achievements) then you can get out much sooner.  I was having so much fun I went for everything.  I'd say my playtime is at the upper-end of what you could expect, because I tooled around with the camera and just explored a bunch.

The level design is spectacular, with a ton of variety.  The first and third world feel the most like your classic Mario/Banjo game, while the second plays more like a series of challenges and the fourth is more like an open-world game.  Likewise, the control feels just right.  They've opted for a smaller number of normal moves, pretty much only a double jump, lungs, and wall jumps/slides, but they combine in interesting ways.  Example: You get an extra jump after a lunge.  Also, if you jump up a half-second or so after landing in a slide from a lunge, you get a speed boost.

Outside of the core move set, you have hats which do different things.  Most aren't that novel outside presentation, but they are put to good use.  There's also badges, which further mix up gameplay.  I found myself using the grappling hook one with a treasure hunting map and one that kept me from taking damage from falls.

This game also features reasonable to good voice acting in a lot of roles.  If you don't like that, you can muffle them with a badge.

You really should play this game.  There's a ton of content in it, and its all extremely unique.  The  game camera isn't perfect, but its a major step up from the games of yore.  The platforming is tighter too, and I actually felt like I had good control over my character.  If you're looking for a cheerful game about an adorable alien becoming a movie star and kicking mafia off ledge, please buy this game.

35653182.review:
Played this game blind on launch to 100% completion. Heres some bullet points because I could gush for hours about what I just witnessed.

The Surprising:
-Control is fluid and allows for a lot of variability for completing objectives. Very similar to Mario 64 and Sunshine.
-All of the level missions feel like completely unique tasks, rather than 'do platforming challenge and recieve reward'
-Every single mission has its own beautiful title card and some missions even change the whole level on some way.
-The bosses are surprisingly high energy compared to the usual 3d platformer. Makes the most of Hat Kid's movement kit.
-Camera is very good for a 3d platformer and rarely gets in the way. Has various quality of life settings for the camera too.
-Soundtrack is baller and changes dynamically like banjo kazooie
-A lot of graphical settings to fine tune the game to run even on toasters.
-My horrible direct input gamepad worked immediately with it, though that might be because of steam big picture. Still cool.
-Ability hats can be changed on the fly (even mid-platforming) and all stay useful through the whole game.
-A lot of TECHNOLOGY. Hat Kid wears a raincoat when its raining, she blows raspberries at close by enemies, she lays belly down on the floor after landing from a dive, she kicks cans when you walk over them.
-Low/medium difficulty, but with a very very very high skill ceiling. Custom workshop levels will be insane.
-Tricks like jumping right as you land from a dive for a speed boost and chaining jumps into wall climbing and jumping into dives are treated as something the player learns naturally through playing rather than something that requires a tutorial to teach.
-Loads of secret areas and things to find in each level.
-Dangerously cute and charming. Hat Kid and the various NPCs you meet are oozing with character.

The Disappointing:
-Maybe one or two of the bosses use the same or very similar attacks to other bosses.
-Visually noisy at times. It doesn't really hurt knowing what you can and cant jump on, however.
-Too Shoooooort. 40 hourglasses aren't nearly enough, even if the levels are very big.
-Yarn becomes useless after getting all of the hats. I'm sitting on 20 extra balls of yarn at end game and still finding more.
-Would be nice to keep the mission specific cosmetic hats as a reward for fully clearing areas
-The last two worlds are veeeery large and hard to keep track of progress in. A map item might help.
-Rift tokens and yarn balls aren't trackable, making it a little sad for completionists.
-Not many badges to play with and one is absolutely required to have on at all times.
-The inventory is largely unused
-There is a weapon slot but only one weapon in the game (Two, if you count when you're holding a key)
-A lot of content from alpha footage is missing. Understandable that the developers would want to put out something that feels like a complete package rather than an incomplete forever early access type thing but it would be very cool to see these things return as official dlc or free updates.

Considering the dev team listens quite closely to their fanbase, I wouldn't be surprised if some of these things were fixed or added to in the not too distant future. Its obvious to me that A Hat in Time is a passion project with a lot of heart poured into it and I wish I backed it when the kickstarter was running. Would absolutely recommend for fans and veterans of the genre.

35650136.review:
I've played a lot of 3D platformers growning up (Sly Cooper, Psyconauts, Mario, Sonic, ect). I love the genre and when I saw A Hat in Time I knew I was gonna love it. Unlike Yooka Laylee, this game adops features from almost every popular 3D platformer. And it pulls it off magnificently.

The story is what you'd expect from a 3D Platformer, plain and simple. You play as a girl named Hat Girl who is trying to get home but when she passes over a planet, a Mafia man stops her and causes all her fuel (time pieces) to fly out and it's your job to get them back. 

The gameplay is extremely fun. Hat girl is fun to control and extremely responsive. She can do the dive from Super Mario Sunshine which is very fun to do. Throughout the game you can collect hats with different abilities that help you with certain platforming challenges. You can collect tokens to spin a wheel to get items to customize Hat Girl. It can be from music remixes to color palette swaps to different hat variations. 

The music is absolutely amazing. It's so catchy you'll find yourself humming the tune of some of them. Every track in this game is phenomenal and I can't stop listening to it.

Overall this game is a must buy if you like 3D platformers. I highly recommend you buy this and show the devs some love. :)

This game is easily my Game of 2017. It's a fun casual Playformer with the niche ability to be a speed running game, the speed running is important as it's implying that there are shortcuts that shave off seconds at a time and learning how to control the great Hat Girl can leave you bouncing around the level's like your playing Just Cause or Kingdom Hearts DDD.

Where do I even begin with this game. It is so freaking charming and fun. 

No level ever seems the same as the previous one. In one world you go from collecting paintings through fighting a possessed toilet through hiding in a haunted mansion to delivering mail for the devil. The diversity makes the whole experience enjoyable from start to finish.

The game is filled with so many details and stuff to collect, but none of it feels like a chore. Everything you get is useful for something and collecting the main Time pieces feels satisfying. It's never the case of stuff being overly hidden just so you have to look through every nook and cranny just to find your 100 %. Collecting all the Time pieces always provides a different challenge.

The soundtrack is a stroke of genius, diverse, a pleasure to listen to. Makes me regret not buying it in the bundle. 

I was quite hesitant to put 30 bucks into this game, but the 11 hours it took me to finish it were 11 hours of uninterrupted fun. I can hardly remember a game where I felt like it didn't have some weak parts, but this one is just so polished, the passion and dedication of the team at Gears for Breakfast can be felt through the entire game.

I can hardly wait for the DLC!

35646572.review:
Ein wundervoller 3D Platformer / Collectathon und ein Liebesbrief an insbesondere die Platformergrößen aus Zeiten des N64 und GameCubes. 

https://youtu.be/QOEzDgrlgLk

Das Spiel bietet sowohl Free Roaming Levels mit unzähligen versteckten Geheimnissen, als auch lineare Level mit ausgesuchten Challenges für das ein oder andere Collectable. Man hat einen Dash, mit dem man einen Hechstsprung a la Mario machen kann, man sammelt verschiedenste Hüte mit denen man neue Fähigkeiten bekommt, ähnlich Banjo Kazooie und kann sogar Erinnerungen sammeln wie in Psychonauts. 
Dazu kommt eine gehörige Portion Charme, sowohl in den Charakteren, wie auch im Level Design und auch in den vielen kleinen Details, wie wenn Hat Kid vor Schmerz auf und ab springt, wenn man gegen eine Harte Oberfläche schlägt oder bei Regen ihr normales Outfit durch einen Regenmantel austauscht.
Dabei fühlt sich das ganze Spiel durchgehend gut an. Man hat eine befriedigende Grundgeschwindigkeit, und kann sich aber durch waghalsige Sprünge, Dashs und Wandsprünge schneller durch die Level bewegen und Abkürzungen finden, und dies alles läuft vollkommen intuitiv ab. Selbst Schleichmissionen behalten diesen Flow und diese Geschwindigkeit.

Natürlich ist nicht alles Perfekt. Manchmal teilt das Spiel nicht optimal mit, was sich gerade abspielt und die Steuerung ist etwas "floaty", was an vielen Stellen hilfreich ist, gerade aber bei genaueren Sprüngen das Manöver etwas erschwert. Dazu kommt, dass man keinen Schatten zu haben scheint, weswegen man nicht wirklich einschätzen kann, wo Hat Kid landen wird, was aber für mich nicht zu häufig ein Problem darstellte.

Alles in Allem kann ich sagen, dass Hat in Time ein witziges und gutes, vielleicht sogar großartiges Spiel ist, mit ein paar Makeln.... anders als soetwas wie Yooka Laylee, was auf den ersten Blick toll aussah und sich als eher durchschnittlich bis frustrierend und uninspiriert herausstellte.

35645896.review:
Hot damn. Admittedly I haven't finished the game yet [spoiler] too busy tryharding to go through with a fine toothed comb to get all the rifts [/spoiler] but I'm an impatient bastard and what I have played so far is well worth the recommendation.

Gameplay is refined, controls are fine tuned, and I truly appreciate the hat system that was implemented. You can switch from several hats you stitch from yarn pickups, each with their own special abilities. While the abilities aren't jaw-dropping unique, their presentation is, and each one has their use (though honestly, if you're like me, you'll find yourself with Sprint the vast majority of the time). There's also 'skins' for each hat you get through a slot machine (no microtransactions, just in gameplay) as well as remixes of the music and colors. Adds a bit more character to the game, and its fun.

Complementing these abilities and hats are badges sold by a mysterious vendor. These are very varied, from badges that give you a 'hookshot' to sling around, to giving you a scooter, to making everyone 'mumble' during their dialogue (in the same vein as Banjo) to even giving you a 1-hit-death challenge. They're very fun to play with, and definitely do spruce up the game.

But above all in the gameplay is the [b] variety [/b]. Holy fuck, the variety. You are virtually never doing the same thing. Granted, all of the stages revolve around platforming, but the devs [b] really [/b] gave it their all into you never being bored, and you never are. A murder mystery? A parade? A stealth/horror mission that actually makes me shit my pants a bit because I'm that much a puss? All are in there, and each one is really enjoyable. The game does such a swell job at keeping varied, but don't worry, there's still some free roam in there too. Debatably the best looking area in the game is completely free roam, and even then it's large and is varied enough in and of itself. It hits all its marks, and does so with a straight As.

Not only is this game an excellent throwback to collectathons and platformers of yore (SM Sunshine, SM Galaxy, and Banjo in particular) in terms of the flawless controls and platforming in general, but it has the atmosphere to boot. Excellent music to each stage and level, and the soundtrack in its entirety is swell and nostalgic of previously mentioned upbeat platformer/collectathons. Along with games like Hotline Miami, Redout, and Undertale this has to be one of my favorite soundtracks in a game to date.

Aesthetically it keeps a beautifully styled, colorful world on each of its areas, and all of them are chock full of stuff to see and collect. Atmosphere on each world, and even parts of them, are unique and blissfully pretty to look at. The world doesn't feel empty in the slightest, as there's a multitude of secrets and jokes to find, as well as bonus worlds that are very reminiscent of Super Mario Sunshine's bonus levels. The jokes in this game, atleast for me, really land their mark. I really enjoy the wit and comedy of this game. [spoiler] One such example, as I'm sure you've seen on the Community Hub, is the drawings of the Protagonist, that actually stick with your save file in a certain level. Another would be playing pattycake with a mafia member only to be socked in the face for it. [/spoiler] I'm no comedian, but for whatever reason this game really tickles my funnybone.

Lastly I'd like to talk about the characters. They are [b] memorable [/b]. Bosses and side characters, while many are tropes youve seen before, are very memorable and loveable. Especially the Snatcher, who gives such a hilarious performance I can't stand but to not love him. Certainly the fully voice acted dialogue is a huge part of that, and it really helps the characters shine. The voice acting is very well done, which is why I personally would abstain from the previously mentioned 'mumble' badge. The game is drenched in the witty dialogue and the voices only help to add to it.

So yeah, my one flaw I could even begin to fathom mentioning is that it's probably a bit on the shorter side, but it is still well worth 30. This game is a blast to play and I hope it gets the attention it deserves. There's so much heart and charm put into this thing it'd be a shame to not buy it if you're even the slightest fan of 3D platformers or collectathons. Good humor, amazing variety, and a beautiful, nostalgic presentation.

tl;dr

Buy this thing.

35645559.review:
Finally the day has come!

I've been following this game for a few years now, played through the Beta and enjoyed it quite a bit. When I heard it was finally coming out a was gleefully hoping for my pre-order key to be ready to use.  I'm glad I waited so long for this game to be done. I think Gears for Breakfast certainly did a fantastic job creating their first game. 

First the cons: 

-This game isn't perfect, there are some technical aspects that aren't 100% (lucky they're very small details). But the charm, polish and the amount of love that went into this game is more than obvious. 
-The game is short (But the Gears for Breakfast announced there will be FREE DLC to expand the game. Can you believe that?!)
-There is no more mumble option in the menu, it's now a badge. (I know it's minor but it takes up a slot for something that was an important feature).

Now the pros:

-The game is SOLID. The movement works, no part of the game is broken, it's very responsive. Something I can't say from the recent big budget games I've played. Every time I've missed a platform or failed to get to an area, it was my OWN fault, unlike other games I've played where I clip through the platform.
-It's quirky, charming, funny, adorable and most of all FUN.
-Somewhat challenging but forgiving.
-The boss fights actually require skill and everything you learned from the game to beat them.
-Tries to follow the convention of platformers but doesn't copy the problems platformer usually have (like tricky camera controls).
-Good camera controls.
-They actually try to form their own identity than trying to be a carbon copy of another game.
-The game rewards exploration, creative thinking and you can always go back once you get new upgrades.

Easily the best 3D platformer in recent years. I like this game a lot.

Pros:
+ The most charming game this year, they did a great job with both characters and story.
+ The platforming is spot on. The player is allways in full control and wizzing around the levels is super satisfying.

35641544.review:
TLDR this game outshines Mario Sunshine at its own game (see what I did there?)

I've played a handful of Indie 3D Kickstarter platformers but this one is hands-down the best. Yooka Laylee stole the spotlight with regard to that market but here comes A Hat in Time to show us all how it's done. This game is a delight from start to finish and polished to a perfect sheen. This is really astonishing given this game raised about a tenth of the money that Yooka Laylee did.

I've seen the game labelled as a "Collect-a-thon" game but I don't think that's quite accurate so don't get scared off if you're not a fan of those games. I think a better comparison would be the more evolved platformers we got during the Gamecube/PS2 days like the Jak Trilogy, Sly Cooper, and Mario Sunshine more than anything else. I've never felt the 3D Mario titles (64, Sunshine, Galaxy) were true collect-a-thons, as they emphasized missions rather than collecting trinkets and a Hat in Time follows suit with this. Each star (they're hourglasses in this one...) has a lot of story packed in and most of them wildly change the nature of the level. 

Like in the Mario games, you have a couple different missions you can pick from that will task you with a fun challenge in the level. Most of it is platforming but there's a ton of variety as well: stealth missions, surprisingly good boss fights, a detective mission, etc. This game achieves better variety than Mario Sunshine with only half the levels! Each and every star feels worthwhile here and the game never asks you to scour a level looking for every last shiny object. There are other collectibles but most of them serve as currency to buy upgrades. There are also a couple abilities you acquire during certain missions so there's some "come back later when you get this power-up" but it's never too bad. The game also yoinks Mario Sunshine's secret stars and actually does them far better than Sunshine (that music, OMG!). 

If I had a complaint, it would be that I wish the game encouraged exploration more. I wrongfully assumed the game would be a collect-a-thon based on the previews that showed the very open Mafia town level. Though I quickly grew to like the more mission-based approach, I still wished the game had encouraged me to explore these beautiful worlds more. Aside from locking you into the mission you select, the second level has almost no exploration with 3 disconnected linear maps. The 3rd and 4th levels allow you to explore and do things out of order but it's still fairly limited. The 4th proudly touts itself as a "free-roam" level but I found that aspect underwhelming. You start at the center of the level and just choose one of four paths that quickly become linear platforming levels. That, to me, is not free-roam. Thankfully, the secret stars pick up the slack quite a bit with giving the game some more exploration.

Aside from that, I really have no complaints with this game, it is polished to a sheen. The visuals are always slick and stylish, I encountered no bugs at all, the game controls like a dream and has more depth than I thought, and even the camera works really well. It's just a delight from start to finish, and I relished every single star. If you love platformers, and even if you hate collect-a-thons, you should absolutely check this out.

35638372.review:
I'll go into this review by category first, then personal thoughts. 
Gameplay: difficult to convey on my end, as I went keyboard and mouse the whole way (still not computer savvy enough to know how to set up a controller), which is decidely not ideal, as maneuvering in the air is really stiff without a control stick, among other things. That said, was pleasantly surprised at how creative and challenging the game was overall, as while some sections would undoubtedly be pretty easy with said controller, there are things like diving under a glass wall and jumping immediately upon getting under it, or you fall. How a 3D game managed to accurately convey the type of jump normally seen in a Mega Man game, I don't know, but kudos. 
Music: varied and always fitting of the settings, from the chill Mafia Town to the epic *spoiler final level*, but special mention goes to boss music, which leads into: 
Bosses: Honestly my favorite aspect of the game, there is all of one boss that could be considered average, that being the first against some mooks and an elite mook throwing barrels. Likely intentional, as it is the first boss. Every single subsequent boss is honestly the best selection I have ever seen in a "collectathon" platformer, each with something unique to them, and amazing music that really captures the nature of the fight, particularly the fever-pitch MIDI number used in the super frantic final boss fight. 
Graphics: cute, cel-shaded look ensures this game's appearance won't likely age anytime soon, and as a special note really emphasizes the stark contrast the absolutely terrifying manor mission has with the rest of the game. Adorable, cartoony protagonist alone with a psychotist demon-ghost...thing... in a less-cartoony-than-normal location, complete with "music" that won't let you calm down. Props for that one, guys. 
Personal thoughts: I notice people attempting to compare this game and Yooka-Laylee quite a bit lately. Honestly, having played and finished both, I don't see a lot of similarities between the two. YL was trying to continue the Banjo-Kazooie legacy, and only really did that. Whether that's good or bad is up to you. A Hat in Time, on the other hand, has far more in common with Super Mario Sunshine, while having Wind Waker-esque cel-shading and movement options reminiscent of Psychonauts, and still managed to develop an identity separate from its inspirations. Honestly, I feel if you liked these games, you'll love this one. I know I did (and am kinda sad it had to end, wouldn't mind seeing further adventures with Hat Kid somewhere down the line, DLC notwithstanding.)

10/27/2017 Update: figured out how to set up an XBox 360 controller. As expected, controls WAY better than Keyboard and Mouse.

35637800.review:
FOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOL BUY THE GAME NOW.

A Hat in Time is a really good game that's worth every dime of its $30 price tag but it has some flaws that needs to be work on. 

-For instance the game only has 4 worlds + 1 stage. This makes the game very short, a good ride that ends up with you wanting more.
-A lot of stages have great ideas to them and how you can use your hats to complete the level but most of the good ideas aren't used throughout the game and are only on little bits.
-The enemy variety is very poor and I can see it isn't because of lack of ideas, they have everything they want and they've proven it. Unfortunately, the game falls short on this.
-Towards the end of the act 3, right on the final seconds of the boss, the game shows a laziness it didn't show on all of the other stages. Almost if they decided to cut short the game from there on out. The chapter 4 is underwhelming and easily one of the worst chapters on the game and then they give you the chapter 5 which is actually only one level so I don't count it as a world.
-The game doesn't reward or at least it doesn't have enough incentive for you to explore the world. I did it so it's why I've played 53hours of it and I can say the game doesn't reward you to explore it on its entirely. Because of this the game feels like a linear level almost every time.
-I think there's not enough hats for you to enjoy. For a game called A Hat in Time, this could've been fixed. Also having only so many tries on the slot machine was a mistake.

Despite all of its flaws, the game still stands up but I think it'd be better to talk about his flaws more than why it is so good, everyone is talking about how good it is but they don't find any flaws.

As for the pros for this game, it has too much to count so I'll simply make a tiny list.
+Charming atmosphere.
+Level design.
+Boss battles and their difficulty. Not too easy and not too hard.
+The music is outstanding.
+Sounds effects are well done and every one is satisfying.
+Our control over the character is over the top, the best platformer controllers I've had the pleasure to play on the last couple of years.
+The writing of the characters are so good, the jokes are on point and they don't use memes every five seconds. They have their own identity and raise it proud.
+Full voice acting to inject more life to the game. While it can't be good for every character, it's worth to mention for a couple of them.

With everything and all I think this game stands out against the huge behemoths of the genre but it needs to work on its flaws if there's a sequel. Then it'd be a master piece.

35632740.review:
[b]A Hat in Time[/b] is a game I feel a deep nostalgia for, yet it's release was the first I've ever played of it. It's a feeling that I can tell a future me, with such confidence, will recall fondly as a real joyous gem and will have me absolutely playing again. 

With controls so smooth, even for keyboard of which I played with, I had a grand experience flowing movement from each point. When failing my jumps, it wasn’t frustrating to try once again. Certainly when the game provides, at times, swift checkpoint recoveries that brings you back in a near seamless instant. The variety of each chapter’s stages kept the experience fresh, all peppered in quirky voiced characters and bosses. With a gorgeous soundtrack to boot, compositions in flavor of favorite platformers of before. It all haunts on me of the advice, [i]"If you want to speedrun a game, it should be a game you could see yourself playing forever"[/i] I hadn't an image in mind what I could ever personally consider until I beat this wonderful game.

Now be it, it's still no perfect game overall. A few collision bugs scattered about, stiff animations at early parts, recent decisions to swap chapter 2 and 3 around that were obvious in pacing both good and bad. Though I have no doubt or regret saying that this is a perfect game for me and to recommend absolutely. This is an experience I could see myself picking up speed running for, that I would freely recomplete 100% again on a whim with glee indeed.

For when I collected every Timepieces and possible extras. I felt the need to push myself to ace each and every achievement as well for how much I enjoyed my stay. Even afterward I still hadn’t enough. Without new progress to be made I find myself recollecting previously collected Timepieces just for the fun of it. Like a song you repeat, a story that deeply resonates, this is a game I find myself thinking about even after it’s all done. And I wish It wasn’t done, for I’m truly happy to of enjoyed such an adventure and I look forward to playing a many more times [b]A Hat in Time[/b] in the future.

Edit: This game, with out a doubt. Makes for my Steam's “No Apologies” 2017 Award! As my glowing praise before hasn't made it obvious enough for my choice haha

35631313.review:
A good _original_ 3D platformer for PC? You better believe it!

The game plays a bit like a mix between Super Mario Sunshine with it's world design and Galaxy with it's mission system, but the game goes well beyond being a Mario 64-wannabe. Each world feels very distinct from one another. Not only because of the different themes, but because each world is structured different just enough in it's narrative to keep it fresh. Exploring these worlds is made better with the buttery smooth controls. Hat Girl's air dive technique feels incredibly fluid and is an absolute joy to use and works as a great reward to skip certain platforming challenges with well timed execution. Her hat gimmick is also pretty easy to understand as well, with one button being used to control the actions of each hat. Combine that with two methods to quickly access your hats during gameplay, and the action is pretty much constant.

Not only does the game have a pretty solid core, but it's oozing with charm and has a surprisingly good soundtrack from a composer I haven't really heard of before (most of the boss tracks and 'Mafia Town Is Asleep' being my personal favorites). My only real negatives are the game's somewhat short length and a slightly odd-feeling ending.

For the asking price, you really can't go wrong here.

The bosses are challenging enough to keep you on your toes, yet as you die they do make the phases you've completed more forgiving. They throw in something new every world that kept me both happy and guessing as to what would happen next. It is all around a fantastic collectathon that can stand on its own and thrive, and I adore it for doing pretty much everything right when it could have easily played on nostalgia and gone the route of Yooka Laylee, the devs knew what made a good game and they implemented it rather then half assing it. 35627870.review:
This is the sort of game I'm looking for when I play a 3D platformer, and it's an excellent example of one to boot. Pleasantly silly (though not afraid to get a little spooky), with excellent variety that made me actually eager to see what was coming up next. The boss fights were fantastic, and while long and full of moves I had to watch out for, I didn't think any of them were particularly unfair, or that the game mechanics themselves were working against me.

The controls were pretty dang great, and the only actual hiccup I found was when using the aerial homing attack. Sometimes the window in which you can trigger it is iffy, but there are very few parts in the game where such a thing was required, and it's not like it failed every time.

My biggest complaint is that one of the achievements needs you to think like a 5th grader. I'm not going to say which achievement or what it needs you to do, but if you go through the game, you should know which one I'm talking about.

The length of the game was pretty good. 13 hours for 100% is not bad at all for a platformer.

If you like N64-esque platformers, I strongly recommend you get this game. Unlike the other one that came out recently (you know who you are) I didn't regret buying it.

35627313.review:
I first heard about A Hat in Time several years ago. Followed it briefly, quickly allowed it to fall to the back of my mind - after all, it was likely to take a few years. The game seemed charming enough - they wanted to make a game to harken back to the days of old, a new Mario 64, Banjo Kazooie, Donkey Kong 64 type game. It's been a very long wait. Has it been worth it?

I believe this to be a resounding yes. The game does resemble games of old - resembling closer to Super Mario Sunshine or Super Mario Galaxy than the N64 classics - however it does this without feeling overly derivative. While the game is clearly inspired by these older games, it brings a completely fresh experience to the table that feels like its own game. Inspired, but not quite a true successor - A Hat in Time is its own game.

What a game it is too. It took me 10 hours to complete the game - albeit there are still achievements and a few other unlockables left to go back and get - but it feels like far longer. The game is very charming and the sound direction ties everything together, the sound effects and especially the soundtrack being fantastic. On that note, I do recommend buying the soundtrack along with the game.

Difficulty felt about right. There were some challenges I ran into, but everything was fully beatable. You will not be fighting with the controls in this game outside of occasionally sliding along a wall you don't want to, and even that very rarely. It controls well and is very responsive. The boss fights are satisfying and end before they get old. Checkpoints are very forgiving throughout the game, and will keep you from getting too frustrated if you are struggling. A feature I found amazing was that if you fall in certain vertical areas of the game, it will treat you as having voided out rather than you having to climb all the way back up - a definitely welcome choice.

I have 2 relatively minor issues - the Final Boss has an attack with a very wonky hitbox. This probably will not impact your experience at all unless you feel like playing through with the option that becomes available to reduce your health to 1. The other issue is that the whole way the final boss's stage is introduced feels fairly sudden. This isn't really a real issue and the final stage and boss are very satisfying, but is worth mentioning.

I highly recommend this game to anyone looking for a modern age 3D platformer. If this is what the genre's revival is looking like, I am ready for what it has to show us.

35626972.review:
Was a slacker backer to this years ago, and I've gotta say this game has ship-loads of charm.

I've played the final release to 100% completion on Time Pieces now, and can safely say this was a blast. While shorter than I thought it would be (I never kept *that* much up the devs, just general time windows to the launch), the good news is that what's there feels *great*. I cannot emphasize enough how nice it is to jump around as Hat Kid, with the sort of responsiveness that I haven't felt from a non-Nintendo platformer in a long while. With all your abilities unlocked at the end, you're a high flying, hat swapping machine. The little touch of the dive cancelling and mild wall climbing/jumping opens the exploration up to a level close to SM64/SMS, and I'm the kind of person who really likes taking the oddball way to my goals when possible. A few camera hiccups aside (and that's next to impossible to avoid having in this genre), I always had confidence my jumps were going to land where I intended, and wasn't proven wrong.

Beyond a control standpoint, the presentation is smile-inducing. The voice acting that's here is surprsingly memorable, which almost all character types having something distinct to their voices to accomadate their physical appearance. My besty description is that I'd see some shady crows, have one talk to me, and I'd go "Yeah, that's how I thought they'd sound!" It's very fitting, and in a few cases, surprisingly earnest during the sparse moments that are more serious/sincere. I really liked the tweaks to the HUD on particular missions, and the screen effects used during key moments or challenges were right on point. The humor is well done too, and in two instances a really comedic combination of grim and honest.

I wish there was more at launch and am aware there's more coming, but I also don't feel gipped out of a quality game, either. It's a very concise game without padding/fluff, and what is there is very memorable. (By the way, the boss fight songs get stupendous.) If you want to itch that SM64/SMS vibe and can't get/wait for Odyssey, you should give the devs here some credit and buy this game. There's clearly been a lot of love put into this concept, even if it's changed a little from the Alpha/Beta days to now.

35620996.review:
Probably one of the best platformers you'll find outside of Nintendo.  It still needs polishing in places (I've gotten stuck in the wall twice so far) but honestly for what you're getting, the price tag seems fair.  

Also loved the Strong Bad reference.

EDIT:

Though a glowing example of modern platformers, A Hat in Time is not without its flaws.  None of these are a deal breaker, but I'm listing them below so you're aware they exist in advance.

Precision Jumping:  This will always be a hindrance in 3D platformers. The game does have a nice homing attack and clipping feature to help you stick the landing, but more often than not you'll plummet to your death when you're trying to land on that next high-wire the first time.

Controls VS Platforming Segments:  With the double jump, long jump and wall jump, you can pretty much reach any surface with ease, which can sometimes make it easy to get lost when you're trying to get from point A to point B.  Try to follow the gems exactly to see where you're INTENDED to go rather than making up your own path.

Cut Content:  With all games a lot of intended ideas end up on the cutting room floor.  Here you have ideas that were cut, but just enough of the intended design remains for you to look at, sigh, and say "I bet that would've been pretty cool".  Personally I'd rather the whole thing just get cut.

Writing:  Inconsistencies in characters is really a small complaint but it stuck with me so I mentioned it.  Constant flip-flopping between ally and enemy gets grating after a while

35620834.review:
A Hat in Time ist ein Spiel bei dem man endlich mal merkt, dass die Entwickler ihr ganzes Herblut in das Spiel gesteckt haben. Neben dem schon aus Mario bekannten Spielstil glänzt das Spiel mit unzähligen kleinen Details. Man möchte am liebsten jeden Winkel des Spiels erkunden, um zu sehen was sich dahinter verbirgt.
Doch nicht nur der Grafik- und Detailliebe überzeugt. Auch die Musik passt hervorragend zu den einzelnen Leveln und verbreitet eine warme und schöne Stimmung. Doch auch das wichtigiste, das Gameplay weiß zu überzeugen. Die Steurung ist wunderbar umgesetzt und geht einfach von der Hand und abgesehen von dem ein oder anderen clipping Fehler läuft alles perfekt. 
Mit dem noch kommenden Workshop, Leveleditor und Coop ist dieses Spiel eindeutig ein Titel, der die ganzen auf den Markt gepeitschten Spiele in den Schatten stellt. Somit kann ich es uneingeschränkt jedem Jump and Run Fan empfehlen und der Preis ist mehr als nur gerechtfertigt. Ich freu mich schon auf die weiteren tollen Stunden, die ich mit diesem Spiel verbringen werde.

35620695.review:
So, I'm going to cut the crap and just jump right to the main reason anyone would be reading this; Would I recommend the game?

Yes. Yes I would.

Don't get me wrong, the game isn't a long one, but is that really a problem? Personally, I'd much rather play a short but excellent game, than a long and mediocre one and "A Hat in Time" is anything *but* mediocre.

The artstyle is lovely, in my opinion. Has a very strong Wind Waker feel which I adore and the soundtrack is sublime.

Gameplay wise, I cannot at any point fault it. Except for perhaps the lack of a "restart level" button, but that was only really a gripe while trying to get the "No Time to Explain" achievement. The controls are tight, the mechanics are simple and the levels are well designed and clearly set out; Not once did I stand around thinking "Where do I go now?".

The characters that you meet are one of the major highlights for me at least, they're all full of charisma and fully voiced to boot. (The voice acting is great <3).

So, if I had to give it a numerical score, it would be a solid Yes/10. Don't even wait for a sale to buy this game, it's 100% worth the money.

Only 4 hours in and I am blown away by this game. It is just fantastic, and one of the best 3D platformers I have ever played. The level structure is built like Mario 64 in that each world has multiple missions to complete but the worldspace itself never really changes, which is absolutely fine.

The controls are fluid and responsive, and while there isn't quite as much to master than in Mario 64, skipping portions of a level or getting to collectibles before you're supposed to is entirely possible and incredibly fun to do. The first level, for instance, has you following a mysterious figure to the game's Jiggy/Shine Sprite equivalent, but you're also welcome to turn around, run up the wall behind you, and wander around until you find the thing yourself.

I could go on and on about how collecting things is finally fun again, the different powers you can unlock, the excellent soundtrack, and the genuinely funny writing, but the bottom line is that if you're a fan of the 3D platformers of the N64/PS1 era, you will not be disappointed with A Hat in Time.

35617684.review:
A Hat in Time is a good game at it's base. The mechanics for getting around the worlds you'll be visiting have clearly been tested and refined to near perfection, being perfectly functional while also being designed so that there's always more than one way to tackle an obstacle in your way.

This is both a strength and a weakness, however. Through the course of the game you'll unlock multiple hats, and I was surprised early on to realize that, while I thought I'd be getting tons of hats for tons of different abilities, I'd actually be getting less than ten.

Throughout the entire game, I almost entirely used two hats - the sprint hat, and the default tophat which points you in the direction of clues and mission objectives. The sprint hat doesn't do much else other than allowing you to move much faster and jump further, but that's all it needs to make many of the games' obstacle courses throughout most of it's worlds' sublevels completely trivial and possibly to complete in a way that probably wasn't intended.

The other hats consist of a hat that allows you to throw potions specifically for the purpose of blowing up otherwise undamagable objects, a hat that allows you to freeze yourself and pound the ground, a mask that allows you to bring in objects and so on from another reality, and a hat that presumably stops time.

The problems with the hats that aren't for sprinting or clue-finding is that they're too overspecialized in what they do, having one specific use that clearly caused the developers to shoehorn in situations in where you have no choice to use them. In short - a possible lack of playtesting and foresight means that you will rarely if ever be using these hats for anything other than the situations where they are utterly needed to get an item. 

The Ice Hat's only use seems to be activating jump pads to new locations, most of which are extremely easy to reach with the platformer mechanics alone and, usually, the sprint hat. 

The potion brewing hat and it's projectiles serve only to destroy certain objects that you can't destroy otherwise, and nothing else. It's capable of damaging enemies, but combat is fairly trivial and easy anyway.

The hat that brings in objects from other realities is the one out of the three that the game gets the most use out of, but it was still clearly created with a specific purpose in mind, and again many situations that were designed with it in mind can be bypassed with relative ease without it. 

Despite the variety and uniqueness of these hats being a clear selling point for the game, I did not actually unlock the Time Stop hat before the game ended, and the game never stopped me from playing a level to tell me that it was required, meaning one of the possibly cooler ideas for a hat - again, one of the main selling points of the game - is not only completely optional, but you also discover it's existence when you're practically done with the game anyway.

As for the worlds and the sublevels in those worlds, the game starts of good, becomes briefly brilliant, and then slowly loses steam over the course of a few hours, ending in an exciting but genuinely abrupt way that feels as if it was rushed.

Mafia Town is the first world, one that's generally open with a lot of good design in it, clearly made with multiple types of players in mind. New players won't have much trouble with it at all thanks to it's pacing, while those more experienced with platformers will enjoy how Mafia Town allows you to tackle different problems in different ways. 

Sadly, Mafia Town is the first hint that the game was either rushed, or the time that the game had, enough or not, was misused. Even in the very first world, you can find various obstacles that the designers made with the hats you recieve later in mind - even the reality changing hat, which you'll receive most likely several hours later, at what I can only describe as halfway through the game, if not later.

The need to include uses for all of the hats you can find in the game, with only their specific uses, means that Mafia Town is a bit of a general mess when it really should have been the part of the game that focuses mostly on the platforming mechanics themselves at first, and later introduces the mechanics of hats to organically open the world up for the player to explore. As it stands now, Mafia Town can be completely beaten with nothing but the sprint hat, and will likely later be revisited for yarn - the item you must collect to create hats - and relics, which serve as nothing but ways to open up small obstacle courses you can find in any of the world sublevels, mostly for completionists.

It's worth mentioning at this point that there are 4 worlds, and each one has 5 or so levels for you to play. The length of these missions vary, but my final playtime clocked in at 8.5 hours. I didn't go for 100%, but I did finish all of the worlds and their missions.

The game is at it's best when it's sublevels change the game in a way that, while being unique and interesting, still meshes well with the platforming mechanics. Mafia Town is good with this, having sublevels that are a fairly good example of what's to come - changing the level with different types of objectives that, of course, will require different approaches depending on the sublevel you're playing. You may be chasing a character in a rainstorm in one sublevel, and traversing a lava filled mafia town in the next.

The second world is, in my opinion, the best part of the game. Not only does it contain the most charming writing and characters in the game - as well as having the most dialogue out of any other world - but every sublevel is unique, and the game is at it's best when it's trying to BE unique.

Without wishing to spoil anything, World 2 takes the form of a kind of contest between two different characters and you can take a side to get a different result at the end of the world, though that isn't too important. Regardless of which side you like, the world starts off with a single level to introduce you to these characters, and the mechanics you'll later find and use in both of their levels - quick, open area platforming, and slower stealth segments. From there, even though both of the characters sublevels will take place in their same area, the mission will be completely unique every time. 

Compare this to level 3 - it's a fairly large open area, but it's one that was clearly made with finally getting some use out of the hats that all have specific uses. Rather than meshing together with the hat and platforming mechanics to make one smoothly playing cohesive level, World 3 and all of it's sublevels, with the exception of one stealth level, are little more than larger areas with small obstacle courses scattered around the world that exist for the sake of existing.

World 4 is my personal least favorite part of the game, only having one sublevel that is called "free roam", aka a small hub point that takes you to four massive obstacle courses that are all incredibly generic and forgetable, without a single notable character or interesting event. 

The final world is level 5. It's a massively abrupt, fairly easy long obstacle course that tries and fails to be a "final exam" with all of the hats you've collected so far, culminating with in a final battle with your so called "rival", who failed to make a single apperance other than said boss battle from the moment she became your "rival!"

The game feels incredibly rushed, but not just because of the length. It started off excellent, but the hats that serve specific purposes that don't smoothly mesh with the rest of the game's design and the lackluster design and thought put into later levels lets it down towards the end.

Hopefully, this game will one day get a sequel where the devs not only learn from their mistake, but either have more time or - in the case of having enough time - learn to use the time that they have properly.

8/10 - Great..at first.

35616817.review:
Alright, so first of all, I gotta showcase my bias so you know where I'm coming from.
I am a huge fan of Super Mario 64 and Super Mario Sunshine. I'm hyped for explorative, but action-packed collectathons like Super Mario Odyssey, and I was indeed hyped for A Hat in Time.

So did it live up to the hype? Was it less so? The answer probably won't surprise you.

A Hat in Time caters exactly to the type of gamer that I am. I love cutesy stuff. I like a story that attempts to be genuine and heartfelt. And I sincerely enjoy a game that is packaged with different visuals and themes. Yes, this game has all of it, and it is an incredibly solid platformer to boot.

The main thing that we are told by the devs of this game when it comes to the moveset of Hat Kid, is that she was deliberately designed to be as versatile as possible, yet still within the realms of not being considered overpowered. Her versatility allows many players to make up for inaccuracies with their jumps, because of the combination of double jumps, dives, and divecancels, as well as the wallrunning move and walljumps.

You will be surprised just how far you'll be able to go with Hat Girl. Some jumps seem impossible, but you just might make them regardless. Some walls may seem just about too high, but you can do just the right maneuvre to climb them and make rapid progress.

The game's content is pretty much divided in 2 different styles of worlds. The traditional open-ended collectathon type, and the more narratively focused linear type. There are 3 of the former, 2 of the latter, and all feature super varied setups, characters, missions, and stories. Some may make you laugh, others may make you cover in fear.

I like to connect this type of game with the selfsame principle that Paper Mario: The Thousand Year Door went for. It makes sure that every mission and world feels distinct and interesting. With the exception of the time rifts, you don't quite see much of the same here, and you can always count on being pleasantly surprised.

As for the collectibles? Most are used beyond the sole promise of story progression. You can collect gem pons to buy badges, you can buy badges to gain several abilities, and you can collect yarn to make different hats, which also grant you prominent abilities. There are also custom palettes for Hat Kid, as well as unlockable remixes for ingame music tracks, and different types of the hats that you already have.
All of this, and yet the Time Pieces are the only collectibles that count towards your completion percentage and bonuses.

It's kind of nifty I'd say.

So would I recommend it? By all means yes. As a guy who loves the genre and enjoyed the Gamecube era's take on it, I feel that I would say it's worth at least it's basic asking price. I myself spent about 11-12 hours getting all Time Pieces. People on average say that they took 13 hours just to beat the game. So you'll get your bang for the buck regardless of whether you are a veteran in the genre or not.

Are there shortcomings? Yes, but I would be spoiling the game if I listed them. Just know that my issues are entirely about some of the story, and you may disagree in that regard. Nevertheless, I loved this game, and I am looking forward to see what kind of modding we'll see in the future, because I will for sure come back to it when that workshop is open.

35613057.review:
As evidenced in at least a handful of the other reviews I've written, the 3D Platformer is one of my all-time favorite genres. Combining tight, reflex-intensive gameplay with sprawling, diverse levels is a recipe for excellence in my book, although in recent years the genre has somewhat fallen into neglect. There have been a handful of games in the past year that attempted to breathe some life back into it, though, with different approaches. Yooka-Laylee vied to bring back the Collectathon genre. Clustertruck is a different sort of 3D platformer, based around fast, constantly-moving autoscroller levels. Super Mario Odyssey, out in just under three weeks, looks to be a love letter to Super Mario Sunshine and 64, my two favorite 3D platformers ever.
When I Kickstarted A Hat in Time, I expected to get a game that aped Sunshine and 64, had a handful of great ideas, played well, and was a fun game in a genre that was woefully underserved, especially on PC. Instead, Hat took its lengthy development time in order to polish, expand, and perfect its core concepts, and the result is a fantastic game that doesn't pay homage to its predecessors so much as graduates from them with flying colors.

You start the game in your novelty-shaped spaceship, on your way home from adventures unknown. You're passing by a small planet with a load of strange, unique regions, when you're hailed by a Mafia member who tells you that you need a permit, or can't fly by the planet for free, or some such nonsense. Hat Kid has no time for any of this nonsense, and attempts to break free, which results in the fuel for her spaceship, Time Pieces, being scattered all over the planet below. Now marooned, she heads to the planet's surface in order to get these hourglasses back by any means necessary.
This sets a tone that you'll see for the rest of the game: Hat Kid will help people with their issues, but her main goal is absolutely to get the heck back home. True Neutral.  This encounter with the Mafia also shows you the kinds of characters you'll be encountering: goofy, bumbling grumps with writing that I expected to grow old quickly, but which kept me chuckling until the end. 

The first world is Mafia Town, a bustling seaside city where bald, broken English strongmen who all look the same rule with iron fists. You quickly team up with Mustache Girl, a character with just as much spunk as you, but who is decidedly more good-aligned. She helps you get your first couple Time Pieces in levels designed to teach you many of the mechanics of A Hat in Time: the double jump, the dive, the dive cancel, and hat powers. 
Almost immediately, you'll see just how much effort has been put into making every single part of this game feel exceptional. 3D Platformers have long been bemoaned for their attempts at camera control, whether they opt for an automatic camera or user-controlled. I can safely say that there was not a single time in this entire game that I felt like I was fighting the camera. In almost every scenario, the camera is smart enough to adjust automatically, letting you focus on the platforming. When you feel you need to take control, you can make minute adjustments that don't autosnap back, letting you control the camera as you run, jump, and dive your way around tricky platforming sections.
Mafia Town is an incredible vertical slice of A Hat in Time for multiple other reasons besides showing you the ropes, though. Not only does the world offer a good amount of quirky characters, both in the mafiosos and the hapless townspeople, it also has a decent amount of collectibles to find, including Yarn which allows you to knit new Hats (which grant powers that can often open up sections of prior levels to find new items, including Yarn, and so on), Relics that allow you to play a slot machine where you'll unlock cosmetic items, and one of my favorite features: Time Rifts. These small glowing orbs are unlocked after certain Acts, and show up in the world screen as photos of locations in the world. You have to study the photo and then pick an Act, then hunt down the orb. Once you touch it, you're transported to one of two level types. The first is a love letter to Super Mario Sunshine's F.L.U.D.D.-less levels, great abstract blocks in space with incredibly tight platforming that's often a lot more challenging than in the core Acts. The second are strange, memory-hunting collection levels where you must find relics and pieces of a journal in order to progress, which will let you view a short picture book at the end with the memories you collected. The former are some of my favorite levels in the game, but the latter are fun in their own way, especially as a cooldown from some of the difficult levels of the core Acts.

There's one other core Hat in Time concept that Mafia Town introduces, and that's the stunningly fun boss fights. There's a miniboss that is played on a purely horizontal plane, where you must jump over barrels and dodge them, and that core dodging mechanic carries through to every other boss fight in the game. Boss fights in A Hat in Time feel akin to Donkey Kong Country boss battles in 3D, which is not something I would have anticipated working (or being fun) but they are some of the highlight encounters in the game. Each boss has multiple phases and attack patterns, and often has in-match cutscenes and dialogue (which is skipped if you retry the boss - one more excellent Quality of Life feature). These are not your 3-hit Mario bosses or 5-hit DKC bosses, though -- often, each boss takes 20-30 hits to defeat, meaning each boss battle is a test of stamina, reflexes, and patience. I'm not usually a boss guy in platformers, because I find them to often be trite or unnecessary, but Hat's bosses shine with the same polish as everything else in the game.

The boss encounters also have some of the best music in the game, with bombastic tracks that call to mind everything from Mario to Undertale. These are far from the only standout songs, though: the entire soundtrack is a delight, with each track suited perfectly for its area. Sound design in general in this game is fantastic, whether it's the Link-style groans and oofs when you bash into something or the thousands of voice-acted, well-written lines. 

I don't want to talk too much about the other three worlds in A Hat in Time, to avoid spoiling some of the best levels in what is unfortunately a pretty short game (I finished in just under six hours, with over half of the total Time Pieces, although from looking around I was on the short side), but rest assured: each world introduces new concepts, enemy types, and even entirely different gameplay mechanics. There's a murder mystery, a parade, and a sneak-and-hide horror level (which is genuinely scary!) as well as levels that are nothing but good old-fashioned platformer fun.

A Hat in Time is one of the best games I've played all year, and one of the best 3D Platformers ever. With two worlds coming as free DLC, as well as co-op in an upcoming patch, mod support, and more, it looks like this instant classic is going to stick around for some time. I hope that anyone who likes the genre, great writing, fantastic music, and genuinely perfect controls picks this up, because they will not be disappointed.

5/5

Alright so, from the initial reviews, people are comparing this as a mix of Super Mario Sunshine and Mario Galaxy, and I have to say, they are right.

One of the rare games to come out of Kickstarter and for not only for it to be GOOD, it's actually nothing short of amazing. 

The game's controls are very well done, there's a certain fluidity of switching from running to sliding that controlling Hat Kid harkens back to controlling Mario in Sunshine and the controls are also very responsive  and you could easily scale up a wall with how fluid you can switch movement to, you can really tell the devs put a lot of love into the movement, it ALMOST feels like Super Mario Sunshine

But outside of the fluid controls and the expertly done levels throughout the entire game, I felt like there was a couple of detracting points that made

- A huge, sudden difficulty spike right in World 2 that felt completely out of place. I did my own little research on this(and I'm not too sure on this) but from what I saw is that World 2 (Battle of the Birds) and World 3 (Subcon Forest) were switched, as it World 2 was Subcon and World 3 was Birds.

- The level switch lead to some of the levels in Battle of the Birds to be locked out until World 3, when you could unlock the Hookshot as part of a story mission which leads to another point...

- The Hookshot being a BADGE instead of a permanent unlock. I wasnt really a fan of the Hookshot being considered a Badge because that just means that you got one badge slot permanently used because most levels and worlds use the Hookshot in one way or another, which leads to unnecessary switching to the Hookshot if you took it out of your equipment.

- I feel like some of the Hats and Badges should have been permanent unlocks or have a better use of their respective badges

Overall, these small detractions from the game do not stop the game from being  one of the rare GOOD Kickstarter backed games I've seen.

It really is what Yooka-Laylee SHOULD have been.
