35612481.review:
[b]TL;DR:[/b] Cutesy 3D collectathon platformer with a lot of gameplay and thematic variety, reasonable controls and camera, at-times-nonsensical story that doesn't take itself seriously, and a bit of a sense of humor. If that sounds interesting, get it now, it's really well-done.

[b]Note:[/b] I played using an XBox360 controller as an input device. If you're going to use keyboard and mouse, YMMV in regards to controls. I think controller is the preferred input method, so I will hazard a guess that kb&m controls aren't as natural.

This review contains no hard spoilers, but slightly-sensitive examples and comments are under spoiler tags. Don't read if you want to go in blind.

[b]Slightly longer version:[/b]

Pros:
+ Cutesy designs and animations, bright colors, overall nice to look at
+ Nostalgia trip for those who remember mid-to-late 90's in gaming
+ A lot of variety in gameplay and presentation -- a lot more than I would expect going off from genre alone
+ Usually very fluid and satisfying controls, but see below
+ A reasonable amount of stuff to collect/unlock. Not too much. Could be a negative for some.
+ Runs beautifully, not a single crash, no slowdowns, no graphical glitches or any other problems during almost 10-hour continuous session.

Neutral:
* Game length: 8-10 hours of casual play, probably closer to 15-18 if going for 100%-completion.
* Story is nothing more than an excuse for doing stuff. Sometimes nonsensical stuff. Sometimes story is nonsensical as well. Latter might be a positive depending on your sense of humor.
* No new grounds broken graphically, but it fits very well with overall style, so there's nothing to complain about
* Characters have about enough personality to carry you through completely nonsensical bits of the story, but that's about it. While not necessarily one-dimensional, there's not much depth to speak of either.
* Ending [spoiler]is pure cheese, which[/spoiler] is fine by me.

Cons:
- Camera can be difficult and frustrating at times. Developers deserve much praise for making it work well most of the time, but when it doesn't, it really doesn't. A way to temporarily lock camera in manual mode would solve this completely, but as the time of writing, there is no such option.
- There are a few precision-platforming sections, and those can be extremely frustrating due to slippery and imprecise controls. Usually, precision of controls is not an issue, it's precise enough. Not for these sections though. Expect accidental wallruns of death and plummeting into bottomless pits of doom after missing tightropes by a hair. Somewhat offset by generous checkpoints, but can be rage-inducing nonetheless.
- Excluded from Steam's Family Sharing. I have no idea why, and find this decision rather baffling on part of developers. Personally I have no problem just firing up my account to let someone else play. But it's rather inconvenient, and for no good reason, in my opinion.

Overall, while A Hat in Time isn't without some problems, it's very enjoyable overall, and I can easily ignore some of the frustrations I had with it. So it gets a wholehearted "thumbs up" from me.

[b]A really long version:[/b]

A Hat in Time is a great callback to good-old days of 3D collectathon platformers. Also if it's not obvious from promo videos, it's dangerously cute, both visually and thematically.

It's not just that though. A Hat in Time innovates on the genre a bit, making it more of a variety show, varying not only visual design between "worlds", but also changing up gameplay and underlying theme, which helps keep the experience fresh for all 8 to 10 hours of casual play (not completing 100%, but definitely not speedrunning either). Some levels actually throw platformer conventions out of the window for something entirely different. [spoiler]At one point, for example, it turns into something resembling a survival horror game, at another it becomes a stealth game, etc.[/spoiler] That variety is very much welcome, since many older platformers could get a bit repetitive down the line.

Graphically speaking, there is no new ground broken, but it's very nice to look at, with bright colors, cute and imaginative designs, and adorable cartoony facial expressions. It's nothing really unexpected, but very well done.

Story is... Well, rather simplistic. I won't get into spoiler territory, but it's rather obvious that story wasn't the focus. It's perfectly serviceable for what it is, if completely nonsensical at times, but it's about as deep as a kiddie pool, and not terribly engaging either. Most of the time, story serves as an excuse to get you do stuff. It doesn't take itself seriously, so neither will I.

Characters have about enough personality to carry the nonsensical story forward. While not necessarily one-dimensional, they don't have much depth either.

Ending is [spoiler]as cheesy as you would expect from a Saturday morning cartoon. It's basically pure cheese, but it's[/spoiler] entirely consistent with the rest of the game, so it gets a pass.

The game isn't without its problems though, none of which are game-breaking, but some are extremely frustrating to deal with.

First problem is inherent of all 3D platformers and that is the camera. While considerably better than your typical camera from late 90's, it's sometimes too smart for its own good, either locking or stubbornly shifting into a particularly awkward angle that makes judging distance unnecessarily hard. It is usually adjustable, but I had to fight with it a number of times in precision-platforming sections. A way to temporarily lock the camera into a manual angle relative to the level would solve this complaint entirely, but at the time of writing, there is no such option.

While on topic of precision platforming, I have to say that while the game forces you into it a few times, it doesn't handle that all that gracefully. Don't get me wrong, most of the time controls are very good and satisfying, but it's much better suited for moving though a relatively open stage fast, rather than precisely landing on a tightrope after a hookshot swing. Landing on tightropes is particularly frustrating, especially in dimly-lit areas where everything's grey and judging distances is a pain in it's own right.

I've also had problems with character locking into a wall-run, then jumping away from the platform I was trying to land on, and towards inevitable doom, if I as much as bumped the wall. And it's nigh impossible to avoid bumping walls when trying to jump through series of small ledges.

I should also point out that some platforming sections are timed, and while you can get a few upgrades to make those much easier, without those upgrades they offer very little room for error, requiring nearly frame-perfect movement in some cases -- and while some of the more difficult ones are entirely optional, some aren't, which can be a source of frustration -- and hand-cramps.

Difficulty of some platforming sections is offset by the game's generous checkpoints and infinite "lives", as would be expected from a modern game, that isn't positioning itself as "NES hard". But playing through a segment 10x times only to be tripped up repeatedly by imprecise controls or camera acting up can be very frustrating. Expect that resisting sudden urges to break your controller/keyboard is a part of the challenge.

That said, the cases where I really had to re-do a section more than thrice, where I felt it wasn't my fault, are few and far in-between, so overall the game controls very nicely.

I should probably mention that I finished the game in one go, in about 10 hours or so, which itself speaks volumes of how much I enjoyed it. But I bring that up to say that I didn't experience any technical problems whatsoever, the game is wonderfully stable and runs beautifully.

As stated earlier, I find this is a great game, and it's faults are not game-breaking, and can be easily forgiven, so it gets a wholehearted recommendation.

35609258.review:
I can say without a doubt that 'A Hat in Time' is an excellent game. While calling back to games of the Nintendo 64 and GameCube eras, 'A Hat in Time' isn't afraid to mix things up and get out of the conventional 3D platformer's comfort zone.

Though the story as a narrative isn't much to write home about, it is more than made up for by the game's quirky, lovable, and especially humorously-written cast of characters.

The presentation is fantastic, with sickeningly adorable character design, expressive and alluring worlds, both silly and awesome visual flairs, and a top-notch soundtrack to boot. The voice actors/actresses chosen varied on quality of their performances, but the cast as a whole fits the game near-perfectly.

Perhaps the greatest quality of 'A Hat in Time' is its gameplay. The game's lead, Hat Kid, controls similarly of Mario back in Sunshine, though she has many a trick up her sleeve. Jumps, dives, and short wall dashes, in conjunction with an assortment of various, wacky hats, make Hat Kid one of the most versatile platforming characters that I've ever seen, yet much of the game's controls feel very natural and easy to pick up. Each of the worlds Hat Kid explores are filled with goodies to collect and obstacles to face. In terms of difficulty, the game makes a steady incline in progression, with perhaps a few exceptions.

All this said, there are a few noticeable issues, one being that completion may be impossible, at least in regards as to the game's "Rift Tokens", used to unlock cosmetic bonuses and soundtrack remixes, as after searching high and low through every world (with the game's dedicated item hunting skill equipped), I found myself short of two final goodies. Secondly, the game has its share of noticeable bugs here and there, mostly a handful of segments simply lacking the spit and polish of others. Of course, it's only been a matter of days since the game has released, so these issues are subject to a possible patch.

At its core, 'A Hat in Time', is practically a masterpiece, despite some issues/nitpicks every once in a while. I binged this game over three days, playing from 11 in the evening to 3 in the morning, and I don't regret it. I can easily see myself replaying this gem over and over again, much like 'Banjo-Kazooie'. 'A Hat in Time' not only honors the 3D-platformers of the past, but breathes new life into the genre, making the genre's revival seem much more hopeful than previously. Do yourself a favor and play 'A Hat in Time'.

tl;dr: This game is an excellent successor to 'Super Mario Sunshine', 'Banjo-Kazooie', and the like. If you're a fan of the genre or of great games made with passion, play this now.

35608596.review:
With 100% Completion (including achievements), I can safely say that this is one of the best games to come out recently. For a game that was crowdfunded and in development for around 4 years, by golly is it impressive how good this game is.

THE GOOD
- The controls are fluent and jumping around and climbing is quick and feels natural. A controller is highly recommended.
- The music, graphics are exceptional and create unforgettable worlds and levels. The game's 'cute-as-heck' slogan is 100% accurate.
- The amount of care put into making this IP feel original is clear, unlike many other crowdfunded games which market themselves for nostalgia value far too much.
- Most, if not, all levels are fresh and unique. They rarely ever feel like busy-work and are engaging to play and complete.
- Chapter 1 is the first world (duh) and is the best world in the game. It has the most to do and see and is very beautiful and simply fun to explore.
- Pons (the coins of this game) are common and easy to collect, and it is not required to collect them all in a level, so it is not made a chore to gather them.

IN THE MIDDLE
- The story is simple to understand not very complex, there is little dialogue and few named characters.
- Customizing Hat Girl is random, done through use of a slot machine following a special, mini stage. Customization is the only use of Tokens you find throughout the game's levels.
-  There is only one weapon, and although this game is not combat focused, the lack of customization is somewhat dissapointing, but not problematic.
- Chapter 2 is extremely linear, Chapter 3 is more open but lacks verticality or interesting features, and Chapter 4 is way too open and feels like many tiny levels that are glued together and lack congruency. Chapter 1 is by far the most polished for a game about exploring and collecting things. 
- A certain achievement requires you to make a crude joke. Your mileage may vary.

THE BAD
- I beat this entire game in 17 hours to 100% completion. This game is short, if you are proficient at these kinds of games.
- There are three annoying enemy types: Crows, Cats, and Headless Statues. The crows are small and weak, but a certain variant moves quickly and can push the player very far without warning. The Cats can turn invisible and invulnerable, and only reveal themselves to quickly attack. Headless Statues are fast, indestructible, and pursue relentlessly. I do not know what you are meant to do if one starts chasing you and can catch you off guard since they don't move right away.
- As of now (a few days following release), the camera has a tendency to get stuck on ceilings and jitter around. Many walls cannot be climbed up due to the top of the wall ending in a lip that you get caught on.
- Some achievements are difficult to attain due to some frustrating mechanics (STEALTH).

"Short, but sweet" is how I would describe this game. If you asked me to give it number out of 10 I'd give it an 8. The biggest problem is just how short this game is. Hopefully Gears For Breakfast will have a bright future in developing more great games like A Hat In Time.

Fantastic game. Each level has unique, well crafted missions to play through that build a bizarre and interesting world. Scratches the nostalgic collectathon itch without being overly grindy or repetitive. Each new mission takes you through different areas of the worlds, keeping the experience constantly fresh. 

Level Design: 9.5/10
Levels are open yet nuanced, with lots of hidden areas and collectibles to find.

Character Design: 10/10
Every character has really witty, well voiced dialogue. The missions are built around the various main characters you encounter, so you get to know them well enough in a short time.

Gameplay: 9/10
Besides the occasional glitchy movement, gameplay feels very crisp and tight. Platforming is very enjoyable and varied, the movement mechanics are most similar to super mario sunshine, except instead of a water pack you get a double jump and a grappling hook.

Music: 10/10
Fantastic soundtrack, bringing back memories of super mario, legend of zelda, donkey kong 64 and the banjo kazooie games. Obscenely good.

35604837.review:
3D platformers aren’t my cup of tea, I prefer 2D platformers. The last time I remember 100% completing a good 3D platformer was over a decade ago. But for some reason, this game is the most addicting 3D platformer I have ever played. It is to the point where I 100% completed the game within a matter of days. 

I like the variety in the missions where each mission has its own distinct feel to it that makes it recognizable just by looking at a screenshot. The controls were very well done, and the camera is surprisingly good. In 3D platformers, the camera is usually the worst part of the game. Here, I’ve rarely had a moment where the camera got in the way of the gameplay.

If there is one thing I didn’t like about this game, it’s the use of urgency in some levels. Aside from the infamous manor level, there is the train bomb level and the stealth sections. Levels like these are fun to talk about, but playing them is a different story. 

Overall, this game needs more love. Indie games that go through Kickstarter have a bad rep nowadays, but this game is something that shouldn’t be overlooked.

35604564.review:
good game. I bought this back in the stone ages, before time existed itself for like 20 bucks. Was it worth the wait and the money? Uhhh, probably I guess, it's hard to tell after so much time was taken. I came back into this game with zero expectations and had forgotten it existed, so I guess it was a nice surprise. 

It's really light on content though. As you can see, less than 20 hours and I even got all the time pieces (AKA STARS.) 

It's a nice game, if you can ignore that. The gameplay feels really good. Music is pretty decent. Animations can go from pretty good to reaaaaally stiff and ugly, but it's nothing that I feel harms the game that much. The zones themselves are really pretty and fun to explore. 

You get a sprint hat, and that's pretty much the only useful hat. I feel it's kind of strange to tie sprint to a hat and grapple to a badge when you kind of need both, or at least would want them on at all times. You do have to switch hats to use different abilities which is mildly annoying, but they're barely used that it's a non issue, at least to me. I can see how some might not like it, but eh, minor flaw, just leaves a very light meh feeling in there. 

It's got a few glitches, but nothing game breaking. Some walls are a little goofy, but mostly a solid game. 

Very similar to Mario 64/Sunshine/Galaxy. I figured it'd be more like Banjo Kazooie, but MUCH much closer to 3D Mario games. I think it takes after Galaxy most in terms of it being a bit more linear than 64 and Sunshine, but it likes to mesh the line a lot.  Some levels are a lot more open, some are not. 

Bosses are very uhh... inoffensive is probably the best way to put it. They're not bad by any means, but probably nothing I'd feel the urge to replay again. They tried to make it pretty fast paced, and look exciting though, so I give em credit. They're all right. 

Voice acting can vary. it feels really strange at times. I guess I got used to it as time went on. EVERYONE is voice acted, for EVERYTHING except until later when.... they're not?? So it's a little weird. You can get a badge to make it be mumbling, but honestly, even the mumbling feels a little off. Not a huge flaw, still.

Camera can be a little annoying at times, but this seems to just be the way of 3D platformers and something you'll have to get used to. 

Overall though, the gameplay feels good. You have a ton of movement options, and it feels good to abuse them. Also, very easy game, but still felt rewarding.

It's a decent game, and I hope we can see more indie devs follow this game's way of doing 3D platformers. Pretty high quality, and pretty fun. It's not going to blow your socks off and be GOTY, but it's a good stepping stone for bringing back 3D platformers for sure. 

I think if you're interested in an INDIE 3D Mario-like game, you should give it a shot. 30 dollars might be on the expensive side for a 15 hour game, so maybe wait for a sale.

35602957.review:
Having not really played any collectathon platformers prior to this, and therefore having not much of an opinion on the genre, I have to say that A Hat in Time is easily one of the best games I have ever played.

The game is great to control, the protagonist Hat Kid moves fluidly and at no point did I ever feel like I was fighting the controls to do what I wanted. The level design itself is amazing - the environments that you explore are unique and varied, and are open to explore and search for collectibles and secrets. The collectibles themselves never feel like a chore to find, as they help unlock both upgrades for Hat Kid to improve her arsenal, and cosmetic changes to allow for you to customise Hat Kid.

Charm oozes from this game, between the world and characters that inhabit it. Hat Kid is simply a very adorable protagonist, shown mostly through her animations in the game and the few small lines of dialogue that she speaks. Most of the characters are memorable and have genuinely funny dialogue, which is backed up by good voice acting. The places you visit are all unique, vibrant and full of things to look at and explore, which backs up its already great level design. The soundtrack is fantastic, Pascal Michael Stiefel, Grant Kirkhope, and the rest of the composers outdid themselves, with every track being great to listen to, which really helps you get immersed into the experience that this game provides.

Overall, you should definitely give this game a look, and possibly even try it. It's one of the most fun, charming and polished games that exists right now. It's left a massively good impression on me, and I plan to keep on playing it in the future, especially once the modding support comes out (which will be very soon), as well as finally go and try out the games that inspired this wonderful game.

Pros:

35600776.review:
A Hat in Time is a solid, charming, and fun little gem of a game.

I backed this game when its Kickstarter launched, and the moment they had the Alpha up I knew it would be good - it definitely needed time in the kettle then, and now, three years after the Kickstarter, it's finally out. Definitely worth the three year wait.

The game plays solidly - it's a 3D collect-a-thon platformer in the same vein as Banjo Kazooie (which I've never played) and games like the old Spyro trilogy (which I've played a ton of.) It certainly plays smoothly, even on a mouse and keyboard. There were a few spots where I struggled to get timing right, mainly with stuff involving the Dweller's Mask, but overall nothing would really frustrate you for bad handling.

Graphically, the game is a beauty. The characters are absolutely charming, and the environments are lush and beautiful. The game even gets a lil creepy at certain parts, and works it out really well! The levels are varied and carry a unique feel to each one.

The music and sound design is fantastic - the voice acting is great, although I'm pretty sure they ripped out a certain NPCs voices due to dumb backlash - which is a huge shame, in my opinion. Each level has really great music, with a few getting remixes as well due to the Kickstarter stretch goals. You can also opt to go for garbled dialogue by getting a badge, if you want it to feel more like Kazooie.

Everything about this game is great - really, the only thing that's bad is that it's pretty darned short, so hopefully Gears for Breakfast will find a way to give more content some time!

Absolutely recommend this game if you love platformers or if you loved old platformer games like Spyro and such, it carries a lot of the charm that those older games had in a nice, modern package!

Really good to see this be such a success!

35600772.review:
The level design is fantastic. 

There's a lot of games where after a while you're just rushing to the end, and it gets repetitive. I never had that issue with a Hat in Time. The amount of detail they put into their maps had me put in an hour just running around the first level. 

The game may be shorter compared to other games, but the detail certainly makes up for it. The areas are filled with decorations and interactable platforming/mobility objects, while at the same time the areas all feel different, even within the same level each area felt different.

I nearly forgot to say something about the soundtrack, its just really good, and you can unlock remixes for it too. I have no regret in getting the deluxe edition for the soundtrack, the music was definitely worth the extra $5. I'm not one that usually listens to OSTs either. The OST includes 78 tracks.

Each area truly felt unique, top it off with satisfying mobility, the game is really fun to explore.

35600617.review:
y'all this game is seriously wonderful.
If 3D platformers are your vibe and you like Gamecube-era Nintendo in general, it's basically a huge love letter to that in particular. 
The levels are gorgeous and super fun. Big, open-world, Sunshine style platforming. (minus FLUDD, at least)
And on top of that are areas with really fun, wacky plots instead, where platforming is seamlessly integrated with stuff like the "Murder on the Orient Express" parody in the trailer.
The third world does both and features a pretty genuinely unnerving horror chapter.
The movement is super fluid. It's fast and responsive, upgradeable to be more forgiving (anti-wallbonk badges, for example), and pretty dang fast if you get good at it.
The voice acting is phenomenal, with every character full of (silly) personality and nailing every line. Or you can even turn it into Banjo grunts with a badge as well if that's your thing.
And the MUSIC. Kirkhope was commissioned for a few tracks, but the team's own work shines wonderfully on its own.

I couldn't stop smiling the entire time I was playing it the first night. It's really cute, funny, and entertaining as hell. If you are even remotely interested, please give it a closer look. You even get a hidden Corgi text adventure~

35600417.review:
Stupidly impressive for a game that was Kickstarted from the ground up.

I first heard about this game because it was being developed by Mecha the Slag of TF2 fame. And then I was instantly hooked when I saw the alpha gameplay footage of Mafia Town. The game looked beautiful, it was well-polished for a single level, and it looked like it understood exactly what a classic platformer is supposed to be. And once it was released, the rest of the game didn't disappoint either: every other level is just as beautiful if not moreso, and everything from the 2D art, to the small touches everywhere and even the appearance customization is the frosting on a cute and adorable cake that already blows all the rest of the competition out of the water.

Of course, to be certain, this is not a perfect game. The checkpointing system is flukey, and the respawn-after-falling-into-an-instant-death-pit mechanic can be glitchy, especially on the second-to-last level. For all the time it spent in development, the game is quite short, I was honestly expecting two or three more levels than what was in the final product. And the story is little more than token, I was expecting something more flowing, and more involvement from recurring characters.

However, given that it was developed by such a small team, and that its only funding came from Kickstarter, these are easy sins to forgive, as the final product still far exceeds any expectations one can reasonably have, and it's still a great and fun game.

35599698.review:
I've been playing platformers ever since the days of the original Paper Mario, Banjo-Kazooie, Donkey Kong 64, Spyro, and Crash Bandicoot. Coming into this game having finished Yooka-Laylee, I was very impressed by this game especially. It delivers what YK failed to do, captivate the audience and innovate about what made platformers so fun and special. A Hat in Time didn't reel me in during the demo because it seemed like a buggy mess with horrible colors and contrast. However, after a month of not touching it and opening up the game upon release, it was nothing like Beta! The game has wonderful and vibrant colors! The game reeled me in quickly when I noticed how quirky and hilarious the characters were. Hat Kid is very adorable, and the gameplay feels extremely rewarding unlike Yooka-Laylee. It actually means something to get equipments (different hats and hat-badges), as opposed to just "unlocking" a new movie like in Yooka-Laylee. I'm only barely a few hours into the game, and I already love many aspects about it. It's not a perfect game by any means, but the quirky characters, vibrant colors, and rewarding gameplay hooked me in ASAP. I plan on finishing this game soon in a couple of months and recommend it to folks who were a little disappointed by Yooka-Laylee! :)

EDIT: After finishing the game with all achievements, I am still impressed by this game. Everything about it was expected, and more!

35599634.review:
I've played about 6 hours and I'm at the 50% mark, having nearly 100%'d the first two acts (out of 4 it seems like)

The game has a million graphic settings, way beyond what I was expecting so you can tune the performance however you like. The artstyle is cutesy but I wouldn't call it childish. It's stylized really well and the whole game is a coherent package.

A to jump, X to attack, R to do a dive, then L is your special ability. You start off with a compass of sorts but you get at least 6 more. You can double jump, wall jump, you can recover from a dive at any time but it uses your double jump. The game controls well.

Difficulty is almost non existent but that's fine, it's more about the fun of moving around. The challenge comes from understanding what you need to, more than actually doing it, which is fun. There are secret levels that take one or two minutes to finish and those can be a challenge. 

Every world has its own set of stories and level designs. The first was a large island you move around in, the second world was a tiny train and a small indoor building, world 3 so far is a large flat open forest. There isn't as much moving around as solving stuff, which is weird to say. I was expecting more stuff like world 1 in Mario 64 but it's more contained than that. Not a bad thing but it would be cool to see bigger worlds.

Overall I'm very happy with this. Check out Poi for a similar game.

35599411.review: A love letter to the 3D platformers I grew up on, and by extension to me and fellow fans of it, but instead of simply copying from any one game, it takes  inspiration from the best, most memorable parts of several games, and puts its own spin on it. But it's more than just that. The game absolutely [i]oozes[/i] creativity and invites you to actually have fun;something an overwhelming amount of games just don't do anymore. I'm looking forward to what Gears for Breakfast can do next!

35599357.review:
I backed this game on Kickstarter and I don't think it was worth the wait.

Credit where due: the levels all look great, and the music is all flawless. Every song I heard was great and fit perfectly, full stop. Everything else suffers from really uneven amounts of focus - some areas got tons of love, while others got neglected. Hat Kid is an absolute joy to control, but that fun stops dead when you run into buggy or confusing level collision. Hat Kid has tons of great animations, but the NPC animations are all stiff and terrible - characters will move frantically when idle, or wave and beckon to you despite having zero dialogue.

The game is clearly an homage to things that came before it, but a lot of the times it's just straight-up derivative. If you've played Psychonauts or Paper Mario: TTYD, a lot of characters and beats will feel uncomfortably familiar. It's a shame because the game is quite capable of witty one-liners and inventive characters, but bits like these make the game feel unconfident in its ability to be original. Hilarious jokes about microwaves punishing naughty food will be followed up by jokes that are just "here's some podcasts we like." Characters like a Scottish bird-monster train conductor will appear alongside "here's the G-Men from The Milkmen Conspiracy".

There's the final strange matter of giving a voice cameo to JonTron, a guy who's dabbled in white supremacy. For a game that wants to be a smol bean cute-as-heck indie and make jokes about unethical consumption in capitalism, it's a baffling choice - like they wanted to be cheeky and Political but not have any firm political views. But really, considering how the rest of the game seems to really hurting for unique voice talent, it's just another example of the unbalanced polish. Why grab a YouTube celeb for a 15-second cameo and then give several other characters identical "wacky" voices?

The game is of course going to get patched, especially with two bonus chapters supposedly on the way. Right now, I'd recommend holding off until then.

But most importantly, I don't think I stopped smiling this whole game. Every moment was fun and exciting to play.

If you loved the old platformers; Mario 64, Banjo-Kazooie, Donkey Kong 64; you [i]have[/i] to get this game.

35593730.review:
One of the best 3D platformers made in a long time!
It's wonderfully unique, charming and a absolute blast to play.

It essentially took the Shovel Knight Route, it takes inspiration from several different sources (Mario Sunshine, Mario Galaxy, Psychonauts, Banjo Kazooie, PP:TTYD etc), got rid of what didn't work, has a lovely art style that not only looks good but can almost perfectly encapsulate what we remember those games looking like.

The game consists of 4 chapters and a finale level and it took me around 7 hours to beat the game with the bare minimum to get to the finale and then another 8 to 100% the game and I'm already pumped to start my 2nd playthough.

While not available at launch, Gears For Breakfast has promised updates that'll add Local and Online Co-op, An Additional 2 chapters as well as Workshop support (should be coming sometime the week this is posted, it'll support custom levels, hats, all sorts, along with some already made custom content made by the devs)

If you are at all a fan of 3D platformers you NEED to play this game!

A Hat in Time is a platformer that brings me back to when I was 7 years old, having just bought super mario sunshine and got home to play it.Its charming, its funny, it has expressive voices and smooth controls. 
Everything I could have wanted in a game.
A platformer with big worlds and interesting characters is already a good start, but the scenaros are all fun to play in.

Queen Vanessa's Manor was completely unexpected for me, I'm really bad with horror games and so I got terrified during this mission, especially when you first hear her. Despite being shit-scared, I can't deny how well made the level was. The surroundings changing, the locked camera angles, the visuals and noise when she chases you. It was well put together and frankly terrifying.
It was at this time I really was floored by the whole composition of the game.

Overall: pretty good game, would recommend, can't wait for the extra dlc to come.

35592646.review: I've been seeing news on this game every now and again as it was being made, and I'm happy to see it succeeding so well right from launch. If you love classic collect-a-thons like Mario 64, Mario Sunshine, Banjo Kazooie, etc., then you'll love this game. It's not as big as them (only 5 worlds and 40 of the main collectable to progress the game called Time Pieces), but it still is a fun game. It brings back that classic collect-a-thon game feel with its own modern twist. You collect yarn to make different hats with different powers, and equip badges to them to give you new abilities or enhance your hat's powers. The worlds were fun to explore and the characters always amused me. It took a little while for me to get used to the controls, but after I did they were very responsive and I never felt like the game was the reason I messed up. The soundtrack is also great, and you can buy it as well with the game. Overall, this is great indie collect-a-thon game that I recommend getting, especially since modding is now being added to make the game continously fun with all the different mods like levels, hats, badges, and dyes that people are making in the workshop.

35592623.review:
I normally don't write reviews, but I have to for this.  I've been wanting a platformer that shined a light to my favorite platformers growing up (banjo kazooie/tooie, Sunshine, Psychonauts).  I was hoping that Yooka-Laylee would fulfill that (at least the BK/BT part), but it suffered from many problems.  The game was not terrible, but it wasn't great either.

When I bought the game, desperate for another great platformer, I wasn't sure if I wanted to pay 30 dollars for a 15 hour game.  As I was playing through mafia-town, I tried to give myself reasons to refund it, as steam has that >2 hours played refund rule.  As I played more, I regretted even thinking that.

Playing through the acts/chapters, it's not hard to see how much love was put into the game from the developers.  No levels play the same, so every level is a new experience.  The boss fights were easily the best boss fights I've played in a platformer game.  They were tense, and the music definitely helped.

A Hat in Time made me remember why I love platformers. As I was playing, I never wanted the game to end. I can't wait for the next two free DLCs, and even though a sequel seems unlikely due to the low amount of sales, I'm hoping for that too.  

Pros
+Music
+Level Design
+Bosses
+Variety (acts/chapters)
+fun mechanics

Cons
-Length
-Controls can be iffy (wall running, jumping after diving)


If you love 3D platformers. GET THIS GAME.

Honestly, this is one of those games where you get halfway through the tutorial and you're already saying "man, I love this game". At this point in time I haven't progressed very far into it,heck, I'm only on the second stage, but everything about this game is just fun, the controls are fluid, the humor is spot on, the level design is easy to memorize and a fun to blast through, and this is one of 3 games I have bought the sountrack to, and I only had to listen to a handful of songs before I made that decision. It's very well optimized for pcs as well, I have a gtx970 and an i74790k, and while playing this game at some of the highest settings possible, I have yet to see it drop one fram below 60, and my dualshock 4 controller works from the start without having to instal 3rd party software (take that dark souls). This is one of those rare cases where I honestly reccomend buying it whilst at full price because the developers deserve every penny of it for the amount of love and hardwork put into this game. I'd say my only issues with the game are that the dash doesn't go in which way you're pointing your analog stick, but rather where your character is currently facing, which has led to  a few deaths, and the game seems to have a philosphy of "Come back when you have the proper power up so you can get this collectible" ie: banjo-tooie (I'm just not a big fan of this kind of design, I much prefer being able to get everything in one go if I can), but these hardly detract from everything else this game has to offer. If you have an itch for a 3d collecthon platformer, especially if you feel like yooka-laylee blueballed you, then you have no reason not to pick this game up, it's everything I wanted from it and more.

Cons

"Come back later with the proper power up for this collectible" design

TL;DR, if you like 3d collacthon platformers from the n64-ps2 era, this game is worth the 30 dollar investment.

35590838.review:
- SPOILER FREE REVIEW! -

What a wonderful example of a 3D Platformer done right. A Hat in Time is a game that obviously draws inspiration from certain N64/GCN titles, but it does so subtly and even improves on their formulas in both fun and interesting ways. I don't intend to provide an in-depth review, but I hope to convince a few 90's gamers to try it out! Without further ado...

Worlds/Graphics:
A Hat in Time will throw you into a delightful selection of worlds, each with their own unique style of both graphics and gameplay. I can honestly say that each of the worlds almost feels like its own game -- everything from the stage selection screen to the NPCs and flavor text contribute to the thematic style of each area. Graphically, the game is wonderfully cartoonish, and I think best described as a blend of Wind Waker's bright colors alongside Super Mario Galaxy's alien environments. I experienced the game Maxed out at 2560x1440 and can honestly say it's one of the most beautiful games I've played. It also looks gorgeous at higher framerates if your monitor supports it.

Music/Soundtrack:
Many indie games fall flat when it comes to their soundtrack, given that their development team usually isn't large and doesn't contain a dedicated composer. With "A Hat in Time," this could not be further from the truth. The game's soundtrack immediately grabs you with its unique space-y sound and happy-go-lucky attitude, and the experience only gets better from there. Each world has its own "theme," but the music undergoes subtle changes as events take place and you progress throughout each mission. Everything from the area themes to the boss music is a home-run. Simply a phenomenal job. If you're a fan of VGM soundtracks, you'll be coming back for it later, I promise.

Gameplay/Mechanics:
With any platformer (especially 3D platformers) it's important that the controls function well. Given that "A Hat in Time" does require precision platforming in some of its areas, it is clear that the developers spent a lot of time tuning the physics and controls to ensure tight, responsive movement. Hat Kid generally goes where I expect her to go, and keeping her aligned to platforms/tightropes/etc. usually works as expected. Not everything works perfectly, however-- wall kicking is more difficult than it should be and it often causes the camera to jitter if done incorrectly. This is something that could easily be addressed with a patch, so I expect this won't remain an issue forever.

Conclusion:
Although this might seem a bit cliché, the biggest problem with "A Hat in Time" is that it's too short. Not for the price, mind you -- $30 is completely reasonable for a game of this complexity and length. It's too short because it leaves you wanting more. You want to take Hat Kid on more adventures. You want to hear more of the entralling soundtrack. You want to stand in awe of the next enormous environment, precisely crafted to its own style. In theory, two additional worlds will be arriving at some point as free DLC. If so, that's fantastic news -- I just hope the Developers take their time and put just as much effort into the DLC worlds as the originals. Don't rush them; just make them fun. 

In a way, that's the whole theme of "A Hat in Time." It wasn't rushed, but rather carefully crafted over many years of hard work. The result of that work, however, is an experience brimming with such a pure, genuine fun that I haven't felt since playing Super Mario Galaxy nearly 10 years ago.

35590388.review:
First off I’m going to say this game is amazing, if you want to know if it’s worth it, absolutely yes! If a cute, fun, solid 3D platformer is what you’re looking for this is the game for you! Now on with the review!

I'll start with the pros and cons. Cons first, so let’s get these bad boys out of the way.

Cons
- The length 
- Visual glitches 
- The lack of voice acting near endgame 

The worst thing about this game would be its length... Well if you do the bare minimum; which is getting 25 time pieces and not going out of your way to grab collectables. In which the game is about 10-15 hours. If you however, collect everything, the game is much longer and more enjoyable in my opinion. This also negates the length problem; however even after finishing everything I could, I was still left craving more.

This game is definitely beautiful, but one thing that happened a decent bit were visual glitches, mainly shadows on some  characters being off and clipping on models, a lot of clipping. An example is a cut scene after the first boss. Where hat girl closes her eyes and shakes her head, her eyes clip through. Though that only happens in that cut scene.  Distracting but that's about it.

Another thing that is merely distracting is the lack of voice acting near the end of the game. Some characters were voiced while some were not. Note that these same characters were fully voiced earlier in game. That’s the reason why this is distracting, IS because it is fully voice acted other than those handful of lines. 

Pros 
- The visuals 
- The camera
-The voice acting 
-How hat kid controls 
-The Characters  

To start right off the bat you’ll notice this game looks good, but not really detailed, most textures are relatively simple. However what makes this game’s visuals mostly simple but down right gorgeous, are the visual effects. From sand and snow sparkling, to partials and butterflies in the air. The wind blowing, dust and fog hanging just above the ground, and ambers floating in the air around fire and lava. And probably more that I’m missing. That alone makes this game so beautiful to look at; really it’s just a treat for your eyes.

They defiantly took a lot care with the camera; it feels like an extension of yourself. It never got in my way, nor did I have to fight it. To the point that hardly noticed it. The only two problems I had with it. Were that sometimes I couldn’t make a sharp turn fast enough; likely do to my settings. And that you can clip the camera through a lot of thing ever so slightly.  

I’ve got to say the voice acting is wonderful, some of the best I’ve heard! Not much to say, the character’s voices are distinct, and fit perfectly with each character. Lastly the lines were read with so much character and emotion.

 Hat kid controls beautifully, every move can flow into each other. You’re given so much control over how you move. Not to mention how fast you can move, do to being able to have each move go from one to the next. I don’t think I’ve ever played a platformer that allows for such movement. To go from one side of an area to the next with lighting fast speed and simple but accurate controls; well one just has to feel for themselves, to truly appreciate it.

Last but not least the characters, oh the characters. Every character has an distinct and quirky personality. They also play off one another beautifully. From two characters fighting for a trophy, by all means possible, do to believing the other will cheat to win. To one that your obligated to do, let’s say “chores” for. And not to spoil anything ends up in a disagreement that goes back and forth in a humorous way. I’ll leave the rest for you to see for yourself. 

And that’s A Hat in Time. A must play if you ask me, so what are you waiting for, pick it up and play it already!

I initially expected a game similar to Banjo&Kazooie, but it ended up feeling a lot more like Super Mario 64 with a Banjo&Kazooie personality. I'm two worlds into it, but I'm already very pleased with it. The controls feel great and controller compatibility isn't an issue, ALL of the characters in the game I've seen so far have so much personality and it ranges from relating to being outright silly (that being said, the first world Mafia was phenomenal in interactions across the world), there are a lot of interesting collectibles and different abilities to collect over the course of the game as well. For me, this game may have faded to black during the past 3 years, but when it finally came out, I'm very happy to say it absolutely does not disappoint, in my honest personal opinion. If you're a fan of 3D platformers and collectible hunting give this a shot. If you grew up with the N64 during your childhood, give this a go. Finally, if you like a game where a good variety of characters have... well... character, not to mention voice acting, I recommend this. I may have been redundant a good number of times in this review, but I'm having a good time with it and I'm very happy with what Gears for Breakfast has produced. Thank you.

35589396.review:
Excellent, this is what 3D Platformers are all about!

Right from the start A Hat In Time's cute charm will suck you in, and you won't want to get off. As a fan of 3D Platformers I've  seen other people describe this as a throwback to Super Mario 64 and Banjo Kazooie, but in all honest i'd say its more a combination of Super Mario Sunshine and Psychonauts, while at the same time having enough of its own unique identity to create something incredibly memorable.

From the incredibly quotable "Mafia guys" to a Film Noir murder mystery, to a surprising Resident Evil 7 style survival horror stage, there's more than enough variety that you just keep wanting more.

It is a bit on the short side though. I beat the Story in just under 7 hours with 26 timepieces (The equivelant of Stars in this game) though there is clearly more than enough post game content that I'm more than eager to dive into to go for 100%.

There are a few visual hiccups that do pop up every once in a while from clipping characters to animations not playing quite right though nothing that ever hindered my playtime.

8.8/10

Side note: I noticed that some people are upset by the fact that JonTron has a cameo in this game. For the record I really do not agree with his controversial views at all. But having said that ... it's a freaking cameo with only 2 lines, and you don't even need to talk to his NPC. I think the outrage from his appearence was totally blown out of proportion, especially considering it was recorded before the controversey happened, and the fact that Gears is a small indie company on a tiny budget which makes any sort of replacement job easier said than done.

Still if you're really upset by JonTron you can make Lemonade out of the situation: By being able to beat the crap out of him.

This game just makes me smile.

Everything about it. The visuals, the music, the sound effects, the movement, the level design, the characters, the writing, everything. 

I'm just going to list what I didn't like, and let you assume that anything I didn't mention was perfect.


*There were some bugs.
  -Occasionally, you can get stuck in a weird position and teleport. It happened about 4 times in my 14 hour 100% casual run. 
  -Occasionally, when a character's eyes are closed, you can see sliver of their open eye texture behind the skin texture. 
  -Sometimes the camera freaks out. 
  -While doing some speedruns, I'd buy the badge pin to use more badges, and both times, it didn't actually work, and I was stuck with the single badge slot. (Might be a bug with skipping skippable cutscenes, which you're hopefully only enabling after your first playthrough)
  -These sucked when they happened, but still didn't detract too much from the experience (except that badge pin one, fuck that)

*Game's a bit short.
  -Fortunately, they're working on 2 free DLC chapters, and workshop support is coming, so this will hopefully not be an issue for too long.

*Some things can be a bit confusing
  -I don't want to get too into spoilers, but I'll just say that 2 points I got a bit lost at were:
    1. Getting myself in a position to accept the 5th mission of the 3rd chapter.
    2. Starting the 4th chapter. This one's a bit more on me being bad at looking for things, turns out you had to spin 3 things at the top of the place. Again, being real vague here.


So yeah, aside from those, everything else is fantastic. Characters, Movement, Visuals, Writing, Music, Level design, Sound effects, Boss battles, everything is just so good. I love this game. 


On the "Mighty Number 9 to Shovel Knight" scale of quality of nostalgiabait kickstarter games, this is way up there with shovel knight.

35589080.review:
[h1]Vorwort[/h1]

Schon 4 Jahre ist es her, als ich dieses Spiel im Jahre 2013 über Kickstarter mitfinanziert habe. Wer hätte damals gedacht, dass ich so lange warten müsste? Nun, eins steht fest: Ich werde nie wieder ein Spiel über Kickstarter mitfinanzieren. Um schon eine Sache vorweg zu nehmen: Ich finde "A Hat in Time" besser als aktuelle 3D-Marios und hoffe auf einen Nachfolger. Leider scheint dieses Spiel bisher auf Steam unterzugehen. Im weiteren Verlauf dieser Review werde ich auf das Gameplay, den Umfang, den Sound und Sonstiges eingehen.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

Man hüpft, rennt, klettert und sammelt Items ein. Dies beschreibt schon ganz gut die Tätigkeiten im Spiel. Das hüpfen macht Spaß, da es sich präzise anfühlt. Das Repertoire beinhaltet Doppelsprünge, Weitsprünge, Wandsprünge und mehr.
Im Spiel gibt es eine Anzahl von Hüten, die alle ihre besonderen Fähigkeiten mit sich bringen. Zum Beispiel sorgt der eine Hut dafür, dass man sehr weit springen kann und der andere Hut sorgt dafür, dass die Zeit verlangsamt wird. Durch "Badges", die sich auf den Hut befestigen lassen, werden weitere Fähigkeiten hinzugefügt z.B. einen Greifhaken, damit man über größere Abgründe sich schwingen kann. Ein schnelles Moped, damit man nicht mehr schnell laufen muss. Eine Badge, die die Abklingzeit von Fähigkeiten stark verkürzt.
Ziel ist es genug Sanduhren zu sammeln, vergleichbar mit den Power-Sternen aus Mario 64. Des Weiteren gibt es noch Sammelzeug wie Wollknäule, Münzen und Währung, die man für alles mögliche braucht.

[h1]Umfang[/h1]

Das Spiel ist an sich jetzt schon komplett, es wird jedoch in Zukunft noch kostenlos erweitert.
Insgesamt gibt es 40 Sanduhren zu sammeln, die auf 5 Welten (Chapters) verteilt sind.

Jede Welt hat ihre Besonderheiten, die am Ende mit einem lustigen und spektakulären Bosskampf enden.
Welten können offen sein mit viel Erkundung oder eher linear.
Je nach Spielart dauert das Spiel 6-15 Stunden (Nur schnell durchlaufen und Bosse besiegen vs. Sachen sammeln und umschauen).

Für die Zukunft ist ein Coop-Modus geplant und weitere 2 Welten(Chapters). Die "Story" ist bereits jetzt schon abgeschlossen.

[h1]Sound[/h1]

Der Sound ist sowas von genial und abwechslungsreich, echt der Hammer! Das liegt wohl auch daran, dass der berühmte Komponist von den Banjo Kazooie-Spielen auch Musik für dieses Spiel komponiert hat(Grant Kirkhope). Die Stimmung im Spiel, ob fröhlich oder traurig, wird perfekt mit Musik untermalt.

[h1]Sonstiges[/h1]

Des Weiteren ist es möglich, die Spielfigur optisch anzupassen. Es gibt verschiedene Skins für Hüte und verschiedene Farben für die Kleidung und Haare.
Die Story, oder besser gesagt die Rahmenhandlung, ist ganz nett. "Hat-Girl" verliert ihren Treibstoff(Sanduhren) und muss den wieder einsammeln, um nach Hause gelangen zu können. Generell ist die Story und das komplette Spiel sehr witzig. Die Charaktere sind fast alle liebenswert und liebevoll gestaltet. Die "Grafik" sieht ganz gut aus, was auch dem zeitlosen Cartoon-Look geschuldet ist.

[h1]Fazit[/h1]

Wie man schon im Vorwort lesen konnte, bin ich sehr begeistert von dem Spiel. Selten wird wirklich ein so liebevoll gestaltetes Spiel veröffentlich. Es braucht sich nicht vor den Marios und Banjos zu verstecken. Wer Jump 'n Runs mag oder das Collect-A-Thon Genre, wird sehr viel Spaß mit dem Spiel haben. Die 30€ für das Spiel sind auf jeden Fall gerechtfertigt, obwohl dies für Steam Indie Verhältnisse viel ist! Kauft es Euch!

35588991.review:
Let me be frank.
I wasn’t aware of this game’s development until a few days ago and I don’t do reviews, ever.
I bought A Hat in Time on a hunch and I have never been so delighted. A Hat in Time is the most enjoyable game I have played in YEARS. 
The writing is spot on, the music is incredible, the characters are endearing and memorable, and the game plays incredibly well. Every world had me gripped with anticipation as to what would come next, and I was never disappointed. New abilities and tricks are supplied over the course of the game, but backtracking to find new secrets was never a bore and kept me gripped for hours. Several times I found myself just wandering around, honking my scooter horn at NPCs and enjoying the music, and just discovered some new puzzle or hidden goodie completely by accident. As of writing this, I am only at 80% completion, but I am eager to dive back into this hecking cute game to find every last secret -currently- available. I sincerely hope you’ll join me if you have not yet had the pleasure to do so, it’s the best money I’ve spent on Steam yet.
(Unrelated note: I want to adopt Hat Kid and spoil the snot out of her. She is a perfect little princess and I want to carry her around on my shoulders and… I digress. Play this game.)

35588977.review:
Okay so how is a Hat in time? 
[h1] Short aswer	[/h1]
10/10 Amazing buy it!

[h1]Long answer:	[/h1]
I have never written a steam review and I own 200+  steam games! Hell this is the only game I took the time to 100% with all achievements! 
A Hat in time is hecking cute 3D platformer that oozes polish and charm in every nook and cranny. Hell they hand coded the physics of the Cans! OF THE CANS THAT YOU CAN KICK. What’s most surprising about that is it’s an indie studio using an engine, but despite the corners they can cut with the engine. THEY DON’T they don’t cut any corners. Well now ill talk about the gameplay and stop nerding over the polish and coding. Sorry it’s the Dev in me…. I ASPIRE TO BE THIS GOOD


Ahhemm.. well this game is said to be a love letter to all the old 64 and gamecube collectathons. However, I feel that it did indeed take some aspects of the old games and mesh it into theirs. And I would agree with that, however it did it SO DAMM WELL. You can’t just take an old formula and repeat with slight differences we will notice. This game took thoughts and truly used them to change the 3D platformer genre. They made them their own and implemented them in the modern scene of gaming to perfectly.  The devs know what makes a game fun and I find that not a lot of devs nowadays know what that truly means
The movement of hat kid is enjoyable, the characters are adorable and loveable and ooze personality, the level design is actually a full level with something to do around mostly every corner. The missions are fun, and have replayability. The bosses are fun and enjoyable. The game is just a really well done, thought out beautiful game that I think everyone should play.

[h1]TLDR:[/h1]
So, for $30 it’s worth it. Also, more free levels and FULL MODDING support is on the way. People will have the ability to create their own level and missions! So… yea its pretty good

35588860.review:
If you’re interested in A Hat In Time at all, pick it up. I wouldn’t call it cute-as-heck, but instead lively-as-heck. There’s a lot to say, so let’s get to it!
As far as the size of the game, I would say it was shorter than expected. It took me 10 hours to beat (while looking around for stuff), 12 hours to get the achievements after that, and 14 hours to get all of the pins on the Collectibles Map. HOWEVER, this isn’t actually really a bad thing! Every 1/40th of the game is very sizable and unique in its own way, and it also means the game doesn’t overstay its welcome with padding.
The main selling point of this game is Hat Kid’s movement. With a double jump, a far dive, a jump after that, and a wall climb, her horizontal movement is insane. There are a lot of moments in the game where you see a platform far away that you MIGHT be able to make, jump and dive to it to see if you can make it (since failing a jump isn’t much of a penalty thankfully), and ACTUALLY DO. It makes you feel like a gosh darn GENIUS, especially when you skip other platforms. The fact that there are very few enemies in the game is telling that the focus went into the platforming level design, and it compliments your movement options extremely well so that every moment of the game is “Can I get to that ledge?” Hat Kid’s vertical movement being very limiting is a smart way to “balance” this out. She can only run up the wall for a second and her wall kick only goes outwards, so you need to be crafty to get UP to places. Finally, Hat Kid’s dive is really fast if you get the timing right , which makes navigating any more open areas more fun and satisfying than, say, spamming a long jump.
As for the bulk of the game, the missions, the thing that stood out to me the most was how most of them felt like they told a part of a story and were distinct in their own right. Your objectives never really felt random or misguided, and this makes it feel like much more than a game about Hat Kid’s ability to platform. The dialogue’s a part of this. The thing is that there’s a lot of dialogue, and even with the Hold A to Skip mechanic in parts, feels like it could be obnoxious for repeat playthroughs, but it’s important for worldbuilding. As for the worlds, they’re pretty bulky and fun to run around in sometimes (except for Chapter 2, which is more “individual missions), but thankfully getting to each mission isn’t a struggle. For example, my favorite Chapter is Chapter 3 because the world’s big and relatively flat, so it’s easy to see a new point of interest, check it out, then repeat a la open world games. There are three Time Rifts per world, and they show up anywhere in the area with only a picture of its location to go on. With how big the worlds are, I figured this would be tedious and awful…but the worlds are designed with enough distinct areas that I actually ended up enjoying the little scavenger hunts. The Time Rift levels are pretty short and a series of floating platforms that are “pure platforming,” and they’re really fun. And a little tidbit that goes a LONG way is the game telling you if you don’t have an item to complete a mission instead of leaving you to flounder and find out for yourself.
Now, with the base parts of the game out of the way, we can talk about my favorite part of it: just how alive and real each world feels. Like I mentioned before, every platform is there for a reason because it’s a part of an environment. Buildings, leaves, piles of crates, etc. all feel like a part of the environment first and a platforming challenge second. And, of course, the game uses colors that are appealing to look at and aren’t samey in both light and dark areas. The game gives you a camera for a reason! The most obvious part of the game feeling lively are all of the characters, and not just all of the ones represented in the logo of the game itself. Everyone either is doing something or has something helpful or witty to say, even if they use the same model as another character in the area. A lot of characters have motivations, some silly and some understandable (like in some boss battles, for example). I’ve heard people knock the voice acting, but I think the full voice acting is excellent and helps the “alive” feel exceedingly well, as even the minor “set piece” characters talk and are a joy to listen to instead of having to read a bunch (since this game has a lot of writing for what it is). In fact, only the forest minions, the foxes, and the Chapter 4 people had voices that I didn’t like. And of course the music ties the environment feel up perfectly. Each song is fitting, and even the more subdued and ambient songs are interesting to listen to. The subtle dynamic music per area also helps make each sub-area on a stage feel more unique. Not to mention, the unique title cards for every mission are nice.
This game has collectibles, but it’s not labeled as a collectathon for a reason. To me, the collectibles were really fun platforming challenges to get them, fitting the game’s excellent platforming and giving you more to do in certain areas. You can see most of them since they are surrounded by light (with others being findable with a map badge), so it really does become a matter of “How do I get over/up there?” A little cheat is that the camera badge is helpful for looking around areas, whether they intended that or not. You could get yarn for making new hats, coins to get different clothes colors/hat skins/stage remixes (customization options I love in any game), and relics to unlock Time Rifts. I never needed to stop progress to get yarn for a hat I needed or to unlock a Time Rift, so putting those behind collectibles isn’t a nuisance thankfully. There are badges that you can buy with little orbs strewn around the stage called Pons, but none of them are really NECESSARY and are just nice boosts to have. Another extra are the achievements. Their simplicity makes them fun to go back and do post-game.
The game’s not without flaws, though. They’re all minor, but let’s list my bigger gripes. The Golden Safe mission didn’t make it obvious you could touch it for trails. I never struggled with Pons unlocking some levels, but it seems arbitrary and pauses the fun. If you mess up in a subarea, there’s no Restart Area option and you have to start the WHOLE MISSION over. Getting everything is kinda a nuisance when the game says you have 100% when you get just the Time Pieces, the Relic Badge only shows an arbitrary amount of things, and some things like yarn are inside blow-upable things. The X counter thing felt kinda weird and finicky sometimes. I also feel like the grappling hook is too important to be a badge, even with three badge slots. Smaller complaints include the camera freaking out sometimes and Hat Kid clipping into things, but bugs are bugs. I feel like gold tape around objects didn’t quite scream “You blow this up!” The Ice Hat is criminally underutilized and should’ve been available for Mafia Town where the ice platforms are beautifully placed (but it’s great for bosses). The stealth section lights are shorter than the actual hitbox. 
But despite all this, none of it REALLY got in the way of my enjoyment of the game. Just minor nuisances with some collectibles I can’t be bothered to get for a true 100% completion. Each Time Piece is packed to the brim with fun platforming, environments/characters/music with personality, and little collectibles to go for along the way. I’d say it’s one of the richest games an indie group has put out and makes a name for itself among bigger developers with its charm. I’d say that the full $30 is a great price…but if the low play time makes the price seem not worth it somehow, then definitely pick it up in a sale. It’s an enjoyable experience front to back.

35588858.review:
Absolutely one of my favorite games ever. Probably the only game I've ever 100%'d. I was a slacker backer for the Kickstarter, so I bought my copy like... 2 or 3 years ago? And honestly, it was like a gift from my past self to my present self.

This game made me feel like a kid again. The absolute joy of taking control of Hat Kid for the first time, discovering what kind of jumps and leaps you can do onto platforms. The controls are just so tight and responsive, and everything just works together so well. The worlds are all so incredibly unique, and no mission is like any other. The characters you interact with are well voice-acted and full of character. The bosses you fight are unique and memorable. The music is STELLAR! There is not a single song in the game that I don't love! 

One issue is that the game does not keep track of your progress on certain collectables such as the pages in Time Rifts (unless you're currently in said Time Rift), yarn, or tokens. It's very difficult to tell if you've completely cleaned out a world of its things to do when there's no stats on the menus to tell you. This is pretty minor, as it doesn't really detract of the general experience. It'd just be icing on the cake if they fixed it.

This game is getting workshop soon! Which will involve custom hats as well as custom made levels with modding tools! Meaning that when you're done with the game, you won't truly be done. Even after I 100%'d this game I still want to play more. Hopefully we can get some level ports of Super Mario 64 so we can play through them as Hat Kid!

Overall, the entire game is fantastic. It's unforgettable to me. It made me genuinely feel like I was playing Mario Sunshine for the first time again. It's truly unique, and a great result of a long time development cycle.

35588828.review: You can just feel the passion from the developers in this game.

35588310.review:
A Hat in Time is easily the best game you'll find in this genre on Steam. It managed to bring me back to my childhood right from the beginning, and kept me playing gleefully with its cute characters, excellent writing, and surprisingly great visual design. The gameplay also surprised me as it's probably the most comfortable I've felt with a 3D platformer, my fingers really were an extension of the character. And don't even get me started on the soundtrack; They really knocked it out of the park, it's like the Undertale soundtrack of 2017. It's really just a great fun ride all the way through, and it's clear that a ton of love was put into it. I look forward to coming back to 100% it when online multiplayer is added. 

All that said, there are a bunch of opportunities for more polish, but they're easy to let slide because the game is so fun. Some of the UI elements don't look great scaled up to 1080p for example, and there are a couple missions that I felt were just filler. The subcon forest in particularl is partitioned in a way that made it frustrating for me when I wanted to explore. Nitpicks aside, the game is excellent. Do yourself a favor and jump in.

Another thing that is a great plus is how great the soundtrack is which is a one of the most very important parts of games imo. I hope to see more from Gears for Breakfast if they keep up quality titles like this. Maybe they'll have more to release for this title but all I know, I'm definitely going for 100% on this game.

35587859.review:
A Hat In Time Hearkens back to the days of N64, where 3D platformers ran wild and free. Fondly do I look back upon collecting that next Mumbo Token to unlock the next transformation spell. The days of yore, when collectables abound.

A Hat In Time truly captures what made 3D platformers great, but also modernized the genre. This game often shakes things up in a way you wouldn't expect, transitioning from a 3D platformer, to 2D action with precise controls. Moving around maps is a treat, and the unique characters and themes are wonderful. 

There are a few surprises you'll encounter in the game, one for me was that there is a pretty good amount of difficulty in some areas, necessitating repeating areas. Also there is a pretty terrifying Act in world 3, but I may be more sensitive since I don't play many horror games.


A+

35587802.review:
I wanted to play a 3d platformer that wasn't called good because of diehard fans. There have been a TON of games on Kickstarter that have been funded and didn't seem like I'd even enjoy it, Yooka-Laylee and Mighty No 9 being an example. A Hat in Time was one chance I decided to take after seeing it on Twitter weeks before it came out, I thought it would be a breath of fresh air, and it was indeed that. 

There are a few glitches in the game but that comes with every game, give this a chance. The music is pretty memorable and the characters give so much life to their world that you'd equally enjoy your time in all of them. I'm excited to see whatever is to come in the future from Gears for Breakfast, it was worth the $30.

35587741.review: I've followed the development of this game since it's early days and it became the first game I ever supported on Kickstarter. After years of hype the final product didn't disappoint at all. The gameplay, art, writing, and music are all top notch and any fan of N64 and Gamecube era Nintendo will feel right at home. Even after beating the game and collecting every achievement I've already replayed several levels and boss battles and even want to jump back in for another full playthrough. If you like 3D platformers I can't suggest this game enough, thank you Gears for Breakfast for an amazing game. I can't wait to see what the future holds both for this game and it's developers!

35587699.review: A wonderful game, exceedly and oozing with personality, a game who the lovers of collect-a-thons need to play and try out. This game while it definitely has its inspirations, stands out as its own original IP, and carves its own path in the genre. Though there was a bug or two that annoyed the crap out of me, it was just that a bug. (The bug I'm talking about is the windmill in the Alpine Planes, the one you had to hook onto and wait for it to go up. Mine was moving at an exceedingly slow pace, which made using it multiple times, a pain in the ass.) But other than that, the game itself, excluding the bugs, was amazing. Truly amazing. I've been waiting years for this game, and I can say, this was a kickstarter game that made us have faith in kickstarter in the first place. The music is good, the controls are airtight, that camera is killer, and the story is cute. The characters have personality, which a lot of games lack. There are subtle clues of said personality such as hat kid holding up her little gun hand on the detective mission on the train, showing her more kid-like side. Though she doesn't talk much (besides when picking up stuff), she more than shows enough personality to put a lot of characters in modern gaming to shame. Overall, a recommended game.

35587662.review: I first saw Tanner Of The North play the beta of this game right when it came out 4 years ago. From the second I saw this game I knew this was something very special. I was a sophmore in High School when I saw this game on youtube. I'm in my third year of college now. My life has changed drastically since 2013. I'm not the same man I was in 2013. I can assure you all who are waiting to see how this game turned out after so long. It's worth the wait. A Hat In Time Isn't just the best 3D platformer made this decade (until the 27th) it's one of  the greatest platformers ever made. I've been playing platformers since I could play video games as a toddler. My first experience playing a game was playing Super Mario World on the SNES. Through the years I've played Rachet and Clank, Mario 64, Banjo Kazooie, Mario Sunshine, Prince of Persia, Mario Galaxy, Mario 3D World, Sly Cooper, I've played them all. And after playing those games and hat in time, I can say Hat in Time is not only one of the most polished platformers ever made rivaling Nintendo's pedigree, but it improves upon existing platformers and offers such concise platforming in every level while offering so much glistening cinematics that it far excels most of it's predecessors. Not only this game easy to pick up and play but it offers so much variety and stuck together platforming segments that the fun never ends from start to finish. This game has everything you could ever want out of a platformer. The character design and voice acting is second to none. The platforming is never ending, and the polish is amazing. A Hat In Time is one the greatest games of this decade. Everyone wins. You win for getting a good game. Steam wins for having a killer platformer under their service. Consoles win for having this perfect game ported to their ecosystem. Everyone wins, just BUY THIS GAME ALREADY

35587653.review:
I LOVE this game! If you're a fan of Super Mario 64, Unbox, Poi, or any other 3D platformer, you'll like A Hat in Time. It takes all the best elements of these games and enhances them through big open stages, hats with different abilities, collectables to unlock more stages, and a level where you can answer DICK to every question!

If you are worried this game won't be as good as Super Mario 64, you're right. It's better! Super Mario 64 set the standard for these types of games, introducing a whole slew of elements into the gaming world. A Hat in Time builds and expands on every part of the game, and has a wonderful and whimsical story and interactions to boot. I can't recommend this game enough!

35587552.review: A nostalgic trip that is actually worth it.

35587550.review:
Hat in Time is one of those rare gems that comes out of nowhere, and is a great example of what crowdfunded games can be when the developers really care about the product. This game spent a grueling 5 years in development, and the undying passion throughout those 5 years from the Gears For Breakfast team really shows. Every chapter a with it's own unique personality, and no two acts feel the same despite the fact that you're usually playing on the same map.

This game is a love letter to 3D platforming from the N64/Gamecube era, right down to having Gamecube controller support (seriously, the number of different controllers I can run on this game without configuration is nutty). In many ways I could imagine being a kid and playing this on an oldschool Nintendo system. The controls are really tight and everything feels great. You start off with a whole bunch of movement options and abilities right off the bat. Wall jumps, double jumps, slides, so I don't see repeat playthroughs being frustrating.

Speaking of gameplay mechanics and options, I'd like to give special attention to how much tech there is in this game's movement. The fact that the devs left in an achievement for sequence breaking should tell you everything you need to know. Whenever I wanted to move fast and freely but needed a certain hat for something, I found myself chaining slides to keep my speed up and the levels, although having linier objectives, are designed in such a way where you're rewarded for finding unique ways around them and exploring. You have one primary objective per act but there are loads of small side objectives you can do, such as finding collectables, secrets, or just fun little easter eggs.

Personality wise, this game oozes with it. The dialogue is always spot on and the voice acting is insanely good. I found myself sitting and listening to all the voice acting, even if it meant slowing down the gameplay to enjoy it. The atmosphere in the levels is always perfect, with the music dynamically changing through a lot of the different environments (oh, by the way the soundtrack to this game is phenominal) to just the game generally creating the atmosphere through the gameplay.

A few downsides I will mention, just because I find myself wanting to look at this game critically so it can be improved upon in later patches. First off, I'm two timepieces away from finishing the game. The current build of the game only has 40 timepieces. By the time I finish the game (which unless something supernatural happens will be tomorrow), I will have only gotten four days worth of gameplay out of it. That's not to say that there isn't more I can do. I have the option of grinding out for the rest of the cosmetic items and remixes, and possibly trying the game again with One Hit Hero mode enabled, but for now, that's it. The devs did say they're planning on adding two bonus chapters later down the line in a free update which should hopefully bring our timepiece total to a cool 60 or so, but for now, this is what we have.

There are quite a few bugs left over in this game. Most of them are minor bugs such as small visual glitches, caused as a result of sequence breaking, or just minor things that got overlooked, but there were a couple of times I got stunlocked, or took several consecutive hits from an enemy all within the same few frames, and one time where I straight up got softlocked. Having said that, since the devs have already promised continued development for this game for a little longer, I expect many of these issues will be patched.

All in all though, I will make a couple of bold claims about this game:

1) It's easily in my top 10 favourite games of all time
2) This game is hands down one of the best single player gaming experiences available on Steam, if not one of the best games on Steam period.
