35587497.review:
Allow me to be straight, is this the game to resurrect the 3D platformer genre? No. God no. Far from it, it takes much more than a decent game to do that. With hype abound for Mario Odyssey (Myself included on that hype train), we're all excited for any high quality platforming game. So, ill be very straightforward in this review.

A Hat in Time is a wonderfully made 3D platformer, it nails each aspect of a 3D platformer and does it in spades with seemingly minimal effort! This game is simply a joy to play, it recaptured a part of my heart that was lost long ago. Here are the scores.

Gameplay 11/10
Simply a joy to play. The most important part of literally any game is the Gameplay, and the most important aspect of a 3D platformer is the movement. This game nails gameplay with flying colours!! The movement is fluid and becomes second nature! Each time I play this damn game i cant stop running around in circles or finding new areas to explore and find, this game has a few secrets too! It encourages explorative nature, but it also discourages it in a sense (Ill move into that a bit later). You have a group of worlds to explore, this game is HIGHLY derivitive of Mario Sunshine and BanjoKazooie, so much so to its detriment! This game has a severe loss of identity, as it tries too hard in the opening worlds to be like Super Mario Sunshine 2! It tries waaay to hard to be Mario Sunshine, and it really hurts because this game can stand on its own two adorable legs. When you unlock more worlds, you see the identity in this game, this quirky and really fucking funny game is a marvel at times!

Music 8/10
Not the worst soundtrack ever, but definitely not the best. Some tracks drone on in the background, while others dont match the mood of the overall world at all. The music is servicable and, in some cases, beautiful, but its nothing stellar. Dont buy THIS games soundtrack unless you really want some upbeat drone to listen to, and NO thats not a bad thing! The music is upbeat and is always pleasant, but it just drones all the time and rarely changes. When it does change, its jarring and not fluid at all in some cases, and fluid and welcome in others! Its hit or miss for me, but when it comes to the quality of the music? Thats where it gets its points from. Each track is good on its own in an isolated environment, but if you listen to it while youre playing the game, it can deliver mixed feelings.

Aesthetic 10/10
Positively marvellous, the careful symbiosis between Graphical style and Gameplay style is struck immediately in this game! No point in the game is odd, even the one actually creepy level i played made wonderful use of the graphical style, making it a very creepy game even with its absolutely adorable art style! Hat Girl is one of the cutest characters made in gaming to date, I say that in full body and mind, me and my friend marathon'd this game over the course of 8 hours (My internet was down during the first 3) and we simply couldnt stop saying "This game is adorable" and where it isnt adorable its just plain pleasant! The mobsters are so damn cute I cant hate them! The ghosts had me saying "awww" al the time! You cant go wrong with this games cartoony and colourful artstyle!

Sound 9/10
For the most part, the nail is hit on the head with voice acting and sound clips, but there is one instance where it feels a bit weird. The primary antagonist in the game, Mustache Girl, her voice is a bit weird to hear coming out of the character. Accents are also something that is a bit weird, but I can easily look passed that. The voice acting is absolutely top notch, one level is set in a spooky forest, and the primary enemy in it is a sinister large ghost who's voice actor has the PERFECT EVIL LAUGH!! And his voice is actually intimidating, so to hear him say all these adorable things and throwing out small cute quips here and there, it successfully makes an endearing character! This game nails that aspect again with flying colours, minus a few characters here and there. Two in particular are a bit annoying, Mustache Girl herself and the Owl in the second world. Other than that, marvellous.

Performance 9/10
I have an Intel Core i-5 2500k processor and an NVIDIA Quadro 1000m graphics processor, its not a bad PC and it gets me by with Indie titles. I had a lot of chug on higher settings but when i bumped all settings aside from character detail down to the lowest itll go, I was perfectly fine throughout the game. Now, depending on your PC, I would say stave off till the console releases, but if you truly cant wait and are sure you can deal with some frame drops here and there, youre fine. It runs very well in most cases, and only struggles during highly taxing scenes. This is MY pc too, I had my Girlfriend test it on hers (She's got a magnificent PC with an i-7 6700k and NVIDIA GTX 1080i on hers), and she had absolutely NO issues throughout the game, only dropping to 30 on some parts and it was only for a second or two.

Verdict 9/10 - 10/10
This game is an absolute marvel, get it on PC and its about a 9/10 but get it on Console and im positive itll be a 10/10. And with updates coming along that add modding support and coop, you will NOT regret your 30 dollar purchase of this game. I didnt go over everything, mainly because I wanted to stave off a few details, but there are a few Ill mention before we wrap things up.
 This games primary gimmick is the acquisition of hats, which give special abilities. Hats are limited to each stage you find them in, as in you wont find like the Time-Stop hat in world 2 or anything like that, but you do find yarn to create hats in each and every single world. Now this is cool in concept but I personally have issues with that, as finding Yarn can be difficult at times and piss-easy at others. It makes you reconsider grabbing on piece of yarn over another because that piece is on a tree branch that takes 5 minutes to get to, or you can go get the one frozen in ice with an explosive literally right next to it. Its annoying how hard it is to get 1 single piece of yarn while you can get 5 perfectly fine with NO effort whatsoever in other worlds. 
Another small issue is Boss Fights. Some are imaginative and interesting while others are so damn boring. My least favorite thus far was the fight with the primary Ghost Boss. Its visually impressive, yes, but its also incredibly tedious. I dont like how long these boss fights are either, you have 2-3 phases, and well thats good but also thats bad. You'd think 3 hits to get into the next phase, but one boss was like 5 hits while another felt like fucking 20! its infuriating to say the least. But, the boss figths arent BORING in any sense of the word, they are all fun and impressive visually, absolutely wonderful on most occasions. 
All in All buy this game if youre confident in your PC, if not, I would say wait until you're certain or await its arrival on PS4 and XBONE. You cant go wrong, best 30 dollars Ive spent nearly all year!

35587431.review:
A Hat in Time is the platonic ideal of joy and fun translated into a series of ones and zeroes. 

I backed this project on Kick Starter four years ago. Even with all the disappointments that Kick Starter has delivered, whenever I checked back in on A Hat in Time, I was confident it would turn out great. And yeah, it did.

I think the one thing that makes or breaks any platformer is controls, camera, and movement. If any of those are bad, then the game immediately falls apart, no matter how good the level design, art, or music is. And A Hat in Time controls like a dream. There wasn't ever a single time that I got frustrated while moving Hat Kid around the levels. Every jump, dive, and attack felt incredibly smooth and natural.

And yeah, what you've heard is true. This game has charm coming out of its ears, eyes, nose, ass, and toes. Every level has some new delight to share. Subcon Forest is absolutely one of my favorite gaming worlds of all time.

After a 100% run, I only wish there was more. Whether that comes in the form of a sequel, DLC, or fan-made levels, I'm itching to get more!

35585658.review:
Every world in this game is completely different and every mission is lovingly crafted and interesting: there is no filler here. You’d be surprised how varied the tasks you do are, considering the genre: One minute you’re ziplining through a vast mountain range above the clouds, and the next you’re solving a murder mystery or hiding from horrors in a creepy manor. The only other example of this kind of variety I can think of is Psychonauts.

The movement is precise and fluid. Hat Kid is so much fun to control. This aspect is very reminiscent of Super Mario 64 and Sunshine, unlike the stiffness of, say, Banjo-Kazooie. Unlike Mario however, Banjo-Kazooie (and Tooie)’s strength was its interesting world full of personality, which is what A Hat in Time excels at as well. It has the best of both worlds.

As for the downsides, the camera freaks out in tight quarters fairly often, but you never feel like you need to fight it. It’s merely a visual annoyance. In some levels the depth of field effect is quite aggressive, and you unfortunately can’t turn it all the way off. (UPDATE: Now you can!)

The soundtrack is 5 hours of pure perfection. The game oozes joyful charm and maintains a consistently amazing experience from beginning to end. Also Hat Kid is hecking cute. I enjoyed every minute of my first 17-hour playthrough with this game.

TL;DR: This game is one of the best 3D platformers of all time.

P.S. Two extra chapters and co-op mode coming later as free DLC!

35585390.review:
Let me just tell you something right now.
A Hat in Time is more than just an attempt to bring the 3D Platformer genre back.
It's more than just a "Gamecube Love-Letter". I never even owned a Gamecube. In fact, I didn't even grow up with Nintendo so I haven't even played a lot of the games that inspired this (Psychonauts being one of the few exclusions).
So, what reason did I have to care?
Well, I did grow up on platformers from the PS1 & PS2 era, so I can say without a hesitation that the 3D platforming genre is one of my favorites in gaming.
But my love for this game goes beyond that.
The things I love most in this game are the things that give it its own identity.: Its world, its characters, its atmosphere, and its personality.
It's easy for someone to look at this game and think "Oh, that's like Mario Sunshine" or "Oh, that's like Thousand Year Door", but to someone who's never played those games, I was drawn to it by its beautiful artstyle, brilliant and hilarious writing, and not to mention its spectacular soundtrack and, of course, the game itself... just looked fun! And I got into it nearly 3 years ago when the alpha build with only 2 levels was out!
The game in no way is trying to bank on nostalgia. One of my biggest problems with Yooka-Laylee was how much I personally felt like an outsider to the whole thing because I had never played a Banjo game. The nostalgia card has never really been a trick that works on me. I mean, it also probably doesn't help that Yooka-Laylee's problems gor way beyond its nostalgia-pandering. Thankfully aside a handful of glitches I ran into (only one of which was slightly game-breaking, but thankfully I had the developer console turned on so I could get myself out of it) and and some minor frame-rate stuttering and visual oddities (likely linked to the fact that my PC's specs are slightly below the recommendations listed for the game), the game is overall structurally solid. And you have to cut these guys a little slack. It's a Kickstarter game made by a small group of people, which actually seg-ways into my next ponit... (You're still reading this, right?)
I was also drawn to this game by the amazing people who worked on it. Jonas, Habboi, Jenna, Pascal, Aruki and others whom I can't think of right now- You're all wonderful people and it is truly more than admirable that you all devoted so much of your time and energy into making the best game that you can. I think other indie developers- no, the entire games industry- can learn a few things from all of you. I love you all and I can't wait to see what you have in store for the future!

But I'm sure there's a question still hanging in the back of some of your minds: Should I get A Hat in Time?
Yes.
I don't care if you didn't grow up with the games that inspired it.
I don't care if this genre isn't your thing.
I don't care if you have some sort of negative bias towards Kickstarter games because this game will prove you wrong.
I don't care if you're 12 and all you play is COD and Madden.
You need to play this game.
If your PC can't run it, wait for the console release. I don't care. Just play it.
A Hat in Time is a landmark for indie games and I predict it will be rememberred and celebrated for many years to come.

35585234.review:
After Yooka-Laylee launched, I was worried people would write this game off before it got a chance to show the world what it was like. This was mainly because of the fact that their kickstarter campaigns set out with the same goals in mind, heck, even I started to get sceptical. But after I debating whether to buy this game or not, I took the plunge and went for it and I have never been so glad to be wrong about a game in my life.

Everything about this game oozes charm to a level that I haven't seen from a game in a long time, in an age where everything wants to be dark and gritty when it isn't on a nintendo platform. I am not lying when I say I have spent all my time with this game smiling, with never a dull moment, which is why this will probably be the only review I ever write, I just want to share my love for this game. 

The two games that are clearly the driving factors for the overall design are Mario64 and Banjo (to a lesser extent). 

Mario64 has clearly influenced the level design and the movement, creating an extremely fun and fluid experience playing as hat girl, but with the world design itself it is a whole different ball game. Starting in Mafia town, I was pretty sure it was heavily going down the "Pick a mission and it does something to the large level but it stays mostly the same", but as soon as you hit the Dead Bird Studios world (Which follows a split path level design that ends up rejoining for a final level in a way I don't want to spoil) I was blown away. Both of the elements taken from Mario64 have been rethought and redesigned into something unique, that feels like a perfect fit for a modern take on what game designers were trying to achieve when making old platformers.

Banjo definitely has an influence in the collectible aspect of the game, and perhaps even the overall world building style. The collectibles in this game feel fantastic to collect, straight from the little dinking noises as you pick up gems, to the beautiful music slowdowns as you near a time piece to beat a level, and the snapping of hatgirls fingers as she picks up a ball of yarn to make a new hat from. I just couldnt deal with not being able to collect everything in one level befre moving onto the next. When it comes to the world style, everything about this game feels unique, the art style and animations, as well as the amazing voice acting (Props to the VA in the forest level) tie up into a cohesive world that, like banjo, feels nothing alike any of its peers and stands out beautifully from the other games I see lining the steam store.

Ontop of all these things, nothing is left feeling uninspiring, I just didnt want the game to end, and with free support and updates in the future, I await to play even more of this game. It is everything I had hoped that would make a comeback, and more, and I really hope that it is a success on steam. When this goes on sale, I will undoubtedly be buying it again to force my naysayer friends to play this amazing game.

I wish the team the best of luck with future development and hope this game is a kick in the teeth to all the big developers out there that churn out the same unrelenting garbage each year without even trying to innovate.

Hope this review can help at least on person on the edge pick up this game and enjoy it as much as I did :)

35583104.review:
An adorable game that controls well and isn't afraid to have you explore their worlds. It's more than just some indie game, it's a game supported by a community that wants to see motivated creators at their full potential, and those creators delivered. 
I thought this game had a good balance entertaining both a younger and older audience, members that want fun challenges and those that want to see what GfB is capable of providing on various aspects. Incredibly appealing visually using the Unreal engine, The storyline is fun and simple with moments that really emphasize whatever themes they're shooting for. [i] Seriously, this game had me tearing up, sweating bullets through the palms of my hands, and genuinely happy. And these moments aren't scarce and scattered far apart from each other, that's not something I can say for most games. [/i]
There are certain aspects I do have to be critical of though. 
Character design was great for most characters, but some models were a bit disappointing, especially for one of my favorite characters. For a spooky shadow spirit, the Snatcher felt too simple. Would have loved to have seen him abuse his ability to change into different forms, but he was pretty much just a blob with a smile throughout the whole game. For a shadow creature trying to scare others into signing his contracts, it would be great to see him have an intimidating figure when he's introduced and have him revert to his normal simple form when he can be himself around you. You got bird blobs with beaks that get boring after smacking 100 of them off your platforms. 
Character designs that I enjoyed were the twitchy Pin Peddler, the birds of World 2, and the two main girls. Pin Peddler guy gave me goosebumps, realizing that there are dimensions that leave a permanent mark upon visiting them kinda makes one hesitant when diving into adventure. He's a real nice contrast to the main character, a care free kid with a simple quest. Nice seeing the owls in different outfits, wasn't a fan of seeing the same model of Mafia Men on every side of the 1st World.

I gotta say, I enjoyed this game (and still am). If the $30 price is too steep, I definitely recommend keeping an eye out for when this game is on sale or a loose pocket if you're pickpocket skill's high enough.

35582335.review:
a bit of background info: this game was crowd funded on kickstarter back in 2014 and since then, some former rareware devs who worked on the hit game Banjo Kazooie worked together as Playtonic Games and made an entire spiritual successor to banjo kazooie caled Yooka-Laylee which was criticized as being underwhelming with repetitive character apperences, lack luster level design, and too much of a cash grab on the nostalgia factor. both of which had kickstarter campaigns and while most kick starter games fail this one however did not.

the game itself: The game has 4 worlds and while that seems small they are very much content filled, each world has unique and memorable characters. You will find yourself either growing to love them or growing to hate them, you certainly wont forget them as generic_background_character_a. each world offers a unique gameplay experience that doesn't intimidate with its wild differences but also doesn't allow for the game to feel stale after 1 level. a criticism I had on yooka laylee was exactly that. you can swap between your hats to offer you differnt abilities and you can attach badges to the hats to offer you different passives. theres also ways to collect different cosmetic styles of each hat and/or color palletes for hat girl. fantastic user interface when it comes to swaping between hats, very simple and intuative

gripes: I will admit I am a bit dispaointed with a few things, the controls can feel clunky if playing with a mouse and keyboard, ive found myself failing jumps when it comes jumping around on platforms to advance up, though that might just be a me issue. ive managed to beat it with 60% completion in 12 hours however free DLC is on the way as well as very wide workshop support in "a week or so" (?)

what i liked: It felt like its own game in the collectathon genre and didn't feel like Banjo-Threeie... which turned out to be a good thing. I did like the "ooo-aaa-ee-aa" sounds replicated in yooka laylee but the full voice acting really brought life into the characters i otherwise wouldn't have gotten. the camera function is really fun and i found myself taking a lot of photos. I also liked that jontron's voice is still in the game.

notes for early access players: if you played the early access, really kinda forget about everything you experienced in it. any of the levels you played were polished and actual story/cinematic work was added in. there are definately a lot more levels than the early access build had.

would i reccomend: yes

35581878.review:
This is not an exceptionally long game (I'm at over 80% done after a leisurely 11 and a half hours), but don't let that stop you. The characters you encounter are interesting in a cartoony way, it has an cute and varied aesthetic, the platforming is engaging, and each area has different mechanics and ways of appealing to you (and, at times, it s willing to use slightly darker tones, which gives good contrast to the more upbeat levels). 

While there not nearly as many collectables as Banjo-Kazooie or Donkey Kong 64, almost all the collectables give you some little reward like a art piece for your ship, music remixes, or new aesthetic items for Hat Girl. (I liked Banjo, but the series had a lot of low points in the interest curve with the million little things to collect for little reason)  

So while it may not be nearly as long as Banjo-Kazooie, it maintains a level of appeal throughout the experience that other collectathons have struggled with.

35581645.review:
if you're looking for a traditional collectathon in the same vein of mario 64 or banjo kazooie, look elsewhere, because a hat in time is ultimately a completely different style of 3d platformer. that being said, the game is still one of the most enjoyable games ive played this year. the game does have quite major issues, but the stuff that is good far outweighs the bad.

first off, the movement is responsive. this isnt a mario 64 situation where you can accidentally end up doing the wrong move (e.g groud pounding when you meant to long jump) or slipping off of a platform because of marios inconsistent turning radius. you stop and turn on a dime, and moves being assigned to their own buttons instead of being context sensitive means every move you do is deliberate.

however, in terms of the sheer amount of movement options you have, hat in time is somewhat lacking compared to other games in the genre. when you boil it down, all you can really do is jump, dive, and wall run. this limited moveset does mean that levels are fully designed around your abilities, there are no "optional" moves here, and the level design is much tighter as a result. however this also makes even the most open-ended levels in the game feel a little more restrictive. how severe this issue is entirely depends on the person playing, personally i didn't mind so much because most of the levels are semi-linear anyway, and the movement options that are there are fun to control and can be chained together fluidly.

in terms of level design, it varies drastically from chapter to chapter. the opening level, "mafia town", is a sandbox level that is exploration oriented, "battle of the birds" is a series of 5 (completely unique) linear levels with one mini-sandbox inbetween, "subcon forest" goes back to the open-ended level design, and then "alpine skyline" is also a series of linear levels, except the levels are all contained within one "area" with no loading screens or menus, and you can freely choose the order in which you do them. there's also the final level, but thats literally just a corridor leading up to the final boss with some platforming along the way.

all of this variety keeps the game feeling fresh, and i personally enjoyed every level. however, only two chapters and one act of the game actually feel like collectathon levels, the rest is significantly more linear. again, i enjoyed the linear levels just as much as the non-linear ones, but i know for some people this may, understandably, be disapointing

the thing that i know a lot more people will find disapointing is the length. mind you this isnt something you can beat in one sitting, its longer than a lot of triple A games, hitting the 10-15 hour mark to 100%, but compare this games 4 chapters to mario 64s 15 levels, or this games 40 mcguffins to most collectathons standard of 100, and it becomes apparant that the game really could have done with some more content. not exactly a fair comparison because one level in 64 was literally just two small rooms of water connected with a tunnel, while the levels in a hat in time are much larger, but even just one or two more levels would make the game feel of a decent length. thats why im very glad that there is going to be two free dlc levels, and workshop support, but i can't let the game off because of content that isn't there yet.

the visuals of the game are my other complaint besides length. i'm by no means qualified in this sort of thing, so i don't know how to correctly articulate this, but some parts of this game just look extremely cluttered. mafia town and alpine skyline are the main culprits. when your running around them they look just fine, but look at them from a distance and to me its just a mess of colours thats very difficult to read visually. its really not a big deal, and other people don't seem to have an issue with it, so don't let it put you off the game. 

the music in the game is consistently good. every track fits their respective level, with one exception. for some reason the track "turn on the pyrotechnics", a track that plays during a certain section of a parade level, has a fast tempo, harsh instrumentation, and use of a descending chromatic scale. all this turns the joyous and lively atmosphere thats supposed to be present into a intense and sinister atmosphere, that is frankly quite jarring. that is literally the only track in the entire OST that doesn't fit its level, everything else is solid. the tracks "mafia town is asleep", the main theme, and "clocktowers beneath the sea" are the highlights for me, and the "timepiece released" track caught me off guard with how relaxing it is, its the perfect music for the end of a level.

overall, a hat in time is pretty darn good. it says a lot when my only major complaint with a game is that there isn't enough of it, which isn't even going to be an issue in the long term because the game has full mod support and extra content coming soon. like i said before, it didn't quite end up as the collectathon it was supposed to be earlier in development, and if you judge it as such you might end up disapointed, but if you judge it for what it is, its solid and well crafted from a game design standpoint, and its genuinely enjoyable as an experience thanks to its abundance of charm and creativity (that ive been trying to avoid spoiling). if your the kind of person who buys based on the amount of content, as the game is now its understandable to wait for a price drop, but if you buy purely based on how much you enjoy a game, its absolutely worth paying full price.

This game is so good! 

I've only completed 22% of the game according to the game select screen but this game has got me hooked already. A majority of my early gaming experience was through playing games such as Super Mario 64, Banjo Kazooie, DK64 etc. Nintendo 64 being my first console. This game has taken me back to when I first played those games. 

The music is outstanding, they don't seem to make games with such enjoyable music anymore - a personal favourite so far was the ice bonus stage (The Gallery - Time Rift), though as I said above, I haven't yet experienced the entire game so no doubt there is more great music to come.

35580193.review:
I saw a glimpse of this game early in 2017 and thought it looked fun. I then sort of forgot about it, all up until it released 2 days ago. Now, having beaten it, I have to say that A Hat in Time will easily find its place in my top 5 games of 2017 list!

The game is a traditional collect-a-thon platformer, that draws heavily on classic 3D platformers. In my mind the heaviest influencers would be Super Mario 64, Banjo & Kazooie and lastly, but certainly not least: Psychonauts! This last inspiration becomes most obvious in a certain train-related level that I enjoyed immensely! It is also the influence of Psychonauts that sets this game apart from most other collect-a-thons of recent years.

The writing in A Hat in Time is not perfect, though, and I feel like it is struggling to decide on its audience. For the most part the game is funny and whimsical and could be considered an 'all ages' experience, but occasionally the game slips into using darker themes. At one point you are literally ordered to 'murder' a bunch of spirits. At other points another character openly suggests dismembering enemies, and towards the end of the game even character suicide becomes a thing, in a way. It seems that the writing tries to mostly go for a more mature audience, those adults like myself who's nostalgia for the 90's and early 00's this game feeds. Your mileage may wary, but in my case I found myself laughing out loud at many of the jokes in this game.

The gameplay is nothing too special. You run, jump, double jump, dive, then jump again. It's a bit surprising how much freedom of movement you have from the word go, and how much more the game expands as time goes on. New abilities are granted through, what else: hats! One hat lets you see into the spirit world, another turns you into a heavy ice statue, another yet lets you sprint fast or even ride around on a cute scooter!

That last one brings us to the most obvious thing about the game, though it is a point that bears repeating: this game is CUTE! The art style is impeccable and I was surprised to see the Unreal engine used in this way. The game is not without faults, though, and there are a few points in the game where you can see the engine not quite adapting to the style the developers wanted to deliver. However, for the most part, the game makes sure you don't get to see these shortcomings for more than a split second before moving you right along. 

In the end, whether or not you will enjoy this game comes down to your nostalgia factor. If those old games I mentioned before, Mario 64, Banjo&Kazooie or Psychonauts tickle your fancy, then A Hat in Time may very well do you a world of good. If those games were not for you, or you never experienced them in their day, then the nostalgia-pandering of this game might end up irritating you in the long run and many of the jokes might not open up to you. 

Still, I recommend the game and feel like this might end up being one of those rare games that even I 100% over time.

Playtime: 9+ hours (Single playthrough, 65+% completion)

Ratings (1-10)
Visual: 8
Audio: 9
Story: 10
Gameplay: 9
Overall: 9

35580186.review:
Okay, I haven't played Yooka-Laylee so I can't compare the two games. Regardless though...

A Hat in Time is one of my most favorite 3D platformer out right now (Not counting the classics.)

I think the art style is quite appealing and many of the worlds were beautiful to look at and explore. Chapter 1's Mafia town is admittedly a bit boring in comparison to other worlds and I found myself preferring anywhere else but there just because everywhere else was more interesting to me. The haunted Forests of Subcon Valley, movie sets of Dead Bird Studios, and the vast islands of Alpine Skyline was where I think the game shined and had me lost the most.

The collectables are fun to chase after and I found myself 100% completing the game. However 100% is a lie. It doesn't take into account the hidden Rift Tokens so that bites. There's also no good way of making sure you grabbed everything. No tracker for Yarns Balls so that also doesn't fall into the 100% complete and by the end I had every hat crafter but still 25 freaking yarns leftover. What's the point?

The music was really great listening to and getting a hold of the remixes through the Orb Machine was nice so you get some music variety in the levels. Customization was also great when you unlocked Hat Styles and Color Schemes. Howeve it's held back by the fact that all Styles, Remixes, and Color schemes are hidden behind a Slots style mini-game that uses Rift Tokens or you get a free one for beating a rift. There's a limited amount of Tokens and tries at the Slots and there's no current way I see of getting every customization item. Taking away against from completionists that want true 100%.

Story is lacking and it sounds like there's a build up between you an early ally, but then they never bring her up again until the ending. Clearly this was not the focus of the game. I enjoyed the little stories I got in each world with their respective main NPCs though. The final fight lacked the proper build up though in my opinion even though I loved the fight.

There's even an issue of the game's title. "A Hat in Time." Well aside from collecting the Time Pieces, there wasn't much of any focus on time in the game. Were we on a time limit for Hat Kid to get home? Is Hat Kid a time traveler? Never quite touched on. Time elements were just really few and far between. It's only there to justify your "rival's" motivation for wanting the Time Pieces.

Hat Kid herself is a fun and cute character. But that's where it ends sadly. She seems to have 0 concern about anyone else and simply wants her Time Pieces back. And that's fine, she's a neutral party. As the game currently is though, we don't know enough about Hat Kid to really care about her goal or understand her. Why is getting home important? We were shown and told nothing.

While it does sound like I've railed on this game, I can't help but still love it to bits. I sunk myself into finding everything and loved the other worlds out there and simply being lost in exploration. The controls aren't the tightest I've played with but that didn't matter to me. I had my fun running and jumping and never felt I messed something up or took damage because a control didn't funciton right. It was afun ride and I enjoyed most of the characters I was preented with.

Hands down though, the Crows are the best characters. Sorry, I meant my fellow Express Owls.

Overall 8/10 for me. Loved my time with it, but the areas that felt lacking hold the game back from earning a 10/10 in my book. I still reccomend the game a lot though. To me, it was worth backing it and I paid a higher price than $29.99 so at this price, it's quite worth it to me.

A Hat in Time est un jeu créé et developpé par le studio Gears for Breakfast !

Financé sur Kickstarter depuis 2013, ce jeu est le tout premier du studio ! Et après 4 ans d'attente, il est enfin sorti !

Et qu'est-ce-qu'il est bon !

Le gameplay est fun, les environnements très colorés et bien pensés, des personnages tous plus loufoques les uns que les autres ! Les musiques sont énormes !

C'est LE plateformer 3D que l'on attendait, après la déception que fut Yooka-Laylee, nous nous retrouvons enfin avec un très bon jeu, qui a certes, pris du temps, mais il est juste parfait !

La particularité de ce titre sont les chapeaux, qui une fois collectés, nous donnent un pouvoir spécial ! 

Néanmoins, il y a quelques défauts : 

- Langue unique, bon après c'est de l'anglais donc allez en cours et vous comprendrez !

- On est obligé de faire des quêtes "secondaires" pour battre le dernier boss !

Sinon, le jeu est très bon, et j'y ai joué 5 heures de suite sans m'en apercevoir !

Si je devais noter A Hat in Time, je lui donnerai un 18/20, si vous aimez les bon plateformers 3D, foncez, c'est le jeu que vous attendiez !

35578732.review:
I want to start this review off by saying, "If you don't have a controller DO NOT buy this game".

Overall, my experience with this game (in the short time I have played) has been positive. The game is fun, it has lovely graphics and artwork, and the controls feel responsive. That said, the reason I have played so little (just over an hour at the time of writing this) is because of the control lay out being very poor for keyboard controls. Two highly required controls lie on the Ctrl and the Shift keys, making using them awkward and tricky, making parts of the game far more difficult and frustrating than they should be. 

Does that make this a bad game? No. Doesn that mean that I will stop playing the game? No (I intend to buy a controller). Would I recommend the game? Yes, just not to anyone who wants to use keyboard controls.

EDIT:
Having now got a controller, I can now say that playing this game is a delight! The controls are much easier, the game plays well, and although at times the game can be frustrating, I never feel like the game is conning me, just that I'm bad at the game, which in my opinion is very important for a platformer!

35575631.review:
I backed this as a kickstarter project all the way back in 2013, and I can wholeheartedly say that I am glad that it took Gears For Breakfast 4 years to make this game. The level of charm and polish in here is unrivaled, and almost every level in the game has an incredibly unique concept and brilliant execution. Chapters 1, 2, 3, and the Chapter 5 boss fight are phenomenal. ESPECIALLY the boss fights of Chapters 2 and 3. However, the only problem that I have with this game is the lack of unique concepts in Chapter 4. You get hit by masterpiece after masterpiece after masterpiece and then Chapter 4's gimmick is that you can zipline. Wow. In Chapter 2 there is a level where you solve the mystery of the murder of an owl on a moving train while you must avoid detection from the crows that are guarding the evidence. But actually, it is a movie that you are in to help the director win the bird film awards against his rival director who is a disco penguin named DJ Grooves. Aaaand in Chapter 4 you zipline. See the contrast? 
This game took me 14.9 hours to beat, collect every collectible, and get every achievment. I would give A Hat In Time a 9.5/10, and recommend it to anybody who enjoys 3D platformers.

Does the game have problems though? Yes.
-Some of the voice-work is kinda bad, though that is balanced out by some very stellar performances with some characters. And most of cast sounds fine.
-Camera is a bit wonky at points, but it's not bad. Just expect the standard 3D platformer yank.
-There's no easy way to see how many minor collectibles you're missing from each level. This one really sucks, if you are planning to go for absolute 100%. If you just want your file to display 100% clear, I guess it's not a problem since that only counts the Time Pieces, and not the Rift Tokens or Yarns.
-I don't think there is a way to change the control mapping? Which is really weird, given how good rest of the settings are.

But really, the positives far outweight the negatives. If you are into 3D platformers and objective based collect-a-thons, I totally recommend this.

35574894.review:
It's time for my Review.

I finished the game just now and it's so much better than what I first thought would await me. Do you remember games like Sonic Adventure DX that tried to tie Story and 50 minigames into one? It failed at that and couldn't deliver. A Hat in Time however, completely does. From racing portions to horror sections, sky exploration to mail delivery, Hat Kid goes on an adventure to return all of the Timepieces after a tragic accident involving her and a planet's Mafia. 

Throughout the Adventure, you will be spoiled with a wonderful, colorful word, funny and sweet portions of comedy, an engaging gameplay Experience filled with optional, yet rewarding pieces that will make your time playing this game just so much more exciting.

The soundtrack of A Hat in Time, partially composed by Grant Kirkhope, THE Grant, the same man who composed for Banjo & Kazooie and other popular Rare titles of the past, adds life to the visual style of the game. The spooky bits are filled with spooky music, the lively towns emit joyful tunes.

If your friends haven't recommended this game to you yet, I hope I can convince you to at least 'try' the game out. If you don't like the first hour, you can still refund the game.

After talking to the developers and artists for many hours, I really couldn't feel bad about spending 30 bucks on a game again. It's been a wonderful experience and the money goes to forthcoming people that put their heart into the game.

Sadly, some portions of the game were sometimes confusing (The spooky world more than once) and glitchy, which subtracts from the overall Rating I am giving this game:

9/10

The game's length is just acceptable for an indie developer team that worked on it for so many years. Their heart and souls went into making this a good game and in the future we can expect more updates! If that doesn't convince you to buy it, what will? You're basically paying for a full game + free content to come along the way!

35572273.review:
A Hat in Time plays very well and has extremely fluid movement and satisfying controls, but the gameplay itself suffers. If you're buying this for a collect-a-thon, you should look elsewhere. Lots of misdirection, illusion of freedom and blatantly linear segments. From what I can tell, the beta seemed to be a lot more appealing and open ended. For its price, a Hat in Time isn't worth the amount of content it offers. The game isn't half as open or fun to explore as it makes itself out to be with the first world. Combat is an afterthought, NPC and enemy variety is very slim, and there's only five worlds. 

Overall, it just doesn't have a lot of personality beyond being cute and having funny voices. This review may change depending on how the free DLC goes over. As it stands on launch, save your money for something with more personality and soul. If you want a better platformer, play Mario Sunshine. If you want a better collect-a-thon, play Banjo Kazooie. If you've exhausted those and need something new to scratch the old-school 3D platforming itch, this might do something for you. Just don't expect anything standout or genre-defining.

Edit: Eh, some of the custom levels are better than the official ones, but honestly the user created challenges only make the shaky mechanics even more clear. You'll constantly be trying to pull off tricky wall run/jumping manuevers only to fall and not run at all. Lots of frustration with the wall running. This game handles like it's unfinished, but you might not realize that until you play custom levels.

35571830.review:
This game is really something special.  There are games that look better graphically, sure.  There are games with bigger budgets, more insane AAA setpieces, and even longer games.  But there are few games out there with the kind of heart that A Hat in Time has.  It isn't just a Mario or Banjo clone (though the DNA of those games is certainly present). It is also its own game, and am I really glad it is.

I have seen many a comparison to Mario Sunshine, but that's just the beginning.  The different levels act as homages to different platform games in some ways, I suppose.  Mafia Town could be a Mario Sunshine stage, but the second level is more like a Psychonauts stage and so on.  

I don't want to say too much else, but if you like games with heart and are willing to put up with a few technical problems to enjoy the kind of game that doesn't come along very often, A Hat In Time is something you just need to play.  It won't be a critical success and won't sell millions of copies, but it will be a cult classic and in a few years everyone will be telling you that you should play it, like Psychonauts before it.

35564521.review:
After years of waiting since backing on Kickstarter I'm left disappointed. The game's length, quality and amount of content are severly lacking.

A Hat In Time is a return to 3D platforming collect-a-thons of yore, akin to what the recent Yooka-Laylee sought to bring back. It cribs heavily off of Super Mario 64 and Sunshine while adding it's own unique spin on things and it mostly succeeds. However, the game super inconsistant in quality and game design and kinda grew stale quickly.

Let me start with the gameplay, the Kid controls fairly well with controls being very responsive and giving you a lot of moves to play with and make your way around the levels. However, certain things get really frustrating because the camera isn't that great, sometimes it's really hard to hell where the Kid is in the middle of a jump because you might not be able to see your shadow and the wall climb/jump is terrible. If you jump towards a wall you'll run up a bit and you have the option to jump off or just slide down the wall. Jumping off the wall leads to a really, really small jump that almost doesn't get you any height and you can't control the direction of it at all, it's always perpendicular off of the wall. You also don't get your double jump back after doing this which you probably should since it'd help.

Most of your moves come in the form of different hats that you knit after finding bundles of yarn, it's pretty interesting but there's no method to this progression. Every yarn bundle looks different, one representing each of the different hats. Once you get a new yarn bundle, you now have a "blueprint" for that hat and any subsequent bundles of the same look just count as a "plus one" on your yarn counter, meaning that any other bundle, no matter what it looks like will contribute to the creation of any hat. It doesn't take long to find every hat bundle and just make all of the hats (if you've been good on finding the bundles). Also, a lot of the hats don't have much of a purpose. One of the first ones you get allows you to run faster, but it's not that much faster and really isn't worth using. The last hat in the game allows you to stop time briefly, but it only has a single use for the entire game and I can't think of any other reason why you'd want to use it. The hat powers are great, but they're not well untilized.

Onto the levels, there's only four and they're not that great. The first level is quite large and sprawling with a lot of visual interest. The second one takes place in a movie studio and has some clever ideas, but nearly every mission is it's own secluded section that's incredibly short. The third is a large forest with a lot of barriers you have to take down but when you do, you're left with a largely empty creepy forest without much in it and it can be confusing to navigate because everything just looks the same. The fourth is an utterly massive level that takes place on the peaks of themed mountain tops but the whole level is "free roam" without any interesting missions or characters to interact with you're left to your own devices to find the various timepieces yourself. It feels pretty lazy. There is a fifth "level" is just the final boss area which is incredibly short, think of the area right before Bowser in Super Mario Sunshine. Other than that there's also several small secluded challenge levels that are all themed exactly the same and really don't have anything to do with the levels they're attached to.

Content: There just isn't enough of it, at 2~ hours of game time I managed to beat the final boss with only optional mopping up to do if I cared to get the 100%. I played for four more hours trying and managed to get to 90% and I won't be going back because I'm already bored of the experience. Also, a lot of the collectibles are pointless, I have all of the hats so all of the extra yarn is pointless to collect and everything else is just cosmetic items that don't even count towards your completion precentage. I believe there's 40 "timepieces" (think Stars in Mario games) and you only need 25 to beat the game.

The good: The music is great (though a lot of it takes heavily from Mario and Zelda), the game has a good art style and stays fresh enough for you to beat it.

I do like the game, don't get me wrong but as someone who spent $15 to get 2 copies I feel like $30 is waaaay too much for what A Hat in Time has to offer and for that I can't recommend it. Definitely get this on sale though if you love 3D platformers.

35563830.review:
A great game that's incredibly well-polished and pumped full of charm. Each mission has enough substance and longevity to make 40 Time Pieces easily equal to 120 stars, without repeating every mission mechanic multiple times like in 3D Mario. Honestly, there's already so much praise out there I feel I'll just repeat others, so I may as well move on to any negative points I have, none of which ruined the game for me;


First are badges. Two badges should never have been badges in the first place. The game's picture cam feature has no impact on gameplay....so why is it you can only use it while it takes up a badge slot? Meanwhile the grapple hook is mandatory for many stages, and is used so often everywhere that you'll NEVER unequip it. Not that you would anyway, since the game severely lacks in a useful badges count. How about a badge that increases health by 2 points? Or one that lets you do the slow hover from the beta? Or a badge that boosts the speed of a belly-dive flip even further?

Second, and this is just personal preference...the overall lack of moves. The game relies soley on two incredibly powerful abilities, the double jump and belly dive. The latter thankfully being incredibly fun and versatile, partially filling the void of an advanced player's need to push a game to it's limits. But it can only do so much. I would've loved to see more moves with that umbrella, like a diving slash, a handstand jump, a spin attack, an umbrella shield, or sliding on your umbrella to go fast like Mario does in Sunshine after he belly-slides through a puddle of water. The belly-dive is a fantastic move, but it frankly just gets kind of boring to dive-cancel/boost everywhere to solve every problem. Don't be too scared of your game getting beaten in unexpected ways.

Third...personal preference again; The double jump makes the game too easy. When HiT is already so forgiving for failed jumps, I think this was a little overkill.

35563413.review:
After doing every single of the collectibles (missions, 40 of them), I can easily say that this game is worth at full price, you won't be disappointed, and really fucking happy when this inevitably goes on sale.
To be honest, I'm not really the classic platforming type. I was afflicted with the autism scale of platformers where I prefer sonic's control stlye to mario's (yes I think that 06 was more fun than 3d world, suck my balls), probably due to the higher level of speed and flow in my opinion. Fret not, for this is a best of both worlds, where you get that elegant mario design with an exquisite move set to tickle your fancies for the coming 10-15 hours. After getting used to jumping and dashing in the first 15 minutes, you will be taken on a roller coaster of a game. The story is a kiddy platformer story, not insultingly bad and actually quite entertaining. The level of flow in the main 20 missions is great, you feel that you're the kiddie that DigibroMLP would have an insatiable erection for, and you are the mofo de la journée. However, the mechanic that helps you grab onto ledges and ropes fails later in the game and in the special stages. I will be trying to latch onto like a basic wall and it will go "heh, I don't think so" this is for the special stages only so keep that in mind. The only mission that I actually despised was the last mission of Mafia Town where you have to collect stupid tickets and your main hat (which locates items) is no help.
Oh, can I talk about how redundant half of these hats are? The main hat that Gamer Girl over there wears in the title only locates the hourglasses (à la stars from Mario 64). That's it, no location of tickets for safes nor relics or anything. You will not be playing with that hat for the majority of the game, instead you use 5 other hats that don't really jive with the art design of the gamer girl. Which is a damn shame because she looks classy with that hat m8. You will be using the sprint hat which looks like one of those fast food caps from Sanic's burger shop. The ice block is simply a ground pound, that's it. YOU COULD HAVE KEYBOUND THAT TO SOMETHING. The kitsune mask causes certain materials to appear or disappear for a limited time. That's reasonable. The witch's hat throws a chargeable projectile. There's a time stop hat for some unknown reason. Then these hats clash with badges. There are 12 in total, which only 3 can be selected from. I understand this gives you the mirage of choice, but honestly you will be using the object magnet badge, the hookshot badge, and then maybe you have a choice with the others until you need to fill the slot with the mad hatter so your cooldowns virtually disappear (they recharge during the time of your standard jump arc).  Then that witches hat could have been combined with one of the badges that binds it with a charged lazer beam. Also, why are the crates that are destroyed by the witch's hat not also destroyable by the charge attack or the ground pound? Missed opportunity guys. If they gave you like 5 badge slots I wouldn't mind because the badges system had some potential, but it doesn't damage the game so oh well. 
It feels really clunky how the main gimmick (the hats) transition half the time. If it was down to about 4 hats that you hotswapped with the d-pad or 1234 keys then that would work great. But it's that stupid max payne 3 wheel where you have to hold down LB (which on the one controller is really clunky compared to the 360) and then hold the right stick in the right direction, then let go of LB while holding the right analog. Holding the right stick all the way was so confusing initially, and I still didn't get it all the time. I've been spoiled by latency timers on other wheels, NYEH. 
I don't hate this game, this a STRONG 9/10. It's just soooo close. SOOOO close. The last main world, the goat plateau world is one of the best platforming world ever made. Even with its jaggies, the concept and execution meld so well that it's worth the purchasing price alone. Gears for Breakfast with its limited team made a game that made me smile like I haven't playing a game since I was 14 years old. Yeah, it's that bubbly nice. I enjoyed myself, and I think you will too.

35563316.review: Fantastic game! Highly recommended to anyone that enjoyed any of the  classic 3D platformers from the N64 and PS1 era

35563223.review:
Full disclosure: I backed the Kickstarter for this game when it was first announced. 

And also full disclosure: me backing or not, this game is an absolute diamond.

It feels like a perfect love letter to the collect-a-thons of old, as well as bringing back that feeling you had as a kid while you were playing Super Mario Sunshine.

The character is an absolute thrill to play as, since she controls so well that, obstacles course or not, you want to continue jumping around! And the level design fits this perfectly; there's a billion different ways to get from point A to point B, and the dev team clearly put a lot of effort into making sure that each one was as rewarding as the last.

Even better, the boss fights ALSO take full advantage of Hat Kid's abilities to manuever, as each one is a wonderful test of how well you can navigate using your abilities.

The soundtrack is also absolutely stellar, with plenty of different selections that all fit the mood their going for. If I have an oppurtunity, I'm definitely going to grab this on vinyl.

All in all: the characters are lovable, the settings are wonderful, the soundtrack is killer, and the aesthetic is an absolute treat. I would recommend this to anyone who likes to have fun when they play video games. 

Seriously, it's that good.

35562660.review:
Let me start off by saying this game is a MASTERPIECE. It brings back so much nostalgia and so many good memories of the good old days of 3d platformers. It's like Banjo Kazooie, Super Mario 64, Psychonauts, and all the beauty of platformers had a baby. Okay, now into the review.

POSITIVE:
It starts off with the most adorable story and light hearted tone. You start in Mafia Town and it's not colorless drivel, it's a world full of color and enemy types, collectibles, vaults, different mechanics and characters. It's the perfect introduction to a game that's so simple, yet can be brought into the speedrunning and complicated scene so easily, just like SM64. You start off with the Kid's Hat, which lets you see objectives; It's so helpful to see where you're supposed to go, yet you have so much freedom it's grand. You can gain up to 5 more hats as you progress, all with their own special mechanics. For example the sprint hat lets you run and the brewing hat lets you throw explosive potions. Even these two hats have so many applications, and it's just the beginning. Oh! And I almost forgot. This game controls exactly like SM64, Super Mario Sunshine, or Super Mario Galaxy would. It has a double jump, a dive, dive cancel, wall jumps, and the mechanics just keep getting more and more complex. For example slowing down time and using a grappling hook. Speaking of the grappling hook, there are badges in this game that you can equip (Up to 2 and 3 of them in the late game) that give you new and different things you can do. Again, for example there's the Item Magnet Badge which attracts nearby collectibles and the Hover Badge that saves you from taking fall damage. There's also negative or trash Badges that give bad effects. For example there's the 1-Hit Hero Badge that makes your HP sink to 1. These negative badges are merely to add challenge to the already rough 3d platformer. Plus, there's a plethera of "Time Rifts", aka special hidden stages, like in SM Sunshine. At the end of every level and rift there's a Time Piece (Or a star in Mario language) which you can use to unlock more acts and worlds. Also at the end of every Time Rift there's a slot machine that gives you cosmetics and tracks, making it able to customize your game, your character, adding your own flair to things. So far as the games' length and replayability, I played the game for a solid 14 hours and I still haven't found everything or completed all the achievements. Character-wise, they're all so lovable and they all have their own personality. Like Mustache Girl, who wants to be the hero of the story and destroy evil. (Mostly the Mafia) The controls are very tight and responsive, and if you mess up your inputs, the game most definitely punishes you. The soundtrack is beautiful and suits the game so very well. Now enough of my rambling and onto the negatives.

NEGATIVE:
I've searched almost every corner of the maps and I've seen only a few glitches and bugs. Which in this day and age is good, yet doesn't mean it's acceptable. I've seen a few T-poses and missing textures, but nothing terribly game-breaking. There's also a lack of explaining advanced mechanics like the speed boost if you cancel your dive when you hit the ground. Plus there's no application for some things, and even if not, sometimes it's only a one time use thing. There's a lack of different physical weapons not counting hats. There's an excessive amount of yarn to the point where it's not even rare. Also everything important glows like a thousand suns, which is nice for newbie players but it's definitely not necessary. I'm not going to talk much about the swimming mechanic because it's literally never used, but it definitely needs some work if it's meant to be a part of the game and not just an instant death.

SUMMARY:
This game is a must get for platformer lovers and fans of the mario franchise. 
Graphics: 9/10
Sound: 10/10
World Design: 10/10
AI: 9/10
Dialogue: 7/10
Story: 7/10
Gameplay: 10/10

Overall: 8.9/10
This game is beautiful, rich, and smooth.
When asked the question of getting this game, my answer is a definite yes.

35562341.review: This game brought back some pretty good memories from some of my old favorite platformers such as Super Paper Mario, Super Mario Sunshine, and Super Mario Galaxy. That being said it doesn't use nestolgia [strike]Yooka-Laylee[/strike] to try and hold itself up. The game has unique ideas and shifts the gameplay, like in the Subcon Forest with Queen Vanessa, or most of the second act. The soundtrack is also radical, the unlockable stage remixes are one of my favorite features. There are a few bugs, but not enough that hindered my enjoyment even though it was fairly short romp. For $30 bucks its not a bad deal, don't feel unjust in waiting for a sale though as it is short which makes sense judging that it's half the price of the games I mentioned above at launch.

35558529.review:
I fell in love with Super Mario Sunshine.  This reminds me of that, in all the right ways, from the creative settings through the insanely annoying secret levels, to the seemingly endless array of hidden secrets that are right in front of you.  It's even got the appropriate jaunty music (and I adore the way the music slows down to a crawl when you sit on a chair to admire the view.)

And on top of that it's got half-a-dozen really funny stories that are well-written and stuffed with clever jokes (the first part of Murder on the Owl Express is hilarious.)  

Sure, the camera is as annoying as in any of these games (the tree in the spooky village almost made me give up in despair), and the controls are occasionally annoying (when she jumps off the top of a wall-climb and plummets to her death... again.)  But they are minor issues in a game that's as fun as this one is.

We're suddenly in a golden era of PC 3d cartoon platformers, and I couldn't be happier.  But the competition is going to have to work hard to push this one off the top of the pile.

35558414.review:
A Hat in Time is one of this year’s best 3D platformers.

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]

The level design is great. Hat Kid controls smoothly and allows the player to navigate the worlds with ease. Its heavily nostalgic of early collectathon games. As you progress you create hats using yarn you find throughout each world. Each hat has its own unique powers which allow you to further explore and complete levels.

[h1] Design [/h1]

Each world bleeds personality with great visuals; no two worlds are alike. Exploring is rewarded with hidden yarns to unlock hats and some hidden levels that give you timepieces.

[h1] Story [/h1]

The story is quick to the point, get back all your lost timepieces. The characters you meet along the way our well written, humorous, and have some top-notch voice acting.

[h1] Sound [/h1]

I REALLY love the soundtrack of this game. It’s upbeat, swingy, and makes you want to dance along. Each piece fits the level well.

[h1] Length [/h1]

I managed to 100% the game in 12 hours. While some might not think thats the longest, I thoroughly enjoyed every minute of it.

[h1] Summary [/h1]

All in all, its one of my favourite games of the year, and I would it to recommend anyone looking for a good collectathon game, or even just a good platformer in general.
(Voted for it in the beyond expectations awards)

35558200.review: A Hat in Time is one of the most fun games I've played in a while. The worlds are bright and entertaining, and the premises for each act are all really creative and executed really well. The characters are cute and unique, and all really enjoyable. The game does well at humor, but when it wants to be dark and scary, it certainly pulls it off. Really, the only negative thing I have to say about this game is that it doesn't run well on my terrible computer. Regardless of this, I had loads of fun with it and it is one of the most worthwhile purchases you will make.

35558172.review:
There's an indie that comes out every once in a while that reminds me how good games can actually be in the sea of hype, AAA releases, and average gameplay.

I'm not saying this game is perfect, but it's damn well near it. It was made with a lot of love and care for the genre and fanbase. Delibirate design decisions that reflect the developers desire to create a game that people are going to like, instead of a game made purely to sell copies. This is a game made for the fans, by the fans.

The music, art design, and even graphics are phenomonal and fit the theme of the game. I hear a lot of people criticizing the graphics, but I'd argue that it was a delibirate decision made to harken back to the days of the GameCube. This game has more in common with [i]Super Mario Sunshine, Paper Mario 2,[/i] and [i[Wind Waker[/i] than it does [i]Banjo-Kazooie[/i] or [i]Mario 64[/i].

One of the best things about A Hat in Time is how the character plays. It's just so fun to bounce around as Hat Kid, climbing up walls, throwing potions, changing your hat in real-time to use different abilities. They put a lot of effort into the fluid controls, and it shows. There's so many fun techs and abilities you can use to jump, climb, and dive your way through the levels.

Some people criticize the length, but those are the same people who rush to 25 Hourglasses required for the ending instead of getting a 100% clear file. This can easily take you about 20 hours, and don't forget that they're adding more worlds as free DLC due to a stretch goal reached in the Kickstarter.

All in all, A Hat in Time is one of the best indie games I have ever played, and I can whole-heartedly recommend it to just about anyone.

35557766.review:
[h1]What would you expect from some modders of an old source game?[/h1]
This bloody masterpiece here.

[h1]What does it make such a masterpiece?[/h1]
First of all. The maps are so designed, so that there is not a single boring thing about it. This is what yooka laylee lacked in my opinion. Each map has been beautifully designed and filled with different things to collect. Mafia Town for example looks like an italian town: every thing is squached thogether. It's colorful and filled with those mafia cooks (everyone looks like a bald muscular guy with a mustache [spoiler]Except for one, which is a huge nerd and scared of aliens[/spoiler]).

Second: voice acting. Yes, almost every character is voice acted, even some of the not so important npcs. They sometimes give you tips, sometimes they say silly things. My favourite voice is from the ghost in Subcon Forest (I saddly don't know his name, if he even has one), the voice actor there had a lot of fun almost screaming in the microphone. For a game like this, the voices are really well done, you can almost hear the fun they had in each voice line.
https://youtu.be/0qKwpwaUaoc?t=6m53s

Third: the music. The music is AWESOME. You can even collect different types of versions of specific songs. Some songs have been made by the glorious grant and some from Pascal Michael (I don't really know what kind of music he did). But every piece just fits in the game. Mafia towns song has bit of italian vibe to it. The spooky Subcon Forest has some scary melodies in it. They did really great music for the game. I really love the music of chapter two. 

Fourth: The gameplay feels just right. The controls aren't overly mapped, so you can play it with a controller. They feel just nice and comfortable. The visuals give some great punch to some actions like throwing explosives or punching a critter with your weapon.

But for such a great game, there are also some flaws, like sometimes spazing cameras or a bit too annoying wall climbs (only in small spaces). But those are tiny flaws, which don't even affect the game all too bad

In other words: if you loved mario 64 oder other platformers, try this one out. You will not regret it

35554534.review:
Spoilers for like the whole game ahead.

Ok, so, for starters, I guess for the elephant in the room: YouTuber JonTron has a voice role, and the dev team has been quiet about it so take that as you will. Even though JonTron is a terrible person, it's not a dealbreaker for me, though a statement by the devs would really be appreciated. I do wanna put that out there as a disclaimer, though, so people are informed.

With that out of the way, this game is really good. The best thing about it is probably how varied it is. Every world has a vastly different mission structure: Chapter 1, Mafia Town, is pretty straightforward initially, but after you're "done" with it and beat the Mafia boss, it gets more open, especially with it containing a Mission you need a Chapter 4 powerup to beat. Thankfully, the game tells you on the Mission Select Screen if you lack something you need to progress. Chapter 2, Battle of the Birds, takes place in a few more linear areas as opposed to Mafia Town's island. Additionally, there's two paths, each for a movie director who wants to make the best movie, and your perfomance in those levels determines who wins, which impacts the boss fight at the end of the chapter. Chapter 3, Subcon Forest, has mostly linear missions, but the world is probably the most open (and sometimes confusing) of the game. The catch here is that you have to sign contracts before you can access missions, so you have to commit to what you do. Chapter 4, Alpine Skyline, is completely open with no selectable missions and isntead only a "Free Roam" option. You can get the 4 main Time Pieces in this world in any order. Chapter 5, Time's End, is only a linear gauntlet with one level.

Chapter 1, 2 and 3 are all very good, with Chapter 2 being the best in the game due to the variety. You have to solve a murder mystery on a train, gain a penguin fanclub and run away from a deadly parade. Chapter 3's dark undertones (for instance, there's a noose trying to talk you into suicide and an absolutely terrifying haunted mansion) make it a close second, though, with it mostly being held back by the confusing and samey layout. You definitely learn it, but it's unintuitive compared to Mafia Town or Alpine Skyline. Alpine Skyline has some really nice challenges, but it feels like it's missing something, especially near the end where it just kinda... ends without a boss fight. Chapter 5 has a nice premise of everyone being prosecuted for their alleged crimes and it has some nice callbacks, but it ultimately feels a bit too generic compared to everything else. The final boss also isn't as good as the previous fights, especially with both Chapter 2 and Chapter 3 having amazing boss fights, Chapter 2's being one of the best bosses I've seen in some time due to the way it calls back to the previous chapters while also just being really fun. The final boss has this nice twist with the enemies being aware of their deaths creating health, but both the Chapter 2 (a time bomb from a previous chapter gets tied to you) and Chapter 3 (you paint the boss blue with his own attack so he becomes vulnerable) bosses had better twists.

Sprinkled throughout the game are time rifts, which have to be discovered before they can be found in the stages. Each stage has 2 blue time rifts and 1 purple time rift. The blue ones are unlocked as you progress whereas the purple ones are unlocked by assembling artifacts that are sprinkled throughout the levels. Their position is hinted at with a photo of their location. While that is a pretty cool idea, some photos are a bit too generic so it's pretty hard to find those rifts. Blue rifts lead to Super Mario Sunshine Secret Stage-esque platforming-centered stages which are usually pretty fun, whereas purple rifts lead to exploration-based stages where you have to find crowns to progress. The latter also contain pages, which you can collect in order to get some backstory for the characters. I would prefer it if the pages were counted by stage instead of globally, since some of the rifts can have a lot of stages so it's tough to know where you missed a page.

The soundtrack is absolutely amazing and oh my god please buy it

The writing is absolutely amazing and oh my god please... buy... it..?

In the end, this game starts out strong, then gets better, but can't hold that standard until the end, unfortunately. It's definitely still a great game, though!

35551915.review:
A Hat in Time is a good game, it's not a great game or an amazing game, but it does some things right. And for every thing it does right there's an issue holding it back from being the best it can be. I'm going to recommend it but I'm mostly going to talk about the issues I've had with the game, because I think if the developers put a bit more work in they could have easily made a great or amazing game.

The raw platforming, without abilities and without enemies around, is very enjoyable. The controls are very responsive and you're always looking for new place to try and jump to. The Hat abilities themselves are also all quite good and blend into the gameplay well, but there's nothing you can do with Hat Kid that hasn't already been done before, everything she does she does well enough and a bit different enough that you don't mind. It never really feels like a cheap knock-off game. There are downsides though. The character controls are camera relative and the camera does tend to move on it's own in strange and unpredictable directions, this means you'll be holding a direction and expecting your character to go in it, only for the camera to move you an inch to the left, causing you to whack your head on a fence and bounce off, plumetting to your death. All of the automated functions like homing attacks, grapple hooks and tight ropes are character relative too, meaning if your character is facing the wrong way because the camera moved on it's own mid jump you're going to miss the prompt for the next thing and also, plummet to your death. The tightropes in particular are very interesting, since many times I've lined up the ropes perfectly only to go straight through them, where my sloppy or rushed jumps that I think I've missed end up magnetizing me to the rope. This hit and miss situation makes the segments where you have to bounce from rope to rope extremely frustrating because you have no idea what's going to happen. Though they space these sections out fairly far apart so you don't frustrated with them, making these things distance based instead of character relative would make these problems go away.

The levels are all well done, the worlds are vibrant and have their own stories and the characters in them have their own personalities and motives that get revealed to you as you progress through an area. As you unlock new hat abilities new areas open up to you with lots of hidden goodies to collect and the stories tend to draw you in just enough that you don't mind doing a bit of backtracking every now and then. There's an unusual reliance on stealth mechanics in the game, where you have to dodge vision cones or get sent back to the start of an area, over traditional fighting. The main reason I think is just that the combat mechanics aren't really there. As you explore a level there aren't really any enemies to fight. In fact fighting is very much optional, for a very large chunk of the game unless you need to chain homing attacks to get somewhere. There are specific combat abilities you can unlock that you never really need and there's a slot for 'weapon' on the character screen that I don't think you ever have to use, because after the first mission you get the only weapon you're going to use for the rest of the game. It's a bit disappointing that they give you a cool lazer beam attack that you never have to use. The boss fights don't require you to use any of your hat or badge abilities either, they have very simple patterns that after a tiny bit of trial and error you can get down straight away. I'm sure you can use your hat abilities to make them even easier but I never felt like I needed to. The bosses as characters are great and they are enjoyable as a result of them characterizing their villains quite well, but the fights themselves are underwhelming.

It's a fairly short game, I have 32 Time Pieces and I've played about four and a half hours or so, about a quarter of that time was spent backtracking through things I've already done to track down whatever I need to progress forward. I haven't finished the game yet but I have unlocked all 5 worlds and 100% completed two of them already. I probably have maybe one or two more hours of gameplay before I've completely finished everything there is to do. Though the smaller worlds and backtracking aren't that terrible, as the worlds themselves are packed full of detail and lore that just makes them a lot more fun to play around in. It's just a shame there isn't more levels. Hopefully at some point there will be, either through DLC. Or mods, as there is full mod support for the game.

Overall A Hat in Time is a good game and worth picking up if you want to play a 3D platformer, just be aware that it's very much a 3D platformer and not much else. It sticks to what it's good at like glue and I think that rigid approach to the level design and gameplay is what lets it down. Not so much just more combat but better combat or even just a reason to fight anything at all would have been very nice. Also with all the hat abilities you get it, you never really find yourself having to quickly switch between them which is a real shame, since the straightforward level design doesn't just bring the game down but it's also a large part of why it's so easy. Outside of their specific usage scenarios inside the areas you find them in and a few others, you basically never have to use them. The game is called A Hat in Time and you never really have to worry about what hat you're wearing until something glowing a certain colour is blocking your way. It does feel disappointing when you have a cool wizard hat that lets you shoot explosions and you basically only use it to clear crates once or twice a level.

Even though my very presitigious Steam review has been fairly negative, A Hat in Time is worth it if you have a young child and want to get them playing games or you just need to scratch that platformer itch. Just don't expect it to really do much else.
