35550794.review:
A Hat in Time is a neat little game that after many have waited 4-5 years for it release, including myself, have gotten the pleasure of it's full release. It's a game that aims to bring back the old style of 3D platformers. Does it really do that? Well I'd say, yes, yes it does. The controls are very fluid and responsive with a bit of looseness to it it making it feel just right. The combat isn't too bad, there's impact when you hit enemies, so that's a plus, as many games I have played have not had that impact that makes you feel like you're hitting an enemy, and moreso like you're trying to hit a pinata directly in front of you while you're next to a hurricane so the pinata is gone and why are you still there, leave, you'll die. And you do. Anyways, gamplay good.

So what about the story:
The story at times, after skimming a couple reviews myself, post playing the game of course, have pointed out that the story may seem a but unituitive and shallow. And I do admit, as opposed to other 3D platformers, it can at some points, but I fell that this could be because the developers perhaps have focused more on the gameplay and the overall experince of the game itself as opposed to the story. There is one really nice thing touch that was really nicely done I must say. And those are the memories of certain characters you can collect whilst exploring these things called Time Rifts, I'll leave it at that to avoid spoilers, but I'll say that one of them stood among the rest and actually legitimately gave me some feels and I felt bad for the character.

Overall look of the game:
So I played the beta, some are saying it looks worse, I absolutely 100% disagree. It's a major improvement upon the beta and alpha of the game. The aesthetic is very clean and has a cell shading to it, and I find the game very vivid and colorful and pleasing to the eyes. Can't really say much more on that besides the fact that my PC is by far the best, and I was almost afraid that when this game came out I would be unable to play and enjoy it, but putting it down on performance mode, the graphics are still very clean and crisp, especially on my 42' 1080p flatscreen. And the game ran at 60 fps nearly the whole time, except for 1 or 2 certain stages that were a bit rough on my PC, but not for long as after the stage was fully rendered and everything the frames wnt back up to an enjoyable state.

Finally, the music:
All I have to say about the music is, it's stellar! It's like really really good. And here's one of my favorite aspects of the game: There's a song remix type of system where ther are multiple versions in different musical styles for each zone that are able to be unlocked and set as the default for that area. And the composition of the music is astounding and very nostlgia inducing. I have the full OST on my phone and listening to it in car rides with my nice sound system is great and the quality is superb, CD quality at that, which it can't get much better from there.

Now to sum it all up:
There are quite a few things I didn't touch on and I won't as I'll leave those for you to find out for yourself if you decide to buy this readers. So if you like 3D platformers like Banjo-Kazooie and Super Mario 64, is this game for you? Very much likely yes! The game was overall very enjoyable, the playtime can differ depending on how you play, I tried to complete as much as I could and collect as much as I was able to. Sadly the game only took me around a little less than 15 hours to beat, but that also could be as I already had experience in playing it from the beta and knew what to do at some points, despite not everything being similar to the beta. But also with the upcoming mod support, the game will be more enjoyable than ever before! Which I eagerly anticipate to see what people can create as I want to get way more playtime out of this game as I love it so.

My overall rating for this game would have to be a 9/10. I know it may seem a bit biased as I love this game for one, and I know games like this are not for everyone, so opinions and reviews will differ. I hope my review was at least somewhat helpful in giving those who are uncertain about the game, even the slightest idea on if it is for them or not.

35550555.review:
I'm not sure why people describe this game as Mario 64, Sunshine or any other Nintendo related games. In my opinion, that is sad because there are so many great and argubly better N64 & Gamecube platformers at the time.

A Hat in Time would best be described as a game that would come out during the Nintendo Gamecube and Playstation 2. In this era, almost every game made was a 3D platformer. If it wasn't a Nintendo game, it was TV, Movies and anything else like Spongebob Battle for Bikini Bottom or Scooby-Doo Night of 100 Fights. Every game was a 3D platformer, and  as a kid, I LOVED IT. I absolutely adore 3D platformers with simple and linear objectives.

Overall, it's a solid 3D platformer. It has all the core and essential elements for a 3D platformer. The worlds and levels are very large and open for exploration. For example, on my first run, rather than chasing the Mysterious pink girl, I started exploring and looking around. Eventually, I stopped caring about the Time Relic until I encountered it after my exploration. From there, I completed the level. This is the style of 3D platforming I missed.  It's obvious that Gear for Breakfast were not afraid to embrace thier creativity because they clearly tried to recreate this style of 3D platformer unlike Yooka Laylee. There a ton of uniquie level designs, and the worlds feel very alive. Even the Time levels don't remind me of Mario Sunshine. In fact, they actually have their own idenity and feel  original. It also helps that the music and graphics look pretty good! It's nothing like Mario Sunshine or Mario 64. 

However, my biggest complain would be that it does in fact feel like it was made during the Nintendo Gamecube era. There are cutscences where you can see no animations in character models. They're just awkwarding sliding or walking. The main protagonist herself doesn't have lip animations, and characters interact by simply moving their hands while a voice narrator reads the text. In general, I feel like I'm playing a gamecube game using Dolphin to run it at 1080p with higher textures.

Reguardless, I still recommend this to any loving 3D platformer fan. If you are a 199X born kid and grew up in the early 2000, you'll love this and have great memories of your childhood. You'll remember all those great moments playing Mario Sunshine on Gamecube or Jack and Daxter on the PlayStation 2. I can understand why some would wait for a price drop, however. If you've never played a 3D platformer, and you are interested. This is a great introduction to why people like 3D platformer.  I recommend it at full price for 3D platformer fans. Near 20 dollars for people who never played a 3D platformer and are used to modern AAA platformers like Uncharated or Tomb Raider.

35549655.review:
Disclaimer: I haven't finished this game yet, this is very much a first impression. Don't get your knickers in a twist if I get something wrong or leave some example out Everything you read here is subject to change.

A Hat in Time is a platformer funded by kickstarted developed by Gears for Breakfast.
It very much wears its influences on its sleeve. The gameplay harkens back to a time where 3D platformers were a total blast to control (Think SM64/Sunshine and Banjo Kazooie). Even though A Hat in Time is supposed to be a successor to the 3D platformers of the late 90s and early 2000's, the amount of games and other media this game takes from is much larger. Those well-read in game trivia from back in the day will notice references left and right that might evoke a smile, or a sigh of exasperation depending on how immersed you like being.

Gameplay: Pretty damn good, but a bit of polish could have done wonders
     A Hat in Time controls far better than the average PC game in its genre, but it still doesn't have the polish that you'd expect from a Nintendo or Rare classic. Hat Kid has many of the same moves as Mario from Sunshine, but she doesn't have quite the same weight to jumping that made Sunshine such a joy to control. Combat especially feels quite stilted and awkward, Hat Kid has limited options for attacking in the air, which can lead to some awkward situations in more challenging levels. Still, despite my problems with the movement mechanics in AHiT, I still had tons of fun moving around the game world.

Presentation: I really shouldn't complain, but here goes anyway.
     A Hat in Time, visually speaking is a mixed bag. While many areas have had layer after layer of visual polish, some areas look flat out lazy in comparison. Character animation ranges from pretty good to pretty bad at times. While Hat Kid has a very appealing design, many supporting characters look like they were stock assets taken from an old Dark Basic game (The owls particularly offend me). I have my complaints, but AHiT will look completely fine to most people.
     On the other hand, the music and sound design here is top-notch. The music will dynamically change depending on where you are in the game or what you're doing. You'll hear instruments be swapped out, the music slow down, or speed up. The songs themselves are quite catchy and evoke the rich sounding music that was present in Super Mario Galaxy. The voice acting, unfortunately, needs work, but the game thankfully gives you an option to have characters mumble like Banjo Kazooie, so I can't be too hard on it.

Verdict: If you dearly miss the days where 3D platformers had actual depth and complexity to them, and Yooka Laylee left you sorely dissapointed, then A Hat in Time might be just what you've been looking for. Especially if you can't afford Mario Odyssey or a Switch. However, if you're like me and constantly nitpick an otherwise fine game for how it's different to what it claims to be, you may be dissapointed yet again.

35548784.review:
A Hat in Time is simply amazing. The controls are fantastic, and it very rarely felt like Hat Kid (the game's adorable protagonist) wasn't doing exactly what I told her to do. Platforming is the core of every level, and the game gives you plenty of tools to move about in a myriad of ways, whether it's diving in midair to get extra distance or swingingly effortlessly with a grappling hook.

The characters are amazingly endearing, to the point where I can't get them out of my head. The entire game is fully voice acted (with some barely-there exceptions). I found myself enjoying the voices, but if you don't you can simply turn them off, or even convert them to Banjo-Kazooie-style mumbling noises! Every interaction is full of humor, and I found myself laughing out loud on multiple occasions.

The music is also phenomenally catchy, with each track fitting the stage perfectly, and multiple instrumentations that fade in seamlessly depending on where you are in the level. A Hat in Time's composer Pascal Michael Stiefel deserves major kudos, and I hope to see him in many more games in the future.

I think the one criticism I would have of A Hat in Time is that its first world, Mafia Town, is a bit rough around the edges. The character models seem a bit messy, and there are cutscenes in those levels that seem like they're missing animations. The game's presentation improves massively after that, and I was absolutely in love with the final world. The boss encounters are also amazingly fun and high-energy, in a genre that generally suffers from slow and boring boss fights.

I highly, HIGHLY recommend A Hat in Time, especially if you fondly remember the tight platforming of Super Mario Sunshine or the constant humor of Paper Mario: The Thousand-Year Door. At $30 it's worth every single penny, and two additional chapters are on the way as free post-launch DLC. Forget the memory of failed Kickstarter promises and buy this game!

35548752.review:
What a great game, honestly. I've been anticipating this game since I've first heard about it several years ago, and the wait has been well worth it.

Presentation is amazingly cute and charming, with memorable characters across the board, an adorable art style, great soundtrack and actually quite funny gags. Worlds are good and varied if laid out a little confusingly at times. The actual levels and challenges in the worlds are a take on the Mario Sunshine formula of collect-a-thon trinket hunting, but are as a rule several times more creative, unique and sometimes more complex than platformers of a similar kind, ranging from anything to an ordinary fetch quest with a small spin or two to elaborate stealth sections to a portion where the game basically turns into a lighthearted horror game, trying to solve puzzles while stripped off your powers and stalked by what appears to be some demonic queen roaming in her manor. It feels like every other world/level throws a new gimmick or elaborate gag into the core gameplay, and it keeps things fresh to the point that I could binge entire worlds without a semblance of being even remotely exhausted or bored with them. Even the boss fights are really cool in this, which tend to be the weak point of most 3D platformers of a similar jib. Fairly challenging, prone to catching you off-guard with how elaborate and lengthy they are and actually quite hectic, they round out the more straightforward platforming challenges and less confrontational on-off gameplay gimmicks.

Beyond some tiny tidbits like the worlds not being as expertedly laid out as they could be and the camera behaving a little unruly at times(it's still perfectly serviceable for the most part, camera isn't your nemesis this game. Just feels a bit jank at times), I just wish it was a little longer. Game has 4 main worlds with about 5 or so acts(and some hidden platforming mini-levels) each and 1 final world that serves as a final parcour section to the final boss and the boss fight itself, and while many acts tend to actually be quite long for what they are, and I haven't quite finished everything yet, it all just feels over a little too soon. I heard there's free DLC worlds on the way though, so I suppose my plight may only be temporary, and besides it isn't really the game's failing that it's short(I reached the final boss and did a bit of other stuff before actually fighting it with 8 hours, which is fine, really), more that it's good enough that you'd like more.

This game is making me live the Gamecube/N64/PS2 days. Taking inspiration to games like Super Mario Sunshine, Wind Waker, Banjo-Kazooie, and Psychonauts, you have this great masterpiece of a game. It's really adorable and its humor is on point. The characters are great and the game feels great to control. It's a fun collectathon and I highly recommend it to those who are fans of those types of games and platformers in general. The things you collect actually affect your gameplay for the good and make your abilities much better. All in all, the game is fun, cute, and pretty funny, I can say my only issues I have with the game is clipping animation and small frame rate issues but it doesn't really impact the game overall. I can say that I just really love this game (Don't even get me started on the soundtrack).

9/10

35544570.review:
[b]SCROLL DOWN FOR TL;DR[/b]

This is one of the best 3D platformers I've played in a long time. Tight controls, great abilities and creative level design.

"How does it stack up to Yooka Laylee?" you might ask.

Well, in terms of level design, humor and characters, it surpasses Yooka Laylee in several points, or at the very least matches it. The catch? The game is WAY too short. Only 5 levels and only 40 hourglasses to collect, 24 of which are needed to beat the game. However, the sheer amount of mission variety is staggering, and the attention to detail in every level is marvelous. You never seem to be doing the same thing twice. If I had to compare it to an existing game, the overall mission structure is like a heavily abridged version of Super Mario Sunshine, complete with platforming levels in a void.

The character cast has an incredible amount of heart and soul in it. Even the bad guys are immensely likable. The Cook Mafia has to be my favorite band of crooks in the history of video games. Hat Kid herself doesn't have much personality beyond "cute and happy" during most of the gameplay, but her character becomes more apparent in her diary entires, relic descriptions and the way she comments on various world objects.

The bosses are easily the most challenging aspect of the game. They're fast, have a lot of attacks, and the fights can go on for ages with no midpoints if you die. Some of them can even get you in a stunlock, which is quite infuriating.

Overall, A Hat In Time is a solid little gem, with its biggest problem being that there isn't enough of it.

[b]PROS[/b]
 + Great level design
 + Great controls
 + Great characters and humor

[b]CONS[/b]
 - Way too short
 - Some bosses can stunlock you

[h1]SCORE: 8.5 / 10[/h1]

PS: How on earth did this get only a Pegi 7 age rating?! The mansion in Subcon Forest will traumatize more children than the haunted piano in Super Mario 64 ever did.

35544366.review:
[h1]日本語化を強く望む可愛く、熱く、優しいゲーム[/h1]

12時間ちょっとでストーリーはクリアしたのでレビュー。

女の子がとある理由で宇宙を旅していた所、ひょんなことから航行不能となり、燃料の不思議な砂時計と共にある惑星へ投げ出されてしまう。砂時計を探しているうちにトラブルがトラブルを呼び、ついに騒ぎは惑星全体を巻き込んでいく...女の子は無事旅を続けられるのでしょうか...？

ざっくり言うと、マリオ64のシステムを踏襲したようなカートゥーンアクションゲーム。
操作はコントローラをお勧め、Steam、PS4、XBoxどれでも大丈夫だと思います。私はSteamのものでやりました。
ゲーム設定はXBoxを推していますが、不便はありませんでした。

クリアするにはどうすればいいか？と考えることに重きを置いているようで、シビアなアクション能力を求められることは殆どありません。でも時々はあります。
その為か、デスペナルティはチェックポイントに戻るだけ。優しい！
そしてクリアまでバグが無い！快適！（EA慣れで感覚麻痺してるかも）
更に収集要素が魅力的！カワイイ！

キャラはカワイイし濃ゆいしで愛着湧きまくりです。マフィアですらカワイイ。
個人的な好みはウェスタン系車掌みたいなのとイジワル魔人系オバケですね。
口調も訛りや癖があり、初見はつまづきましたが面白いです。

熱い・優しい展開有りと、ゲーム性共に自然とストーリーを楽しめるとても良いバランス。
日本語化が実現するかはわかりませんが、SNESや64のアクションをこなせる人なら、残りの壁はPC性能と簡単な英語だけです。
PCではちょっと...という方はフォローしてCS発売のお知らせを待ってみてはいかがでしょうか。

最後に収集要素の一つを載せておきます。着替えだけなので気軽にご覧ください。

35537864.review: A Hat in Time is a solid 3D platformer. It controls very well. It really doesn't do anything new, though. The concept of moving a little character around a 3D world was novel and exciting back in the '90s and oughts, but now it's nothing special at all. I think that most of the game's appeal is in its high visual production values, amazing soundtrack, and straight-up heartwarming cuteness. Those elements alone might be enough to hold peoples' attention for a couple of weeks. You may get some more mileage out of the game by exploring the growing library of user-created content like new hats and levels. At some point, though, if you've double-jumped through one level, you've basically double-jumped through them all. In a world with more games than free time to play them, I'd only recommend paying $15 to $20 for a game like this.

35537863.review:
This is what I wanted Yooka Laylee to be. I do feel I should maybe give Yooka Laylee another shot, perhaps a few patches here and there will make that game more enjoyable... but this game was just fun. It hooked me without much effort and made me remember what I liked about this genre.
Is it perfect? Of course not, it has a few glitches... one even screwing me out of a yarn collectable. Some jumps feel a bit wonky... but I can honestly forgive that. I guess the biggest differences between Yooka Laylee's flaws and this game's flaws it that I was still overall having fun.
One big reason is the game oozing with personality. Like we've wanted, the dialogue is fantastic, with some nice jokes here and there to keep me interesting.
The controls felt smooth, the starting abilities were just enough to have fun early on without feeling like I would have fun later, and the areas I've explored so far have as much personality as the NPCs.

I might expand my thoughts after finishing the game, since this is just me casually having fun... but I'm posting this review for one big reason. This game is just fun. If you were disappointed with Yooka Laylee like I was and just wanted a fun casual experience, this gave me that nostalgic feeling of the N64/Gamecube platformers all over again.

35537456.review:
This game, is just pure magic. I waited for 5 years on this game, and well, it didn't disappoint.

I never backed the game, but i have been closely following it since its very early days, when Mekucube (at the time known as Mechatheslag) was posting small little updates almost every day on his youtube on what progress he had made, be it a small little area to test in, to picking up a water melon and holing it above Hat Kid's head. I was also a slacker backer and played during the beta, i sadly didn't back the game during the original kickstarter, and i regret not doing so.

Now, enough gushing over old stuff, its onto the actual review.

This game, is just from start to finish, full of charm, cuteness, and emotion, every time i booted up the game i got this huge grin across my face (and not just excitement that its actually here), a grin of happiness. This game knows what it wants to be, and it did just that, giving so many memorable characters such as the Mustache Girl, the Mafia, Snatcher, Conductor and so many more. Each character in the game was unique and different from one another, and no two characters are alike, even each mafia member you can talk to has something different about them that makes them memorable. The writing is on par with Paper Mario: The Thousand Year Door (and with TONS of references to it as well)

Next up, Art direction, and oh my god this game looks AND sounds fantastic. It Just oozes with an adorable feeling that makes you giddy at everything you see. The art style is remincisent of the Wind Waker, and it shows, and giving itself its own identity too boot. The game feels fantastic to look at, and also each act of each world has its own title card, which gives you a LOT to look at in between levels. And dont get me started on the music, its just filled to the brim with so many good tracks. Shoutouts to Pascal and special guest Grant Kirkhope, you guys made an OST i can just listen to for hours... which is 5 hours long in total. Great job to them. The voice acting as well is Top notch, everyone delivered their lines oh so well i could feel the emotion they put into each and every line.

Now, how does it play? Well, it plays like Super Mario Sunshine, but a LOT more movement based. Hat Kid feels so good to control that never once did I ever feel like the game took control away, or that any mistake that I made wasn't my fault. Now the main gimick of the game, is Hats. With each hat you gain new abilities, and you can even swap them on the fly too for some extremely fluid switching. and this game wouldn't be a collectathon if it didn't have collectables to nab. You go around, collect Pons, Yarn, badges, other things, and your main plot macguffin, Time Pieces. You can Jump, Dive, wall jump, swing, attack, and so on. Hat Kid's movement options would make even Super Smash Bros. Melee professionals be envious. Theres never one way to get to your goal, and how Hat Kid moves is just right. And if you want to swap from keyboard controls to a controller, its super quick and you dont have to change any settings, it automatically switches over to your gaming preference (and theres Gamecube controller support!)

Now, if i have only a SINGLE complaint about this game, it would be the length. Its short. and I mean, SHORT. only a good 5 hours if you go for everything, while my hours at the time of this review say otherwise, 15 of them were during the beta.

All in all, I HIGHLY reccomend this game if you were a fan of gamecube era styled games, and its well worth your $30.
Thank you, and have a good evening~

A super cute 3D platformer that feels like a mix of the best parts of Super Mario Sunshine and Banjo Kazooie.  Vivid, entertaining worlds to explore, a wide cast of extremely interesting characters, wonderful music, and gameplay that is very fluid and satisfying.  Probably one of the better 3D platformers I've played.  

If I had to pick something from the game that I don't like, it would be that it's too short.  At 9.2 hours as of posting this review, I've gotten every hat, every badge, and every time-piece.  I've finished the entire game with nothing remaining except to complete some of the achievements I didn't do the first time around.  So if you're the type of person who values the amount of time it takes to complete a game over the overall experience, then you'll probably be disappointed with what you get for 30$.

I highly recommend this game to any fans of the 3D platformer genre.

35536064.review:
First off: Do I recommend A Hat in Time? Yes. Do I recommend it for 30$? No. As well polished and good as it is, as of this writing (10/7/17), I was able to 100% this game in 10 hours (the reason I'm not complaining is because I pledged to the KS ~2-3 years back). However, its length being the biggest issue should tell you something about it. I definitely recommend you buy this, just... wait for a sale. Into what I think about it...


The good:
- Take the best parts of Super Mario Sunshine, Super Mario 64, and Banjo Kazooie, mash them all together, and you've got A Hat in Time. You can tell Gears for Breakfast did their homework on what makes a great platformer, because the game controls extremely well from the moment you start. In addition, the camera controls near perfectly, and aside from one area in the game, it never gave me any issues.

- Level design is intuitive and amazing, There was only one area I got lost in trying to 100% the game, and I had no issues navigating through the main campaign. The areas also have little hidden places to put secret levels in them, and locating them was never a chore, but instead a fun challenge. And let's not get into how amazing all these places look...

- Every collectable counts towards something. The pons (currency) are used to buy badges, upgrades for your hat. The yarn is used to knit new hats with different abilities. The time pieces progress the story. The list goes on and on. Collecting them felt fun, instead of a chore, and that's hard to do in collect-a-thons.

- Except for a few parts, there was full voice acting through the entire game. This really struck me as some of the voice actors really sold their character (the spirit in Subcon Woods comes to mind). Some... didn't, but at the very least, everyone was passable, and it really added to my experience.

- Polish up the butt. Everywhere I look, there's little details and hidden things for me to find, and it was a real treat. A lot of the game functions were subtly tailored to player convinence as well. I would describe them here, but it would take way too long. Just take my word on this one.


Now, onto the bad (this is mostly nitpicking though):
- Length, as mentioned above. I can perfectly understand why they want to charrge 30$ for this game, and if it had even just a little more stuff to do on the side, I might agree. But as it is, A Hat in Time would be worth closer to 15$ or 20$ instead of 30$. Buy it when it goes on sale for about that much.

- The story felt flimsy, and its message to me was unclear. In some worlds, it was a fun cliche plotline, but a lot of times, they got no proper conclusion (SPOILERS: There's no real redemption arc for the birds in the movie world where they apologize and that threw me for a loop). I realize this is a platformer and not a story driven game, but the characters felt under-utilized, and I never really cared about them (Also, the main character can be borderline psychopathic sometimes).

- The difficulty was considerably easier than I was expecting. I was never in shortage of yarn (and in fact I had extra left over from when I'd made all the hats), hearts were plentiful, and some hats, like the timestop one, were extremely powerful and made the game feel like a joke at times. Perhaps difficulty settings that alter the amount of yarn needed for hats, how many hearts drop, and etc. would work. The game's current solution, a badge that reduces you to 1 hit point, doesn't fix a lot of the pacing issues outside of battle this game's lenient difficulty creates.


Overall, A Hat in Time isn't perfect, but it's the best darn collect-a-thon I've seen in a long while. If you REALLY like collect-a-thons, it might be worth 30$, but for everyone else: wait for a sale. I hope this game gets way more attention in the near future.

35535960.review:
Take the great level design and mission structure of Mario 64, the cozy hub world of Mario Galaxy, the beautiful cell shaded art style of Windwaker, the humor of Psychonauts, the charming cast of characters of Banjo Kazooie. Take all of that, and you STILL don't fully capture all the things that makes A Hat in Time one of the best 3D platformers in recent memory, if not all time. You'd still be neglecting to mention the outstanding soundtrack, the fluid controls, the legit fun bosses, the expertly paced platforming challenges, and one of the most instantly iconic, cute mascot protaganists ever.

It's not perfect. Yes, JonTron is an ass. Yes, the voice acting ranges from outstanding (FOOOOOLS) to lousy (PECK NECK). Yes, there's more yarn than there are hats to craft with it. Yes, you can't unlock all the roulette bonuses without exploiting the dev console for more coins. But even with some minor flaws, this game is still absolutely worth your time and money, and I suspect it will only get better with future updates.

tl;dr this proves the Valve adage that everything is better with Hats.

35535937.review:
Crazy adorable and fun platformer where you collect shiny things because they're [i]your[/i] shiny things. Cheerful everywhere with fun voice acting and oozing with charm. Does that Mario Sunshine thing where you revisit a world a few times to get new shiny things with a new gimmick behind collecting each one.

35535064.review:
In short, A Hat in Time is a short jump back into the feeling of playing a collectathon back in the days of yore. It truly captures the essence of the whimsical fun of the genre when it was in its hayday, and while the collecting aspect is short and sweet, it is more than worth the wait for those who followed its development, and in the 15 hours it took me to get all the hourglasses, it has earned a spot as one of my favorite games of all time.

To briefly cover what the game is- not that anyone bothering to read this doesn't know the basics, its a game I would say is most similar mechanically to something like Mario Galaxy- there's a few levels, you pick which hourglass you're going going after in that mission, and you go get it, though they constantly mix the forumla around a little for each level. In some, you'll run over a fairly open and large level searching for loose objectives, more like Donkey Kong 64, for example, while in others  you follow the simple mission structure of a game like Mario Galaxy. Beyond collecting the 40 hourglasses- the main collectable of the game- there's also yarn to find in hidden corners of each world for making hats, but not much else, and green orbs you use to buy little badges- basically, interchangable powerups.

First, the good. The game is abundant with charm and characters that are the perfect amount of over-the-top, the music is top-notch, and while I found the level design a little hit-or-miss with me personally, I never stopped having a great time. The gameplay is smooth, fluid, and well animated. The graphics strike a particular chord with me, and each world tends to mix it up enough to keep the visuals interesting and diverse. While I might just be a huge softie, I was surprised to say I felt geniune emotion throughout- a childish joy through most of the game, getting teary eyed at a few times near the end, and one mission in particular that spooked me pretty darn good from the visuals and sound design alone. I could gush for quite some time, but the short of it is, the game is just pure fun- the visuals are fun, the sound design is fun, the music is fun, and the characters are just fun, and the game rarely tries to be anything else. It knows exactly what it wants to do and hits the target dead on at almost every single point.

That being said, I do want to mention a few faults of the game. The main secondary collectable, yarn, is used exclusively for hats, but there's a very limited number of hats in the game, yet yarn is fairly abundant. While I did a fairly thorough job of searching each level, I never felt I was ever NEEDED to. It felt excessive and just a little tacked on. By the end of the game, I had just under 20 extra yarn never used for anything, and collecting it had long since started feeling pointless, especially as the game doesn't track this collectable in any way to scratch that completionist itch of getting that pretty little "100% Complete" written on you game file. That being said, it doesn't detract from the game much, but for those of you who, like me, search every inch of every world and expect some reward for doing so, you'll find yourself wanting. That being said, that's the only thing I could complain about- a small, easilly ignored blemish, besides a small number of visual hiccups I experinced early on that never really detracted from the game in any real way, at least not in my experience. 

Over all, A Hat in Time truly feels like the best version of the collectathons we all remember through our rose-tinted childhood glasses- it takes all the good from those and mixes it well with the polish we expect of a modern game. It's short, but its incredibly sweet, and filled with an undeniable charm I doubt many can resist, and perhaps most importantly, it is a game that knows exactly what it wanted to be, and hit the nail squarely on the head. It is absolutely one of my favorite games of all time, and it was well worth the wait.

35535009.review: My god is this game filled with charm! Just beat it and I found the game to be a very enjoyable experience. Hat Kid is such an adorable protagonist and has funny idle animations. 35534997.review:
I'm still playing through but I absolutely adore the art style. The characters and animations are cute and funny. The dialogue is great. Its packed with  jokes and nonsense everywhere you go. 

The game is dvided up into easy to digest chapters that make it easy to take a break. Or you can just obssessively slam them one after the other. (like I did) 

The game's music, sound, art and effects are wonderful to my earballs. 

Controls are responsive and edges are very forgiving so its easy to pick up and play even if you don't have a controller! 
And speaking of controls the game teaches you how to do everything from jumps, to fighting bosses just by giving you opportunities to try things out and figure things out on your own. It never really stops to teach you how to play. Everything is designed simply so its easy to understand.  So even if you get momentarily confused by a boss or puzzle you can figure it out just by playing. The game just GOES. 

The different hats give you flexibility with how you explore the world and fight enemies. The only hat I wish I got to use more is the Ice hat. But Swapping between hats is easy to do on the fly and the different abilities they offer are varied and fun. 

If I have any nitpicks for the game most of them minor things with textures etc. (Like Hatkid says the line FIVE extra loud for some reason.)  I personally had a hard time with the 2nd boss in mafia town but I think thats just on me and not a fault of the game. But no major issues and certainly nothing that messes with the game experience overall. 

For me this game also has great replay value because even after I finish all the chapters, I know I want to go back and find extra bits of story and items. In one of the chapters there are different minor story+dialogue options, how you play can even change what boss you face at the end of the level ! 

If you enjoyed games like Spyro, LoZ Windwaker, banjo kazooie, Okami, etc. You will love this game!

EDIT: WAIT I FORGOT TO MENTION. THERE'S DLC 'N JUNK COMING. THERE'S MORE GAME COMING. AHHH.

Overall, I'd recommend it. Quick Pros and Cons list:

Pros:
- Controls are very tight and movement is fun.
- Level design is well thought out and not repetitive (for most stages).
- The aesthetic is fairly consistent.
- The camera is mostly manageable. This is a big deal for 3D platformers.
- Music = GREAT.

Cons:
- The biggest one for me: Tonally inconsistent writing.
- Some odd graphic clipping issues (models clip awkwardly)
- Very short for me. But, based on future DLC and collectables, hopefully it will keep up for post-game completion.

35534186.review:
(This is a No Spoiler Review)

A Hat in Time is a collectathon platformer based on the likes of Banjo Kazooie and Super Mario.

A Hat in Time proves to be one of the best modern platformers to date. This game overdid it's Kickstarter and did way better than what Yooka Laylee did Gameplay and Design wise.
 
The team over at Gears for Breakfast really did their research while developing this game. The platforming is one of the most amazing platforming I've ever seen since Banjo Kazooie and Tooie. Everything in the game relies on gameplay rather than adding in a whole bunch of messy elements and holding the player's hand through it. 

There are no tutorials at all, literally. They actually managed to make a game where I don't have to worry about tutorials. I'm so fucking impressed, holy shit. Props to Gears for Breakfast for learning a lot about Game Design. I can see why this game took 4 years to make, and it was damn worth it. 

The game itself is pretty short story wise, but has a WHOLE BUNCH of content like Side Missions similar to Super Mario Sunshine, and also Special Levels similar to Sunshine as well. I would recommend you to play one Level at a time, they're not only HUGE AS FUCK but hold a lot of secrets and fun little collectables.

The soundtrack is the fucking best, I couldn't help rock out to the Mafia Bosses theme and the Train Wreck of Science as well. Should've bought the soudtrack with it to be honest.

Thanks for reading my review on A Hat in Time, I would recommend this game to anyone who is a fan of Super Mario series and Banjo Kazooie and Yooka Laylee.

(PS: Chapter 4 is the best.)

35530748.review:
I first discovered A Hat in Time in early 2013, back when Mafia Town was just a dock, a white building, and a few NPCs.

When the Kickstarter launched a few months later, I made an account just to support this amazing-looking revival of the collectathon genre. It was like the combination of my all-time favorite games. It was too good to be true.

I was overjoyed seeing the project's success, and every video I watched of the alpha just made me more eager to play it.

Eventually, I caved and bought the beta, which I loved because it respected and rewarded the player's will to explore. I could venture out into the sea of Mafia Town past its frightening robotic shark to find secrets hidden in the islands on the horizon. I could surprise myself by venturing into suspicious drain pipes and ending up in secret areas. And I had a great appreciation for how much the badges, such as the parasol and the portal, deepened gameplay.

What made A Hat in Time so special to me wasn't the bosses or the exploding train stage. (Those were actually the weakest points of the beta for me.) What I cherished was the freedom and the thrill of discovery.

The development process on Twitter fascinated me. Chapter 4, originally called Sand 'N' Sails, particularly interested me, because it looked to be a more condensed version of the Great Sea in Wind Waker. Roaming freely in a desert looking for villages and hidden caves while staying hydrated so you don't die of heat stroke? What a cool change of pace!

The end of the beta filled me with intrigue as it hinted towards a greater story. Seeing Hat Kid grown up really made me wonder just how great a role time travel was going to have, and what connections Hat Kid might have with other characters in the story, like Mustache Girl or the terrifying Queen Vanessa.

Cut to release day. I'm anxious to begin. I play for 6-7 hours and beat the game with around 25 timepieces.

I'd like to say I loved the game. I'd like to say that I was charmed to bits by all the silly dialogue and unique environmental details, and that each chapter was better than the last.

But I couldn't help but feel underwhelmed. The final game is missing something. Something the beta and even the alpha had.

The freedom and thrill of discovery have been neutered.

There are fewer abilities than there were in the beta, and the abilities that exist are very context-sensitive, forcing you to switch hats regularly.
The Time Rift areas are now inaccessible until you unlock them, and the game shows you where they are.
The green orbs are less fun reskins of Star Bits from Mario Galaxy in that they're sometimes required to open new missions despite being unlimited, replaceable collectibles.
Hat Kid can't swim underwater anymore, and for that matter, she can't swim much at all.
Remember when Hat Kid could ride on fireworks? That's been ditched, too.
That neat and tense part of Queen Vanessa's Manor where you learn to strategically time the flashes of cameras to defeat shadows is gone.
Chapter 4 is now frustratingly streamlined for a so-called "free roam" chapter.

It's as if the head developer was suddenly afraid of people breaking his game or getting stuck, and he took every measure to prevent that, even if it meant ditching some really cool stuff. The game is less interesting because of it.

If there's anything I wish had been changed from the beta that wasn't, it's the absurd number of duplicate rewards that serve little to no purpose. It'd be one thing if they counted toward 100% completion, but as it stands, they're useless glowing balls that set off my Obsessive Completionist Disorder.

Most of the game's "good moments" are purely cosmetic things, like the damages bill that steepens as you travel through Dead Bird Studios, or the friendship meter when Hat Kid and Mustache Girl high-five. Yes, these moments have their charm, but in my eyes, all they do is add some seasoning to the spoiled meat of the game.

Almost every mission in the game consists of the same few elements: bounce on tightropes, swing on grapple hook targets, and find the next platform to jump on. Beyond that, there's minimal mechanical variation, especially compared to most other games in the genre.

Frankly, in the end, I don't think this game knew what it wanted to be. It tried to be too much at once, and there's a sense of dissonance as a result.

For example, there are quite a few times when the game takes a long pause, like while riding an elevator or a zip-line. They're the kinds of long pauses that are right at home in a long, casually-paced RPG, but for a relatively short, fast-paced action platformer like this, it's jarring and somewhat irritating.

There were multiple times during my playthrough when a new act would open, and I put it off because I didn't want to do it. Navigating the foggy maze of trees that is Subcon Forest was never fun to me, because everything looks the same. The penguin acts in Battle of the Birds were obnoxious and artifically lengthy. Chapter 4, which is easily the chapter I hate most, I stayed away from as much as I could due to its highly inefficient navigation system, lazy theming, and infuriating enemies.

Aside from a few unnatural difficulty spikes, A Hat in Time is an easy game, which is not necessarily a bad thing; but when it's "stroll through the park" easy, it's concerning. Hat Kid feels virtually weightless, is tight to control, and has bizarre horizonal jumping range, trivializing anything that would pose a captivating challenge with the controls of a 3D Mario game. If you do die (which happened for me when I touched hazards I couldn't even see), there's no lives system and checkpoints are frequent. There's hardly any risk versus reward to keep you on your toes.

I knew in advance Chapter 5 was going to be a one-act final confrontation, and considering how impressively dark Chapter 3 is, I was expecting the game's last stand to be truly threatening. Turns out it's a hackneyed final area with a clichéd final boss fight that's all flashy effects and sappy exposition with not much of a fight. It comes out of nowhere without any buildup, too. And to top it off, the ending feels basic and incomplete. Normally this wouldn't bother me in a self-proclaimed collectathon, but A Hat in Time is more of a story-focused adventure game, so it's a shame it doesn't have any of the emotional resonance, complexity, or delicate pacing of your average story game.

A Hat in Time is the first game in its genre that I don't feel inclined to revisit. Most of the replay value is the scripted kind, where the game gives you dialogue options and they might each lead to a slightly different reaction.

It might sound like I hated everything about the game, but that's not true. I started out enjoying myself, and the end boss of Chapter 3 is an honest treat and the highlight of the game. But in the end, it felt very "manufactured" to me and was sometimes a real chore to play.

All the beauty of this game is in its polish instead of at its core. It reeks of missed potential.

It genuinely pains my heart to say that.

A Hat in Time has all the ingredients of a truly great game, but the recipe has all the wrong serving sizes, and it ultimately left a bitter taste in my mouth. I feel emptier than I would have felt if I'd just skipped it.

---

People seem to like bringing up that I prefer Yooka-Laylee, as if that somehow invalidates my criticisms.

My argument is that if you removed all of A Hat in Time's cutesy charm, you'd be left with a lot of straightforward, run-of-the-mill platforming missions with a few cool boss fights mixed in.

Yooka-Laylee is clearly the less polished and less detailed game, but it has all the things I think A Hat in Time lacks: gameplay variety, rewarding exploration, lots of freedom and replay value... I just find it to be a genuinely more fulfilling experience.

This isn't to say A Hat in Time is bad, but I'd only recommend it at one third of its $30 price.

35530306.review:
Its been a splendid year for the 3D Platforming genre. And noteably, the Platformer Collectathon catagory. Many a game tackles the Collectathon in different ways. But the motif that progress is made via a player's push to explore is usually the heart of it all. I discovered this game early 2016. All it took was an offhand mention from some video i was watching that somehow steered me to look it up.

It took no time at all for me to become intrigued, not immediately by the game, but by the team behind it. The charm and love they showed towards their product was more than evident, and their charisma alone is what sold the purchase. As an aspiring Game Designer myself, they reminded me exactly of the kind of team I want to be a part of some day. A team passionate about their project, with great chemistry all around. I had to now trust, that their game would reflect what i saw.

I paid extra for their Beta Bundle. Not only a secured pre-order of the final product, but an extra copy for a friend. On top of that, 2 copys of the Beta Build to boot. And the cherry was 2 copys of the soundtrack. How could i resist? And wonderfully enough, their Beta Build was already out for me to enjoy. Well, i say Beta Build, while it was more of a Beta Demo. It showcased only a few levels, but still felt like there was plenty of content in it to satisfy the long wait.

So quickly did my trust in devs turn into Love for the devs. Every single inch of every level was overflowing with charm and care. The atmosphere hit it out of the park. Any flaws that would pop up, would be overshadowed imediately by the joy that sets in. Of course, that joy was strong to me since 3D Platformers have always been my favorite, but i have no doubt even those with passing interest will find smiles to be had. Of course, those of you who prefer a more serious intense, mature narrative, then theres really no point. Its openly friendly to younger audiences so if you want something hardcore, by all means skip this game. I love me a good gore filled shooter but this kind of lovelyness is something I can always appreciate.

So there i was. My confidence fully earned. I had no doubt the final product would land in my favorites. It was easy to connect the dots, and assume such a thing so early on. But only because of the sheer quality presented so far. Fast forward to Oct 5, 2017 (Yesterday). The game was out. It was time to play. And i spent the next 8-9 hours smiling from title screen to the credits. And this morning, i returned to my save file, to go back and 100% the journey. Do all the optional stuff. And just revisit the parts i loved the most. Im so releived. It was just as good as predicted. I may have missed its kickstarter years ago, but i would give anything to go back in time and donate.

Now... before i go into my critiques, which will be as vague and spolier free as i can possibly make them, know that I whole heartedly recommend this game. Its great. Its a blast. And its a product im proud to say is indeed in my favorites. This next section is honestly mostly nitpicking but of course the game isnt perfect. Id hate to see the day a perfect game is made. What more could i look forward to then?

Chapter 1 was excellent. Top to bottom, a thrill. However, id already experienced a majority of it's levels during my time in the beta, so i knew what to expect. As a level design enthusiast, the layout of this place excites me to no end.

Chapter 2 ended up being my favorite. The game wastes no time after the first chapter showing you that theres plenty of formulas that work with this gameplay. I have no complaints, aside from maybe that the two levels that, well, lets say they center around a laid back penguin, felt lackluster in comparison to the two levels that center around a Irish/Scottish bird. Considering the theme of this chapter as a whole, i feel the Irish/Scottish Bird's levels embraced the concept better. The final level in this chapter however threw me by surprise, and more than flushed away the light dissapointment in the Laid Back Penguin's levels.

Chapter 3 is where things got strange for me. This chapter is very dark by the way. The game is friendly to younger audiences yes, but erm... hehe, i think this chapter will disturb and shock a lot of people. However, this is not the part i didnt like. In fact, i rather got a kick out that whole aspect. What perturbed me was how much of this world you can miss if you just focus the Level Objectives. Only those who go out of their way to ignore the object or come back later will experience the entirety of this environment. So much of it easily missable if youre not purposefully looking for goodies. I think this chapter could have benefited by routing your objective paths through these other areas. Aside from that, i must also take note that the main, ahem, sinister character this chapter centers around delivers the best voice performance hands down. Voiced by a youtuber/musician by the name Yungtown i beleive. Quite phenomenal. Bravo!

Chapter 4.... my least favorite. While personally, the sheer size of this world is cool and all, i think making it smaller would have been nice. Too many areas looked exactly the same too. Not as many landmarks as youd find in the other chapters. Which can make navigation difficult. However, regardless of it all looking similar, the asthetic itself is very pleasant and quite beautiful to look at. Its the most visually appealing chapter certainly. But while those two gripes are really minor to me, i do have a very legitimate complaint. This entire chapter felt void of any story. There was no characters to follow, no overarching plot that was interesting to follow. The chapter just sorta happens. The very little that did happen in terms of... "plot" was strangely confusing. If anything it felt like i caused it to happen in the first place, and its resolution just sorta happened as well. The two main inhabitants of this world desperately need fleshing out, and dialogue with the player. 1 of these species doesnt speak at all. The other main inhabitants dont ever talk to you. I mean, they have voice lines, that are really cute by the way, but they dont... TALK to you. The extent of a conversation is usually "Hey your objective is in that direction...." and thats it. I wish there was more active plot. But oh well, at least the platforming sections were rather fun.

Chapter 5, le finale. Aaaand i was honestly indifferent to it. I dunno. If anything, a bit dissapointing. Very by the books ending. I expected a little more creativity considering my experience up to this point. Seeing such clever takes on everything throughout my journey up till then made the standardish ending feel... i dunno, just sorta dull. Well done for what it is, but not creative enough.

And that wraps it up nicely. Thankfully looking back, any negatives i had towards the game were either heavily overshadowed by all the awesome, or not even worth noting to begin with. Even with my critique of chapter 4, i still enjoyed it regardless. The things that did shine about it, more than made up for it. So yes, i love this game. I wont leave a rating or anything, as rating systems are riddiculous anyways, i leave you with a very, very strong recommendation. You will either love it, or really like it. Good job Gears For Breakfast. I look forward to everything you make this day forward, and cant wait to start modding this game, hehe.

35530213.review:
If you loved Banjo Kazooie, Super Mario Sunshine, or Donkey Kong 64, you will love this game.

A Hat in Time manages to pull off a very dificult feat in that it pays tribute to all of these games (and others!) but it never feels like it's copying them. It has a unique feel, a fresh take on a stale genre, and brings back the magic you might have felt when you picked up your first 3d platforming adventure.

If you haven't played any of those games, AHiT is a wonderful ambassador for the genre and really shows you how fun it can be with its polished mechanics and charming world and sountrack.

Can't recommend it enough, I was very lucky to be able to experience this without knowing anything about it.

35529266.review:
A charming little game that shows that Kickstarter stories don't always end in failure. It matches it's own description of being a  "cute-as-heck 3D platformer" and still manages to pull ahead an possibly become one of my favorite 3D platformers of all time. As a longtime fan of games such as Super Mario 64/Sunshine and Donkey Kong 64; I can say for certain that A Hat In Time (AHiT) manages to encapsulate the essence of those games while still remaining unique on it's own rights. 

The game does a fantastic job of creating large open ended mission based levels which engulfs you into those worlds and makes you want to wander off the beaten path and search through every nook and cranny for whatever secrets may be in the world. Either in the form of a collectible or a sly quip from one of the many characters that fill the large worlds of AHiT or simply to go off and jump and dive around the various areas of the worlds, AHiT's levels always seem to be briming with content and character.

As an aside, this doesn't mean the game isn't without flaws. One of the most jarring things to me personally is the voice acting. Not even that it is bad in general, just that there are some bad voice actors, especially in the beginning of the game from a certain mustachioed character. The rest of the voice actors do some fine work and as always the game has plenty of ways to ignore that either through simply disabling dialogue from the audio settings to buying the mumble badge that gives all the characters a Banjo-Kazooie-esque mumble sound. This game did do the mumbles very well mind you, unlike yooka-laylee's forced mumble that to be fair was quite horrid. 

Another negative thing about the game would probably be the graphical fidelity of the game in terms of the character models. Some just don't look too good in and of themselves. The Mafia is a model that I may find in an older ps2 game or a very early xbox 360 game which looks jarring in comparison to the decent models on almost everything else. Thankfully the game's aesthetic does make up for it's shortcomings graphics wise thanks to the almost The Legend of Zelda: The Windwaker artstyle that makes the game feel very stylistcally sound and makes it a real beauty to look at.

Overall I would have to give this game a 9/10. I deeply enjoy most of the game. I adore the characters, I love the platforming and the levels for me are wonderfully constructed and I feel as if they had a lot of love put into them. The game does have some flaws and I do feel like they stop me from giving it another half a point or more.

One of the absolute best games i've played in the past few years - I haven't had this much fun with a platformer since Super Mario Sunshine first dropped.

[h1] A Hat in Time - Chapter 1 - Pros	[/h1]

[b] - Snappy and quick controls, the game is as fast as you can make it. [/b]
[b] - Full Mod Support [/b]
[b] - Colorful, vibrant worlds. [/b]
[b] - Wacky characters, wacky stories, and even more wacky level/hat design. [/b]
[b] - Tons of pop references, including valve, etc. [/b]
[b] - JonTron is in it, and as a birb. Already 11/10. [/b]
[b] - This game drips with passion, and you can feel it. I haven't seen anything copypasted besides a few props (like checkpoint lamps in the super mario sunshine platformer type levels, the hidden ones) but that's a given. [/b]
[b] - 1440p 144hz full support. [/b]
[b] - Variety of Controller hookups. [/b]
[b] - The ability to make a collectathon incredibly satisfying when you get items. [/b]
[b] - No energy meter for abilities, just a slight cooldown on certain ones. [/b]
[b] - The music is INCREDIBLE. If you would have told me it was done by Grant Kirkhope, I wouldn't have guessed. This game has it's own unique music and it's a knockout. [/b]
[b] - Voice acting is REALLY good and adds to the flavor of the game with storytelling and much more. Mafia sounds like mafia, spooky large devil ghost sounds like a spooky large devil ghost, and so on. [/b]
[b] - Hats!!!! [/b]
[b] - More Hats!!!! [/b]




[h1] A Hat in Time - Chapter 2 - Cons	[/h1]

[b] I can't really think of anything that seriously affects the game to call it a con. Only mild personal nitpicks that comes with every games (I.E. certain voices and so forth.) [/b]

35528384.review:
If you love platformers in any capacity, witty dialogue, variety and constantly interesting gameplay, and want an experience you'll be smiling through for the entire journey, A Hat in Time is for you.

This game takes a classic genre and updates it with modern game design philosophy, clever mechanics, and a whole lot of cute! A Hat in Time is about taking what you loved from 3D platformers, and cutting out what you didn't, and adding a whole lot more variety to make every single mission unique and memorable. While the game is a bit on the short side in terms of the base game, the A Hat in Time's 2 DLC chapters and workshop support should totally satisfy your craving.

While the game is short, it also doesn't have any filler. At all. Not a single mission that was there to fill time or pad out the game. You're constantly somewhere you haven't been, doing something you haven't done, with new set pieces and fantastic music to make that experience unique.

In short, A Hat in Time is a game with it's own personality and goals, and it's almost certain to make you have a fun time. Don't wait for a sale, just pick it up. It'll do you good!

35527578.review:
A Hat in Time, a game ive waited for for atleast 2 years, and have completed in 10 hours. While the game is still extrodinary it is far from perfect, with some major and some minor issues to be found, or maybe my expectations were too high.To anyone reading this, some parts are filled with overexaduration to further highlight the issues, i do not actually think THAT Negatively. Because im a negative nelly, i will start with the dissapointments.
1. The Characters / Story or "The Mafia, The Bad, and the Moustache Girl"
1.1 The Pathetic Excuse of a Villain 
*Spoilers?* After The Act 3 Of Mafia Town, Moustache Girl Ditches you, pickpocketing half of your money and goes on her quest to get time pieces herself. Do you see her doing anything? Does she ever meddle with you trying to get your time pieces? Yes, once. and its just there to set up the lackluster finale. It Wouldve been nice to have Moustache girl atleast interfere with you in some ways atleast once per chapter, because otherwise it seems like she just died offscreen, in the hall of villains that couldve been good. 
1.2 The Story, Beta To Full Release.
Now, i myself dont own the beta, i missed out on backing it, however, The Beta Had signs of a much more fleshed out story such as : The Mafia boss knowing about the time pieces. The Ending After The Beta Hero challenge, with a grown up hat kid in what looks like victorian london. What happens to that? Scrapped it seems. I get it that a game´s story goes through many phases but it has just been dumbed down to oblivion. there are no questions you have, Ever. "Why does the mafia boss know what the time pieces are?" was a thing i was dieing to find out in the full release, only to find the story to be on the same level as an IOS App. 
1.3 Characters, From charming to boring.
Again, ill have to bring up the beta, but Beta Snatcher messed with you towards the end of the mansion, which agreeable would make no sense in the current story, and the puzzle was admittably tedious, however, we dont get to see much of his character anyways, somewhat of a letdown. 
Moustache Girl, dramatically underused. you almost forget she exists.
The Mafia, they kept their charm, but you cant mess those amazing guys up.
Queen Vanessa , Underutilized but for that i dont blame you, she really was a minor character but had quite a bit of potential.
Moonjumper , Was Scrapped pretty damn early but a powerstruggle between vanessa him and snatcher wouldve been interesting, snatchy using you to tip the scales in his favor.
Mafia Boss , Again, his story got dumbed down.
The Conductor and DJ Grooves , Not much to say about them really, i never did like em anyways.
Roomba , The Single best story change, the roomba is the most amazing thing in the universe
2. The Feeling of Accomplishment, or "Just The Normal Ammount of Empty Inside"
This point is very nitpicky, and its kinda just picking up on the grown up hatkid thing again, but i was dissapointed because of the lack of a 40 TP reward. You get a hat. and its not even the best looking one. And its funny that its the regular hat, because that one points you to the nearest time piece, which you got all of. Atleast Something else wouldve been nice G4B. Additionally i dont feel motivated solving small puzzles (which there werent really a lot of) to open a chest to find...wool...woohoo...wool.
3. Chapter 4.  or "Sky High above Fun"
I just didnt like it. i wasnt a fan of the layout. im gonna admit that this is 100% my personal biased opinion instead of imposing flaws on it. Also, the lack of a bossfight.
4. Gameplay Balance and Smoothness of Combat or "Broken Prance"
4.1 Foreword
The Game may not be focused on combat, however certain badges and other things should still be mentioned.
4.2 Issues
There Are a Few issues with the combat, but ill focus on the ones that arent me just sucking
Issue 1 : The "Projectile" Badge. it isnt very usefull, its actually more of a hinderance when you accidnetally activate it and get killed, because you thought it was a cool badge, newsflash, it aint. Though it was fun using another beam to counter-beam the final boss´ final phase.
Issue 2 : The "TIME STOP" hat or "Timepiece Crusaders Ep. 45, Hatkid´s WORLD"
One thing i didnt like was that its called time stop and not time slow, small nitpick
additionally, it is an instant win for bosses. especially on the final one. its ok for it to be a good usefull hat, but in puzzles it was rarelly "needed" and was really just a nice addition making puzzles Easier. Also, does that thing even have skins?
Combine it with Fast Hatter and you can beat the girl with a testosterone defficiency into a pulp.
What im trying to say here is "Pls Nerf" as silly as it sounds, to do such a thing in a single player game, but it needs an overhaul cause it feels genuinely tacked on as a last minute addition
Issue 3 : Lack Of Enemy Variety. You need more enemy types for a game, man. not just 4 recolours of birds.
5. The Overworlds & General Gripes
5.1 The Pickup futility
Look G4B, i appreciate you give me the wool i need, but i dont quite think that making 50% of all pickups on the map into wool is a good idea. Jokes Aside, i dont feel motivated searching areas for pickups that i dont need and dont need for 100%. Most Relic Boxes Only contain rift tokens due to the next point.
5.2 Underutilization of the Relic System. 
As much as i hate padding the game with countless same-y pickups, atleast two sets of relics wouldve been nice instead of just 4, they genuinely intrigued me about what they could do. The Second set wouldnt even need to be one of the purple (really well done) time rifts. it could just be something stupid and cosmetic.
6. The Good Stuff
Now that youve listened to me ramble on about things i probably dont understand, lts get to the stuff done well
6.1. The Visuals. A Perfect, cute cartoony style that fits all enviorments and is allways well done.
6.2. The Platforming and exploring, A perfectly well made thing. Though id have prefered a few time pieces to be hidden in the enviorment behind puzzles instead of them all being inside of rifts or acts. Generally, allways pefectly solid even in my least favorite chapter, chapter 4.
6.3 The OST. its Friggin Art.
6.4 Controls, near perfect. Though sometimes the scooter feels like a downgrade from the sprint
6.5 The Hat Powerup System overall. the hats feel like organic upgrades to the character instead of only existing to deal with certain switches or something, except for the case of the ice hat which i still love to bits.
6.6 The Hat Skins & Colours. They look dope.
6.7 The existance of the camera badge. its a great addition not many studios would care about, probs to you G4B
7. [b] Conclusion [/b]
I Like this game a lot, i intend on getting all the achievements and i will stay interested in anything that develops. Its a Good First Game of hopefully many from this developer.Although i was dissapointed by a few things,I Reccomend it, but id also reccomend waiting for a steam sale cause 30 dollars is a bit too much. Overall a 7.3/10. Additionally, Superior to yooka laylee in every way.
Edit : I had completely forgotten about the two bonus chapters, which may fix some issues with the story i had, but they also may not.

This game brings together everything you could possibly ask for and more in a 3D platformer. Excelling mobility options, fluid controls that are a blast to use, a great sense of humour, memorable characters, and a stellar soundtrack to boot. It evidently takes influence from games like Mario 64 or Sunshine (Even with the hourglass collection animation having some clear inspiration from both of those games), taking their style and adding a special flare that makes the experience feel undescribably great.

35526413.review:
This game definitely has the potential to be a masterpiece.

I've been playing and following this game ever since they launched the alpha test and man have they improved on every apsect of the game since then; the movement used to be a bit stiff but now they've made it floatier which works much better since this game relies heavily on vertical movement but not only that ground movement has been improved so much, they've made it more precise and the slide jump now has a function where if you time it right you can get a small boost which is perfect for speedrunning areas.

The OST is just perfect for this game and I believe Grant Kirkhope worked on at least one track for this so you know it's going to be good.

The visuals in this are exactly the way they ought to be; think of a mix between The Wind Waker and Super Mario Sunshine and that's what this game is.

It does have some technical problems in some areas though. The camera sometimes goes a bit wonky and the collision detection might not be the best at times but these are minor gripes that rarely happen. Surely these problems will be fixed in future updates.

Totally recommend if you're a fan of old N64 platformers and thought Yooka-Laylee wasn't up to par.

35523382.review:
A Hat in Time does a fresh take on the old collectathon with fluid and intuitive controls, that make you feel right at home if you've ever played games like Mario 64 or Sunshine. The concept is simple with act based missions to actually progress in the game, while leaving you a ton of room to just roam and explore the maps for collectibles. Many of the missions are made in such a way that they change the gameplay aspects slightly, which gives you fun little variations.

If you're a fan of 3D plaftormers at all, I strongly recommend you to give this game a try. Even if you don't like the collectible hunting part, you can enjoy the game pretty thoroughly without much side tracking.

Pretty much every npc in the game is voiced, and it's a real pleasure to listen to them not only talk but also make tons of jokes and bad puns. The comedy is there, if you don't like the jokes from the get go however, you most likely won't enjoy them during the entire game, I personally had good laughs pretty often.

The game also has a really solid soundtrack overall.

35523349.review: Words cannot describe how incredible this little gem of a game is.

35523162.review:
TL;DR A great platformer, and a shining example of a Kickstarter gone wonderfully right. I felt like a kid again. Not enough cute hats to wear. I need more cute hats.

Visuals: The art is charming and the worlds are unique and vibrant. Plenty of background details for those who decide to explore each level (you should). Conductor is the best, followed by Snatcher and the not-G-Men C.A.W. agents.

Music: Phenomenal. Hard to pick a favorite track, but a solid OST (the devs said they had to exclude some tracks because the OST was getting huge, so hopefully they release that later -- go bug them about it).

Gameplay: Controls are tight, simple, and fun to play with. Takes the best parts of Super Mario Sunshine's platforming and expands on them. You'll be dashing, sliding, and double-jumping and dash cancelling into a wall run/jump from the moment you pick up the game. Only gripe is that the platforming is too easy. Even the secret worlds a la Sunshine are easy. There's also a lot of beta content that was cut, even though it was interesting. It's probably up to modders to restore this, since the devs don't seem interested in expanding on what they had. Hopefully the mod tools are easy to use, so that we get more fan-made levels. Two additional worlds, co-op, and Steam workshop "soon"™. The second half of the game does seem like it was focused on less than the first half, but I still had fun.

Story: Sorta whatever. Mustache Girl is almost a non-character for most of the game. There's some "lore", but it seems to be a joke by the devs. Don't worry about the story too much.

Technical: Models need a bit more polish. A few glitches here and there that haven't affected gameplay for me, but the hit detection has failed me a few times when going to grab onto a platform (extremely rare -- this only happened to me on Dead Bird Studio's time rift, with the pipes that you have to grab onto and sort of wall jump off of). Also, the checkpoint system that saves you from accidentally falling off a platform onto an area below (great feature, saves you from having to climb all the way back up) is sometimes a little oversealous (only happened twice -- Dead Bird Studio's basement act, where you have to jump off a pipe onto a duct to get a yarn was impossible for me because it kept resetting, and one island in Alpine where it kept thinking I was falling even though I made deliberate jumps to skip sections of the map and wouldn't have died).

If anyone bothers reading all of that, you should pick this up if you want a solid (albeit tragically short) platformer. A shame that this ended up being released near Cuphead and Mario Odyssey, this is a good game that will probably have to survive on word of mouth amidst these two storms.

35522289.review:
Here's some bug fixes for you guys

1. If you downloaded a mod and it doesn't function properly (or doesn't function at all), all you have to do is go to Program Files (x86) > Steam > Steam apps > Common > Hat in time > Hat in time game > Mods. Delete all the mods (folders) except for "Steam Workshop", then restart the game. Also sometimes (sometimes means 90% of the time) when a mod is updated, you won't receive the update. If it happens then just do what I mentioned earlier (delete the mod folders), and all mods should be updated instantly.

2. If you're trying to launch the game and it says "A Hat in Time has stopped working", then do one of the following:

- Uninstall and after that reinstall the game (DON'T FORGET TO BACK UP YOUR SAVE FILES, THIS IS VERY IMPORTANT)
- Delete all the mod folders (and don't forget to unsubscribe from the mods in "Steam Workshop")

3. If you experience any major bugs or glitches that aren't listed here, report them to the official "A Hat in Time" discord: https://discord.gg/Ax2swSU

People that you'll see there:

MekuCube (Jonas Kaerlev, the creator and the lead writer of the game)
Hypo (Cameron Turner, the lead 3D artist and animator on the game)
Jenna (Jenna Brown, the lead 2D artist on the game) 
etc...

4. If you wanna know the history behind "A Hat in Time", like how it came to be? Or what content has been cut from the final release? Or why did they scrapped Adult Hat Kid, then I recommend you to watch an interview with Jonas Kaerlev by "BETA 64": https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Jt7tIDulslI

------------------------------------------------------


Now for my actual review of the game (you probably don't care at this point but whatever)

When you'll play "A Hat in Time" for the first time you're probably gonna be like "This plays a lot like Mario Sunshine" or "This looks a lot like Zelda: Wind Waker" for 10 minutes. But once you'll dive deep into the game, you realize that "A Hat In Time" is a fully original, colorful, memorable journey from beggining to end.

It combines almost everything people love about "3D Platformers", while adding it's own things, and while you're kinda right about the gameplay being very reminiscent of "Super Mario Sunshine" and "Psychonauts", it doesn't try to fully replicate it. This game is also not like "Yooka-Laylee" where you're going to look at the characters and think "Oh, it's kinda like Banjo-Kazooie" or "Oh, it's kinda like Mario" right? No, it's not like that at all here. "A Hat In Time" is it's own thing and nothing else.

Pros:

Game has a great sense of humor
Controls smoothly with both Keyboard and Gamepad
The level design is fantastic
Characters are all interesting and brimming with personality
Power-ups all have very interesting or just helpful abilities
Mod Support!! (You'll never run out of content to play)

Cons:

You currently can't collect everything in the game
Story is kind of random and ending just sort of happens

To Come:

Two additional worlds will arrive later as free DLC
New Game+ 
Developer Commentary
Local and Online Co-Op
More Badges, Hats and pallete swaps

It's an amazing "3D Platformer" that it's now my 2nd favorite game of all time. Cannot recommend the game enough, potential GOTY here.


P.S. DON'T LEWD THE HAT KID!!

35521580.review:
This game is an adorable, fun 3d platformer, the best I've played in years!

It plays similarly to Mario 64, but with some added mobility features that help immensely while platforming or just moving around the map, such as the ability to sprint (and later, even ride on a moped) and the ability to dive while in mid air, allowing you to extend your jump as well as correct your trajectory.

The game is split to several worlds, each world containing several "acts", some of which take place in the same map, while others take place in their own unique map. In each of these acts you can collect "relics" that allow you to unlock secret missions, as well as yarn to create more hats, along with the obligatory hourglasses, that are this game's equivalent of Mario 64's stars, acquired through completion of map objectives.

This game's tone is very lighthearted, with some genuinely good humor (exceedingly rare in gaming nowadays) and some funny characters, though not all of them are paritcularly memorable or good.

If I had to voice some complaints though:
The game is a bit buggy, I've not finished it yet and have gotten stuck on terrain on multiple times, having to restart the level (thankfully, all progress is saved instantly, meaning that any pick up you find is permanently yours, whether or not you finished a map objective).
The camera needs a bit of work, it's fine in open spaces, but in tight corridtors it can go crazy, and also sometimes it just moves in a way that really messes with your ability to jump accurately, at one point I even turned off the automatic camera because it was too much to deal with.
The music is very hit or miss. Some of the levels have some great music, while others have music that was just annoying as hell to me, to the point where I turned it off. But this is an entirely subjective complaint and I suspect different people are gonna have different mileage.

Overall, the game is very, very good. It's great fun, and if you like 3D platformers, do not pass this up!
