A Hat in Time - платформер в стиле Psychonauts и Mario 64, 

+ Милый персонаж: главная героиня - ребенок без имени, путешествующая по космосу в поисках дома. 
+ Красивые и разнообразные локации: город мафии, движущийся поезд, киностудия, горная деревня в облаках, пугающий особняк и темный лес.
+ Огромное количество секретов и тайных мест в которые можно попасть при помощи открывающихся со временем способностей.
+ Удобное отзывчивое управление (играю с Dualshock 4).
+ Отличный саундтрек, динамически подстраивающийся под ситуацию.
+ Много шляп и заколок, открывающих способности героини.

- Озвучка не очень хорошая. Некоторые голоса не подходят NPC. Будто слушаешь любительскую американскую озвучку какого-то аниме.
- Камера часто поворачивается в неудобное положение.

Вердикт: покупать, если вы любите веселые платформеры. Ждать скидки, если не уверены.

35519303.review:
Personally, I've only played this for few hours, but I can already say its a solid game. It's surprisingly small for a game like this and runs smoothly despite my laptop not working as well as a proper PC. The designs are incredible and I felt a joy wandering around the worlds, finding secrets and collectives. The story is also solid and has a humour that made me giggle multiple times. Unlike some other platformers I've played, I feel the controls to be very responsive. I was worried of this the moment I started the game,  but I found it runs smoothy even by using keyboard!

I absolutely adore the voice acting and the marvelous character designs. They are one of the most unique ones I've seen in a while, which each one brings personality. The hats also are very well done, and I love the addons or 'skins' you can get for them as well. Their abilities don't feel too over powered, nor underpowered. They feel balanced. 

My main problems are that there are things that aren't polished, things like text moving outside of text boxes and countless glitches, which so far have only once made me start over the level because I got stuck between walls. I also found the Mafia boss on world 1 be extremelly tiresome because of the 'Mafia ball' being glitchy. Not only did you get hit often when you were trying to get on top of it, you also got stuck often in a way that you are unable to hit the boss. 

Update: I've now encountered a massive game-breaking glitch in chapter 2 finale in the boss. After a specific character does a thrust with a knife and goes for a new type of attack ( I assume), My camera glitched and so did the others. I couldn't die, so my only choice was to exit the level, only to find that I have to go through the same frustrating platform level to get to the boss. In general, I think the game should have a 'Reset to the last checkpoint' option in case of a gamebreaking glitch like this. Same chapter I also got stuck inside of a place I couldn't get out from.

I'd give it a solid 8/10 so far. I love it, but it just needs a little more polishing. Maybe the creators will find this out and maybe update the game with glitch removal.

35519182.review:
这是个类似3D马里奥的游戏。
吸引我的是萌萌哒主角，带着帽子的魔术师形象让我想起了逆转裁判里的美贯，人物还是挺萌的。
因为没有中文，我的英文也不是太好，也没玩多久，只能看出一点大概。剧情对白倒无所谓，游戏的主要也不是剧情。但像是购买道具时的英文说明就有点麻烦，这点其实还是影响游戏体验的，不过问题不是很大。
游戏全程就是控制女主角跑上跳下，攻击怪物，收集各种各样的收集物。游戏的主线是收集燃料fuel（时间碎片，+1s）给飞船续命。除此之外，其他的收集物有可以换取各种道具的货币；制作新帽子的毛线等等。
女主角有攻击能力，也有生命值系统，被怪物触碰攻击会减少一格，可以通过收集生命值道具恢复。
如同游戏的名字，帽子是游戏特色。游戏中，你可以通过收集毛线来依次获得各种各样的新帽子。它们在佩戴时都具有各种各样不同的能力，可以随意切换。例如我刚打过第一个BOSS，制作了两顶新帽子。游戏开始时默认的魔术师帽子的特殊能力是可以直接指出目标的位置；第二顶红帽子可以让女主角有奔跑的能力；第三顶帽子可以制作炼金炸弹丢出去。
总的来说，喜欢这种画风，然后比较喜欢跳来跳去收集的可以考虑入手。

35518777.review:
A charming 3d platformer that controls like a dream. Mac users beware though as it seems to run like hot garbage on mac.

A Hat in Time is a game where the act of simply moving and navigating the terrain is fun. While I have not played Yooka-Laylee nor know the exact feel of the gameplay, I can only assume it was much like the banjo series it was trying to spiritually success. Unfortunatly replicating something so aged isn't always fun.

A Hat in Time circumvents these issues by being superb in all areas without relying on being a carbon copy to a specific old title. It's quite literally fantastic besides a few quirks that may vary person to person.

Things you may nitpick most likely.
-The first boss' song just feels really jarring and unfitting.
-Sprite faces. They're not the best, but they ain't bad.
-Initial comparing of controls to something else you feel better, but like all games you'll adapt.
-The ground slam attack that almost every boss seems to have and it's really annoying everytime.
-Lost because you forgot your first hat exist and acts as a wayfinder when all the other hints somehow fail to point you in the right direction.
-General lack of any puzzle solving skills leading to you getting stuck a few times.
-Trying to do more then you can when starting the first stage.
-Camera, but let's face it almost any game with a unfixed thirdperson camera is gonna do some weird jank time to time if you aren't manhandling it at all.

35516172.review:
베타테스트 버전을 플레이하며 1년 반 동안 기다려 왔던 나에게는 모든 것이 환상적이었다.

 소수의 개발진이 만들었다고는 믿기지 않을 정도의 퀄리티에 그 안에서 느낄 수 있는 과거 3D 플랫포머의 향수는 아직도 잘 먹히는 것 같다. 젤다의 전설 : 바람의 택트 같은 그래픽에 슈퍼마리오 64나 Banjo-Kazooie 시리즈 같은 게임 플레이. 이것이 만나 걸출한 작품 하나가 완성되었다.

또한 이러한 게임들이 스피드 런에 특화되어있다는 것을 인식했는지 스피드 런 이벤트를 개최하거나 게임 내에 타이머 기능이 내장되어있다. 많은 유저들이 스피드런을 즐겨 하고 있다는 것을 반영하여 게임을 개발했다는 것을 알 수 있다.

 킥스타터를 통해 모금되었던 게임인 만큼 우려도 많았지만 (옆동내에 No.9이라던지...) 개발 중에도 유저들과의 적극적인 소통과 알파, 베타 테스트 버전의 공개들로 성공적인 게임 출시를 하였다.

 그리고 게임의 주요 요소 중 하나인 음악도 칭찬할 만 하다. Banjo-Kazooie의 음악을 담당한 Grant Kirkhope가 이번 작품에 참여하였으며 몰입도 있는 음악을 제공하였다.

 A Hat in Time은 과거 3D 플랫포머의 전통을 이었다고 생각하며 유저들로 하여금 과거의 재미를 다시 한 번 느끼게 해주는 작품이라고 생각한다.

35514102.review:
Here's some pretty extensive thoughts of A Hat in Time after playing it for 8-9 hours & completing about half of the game (my percentage on my main file is about 50% done right now, & I've completed 21/40 levels the game has so far.

A Hat in Time's story follows a nameless girl (aka Hat Kid) who is an alien who's ship runs on hourglasses that store time, having the ability to rewind & freeze time. Due to some silly shenanigans involving the mafia on a planet she's passing, her ship crashes and her 40 hourglasses spread across the planet. She goes off to collect them all, meeting a colorful cast of characters along the way. The game's story isn't going to win any awards, but I've been surprised how much I've enjoyed it thus far. The characters are voice acted, & so far the voice acting is pretty good (there's also a badge you can equip which makes them to 'mumble' speak if you wish... more on badges in a bit).A few of the characters I've already come to love, plenty have time to let you come to know them & find them likable or not. I also appreciate the game's villain angle, everything is kind of a gray area in the game. The good guys aren't wholly good, the bad guys aren't wholly bad. Hat Kid actually doesn't seem to care about good vs evil, there's a do-gooder who has a morale high-ground of sorts & can't understand why Hat Kid doesn't want to use her hourglases for good, but Hat Kid just wants her hourglasses back. The bosses you face aren't strictly because they're the bad guys, just they're in your way to collect your hourglasses back. Motives for the bosses so far often have to do with wanting the hourglasses to go back in time & undo a mistake in their past, something they'll do anything to change rather than because they're evil, which I find an interesting dynamic. I don't know obviously if the story holds up all the way through yet, but I like it for what it is so far.

Game has a hub world, which is Hat Kid's ship. The ship loses power & needs the hourglasses to restore it. Get more hourglasses, & more of the ship unlocks as well as access to a new world becomes available to play. The hub world is fun to explore & gets more added to it over time, including patrons who decide to board & do small things for you (ranging from allowing you to switch music in stages to selling you something or just loitering with flavor text). Out of the many collectibles in the game are souvenirs you can find (split into pieces though), which you bring back to your ship & you organize on one of a few pedestals (you have to manually stack them though). If you complete a souvenir, you unlock a new bonus level in one of the stages you can then access, which includes a harder than usual level with collectible pictures that give you a picturebook story (no text, all pictures though) of the backgrounds of the characters who live there.

Speaking of collectibles, the collectibles here are well done, which works well for a collectathon. Every one is linked to something, there's no 'useless' collectible. Green orbs you get everywhere is your main currency, which you can use at a shopkeeper to buy new badges, to buy some new missions in levels, & some other misc things. There's different types of yarn you can collect, which gives you different hats. The hats all give you different powers, & you can change them on the fly with the d-pad or choose one from a menu of hats that slows down times. The hats abilities range from letting you speed forward, doing a statue-esque ground pound, an aura which makes certain transparent objects appear, & more. You also can collect customizable looks for your hats, as well as different colors for your main character.

There's also badges, which are kind of your power-ups in the game. You buy them from the store mostly, but some you get from other means. At the start of the game you can only equip one badge, but there's two upgrade slots you can buy from the shop to equip three badges total. Badges do everything from giving you a grappling hook to decreasing hat ability charge time to a map showing you where nearby souvenirs are, among many other things. You can change them on the fly in the middle of the level whenever you like, & they're fun to mess around with & think what's best for a situation. And then of course, the main goal of the game is to collect back your 40 hourglasses.

I feel the game's controls are going to have some mixed reactions, but I actually REALLY like them. They're a bit floatier than some platformers, & some may have different preferences here to me, but once you begin to get a handle on them you can do some crazy stuff. They can do a great job at making you kind of feel like you're parkouring, as you can run up walls for a short time, wall jump, slide to go faster, dash in the air, do a double jump, & you can begin combo-ing these things like jump, double jump while in the air, dash in the air ahead, hit a wall, wall jump off the wall, dash in the air again & do a double jump off that dash. It also can combo well into the other abilities you begin to get, like the running ability can run up walls a bit higher (as faster), or the grappling hook can chain very well into things. One ability I was not expecting at all is kind of a homing attack similar to Sonic, where if you're close enough to an enemy in the air you can press the attack button to dash towards them in the air as a homing strike. It's not all very complex, but well handled in my opinion, I personally really like the movement & almost parkour element the game has sometimes.

All of this wouldn't matter if the game wasn't fun, which at least I think it's insanely fun. The missions are very creative with a lot of twists & turns. I don't want to speak too much in-depth here, but there's a LOT of variety of what you're doing. The game shows all sorts of inspirations everywhere in its worlds & missions, & has its own set of unique twists on each one. The game is the sort of game where one level is a murder mystery on a train & you're collecting suspects while avoiding being caught, to a previously fine island level being loaded with lava and having to maneuver in a whole new way due to the change, to a sort of Luigi's Mansion/Resident Evil/Amnesia hybrid horror level, to a level where you rush to go from press meet to press meet trying to become a diva & get your reputation up by publicity stunts, or going behind the scenes of a studio in a segment that almost has tinges of something like Portal. There's a lot that happens, & then in what happens there's a lot of twists within the twists, & a lot of cleverly timed and amusing jokes & surprises.The game never loses its identity through this, but you end up going through a large variety of scenarios, & different kinds of stages (the main kind of stages are kind of open-world playgrounds that Collectathoners may know, something akin to Mario 64/Sunshine esque style, but there's some very different other types of levels, including these challenge levels that heavily remind me of Mario Sunshine, more linear affairs or sub-areas in the levels with their own flavor & level design).

I've fought two bosses so far. The bosses in this game are surprisingly not that easy, they take like 20-30 hits before they die & have multiple phases. The second boss I fought I REALLY liked, so much so I won't spoil it.

Music is fantastic, it has some stand-out tracks but all of it I've heard so far is quite good. There's also several variations of most themes which kick in during different gameplay moments, which does amp up & do what's intended.

I need to see if this game falls apart in the second half of the game, & I won't claim everyone will love it as much as I have so far, but this I think is going to be a top five Collectathon title for me. It has made me smile on multiple occasions, I've had a lot of fun with its mechanics, surprises, level design, missions, characters, and collecting.

35514043.review: I've played a handful of levels including the first couple of boss fights and I must say that despite the relatively high production values with full voice acting, cut scenes, little details and context animations alongside tons of unique art assets, it leaves a lot to be desired. The controls don't feel quite tight and fun enough although they technically work and aren't a hindrance to the gameplay objectives. Especially the overall combat and boss battle mechanics are very lacking in feel. It's not nearly as polished as I'd expect (or as polished as the games it's inspired by) and I actually found myself enjoying far lower budget efforts like "Skylar & Plux" and especially "Poi" (both are on Steam so look them up if you're into this sort of game) a lot more personally. This probably has a lot more content (and a higher price of course) but when the core feel isn't as fun as I'd like that doesn't mean much. Overall I'd say A Hat in Time seems to be about on par with Yooka-Laylee to me (so, underwhelming for most but the die hard fans) when all is said and done, although this is more impressive given the smaller and more technically amateur team I guess. Perhaps some patches will resolve my main issues but I don't know if they'd even agree that there are issues at all, perhaps that's just how they meant for it to be designed and consider it a total success in that aspect. I don't want to leave a negative review but I can't bring myself not to.

35513644.review:
For some context, I backed this game about four years ago.

This game is a brilliant example of what a great platformer game looks like. After the Kickstarter started to receive some action, Yooka-Laylee soon came about and overshadowed it. Now Yooka-Laylee promised to be a"new Banjo-Kazooie" that would bring fans' needs of platforming back to the mainstream. Of course, that failed, as Yooka-Laylee lacked character.

A hat in time, however, is completely full of it. I've run into a couple of major glitches so far, such as one that is similar to the backward long-jump in Mario 64, but none of these have made my enjoyment of the game any less. 

The actual gameplay is pretty simple. Its style is nothing new, but it acts more like an amalgamation of several great platforming games. Many of the controls and interactions feel like Mario Sunshine and the style of the power-ups feels a lot like those from Banjo-Tooie. 

I have a butt-ton of games in my library and because of this, I don't usually spend too much time on a single game. With A Hat in Time, however, I plan to get as close to 100% as I can.

35513566.review: If you love 3D platformers in the vein of Super Mario 64, Super Mario Sunshine and Banjo Kazooie; then this is the game for you. It delivers a solid experience, with great controls (no bad cameras here) and a fantastic art style reminiscent of Wind Waker plus a cuteness factor and unimaginable charm. I backed this game on Kickstarter in 2013, and I can wholeheartedly say that it was completely worth the wait!

While I've played Mario 64 since then, I still have not spent a large amount of time in the genre. So when I say that I love this game and everything it does, know that I am not blinded by nostalgia. While there may be a few instances where I want to see more, but I can't get the right camera angle, it has not affected my platforming so much as my visibilty when searching for collectibles. The platforming is incredibly solid, the skills you unlock are interesting, and there are even vanity unlockables - different styled hats and alternate color schemes for Hat Kid. Gears for Breakfast has made a very solid game, and I am a very happy backer.

35512118.review:
A Hat in Time is a cute 3D platformer-collectathon. I've been waiting for this game for a few years, and so far it's everything I wanted it to be, which is basically a Super Mario Sunshine spiritual successor on PC. Controls and camera work seem fine even with a mouse and keyboard. Game lacks a proper tutorial that explains everything, but you can get used to the controls after the first level.

The humor is light and the core gameplay loop is casual. The game lets you progress at your own pace. I'll probably put in 12 hours or more on this game, since I like collecting everything. If you're not like that, the game could probably be finished at around 6 hours.

This is a good quality game that's worth the $29.99 price tag. Level editor, mods, and co-op in the future are something to look forward to. Only downside is the forgettable soundtrack, probably not worth the DLC price. Also would have loved Steam trading cards. (EDIT: Trading cards now added.)

35512032.review:
Having backed this game waaay back in 2013, I can safely say A Hat in Time is well worth the wait. 

Without spoiling much you have four worlds (with 2 more in the form of free DLC on the way) with about sevenish levels each, plus additional challenge levels. The game takes inspiration from Super Mario Sunshine in many aspects, from how Hat Kid handles to the nature of the challenge levels. The writing is very clever with some good jokes every now and then and the voice acting (which most of the game's dialogue is voice acted) is quite good. Missions are quite diverse, giving you a range of scenario's to partake in one world. The badges available in the game (which are equipable abilities such as the default grappling hook or the coin magnet) are quite varied, some don't give you abilities but can change the game slightly (such as one that reduces your HP to 1 for challenge runs or another that muffles all the voice acting so it's comparable to Banjo Kazooie's voice clips).

Plus the variety of available options in the menu guarantee you can run this game even on a pretty crappy computer (I use a Lenovo Ideapad which is more for business than video games)

Now, A Hat in Time isn't perfect, that's to be expected. But don't fret, the faults I had with the game were few and far between, and the blast I had with the game far outweighed the faults.

To be frank, we've had a lot of big name Kickstarter disappointments since 2013, but Gears for Breakfast delivered on their promise to give us a great 3D collectathon platformer, and although some features are coming post launch (such as co-op) I can fully guarantee this is a game that any fan of the 3D collectathon platformer genre will want to pick up.

35511612.review:
Simply put: A Hat in Time is love letter to an era defined by Nintendo's 3D Platformers, which can be seen in the forms of Super Mario 64, Super Mario Sunshine, and Rare's Banjo-Kazooie duology.

It has all the makings of solid platformer, infused with colorful graphics, funny story telling, and unique & varied gameplay styles in levels throughout. DNA from other platformers such as Psyconauts, Rachet & Clank, and even Conker's Bad Fur Day can be seen through its unique story-telling, level design, and collectibles.

It's definitely the next "Mario Sunshine" in all senses, and I feel this will be a new age classic that will live down in history as the shining star of the resurgence of 3D Platformers. It will certainly be a darling of this era, which I suspect will live up to Undertale and other such titles.

In all, this is this studio's first title, and that's utterly imressive. It'f fun, charming, challenging, creative - all the marks, and I can't wait to see what Gears for Breakfast has to offer next.

This is the most charming game I've played this year as well as a true 3d platformer made by a level designer that clearly understands good platforming. Your Hat Kid is easy and fun to control and run around with, and the better you get with her the more fluid your navigation becomes. 

Besides the absolutely top notch platforming, this is a game with very distinct levels and characters that are actually memorable. There's world building that really stays with you, and there are some absolutely brilliant moments in here. 

In an industry where you get so many cookie cutter, copy-paste worlds out there, it's nice to play something that was clearly hand-made with attention to detail. 

I really wish there was more of it, though I think you can 100% it in around 20 hours which isn't particularly long. I hear there's more levels coming, plus a coop mode so I'm more than hype to keep this game installed. It was so good actually, I might replay it. 

Easy recommend. If you don't have a Nintendo system, this is the best platformer you'll play for years.

35510179.review:
First off, I'm going to begin by saying that I have been following the development of A Hat in Time literally since day one (back in 2012 when the creator first posted a video on an experimental UDK game he had just started on.) I managed to keep myself from any spoilers whatsoever (other than the one that he spoiled about the antagonist almost immediately after creating her) by not watching any videos of the beta or alpha builds that were out. So, now that I've got my hands on the game, what do I think about it? I think it's pretty good so far. The music is creative and fun to listen to, the characters are of an interesting and entertaining design, the gameplay is pretty solid and reminiscent of Super Mario Sunshine, Super Mario Galaxy, and a hint of the developer's mod for Team Fortress 2 that he developed, "Parkour Fortress." I haven't gotten a chance to check out too many of the levels so far, but I'm having a lot of fun. I would like to make a note, though, at the time of writing this review, I had noticed a number of simple yet noticeable glitches that are in the game. Firstly, and this is the most major one, if you walk into some objects and then open up the hat selection menu, hat kid will start floating up into the air and clip above the ceiling. So far, this hasn't caused any problems, as the walls seem to extend up infinitely, but it's definitely something that should be taken note of. Secondly, I found that during the first level of the game, when moustache girl asks you to climb up to her and the game shows you the button that allows you to do so, if you instead climb up the rock face onto the construction site-esque building next to you, and then double jump + slide from the edge to reach the top of the belltower that moustache girl is in, she won't move, as, for some reason, the developers didn't think that the player would find their own way of making it up to the top and didn't include a backup trigger or even a simple temporary player clip so that this could be avoided.
In conclusion, I'm liking the game so far and think it's been worth the 5 year wait watching it be developed, even though the game has a number of day 1 bugs. Also, tell people if you're going to include a pack that has the game bundled with the soundtrack for less than both individually, I bought the two seperately at the same time and I could've saved a few bucks :p.
p.s. I liked the prototype theme for mafia town, bring it back!

Now? The concept is still great and its even cuter than it was before. And wouldn't you know it the artstyle is solid, controls tight and intuitive, easy to learn but difficult to master. I can only imagine somebody who played the alpha would be astounded at how much it progressed since.

Buy it. And the soundtrack.

EDIT: The game keeps improving with Workshop support. Its now even more awesome.

Incredibly charming and fun 3d platformer collectathon. Control Hat Girl as she explores several worlds to gather Hourglasses to get her home. Packed with hat powers, badge upgrades, and fun characters.

As of writing this, CooP, Mod support, and 2 extra worlds are to be implemented at some future point.

It feels like a nice and refreshing game that harkens back to gaming classics such as Mario 64, Sunshine,  Banjo-Kazooie, and Psychonauts. 

Hat Girl traverses fairly quickly with double jump, sprinting, and diving -- which makes her very nice to just move. Paired with an actually good camera makes her incredibly satisfying to just travel and explore.

While a Hat in Time will not break any new grounds, its a true love letter that brings both the good and the bad that 3d platformers offered. And is every bit as charming and fun to explore in. A must have for fans of the genre, and honestly the DEFINITIVE PC collectathon.

35509698.review:
[h1] Final Review [/h1]

After playing and completing A Hat in Time I decided it was time to conclude my review. 

Note - 
The company has begun to fulfill their kickstarter promises! Prior, this review was negative due to concerns that they would NOT follow through like other companies have. They have added steam workshop which was one of the requirements for my review change. Did my review motivate the developers? No, no it didn’t, I mainly posted the negative review to check out the community.

[h1] Pros [/h1]
- Awesome worlds
- Great graphics
- Decent soundtrack
- Unique enemies
- Boss battles are cool
- Plot line is okay
- Main character is cute
[u] Overall A Great Game [/u]


[h1] Cons [/h1]
- Relatively short story ( Beat it in 12 hours, spent a lot of time looking around )
- Graphical glitches
- Semi-junky camera
- Absolutely zero depth perception ( Makes some parts extremely difficult)
- Poor level design for some missions
- No Ultrawide monitor support ( Still playable on a ultra wide, but it just widens the screen. No 2560 x 1080 and 3440 x 1440 )

[h1] Ehhhhhhhhhhhhhsssssssssssssssssss [/h1]
- Community seems to be heading in a spooky direction.

This game is great. Characters are unique, gameplay is good, missions are fun. You'll enjoy it! Hopefully they will add multiplayer down the line. I have confidence they will. 

[h1] Point Score [/h1]
[h1] 9/10 [/h1]
+ Good characters
+ Beautiful graphics
+ Solid controls
+ Boss are unique
-  No ultrawide support
- Currently not enough content
- Game graphical and camera glitches

[i] Feel free to leave commits below. If I missed something or messed up please inform me and I will change it! I plan to be active in this review. Thanks : ) [/i]

35507809.review:
A truly fantastic 3D platformer that puts others such as Mario to shame. Hat Kid controls like a dream and simple additions like dive cancelling result in more fluid and controllable platforming. Everything about the game is a marvel, including the OST which is worthy of a purchase.

That being said the game is lacking levels overall and while it has no bad or annoying missions, things like delivering mail are just too boring that they really stand out. I'd take this over actually annoying sections but it's not desirable over all. As you keep playing you'll see each level have less and less content which is disheartening. Despite the game being in development for 4,000 years, it does feel rushed. The game only has 4 proper levels for example.

Also to get the obligatory Yooka Laylee comparisons out of the way, the games aren't similar, there is no real need to compare them (yet people won't shut up about this). Yooka was trying to be Banjo, meanwhile A Hat In Time was deliberately aiming to be more original and clearly took more influence from Mario titles like 64 and Sunshine than any Rareware title. Both are fun games, though I'd still recommend this overall. Just wanted to get this out of the way since people can't seem to enjoy 2 games that are both 3D platformers.

35507756.review:
When I first started to play this game I had a pretty rough start - Issues with my resolution, frame drops, I even managed to softlock the game twice in the first thirty minutes of gameplay, wrote it down as a bad indie game, gave it a bad review.

Then I stopped being a fucking pussy and actually played the game.

The next 7 and a half gamplay (at this moment) was nothing short of magical. Its rare that I even want to play the same game for longer than an hour, so its something else when this game kept me stuck to it constantly and had me thinking solely about the next time I would get to play.

As it stands, the only issue I have with this game still is that I cant play it at the proper resolution and get that crisp HD. And thats it. The atmosphere of this game is just perfect, each chapter is an adventure all of its own and shows just the raw love and hard work that went into making this game. Every time you select a level, you get the good Mario Sunshine showing you the basic idea of the level, and the objective. Is it nolstagic? Yes, but is it still good? Hell yes.

Controlling Hat Kid is just like, what, how- Honestly I havent had controls this good on my character since Super Meat Boy. At first, it can get be a little wonky, but the moment you get it, that moment of 'Aha!' it just fits and works so perfectly. Its percise and fun to use and gives so many options while maintaining the simple concept but also adding a layer of skill and extra thought that can be used.

The camera isnt half bad. It definitely isnt bad on its own, but ever so often theres segments where it locks itself into a place or angle - And then it can start to freak out, but even then I never found it to be too frustrating to use.

To be honest, I really hope everyone read down this far because this is the most important part of the game, and my last point: The charm. I havent seen a game so... Damn, I cant even find the word - Mystical? Amazing? Immersive? - Im not really sure what the proper word is. The characters are so full and unique, the locations are impressive and fun to explore, even Hat Kid, this mostly-mute little girl is just bursting with fluid motion and emotion.

30$ is a little expensive for a game, yes. Usually I go by the rule that for each dollar I paid I should get an hour of gameplay in return. But this game is an exception - Because one hour of gameplay is just so full, so constantly exciting and fun, that the experience is worth more than one dollar. Im sure Im going to get a good 10 hours out of 100% this game and so many more from replaying it and just enjoying it. Do yourself a favor and purchase A Hat in Time.

35506917.review:
An absolutely adorable and charming collectathon platformer that brings the heart of the classics, the controls are tight and it comes with controller support! i've followed the development of this game for a long time (i believe it was 2014) and i can happily say i am not in the slightest disappointed.

The level design is incredibly detailed with a lovely ost to accompany it and plenty you can interact with and rewards you for taking the time to explore in fact, the moment i thought to continue on back to the main story i found myself tempted back into doing so almost instantly when i saw something nearby that raised my curiousity! 

As you go along you'll start to collect hats which will have different abilities and you can quickly switch between at the drop of a hat as well as badges which will appear on them, granting you special abilities as well. you earn the hats by collecting yarn and can purchase the badges from a mysterious merchant who hangs around the levels and the orbs you collect and can find scattered everywhere are the currency that is used.

More content will be on the horizon and with a workshop you're sure to be able to find new things to enjoy with this game, i couldnt recommend it strongly enough!

35506909.review: This game is absolutely adorable. Hat Kid controls like a dream. The level design of Mafia Town at least is fantastic. If you want a cute 3D Platformer that absolutely lives up to Banjo-Kazooie, Banjo-Tooie, and the great games of that era, made with love and attention to detail, you want A Hat In Time.

35506785.review: This game is a love letter to all the great 3D platformers of the past. Here you'll find a mish-mash of ideas found in games like Super Mario 64/Sunshine/Galaxy, Banjo-Kazooie, and Sonic Adventure. The protagonist's movement and combat techniques take a little getting used to, but once you do, you'll see how they each complement each other leading to a very fluid player experience. Each world has lots of things to collect, and as you beat each chapter, even more items to collect appear, giving you yet another reason to revisit a world. Customization options are rewaded to real treasure hunters and explorers alike. Did I forget to mention how cute the protag Hat Kid is? Because she is. A few cons for this game are the lack of a cohesive art direction; the enemies seem to have not as much thought put into them as the protag, lots of flat textures, and less than stellar voice acting. But don't let any of that stop you from playing one of the few kickstarted games that actually live up to and exceed expectations. Buy A Hat in Time!

35506746.review: A Hat in Time is a prime example of how to do a Kickstarter correctly. Gears for Breakfast maintained excellent communication throughout the development process and have delivered an amazing game, not to mention the free DLC worlds that will be added later. Overall, A Hat in Time looks beautiful, sounds wonderful, and controls perfectly. Every level is something unique, and you never know what gameplay style will be featured next (exploration, combat, stealth, mystery, horror…) The myriad of styles aren't half-baked either: each one works great and adds tons of variety. The game is filled to the brim with personality, much of which comes from Hat Kid, who is an absolutely adorable protagonist! If you love games like Super Mario 64 or Banjo-Kazooie, you'll be delighted with A Hat in Time. Support Gears for Breakfast for delivering on their promises and making such a wonderful game!

35506408.review:
I recommend not buying this if you've been looking forward to a Mario Galaxy/Sunshine or Banjo clone.

Poor optimization with heavy elements of no effort put into the game i.e. background becomes out of focus which would seem like it would fit but turns out making what's focused in just look out of place completely. Smaller things like mouths not moving during cutscenes - although this is likely a key design choice which I understand and respect, although it gives off that older style of genre that doesn't seem to fit.

Very straight forward story as to why you're collecting stuff in the first place creating for a stale and dull game play, meaning I'm not given a reason to be attached to the character's story at all. 

The game's controls are very wonky and feel out of place. It's almost like I'm playing an older game from the ps1 era with how jank the camera work is. Alongside very clunky fighting mechanics and almost "brain-dead" like game play for the first 30ish minutes. 

There was no reason for me to continue playing after the "tutorial". There's no indicator as to whether or not I can do X or Y actions at the start of the game. I'm just put into the game. The only bit of a tutorial you're given is that you can double jump if you decide to talk to an NPC early on. On top of the clunky controls you're thrown into the game and baby sat without being told how to actually play. 

As far as progress in the game goes it's very straight forward and simple. It was probably intended for younger audiences unfortunately it has an issue of not having a straight path from Point A to Point B. It seems very easy to get lost in this game and be overwhelmed, almost like a free roam Wind Waker with broader, more expansive and more fleshed out map design.

The map design seems fantastic, unfortunately it feels out of place as stated above. You're given little direction as to where to go, even cutscenes don't aid you that well.

For being given 1/3 of a million backed up on this game it's team did put hard effort into this game I'm sure, unfortunately it lacks a lot of elements and contains a lot of issues that make me not want to play this game - even after backing it since day 1. 

I'd rate the game (30 minutes worth I guess?) a 2/10.

Another major turn-off was the price to game ratio. $30 game that I expected to be around $15-20 due to the length and how much effort was put into it as a kickstarter project.

35506224.review:
[u]Pros:[/u]
-Cute and charming aesthetic, that actually starts to turn appropriately quirky and spooky at times.
-Hat Kid controls like a [b]dream[/b], running, jumping, and diving was perfectly implemented.
-Well-written characters and humor.
-Vast, open levels with plenty of little secrets and goodies to find.
-Excellent soundtrack.
-A lot of the missions are very silly and surprisingly fun. (Until Chapter 4)

[u]Cons:[/u]
-Chapter 4 feels a bit barebone, as nearly all the missions are just simple "Get the hourglass at the top" challenges.
-Once you have all the hats, there's no purpose to collecting yarn, the game doesn't even really keep track of how much Yarn is left in a level, despite it being a limited collectible. 
-The game has a system where if you're climbing to a high spot in a single room, if you fall, the game will place you back where you fell from. While this may seem like a good thing, if you happen to notice a secret goodie you missed on your way up, you have to backtrack down, you can't just jump down to take a shortcut. Thankfully this isn't a problem in that many areas.


[u]Conclusion:[/u]
If you were mega disappointed by Yooka Laylee, or just happen to be a huge fan of Super Mario Sunshine, then this is game will be a breath of fresh air for you. It's clear the developers wanted the platforming to be the main focus, and they nailed it. Hat Kid's controls are solid, and it never feels like I'm fighting where I want her to go. Plus I got quite a few chuckles and smiles from the game's dialogue and characters.

35505402.review:
Now that I have "100%"'d the game, I'd like to share some thoughts.

Despite being able to connect so much nostalgia to this game for old-school 3D action/platformers like Super Mario Sunshine, Croc, Jak & Daxter [1], Sly Cooper, and probably more games... it really ends up being its own thing.

And that, my friends, is amazing! I really think if you are the slightest bit interested in a platforming game, play this one. It's fun. Well worth the asking price. Even if the game might only last 18 hours, it's an experience that will stick with you and make you happy for years to come in rememberance. It stands out in its genre as one of the best.

But, I mean, what do you do? Run around, jump places, get yarn to make hats, manipulate time and the astral planes, beat stuff up with an umbrella, converse with a girl who has a mustache, and listen to good video game music.

Also -- the game has a fully-featured options menu, including frame limiters, an FOV slider, anti-aliasing and anisotropic filtering options, motion blur on or off, more graphics stuff, and a smart camera option that you'll probably want to turn off. I played with a controller, and you can rebind the keys, but I dont see why you'd want to.

35504947.review:
A Hat in Time is a delicately crafted, sixth-generation-inspired platformer. The level of detail found throughout the world is absolutely astounding. The gameplay is very reminiscent of Mario's early forays into 3D-platforming with chapter based encounters. There are a current total of five unique chapters, which are mostly large environments, just oozing with charm. A huge, fishy town controlled by the Mafia! A spooky, mysterious forest! Even a crazy, western train! Feeling nostalgic? Same. 

PROS 

+ Precise controls and an intuitive move-set gives the protagonist an unparalleled sense of 
movement and acrobatic prowess. 

+ Stunning visuals that perfectly blend sixth generation sensibilities with modern resolution/lighting/particle effects. 

+ The soundtrack. Geez. This soundtrack. 

CONS 

- Some collision issues and general glitches. Nothing detrimental. Some of it has actually been rather funny. 

- The difficulty spikes when it comes to bosses. Not going to spoil anything, and perhaps this issue is just because I am not great as I think I am. But, the sudden rise was jarring. 

Overall, A Hat in Time is a game that keeps on giving. From speed-running, easter eggs, developer console, steam workshop, and the later to be added, 6th and 7th bonus chapters, multiplayer, in-game level editor, developer commentary. Buying the game right now at $29.99 is a no-brainer. 

Enjoy the hell out of it now, revisit again in the future with even MORE content. Or, continue to play it while the Workshop keeps receiving content from dedicated fans... You can't possibly go wrong.

this is one of the prime examples of a succesful kickstarter, i have pre-ordered this game in 2014 and i have no regrets in supporting it for so long.
i have played the alpha, beta, speedrunning event, had fun in all of those, though they were only 6 levels of the game.
the game as it is right now is a much more upgraded version from the beta (well duh, its released), it features many more interesting mechanics, improved graphics and well, its finished! i definitely wont play through it only once, as it has a special spot in my heart, anticipating a game for so long cant be healthy :P

it is one of the best 3D platformers you can get on steam, if you are an enthusiast for this type of game just get it, and if you are interested in the genre, you will have no regrets.
you will smile from pure fun, and actually funny writing! it puts humour where it belongs, and in very precise moments just to get that chuckle out of you.
characters are cheerful and memorable, they have great design, atleast i think they do, they look great for the art style the game points torward to, their voice acting is great (you will find exceptions for this, though.), and they are just all around loveable!

every chapter is unique and refreshing, you will go from casual platforming to a motherfucking terror game, then back to platforming with cool mechanics.
i will not write any further as i still have to play through it myself, but i feel confident on making this review, as feedback has been very positive, and the very limited beta was already very fun! seriously! i played through it for 8 times!
the folks at Gears of Breakfast deserve huge props, they come from a modding background (TF2 mods) and are already making this beautiful, fully pledged game, they show talent, and they also show compassion for the modding community, meaning this game will be held alive by the community alone. it is a great pratice that benefits us all as consumers, and seriously, a lot of devs could learn from it.
it is expected for a review written at the time of release that me, as the reviewer, have not played through the game, but i just could not handle it, i really want this game to do good. because it IS good.
